abstract: The Board of Councilmen held their regular session, yesterday, but there was little transacted out of the regular routine order of business. Resolutions to pave Division, Hester, Broome, Delancy, Rivington and East Thirty-seventh streets, with Belgian pavement, were laid over under the rules. An invitation to witness an exhibition of the pupils of the Military Academy of New-Hamburgh, in the City Hall Park, was accepted. A resolution was adopted authorizing the purchase of badges for the Board of engineers and the Fire Department. Resolutions to connect the Fire Telegraph with various Engine and Hose houses, was referred to the appropriate Committee. The usual annual donation of $2,000 was made to the Fire Department. An application of C. LENT, for permission to exempt the Spring-street line of stages from payment of licences, was appropriately referred. The remainder of the business was entirely routine, and the calendar was nearly cleared of "general orders." The Board adjourned to next Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held their regular session, yesterday, but there was little transacted out of the regular routine order of business. abstract: The close of the past week was marked by important events before Richmond, prominent among which was a battle, or rather a series of battles, continuing through two days.
lead_paragraph: The close of the past week was marked by important events before Richmond, prominent among which was a battle, or rather a series of battles, continuing through two days. The fighting, however, was only incident to more important matters, which will be found detailed in our columns this morning. Gen. MCCLELLAN has contracted his lines, and massed his troops between the Chickahominy and James Rivers -- the latter of which will constitute his base of operations until the fall of the rebel Capital, which cannot apparently be long delayed. Whit House has been abandoned and the right wing of the army has been drawn in across the Chickahominy -- not with out considerable loss of life, but still slight, it is believed, in comparison with that of the enemy. The supplies for the army will hereafter be conveyed up the James Rivers under the protection of our gunboats. On Friday morning the enemy made the looked for attempt to turn our right wing. The rebel division of Gen. JACKSON, which must have started for Richmond immediately, after the fiasco in Shenandoah Valley, attacked Gen. MCCALL's Division of the Pennsylvania reserves, on our extreme right. The action lasted for three hours, and was brilliantly successful on our part. JACKSON was repulsed and severely punished. The rebels then made a general attack on our right wing, which was composed of Gen. FITZ JOHN PORTER's army corps. A severe battle ensued, in which the rebels suffered severely. In the midst of this battle Gen. MCCLELLAN executed the movement for which he had been preparing. His whole right wing commenced an orderly retreat, falling back until it had crossed to the south side of the Chickahominy, in the rear of his left wing, and pushed on toward the James River. The movement was carried out in excellent style, everything valuable being secured, and the rebels repulsed in their attacks upon our rear guard. The evacuation of the White House was completed on Saturday, all that was valuable being carried away, and the remnants not worth moving burned. In this destruction the White House itself shared, some unauthorized person's having set fire to it in the confusion. Our troops there were finally put on board steamers and taken to Yorktown.

abstract: This British steamship was captured May 4, twenty miles east of Havana, by the U.S. gunboat Samosel, and taken into Key West, where she was condemned by the Admiralty Court, and was sent to this port to be sold. She was formerly employed in the line between this port and Galway.
lead_paragraph: This British steamship was captured May 4, twenty miles east of Havana, by the U.S. gunboat Samosel, and taken into Key West, where she was condemned by the Admiralty Court, and was sent to this port to be sold. She was formerly employed in the line between this port and Galway. She has a cargo of wines and brandies valued at half a million of dollars. She sailed from Key West on the 23d June, and Port Royal on the 27th, having taken on board at Key West Gen. BLANNAN and Staff, and landed them at Port Royal. Passed, while going in to Port Royal, the U.S. gunboat Quaker City, from Key West.

abstract: -- The feeling in the City yesterday revived the old experiences of the Sumter and Bull Run epochs. Like then, the atmosphere yesterday fairly pulsated with human emotion. If there were such a thing as an instrument that would gauge public feeling as the barometer does the atmosphere, it had surely have shown far up in the blood-heat and high-fever ranges. Everything conspired to enlist the deepest feelings of the New-York public. It was known that at last the mighty stake was being played. But beyond the fact that a bloody battle had been fought during Thursday and Friday of last week, everything was shrouded in obscurity. Only the clash of arms reached our ears; only an occasional glimpse of the combatants seen through the uprolled smoke-curtain was caught. Was it victory or was it defeat? What had Saturday and Sunday brought forth? Of course, the date at hand were variously interpreted according as the knowledge or the predilections of men inclined them. Radicals and Secessionists both united in being well pleased; both saw in it the utter defeat of Gen. MCCLELLAN, and both were at jubilant as they dared to be. For the rest, while there were a plenty of timid souls, there were not wanting those of insight enough to read the reports as indications of a capital success, and who had both the knowledge, and the sagacity to see that amid these operations Gen. MCCLELLAN had effected a strategie coup that must assuredly result in the capture of the rebel Capital. Thus the tide of opinion and sentiment, hope and fear, surged and swelled through all the day. We can have few more such experiences, and it is, perhaps, just as well that we should not, for such intense excitations are sure to bring their own penalty. While they last, however, such spectaries are certainly sublime, and nothing could have been more so than that of yesterday in New-York.

abstract: Congress has been in session since the first of May, but has done very little, save to amnesty political exiles and prisoners. The old CAUTY grant for building a road from the Capital to the headwaters of the Serapigni River on the Atlantic, has been annulled, or, rather, had not been opposed, and the new Belgian Company's contract had been ratified. This road, if ever it is built, is intended to direct most of the trade of Costa Rica, that now passes over this Isthmus, to San Juan del Norte, on the Atlantic -- but it is doubtful, with a costly road to pay toll over, shallow rivers, and a bad and unfrequented port at the end of the route, will bring the advantages that are expected from it.

abstract: Matter of Patrick Fallis. -- The petitioner enlisted in the army, swearing that he was 21 years of age. His friends being desirous to have him discharged now obtained a writ of habeas corpus for that purpose, alleging infancy. Lieut. Childs (on behalf of the Government) made return to the writ, setting forth that by the act of Feb. 13, 1862, it was lawful to enlist a minor between the ages of 18 and 21, and that the oath of the recruit was conclusive as to his age.

abstract: THE PARTICULARS OF A PURCHASE. In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, Mr. JAMES WILSON, a gentleman said to be widely known (to the police,) was brought up on kabeas corpus.
lead_paragraph: THE PARTICULARS OF A PURCHASE. In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, Mr. JAMES WILSON, a gentleman said to be widely known (to the police,) was brought up on kabeas corpus. It appeared that WILSON recently entered a clothing store and ordered a vest, paying for it at the time. Alter he left the place it was ascertained that the bill given was a counterfeit, (a $10 on the Atlantic Bank.) WILSON was arrested and taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court, and committed for trial, he never having called for his vest, which it appeared he ordered to be ready on a certain day, which had passed. His counsel now contended that there was no sufficient evidence to convict him, and that he should be discharged. The Assistant District-Attorney thought that although there was no evidence that the prisoner was aware that the bill was a counterfeit when he passed it, still his not calling for his vest was a circumstance strongly tending to show guilt. The Recorder decided that the evidence did not warrant the commitment, and discharged the prisoner.

abstract: Now that the crisis of the great rebellion has come, it behooves the people as well as the Government to see to it that the General upon whose shoulders has fallen the mighty ...
lead_paragraph: Now that the crisis of the great rebellion has come, it behooves the people as well as the Government to see to it that the General upon whose shoulders has fallen the mighty work of destroying it utterly, be not left short of the forces needed to this end. It will not do to render the result in any way uncertain for want of men while hundreds of thousands can be had. It will not do to prolong the war by permitting the occurrence of alternate instances of victory and defeat, defeat and victory, when it is possible to inflict upon the rebels a defeat after which no victory shall ever come to crown their arms or to sustain their spirits. We have now, practically speaking, the whole Confederate force centred at one point -- near the rebel Capital, The small detachments in the Cotton States at Charleston and elsewhere, are of little account in the general issue. The capture of isolated rebel towns, or the possession of vast spaces of rebel territory, are of minor moment compared with the destruction of the army upon which the hope of the rebellion and of the rebels rest. To this work now must be addressed the energies of the nation; for its speedy accomplishment must the tremendous military power of the North be directed, and steadily directed, until the work is finally and forever completed.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are comparatively meagre. But they show conclusively that Gen. McCLELLAN has executed with complete success, though with heavy ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are comparatively meagre. But they show conclusively that Gen. McCLELLAN has executed with complete success, though with heavy loss, a most important and difficult military manoeuvre, -- one which gives him a much safer line of communication, which secures the cooperation of the gunboats on James River and of Gen. BURNSIDE beyond it, and which compels the rebels to evacuate Richmond or find their retreat hopelessly cut off. He has carried his whole force across the Chickahominy, and made that prolonged and most defensible swamp the bulwark of his right wing and rear, -- while he holds the James River on his left, giving him a perfect communication with his supplies, and access by water to the City of Richmond. We shall undoubtedly hear very soon that the gunboats have not only gone up the James, but that they have also opened communication with MCCLELLAN on the Chickahominy.

abstract: FROM ABOVE AND BELOW VICKSBURGH. -- The news that our ramboats from Memphis have effected a junction with our gunboats and mortar fleet from New-Orleans, at Vicksburgh, and that the fleet, some twenty craft strong, was about to open upon the enemy's works, indicates a speedy fall of the contumacious town which is now the only impediment to the free navigation of the Mississippi River. The assault was to begin on Friday last; and it is not unlikely that the town may by this time have fallen. Still, we would not be surprised if the Vicksburgh rebels were able to make quite a lengthened stand against our fleet. Their heavy guns are planted on the high bluffs, and at commanding positions, where it is quite difficult work for the guns of our gunboats to reach them, or for the mortars of our bombketches to strike them; and we have no land force sufficient to attack the town in the rear. The telegraph says that the rebel force there is estimated at twelve thousand men, which is much more likely to be true than most of the other stories that have come to us from the Southwest of the large rebel bodies massed at various points. The rebel army at Corinth had direct railroad communication with Vicksburgh, and we know that a considerable body of rebels went southward from Grand Junction on the Mississippi Central Railroad. Their object now is simply to delay and annoy us as much as possible, and also to defend the State Capital. This is petty work, compared with the great things that were to be done by BEAUREGARD's army of the Southwest; but then it is all that the rebels in that region are now capable of doing. They will be deprived of even this trifling pleasure before long.

abstract: To the Senate yesterday, a bill to punish persons giving or offering to give members of Congress or officers of the Government any consideration for procuring contracts, office or place, was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a bill to punish persons giving or offering to give members of Congress or officers of the Government any consideration for procuring contracts, office or place, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The [???] providing that a list of contracts made by the Departments shall be published weekly, was passed. The bill providing that vessels recaptured from the rebels shall be returned to their original owners without salvage, was passed. The bill granting a pension to the widow of Gen. C.F. SMITH was passed. The bill prescribing an additional oath of office was passed. The bill to establish certain National Arsenals was passed. After some further unimportant business, the Senate went into Executive Session, and then adjourned.

abstract: Jackson leads Confederate attack on McClellan right wing at Richmond; McClellan changes concentration of troops to location between Chickahominy and James rivers

lead_paragraph: CAMP BEFORE RICHMOND, Saturday, June 28, 1862.
headline: {'main': 'AFFAIRS BEFORE RICHMOND.; Details of the Events of Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Attack of the Rebels under Jackson upon Our Right Wing. abstract: The United States vs. The Schooner J.W. Wilder and Cargo. This vessel was captured by the R.R. Cuyler on Jan. 20, 1862, off Mobile Point.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner J.W. Wilder and Cargo. This vessel was captured by the R.R. Cuyler on Jan. 20, 1862, off Mobile Point. The vessel was taken for the use of the Government, having been appraised at $3,250, and her cargo was sent to this port and libeled as prize. An appearance was put in for the vessel and cargo, but no answer was put in and the case was heard by default. On proof that the master and crew of the vessel ran her ashore at the time of capture and abandoned her, so that no witness from the vessel could be produced before the Prize Commissioners, the Court on on motion ordered the prize master who was present at the capture, to be examined as a witness on the interrogatories in preparatorio.

abstract: The citizens of Bridgeport, Conn., intend to celebrate the Fourth of July in a manner unequaled in Western Connecticut. Great preparations have been made for a grand military and firemen's procession, and for other appropriate methods of celebrating the day. Gov. BUCKINGHAM and Staff are to be present, and will review the military. The Bridgeport Battery of Flying Artillery -- a splendid corps -- will exhibit some target practice with solid shot and shell. Engine Company No. 28, of this City, with Dodworth's Band, visits Bridgeport on that day.

abstract: respondent of the NEW YORK TIMES has a communication upon the subject of the Government Hospital in this city, which, while evidently desiring to give due credit to all concerned in its establishment and subsequent operations, falls into a surprising number of errors. It should be understood that the hospital here is a Government institution, and subject to precisely the same regulations as all other Government hospitals. The location of the hospital here, and the fitting  it up for patients, is in a great measure due to the efforts of MAROUS L. WARD, Esq., but so far from his being a salaried official, as stated in the communication referred to, he has given his time and labors without the thought of remuneration. Our citizens will smile at the idea of Mr. WARD being a salaried official, well knowing that from the very commencement of the war, his time and services have been given freely to the soldiers and the cause of the Union. -- Newark Mercury.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: The house devoted its entire session to-day, continuing for more than five hours, to the discussion of the bill for the enlargement of the Erie and Oswego locks and the Illinois Ganal and River. The expenditure of the United States is carefully limited by the bill to three and a half millions for the former work, and ten millions for the latter, which sum is to be expended gradually, and only so fast as the accruing tells pledged to the United States shall suffice to pay the interest. The merits of the bill were sustained in able and effective speeches, by Messrs. FRANK BLAIR, of Missouri; ARNOLD, of Illinois, and ELY, POMEROY OLIN and VAN HORN, of New-York. The Pennsylvania delegation and that of New-Jersey, and those of the Border States, opposed the bill en masse. Mr. SEEVENS, of Pennsylvania, the only speaker against the bill, undertook to throw ridicule upon it by introducing a sham amendment for a slack water navigation of the Sasquehanna for the passage of gunboats, followed by a motion to postpone the whole subject to the first Monday of January next. The previous question being demanded on the latter proposition, it was defeated by the close vote of 57 to 58. A series of fillibustering movements were then made by the enemies of the bill to prevent further action upon it, and the Ayes and Noes were repeatedly taken. It is a very singular and noticeable circumstance, that Hon. FREDK. A. CONKLING, the only Republican Member from the City of New-York, steadily voted with the Opposition, in which he was sustained by his brother, Hon. ROSCOM CONKLING, who lives upon the line of the Erie Canal. With these exceptions, the whole body of the New-York Delegation present, including Messrs. WARD and BEN. WOOD, of New-York City, firmly supported the bill. It also received the votes of many of the substantial Members from New-England, and nearly all the Members from the Western States. The House at length adjourned, with the understanding that the final vote upon the measure should be taken in the morning.

abstract: The Commencement exercises incident to the nineteenth school-year of the Mount Washington Collegiate Institute, took place yesterday morning at the Marble Church, Fourth-street, near Sixth-avenue.
lead_paragraph: The Commencement exercises incident to the nineteenth school-year of the Mount Washington Collegiate Institute, took place yesterday morning at the Marble Church, Fourth-street, near Sixth-avenue. There was a very large attendance of parents and friends of the pupils. The exercises consisted of thirty-one addresses, declamations and dialogues, interspersed with music, and concluded with the distribution of prizes and diplomas by the Principals, G.W. CLARKE, A.M., and JAMES FANNING, A.M. The whole concluded with an interesting address to the Graduating Class by Rev. J.S. NEWMAN, Pastor of the Church. The compositions of the following young gentlemen, as well as their delivery, deserve especial mention, viz.: JAMES D. MCCLELLAND, CLARENCE BRAINERD, HENRY J. KING and CHAS. A. DURFEE. The report of the Principals signals the following young gentlemen for special acquirements:

abstract: The Company which proposes to be about to open the Nicaragua route to California has raised the old steamer Virgin, long ago sunk in Lake Nicarauga, repaired her, and put the boiler of the steamer John Hart in her, which latter vessel was wrecked on the lake, near Grenada, last December. The Virgin is now in running order. Some repairs have been made on the transit road between Virgin Bay and San Juan Sur. Advertisements appear for mules, &c., to transport passengers. In fact, everything seems to be going on just as if the Company was in earnest, which nobody believes it is. The old transit charter runs out in a few months, unless something is done to make a show of reopening the route, and it is probable this splurge is only intended to keep it alive, in the hope that "something may turn up."
lead_paragraph: The Company which proposes to be about to open the Nicaragua route to California has raised the old steamer Virgin, long ago sunk in Lake Nicarauga, repaired her, and put the boiler of the steamer John Hart in her, which latter vessel was wrecked on the lake, near Grenada, last December. The Virgin is now in running order. Some repairs have been made on the transit road between Virgin Bay and San Juan Sur. Advertisements appear for mules, &c., to transport passengers. In fact, everything seems to be going on just as if the Company was in earnest, which nobody believes it is. The old transit charter runs out in a few months, unless something is done to make a show of reopening the route, and it is probable this splurge is only intended to keep it alive, in the hope that "something may turn up."

abstract: MARY PROVOST'S OLYMPIC. Miss PROVOST appeared on Tuesday in two pieces, both of which were, from long disuse, comparative novelties. The
lead_paragraph: MARY PROVOST's OLYMPIC. -- Miss PROVOST appeared on Tuesday in two pieces, both of which were, from long disuse, comparative novelties. The first -- "King Rene's Daughter" -- is a one-act, dramatic poem, the idea whereof is pretty; but, like all dramatic works of Scandinavian, or Teutonic origin, it is too talky and tedious to ever become popular with an American audience. The part of the heroine is played very pleasingly, however, by Miss PROVOST -- pleasingly enough, indeed, to make the piece attractive in spite of its inherent lack of vitality. After "King Rene's Daughter," Miss PROVOST tried an experiment in Hibernian comedy, which can scarcely be considered successful. She has not the rollicking dash nor mellifluousness of brogue to do Andy Blake as well as we have seen it done before.

abstract: Editorial argues against vindictiveness in dealing with the Confederates
snippet: Editorial argues against vindictiveness in dealing with the Confederates
lead_paragraph: The pulse of our people is rapidly working up to fever-heat. By nature the Northern American is one of the most cheerful and long-suffering of mortals. He bears the tyranny of servants, the fleecing by railroad companies, the impositions of hotels, the explosions of steamboats with an equanimity and good feeling which utterly surprises a European. Mr. TROLLOPE considers this trait a National defect. The Northerner is not naturally vindictive. It has taken him a year fully to realize that his Southern brother really wants to cut his throat, and that war is war. But he is finally becoming convinced of these facts. The madness of the enemy, their ferocity to the wounded, their causeless destruction of property, their determined resistance, and the priceless blood which is staining the Southern fields, are all lighting that dull glow of passion which fires slowly in our Northern heart, but which burns up finally to an intense all-devouring heat. When we think of the little cause we have ever offered for this satanic rebellion, of our patience through years of stinging provocation, and now of our brethren and friends -- every man of them worth to the world hundreds of the wretched "white trash" opposed to them -- dying by thousands from disease and wounds, we are ready to feel that no punishment could be too great and no revenge too bitter for such wrongs. A cry goes up from the people for punishment, for severity, for unrelenting sternness. Confiscation is demanded; the wasting of the rebellious districts, and condign and terrible punishment on the leaders. To a certain extent these feelings are just. No punishment could be too severe on the leaders in this unnatural and gigantic rebellion. Confiscation of the property and slaves of the Southern treasonable aristocracy is called for by every motive of policy and justice. Neither should our soldiers suffer when their supplies are short, and provisions and forage are plentiful around them in the rebellious territory. No one demands this, and there is no likelihood of its ever occurring. But it is time now for the leaders of opinion in the North, and for the religious teachers to instruct the people what should be the limits to these feelings of vindictiveness. We must remember that we are not engaged in an ordinary war with the South. If we were, the task would be comparatively simple. We should then only have to consider how we could inflict the most loss and damage on the Southern country. But this is not our object. We simply desire to break the armed resistance of the rebels. To do this, we must blockade their coast, capture their towns and destroy their armies. But after that, we are obliged to hold their territory in peaceful bonds, to develop the loyal feeling, to change treason into loyalty, to make it for their interest to be associated with us in one united Republic. It is true, if this cannot be done by all reasonable means, the North is in such a frame of mind that it would give up the Southern country to emancipated slaves or to Northern armed colonists, or even to crocodiles, rather than have it held by a foreign and hostile Power.

abstract: Mass meeting held, Cooper Institute, by Submission Party urging retention of slavery and status quo of Union
snippet: Mass meeting held, Cooper Institute, by Submission Party urging retention of slavery and status quo of Union
lead_paragraph: A crowd, indeed, gathered at the Cooper Institute last night for the purpose of announcing to the world generally and the United States particularly, that they are white men, that they hate black men that they have confidence in MCCLELLAN, that they disapprove of emancipation and emancipation leagues, that the Union as it was must and shall be preserved, and that if they can prevent it the life blood of an already overburdened people shall not further be drained for the benefit of infamous robbers, who, calling themselves defenders of the country, have for it only the attachment of the vampire.

abstract: It may be remembered that some two years since the Arion Society, which has seceded from the old Liederkranz, competed at Buffalo for a silver goblet which was offered for the best choral singing. They won it, and have since established their reputation by their annual concerts in New-York as one of the best choral societies, if not the best, we have ever had here. Their annual masked ball has also been largely attended by the leading German and French families of the City -- many of the younger members of which are enrolled among the members, with some of our best resident musicians. Now, this Society has determined to make an excursion of pleasure to Niagara Falls, during which it is their intention to give two grand choral and instrumental concerts, conducted by their musical directors, CARL ANSCHUTZ and BERGMANN, at Buffalo and Rochester -- to the former of which cities they have been repeatedly requested to repeat their visit. For the purpose of combining pleasure with an increase of reputation, at a reasonable rate, arrangements have been made with the Directors of the New-York Central Railroad for a trip of twelve days, visiting the intermediate cities between our own and the Falls, while many of the leading instrumentalists have been secured to make their concerts the veritable musical features of the season in Buffalo and Rochester. Among these are MILLS, the pianist; SCHREIBER, with his cornet-a-piston; WOLLENHAUPT, NOLL and MOLLENHAUER. With such an array of talent, we are disposed to guarantee them a pleasant as well as a profitable excursion -- profitable, because the expenses will scarcely be more than it would have cost them had they remained in New-York.

abstract: We are still without any specific information as to the present status of our army on the James; but all the items of news that trickle from official and unofficial sources, the gleanings from persons who left the lines as late as Sunday, and from the bearings of movements known to have been successfully accomplished, the inference is that the work which Gen. MCCLELLAN has in hand is progressing to a favorable result. The heavy operations of the battle-field, last week, practically ended with Friday, by which time the change of position which was desired, had been effected, and further offensive action on the part of the enemy was impossible. Our left wing rested upon the James River, our right upon the Chickahominy, and the whole National line was less than nine miles in length. Communication with the gunboats had been opened up; perhaps other forces to the southward had been spoken with; and the now compact mass of the Union army was ready for the next word of its Commander. Of the rebel army, we hear actually nothing. Whether that section of it which pushed to the railroad and the York River still remains there; or finding that in their occupation they had achieved a barren conquest, and that it were altogether useless to attempt to hold or use it, whether they have drawn back again to the main line of defences, near the rebel capital, there to await the onset of MCCLELLAN, we are quite in the dark. We should judge that the latter would be their policy, and that they would have carried it out just as rapidly as possible. They cannot cross the Chickahominy; they cannot operate on the York River, or anywhere north or east of it; and so, perhaps, leaving a small force for the sake of show, and to give themselves assurance of a victory won, JACKSON at once hastened in the direction of the beleaguered capital. JACKSON's name and army would be a tower of strength there at present, crowned as he is with the laurels of the Shenandoah, and followed by fifty thousand of the beat troops in JEFF. DAVIS' service. All these rebel masses, however, cannot avail for the defence of Richmond when once our gunboats shall have passed Fort Darling and the rebel obstructions in the river. When they reach the town, its surrender is certain; the most feasible line of retreat of the rebel army is cut off, if indeed the iron-clads be not capable of rendering a successful retreat altogether impracticable. At present, we judge that the National and rebel armies are now again fronting each other, with the former in an incalculably better position than it formerly occupied, and consequently far stronger, and with a line not one-third the length of its former line to defend.

abstract: EXCURSION OF THE RANDALL's ISLAND CHILDREN TO NEW-ROCHELLE -- The Warden of Randall's Island, Mr. W.H. STEVENS, yesterday travelled the children [???] to a steamboat excursionto the beautiful village of [???].steamer [???] owned by the [???] Charities and [???] was [???] for the [???] by Capt. [???] LEE, with their assistants, Miss Cox, Mrs. Bormer, Dr. Whittlesey, Mr. Ripley, and others. The famous Randall's Island Light Guard, commanded by the juvenile Capt. DALY, accompanied the excursion, and furnished the music, which was confined to the martial drum and fife. Messrs. ANDERSON and RODERIGUE, of the Commissioners' office, had charge of the commissary department, and dispensed the crackers and cheese to the little orphans in the most bountiful profusion. Officer CRONIN, of the Thirteenth. Precinct, also accompanied the excursion, and rendered valuable assistance. The children were in high glee throughout the day, and the excursion to New-Rochelle will long remain a bright spot in their memory. Only one incident occurred to mar the jovousness of the occasion, and the cause of this, it is be hoped, for the credit of human nature, will never be made known to the children. It was the intention of the Warden to have the children land at New-Rochelle, and to allow the little girls to enjoy themselves in the shade, while the boys composing the "Light Guard" were to march up to the village, a mile and a half distant. On arriving at the landing, however, the proprietor of the Neptune House peremptorily refused to allow the little orphan girls to sit in the shade of his ample grounds while their brothers marched up to the village. They were consequently obliged to remain on board the crowded steamboat during the absence of the boys, but, meanwhile, the Warden, to compensate them for their disappointment, directed an additional excursion to be made over to David's Island, where he some 500 sick and wounded soldiers, who were able to appreciate the innocence of childhood and sympathize with the hard lot of the orphan. The boys, in the meantime, visited the village of New-Rochelle, where they were received most kindly by many of the prominent residents of the place, who expressed the utmost indignation at the treatment received at the landing, and regretted that they had not known of the excursion in time to prepare a collation for the toys. The kindness shown them at the vilage by Mr. BANKS, Dr. WELLING, Mrs. UNDERHILL, Mrs. LELAND and others will ever be gratefully remembered. The young folks of the village turned out on masse to witness the drill of the Light Guard, and during their short stay there the boys enjoyed themselves exceedingly. On the return trip to the Island the company were treated to singing by the children, and to speeches and dialogues, in which Masters DALY, BRIGGS, MCLAUGHLIN, MATTESON, CARTEL, GILLESTIE and THOMAS took part.
lead_paragraph: EXCURSION OF THE RANDALL's ISLAND CHILDREN TO NEW-ROCHELLE -- The Warden of Randall's Island, Mr. W.H. STEVENS, yesterday travelled the children [???] to a steamboat excursionto the beautiful village of [???].steamer [???] owned by the [???] Charities and [???] was [???] for the [???] by Capt. [???] LEE, with their assistants, Miss Cox, Mrs. Bormer, Dr. Whittlesey, Mr. Ripley, and others. The famous Randall's Island Light Guard, commanded by the juvenile Capt. DALY, accompanied the excursion, and furnished the music, which was confined to the martial drum and fife. Messrs. ANDERSON and RODERIGUE, of the Commissioners' office, had charge of the commissary department, and dispensed the crackers and cheese to the little orphans in the most bountiful profusion. Officer CRONIN, of the Thirteenth. Precinct, also accompanied the excursion, and rendered valuable assistance. The children were in high glee throughout the day, and the excursion to New-Rochelle will long remain a bright spot in their memory. Only one incident occurred to mar the jovousness of the occasion, and the cause of this, it is be hoped, for the credit of human nature, will never be made known to the children. It was the intention of the Warden to have the children land at New-Rochelle, and to allow the little girls to enjoy themselves in the shade, while the boys composing the "Light Guard" were to march up to the village, a mile and a half distant. On arriving at the landing, however, the proprietor of the Neptune House peremptorily refused to allow the little orphan girls to sit in the shade of his ample grounds while their brothers marched up to the village. The boys, in the meantime, visited the village of New-Rochelle, where they were received most kindly by many of the prominent residents of the place, who expressed the utmost indignation at the treatment received at the landing, and regretted that they had not known of the excursion in time to prepare a collation for the toys. abstract: -- To-morrow, the "Cuban InstituteCadets," from New-Hamburgh, will visit this City, arriving by the steamer Mary Powell, at 11 o'clock A.M. They will be received by Dodworth's Band, and march to the City Hall, where they will be reviewed by the Common Council. They will then march through Broadway to Union and Madison squares, where they will go through company drill and manual of arms. In the evening, at 8 o'clock, the Cadets will give an exhibition at Lafayette Hall, Broadway; and, on the 4th, they will march in the line of parade.

abstract: Matter of Alanson Nash. This motion was stated in the Times of May 21. The motion to strike From the roll of attornies is based upon the allegation that, in 1852, Nash, who was at the time a judgment debtor of one Caroline Donaldson, made an assignment to her of his interest in an action against the Hudson Railroad Company, in which one Frederick
lead_paragraph: Matter of Alanson Nash. -- This motion was stated in the Times of May 21. The motion to strike From the roll of attornies is based upon the allegation that, in 1852, Nash, who was at the time a judgment debtor of one Caroline Donaldson, made an assignment to her of his interest in an action against the Hudson Railroad Company, in which one Frederick Ritter was plaintiff and Nash his attorney. Nash, as alleged at the time, owed Miss Donaldson $700, and this assignment was taken by her in payment thereof. Upon the recovery of the judgment by Nash against the railroad company, he failed, as alleged, to pay over to Miss Donaldson the $700 which he had received, and which he had promised her to collect for her. The affidavit of Miss Donaldson was corroborated by that of Wm. B. Leeds, Esq. The defence set up was, that Nash's interest in the suit against the company was derived from an assignment from Ritter, and that subsequently he ascertained that Ritter had made an assignment previously to a Mr. Hough, who had made an assignment to Ritter's wife, and that he (Nash) prosecuted the suit for the benefit of Mrs. Ritter.

abstract: Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD will appreciate the delicacy of the allusion when we offer him our hearty congratulations on his luck in drawing a plump prize from that lottery of Fame, whose prizes are fewer, and whose blanks are blanker, than even those of that little arrangement wherewith rumor whilom linked his name. The London Times, which has, this ever so long, been on a Diogenes-hunt throughout the United States for a man, has at length discovered one who, take him for all, it thinks, it will never be given it to look upon his like again. The Thunderer has exhumed from the obscurity whither the modesty of genius had carried him, an American who is at once a "statesman," a "philosopher," a "patriot," a "scholar and a gentleman." (Such are the lush laurels it places on his bashful brow.) His name -- it has already been anticipated -- is B. WOOD.

abstract: Advices from Europe to the 22d of June have been received, by the arrival at this port of the steamship Scotia. The news is not of special im
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe to the 22d of June have been received, by the arrival at this port of the steamship Scotia. The news is not of special importance. The condition of affairs in America continued to form the staple topic of discussion in the London journals, but no new points are brought out. It had been stated in the British House of Lords, in answer to a question by Lord BROUGHAM, that the correspondence in reference to the case of the ship Emily St. Pierre, had not been closed, but that the opinion of the law-officers of the Crown was that the ship could not be restored to the Government of the United States. An interesting debate had taken place in the House of Commons regarding the capabilities of India for raising cotton. According to the latest reports the strength of the French reinforcements about to be sent to Mexico will not fall short of 12,000 men. Two regiments at Rome were reported to be under orders to quit for Mexico. It was thought that with the reinforcements a General of long standing would be sent out to assume the command-in-chief, and the names of Gens. BARBATRI, MONTAUBAN and FOREY, were mentioned in connection with this service. The tone of the Liverpool Cotton market was still upward. Breadstuffs were firm and Provisions quiet. No change is reported in American Securities. Consols were quoted at 91 1/8@92.

abstract: Official information has been received at this office that the Minister of Marine at Madrid has given notice, that on and after the 31st day of March, 1862, a light would be exhibited from the highest and southermost of the two towers of the hermitage or Church of Nuestra Senora de Los Angeles, at the village of El Cabanal, at the port [???] Grao de Valencia, on the southeast coast of Spain. The light is a fixed white light, elevated 66 feet above the mean level of the sea, and should be seen in clear whether from a distance of 9 miles. The illuminating apparatus is dioptric, or by lenses of the sixth order. The tower is square, 54 feet high, colored a grayish white, and stands about 640 yards from the sea, in lat. 39 28 50 N., lon. 0 20 6 west of Greenwich. This light replaces the former light which was exhibited from the same tower.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 19th Jane, Earl RUSSELL, after: presenting a petition from Auckland, praying for separation from other parts of New-Zealand, said: I beg to take this opportunity of making a statement to your Lordships as to matters of considerable importance, upon which it is desirable no misapprehesion should exist. It has been stated in
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 19th Jane, Earl RUSSELL, after: presenting a petition from Auckland, praying for separation from other parts of New-Zealand, said: I beg to take this opportunity of making a statement to your Lordships as to matters of considerable importance, upon which it is desirable no misapprehesion should exist. It has been stated in the public prints that a Convention has been entered into by Sir C. WYKE and Commodore DUNLOP on one side, and the Mexican Government on the other, by which the British claims on Mexico will be satisfied, and that the Convention has been ratified by Her Majesty's Government. As to the first part, it is quite true that a Convention has been signed by Sir C. WYKE and Commodore DUNLOP, and it has been sent home for ratification. The arrangement contemplated for the satisfaction of British claims was fair and liberal, but we found that the Convention referred to another Convention between Mexico and the United States, and, fearing that it might involve this country in difficulties, Her Majesty's Government determined not to ratify it. There is another point upon which I wish to make a statement to the House. It is generally believed in France, and much circulated here, that Her Majesty's troops, together with the Spanish troops, were withdrawn, leaving the French troops alone to contend with the difficulties of the situation. After the temporary check which the French troops received, no one can be surprised that the French Government have resulted to send large reinforcements to Mexico, but the order is not founded upon any course taken by the British Government. In the original Convention of October there was no specific engagement as to the number of troops to be sent on the part of the different Governments, but communications were made separately by each Government. The Spaniards declared that they meant to send 6,000 or 7,000 troops. The French said at first that they would send 2,600, which was afterwards increased to 2,500 men. The British Government proposed to send a squadron with 700 marines, to be landed, if necessary, for the occupation of forts. The marines were landed, and for a short time occupied some forts. It seemed that the land forces met with difficulties, and Commodore DUNLOP, in order not to have the appearance in any way of leaving the allies, said he would provide, by his own activity and resources, camp equipage and conveyance. That, however, has not been approved by the Home Government, and orders were sent out that the marines should be reembarked. Commodore DUNLOP, on his side, very soon found that there was no immediate danger of collision with the Mexicans, and he determined to send away the marines, who were never intended to march up the country. They were accordingly removed from Vera Cruz. After this came the convention, and the allied commissioners agreed to a proces verbal, with regard to which I will now say nothing, as I do not wish to enter into the great question involved in it. But it should be known that at that time there were only 150 marines in occupation of the various forts, and when the rupture took place between the French Commissioners on the one side, and the English and Spanish Commissioners on the other, it was determined by Commodore DUNLOP to haul down the British flag in the ports of Mexico, and to withdraw his small force. There was thus no question of withdrawing troops from Mexico, for there never were any land troops there; the only force we ever sent in the naval squadron was a force of 700 marines, the greater number of whom were withdrawn some time previously. [Hear.] I thought it necessary to make this statement, as I believe that great misapprehension has arisen on the subject. I am informed that considerable indignation has been expressed in France as to the presumed withdrawal of troops by this country at a very critical moment. That supposition, as I have shown, has no foundation in fact, as there were no British troops to be withdrawn from Mexico. [Hear, hear.]

abstract: Lord BROUGHAM, on behalf of his noble and learned friend (Lord LYNDHURST,) whose health, as their lordships would be glad to hear, had greatly improved of late -- [hear, hear] -- asked for the correspondence which had taken place respecting the capture of this vessel by the Americans, and her recapture from the prize crew. He understood that there had been some correspondence upon this subject, and he wished to know from the noble earl whether there would be any objection to produce that correspondence.
lead_paragraph: Lord BROUGHAM, on behalf of his noble and learned friend (Lord LYNDHURST,) whose health, as their lordships would be glad to hear, had greatly improved of late -- [hear, hear] -- asked for the correspondence which had taken place respecting the capture of this vessel by the Americans, and her recapture from the prize crew. He understood that there had been some correspondence upon this subject, and he wished to know from the noble earl whether there would be any objection to produce that correspondence.

abstract: After a flourish of trumpets to cover the retreat the journals have ceased the discussion of the mediation question, and we may now count again on an intermission of three or four weeks. One of the discomfited secession sheets says, however, that if England refuses to cooperate with France, Russia will not, and that overtures have already been made to that Power on the subject. This, of course, is a pure fabrication.

abstract: On Thursday evening at 7, I left Fair Oaks for the White House. The train had left the station at Savage's, early in the evening, so I turned my horse's head toward Bottom's Bridge, and concluded to ride the short distance of twenty miles. A battle had been fought on our right that day, but it was impossible to ascertain, at headquarters, any of the particulars.

abstract: The approaching Anniversary of our National Independence is likely to be celebrated with more eclat than its predecessors for many years. If it is not, it will not be the fault of our City authorities, as they have appropriated twice as much as was ever before allowed for the same purpose. How the sum of $8,000 is to be expended is a mystery to outsiders, but that amount has been appropriated, and will assuredly be expended.

abstract: It is to be hoped the right of free discussion was last night vindicated to the content of everybody. The meeting at Cooper Institute
lead_paragraph: It is to be hoped the right of free discussion was last night vindicated to the content of everybody. The meeting at Cooper Institute was evidently not to the public taste, notwithstanding the extreme diffidence with which its object was announced. "The Union, as it was, the Constitution as it is," is an indifferently good war cry, chiefly because it means anything or nothing, at the option of the utterer; treason, if treachery happen to be the individual bent; loyalty, if personal caprice fortuitously take that better direction. But people generally had little faith in any commendable sense to be affixed to the phrase. The antecedents, remote and recent, of the men principally interested in the business, were of themselves sufficient warrant of malign purposes, or of a folly more mischievous than the extreme of malignity; men, who either openly abetted and encouraged the rebellion, or who interposed between it and a punishment which, had it been prompt, might have been instantly curative. Even the mob, which too often runs without reading, understands that an Ex-Mayor of this City, who interposed to secure arms for the rebels, and an Ex-Senator from Kentucky, who paralysed the stroke of justice by attempts at accommodation which the insurgents unanimously scouted, are not likely to wish simply a restoration of peace and order. A strong suspicion prevails, quite naturally, that sympathy with the objects of rebellion, and a desire to concede everything to the spirit of violence and treason, which have flooded the nation with ills unspeakable, really underlie the very temperate professions of these peacemakers.

abstract: -- Mr. B.M. Davenport of Harvard College, recently astonished the natives by walking from Gorham, over the summit of Mount Washington, and down on the opposite side to the Crawford House, in the space of seven hours and fifty-six minutes. For sixteen miles his road was on the mountain, and the time usually required for a horse to travel over this part of the road is from six to eight hours. Subsequently he eclipsed himself by climbing from the Crawford House to the top of Mount Washington, and on the way went to the summit of Mount Pleasant, in three hours and forty-five minutes. The guides who are in the habit of going up this road, say it requires good walking to walk it in five hours.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the admission of Western Virginia as a State was taken up, the question being on the amendment proposed by Mr. SUMNER, that after the Fourth of July, 1863, neither Slavery nor involuntary servitude shall exist there. After some debate, the bill was postponed for the present, and the Army Appropriation bill was considered. An amendment limiting
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the admission of Western Virginia as a State was taken up, the question being on the amendment proposed by Mr. SUMNER, that after the Fourth of July, 1863, neither Slavery nor involuntary servitude shall exist there. After some debate, the bill was postponed for the present, and the Army Appropriation bill was considered. An amendment limiting the number of Major-Generals to forty, and Brigadiers to two hundred, was adopted, but the amendment limiting the number of soldiers to 750,000 was stricken out. An amendment was adopted appropriating two million dollars to provide for the comfort of discharged soldiers who may arrive in the principal cities wounded, and for forwarding destitute soldiers to their homes. An amendment was also adopted appropriating five millons for collecting, organizing and drilling the volunteers. Consideration of the bill was then postponed. A message was received from the [???] recommending a vote of thanks to Commodore FOOTE. Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota, offered a resolution asking the President if Mr. C.C. FULTON, one of the editors of the Baltimore American, had been arrested, and upon what charge, or whether any charges have been preferred against him, and on what evidence. Mr. KENNEDY, of Maryland, moved to add other names to the inquiry, and the resolution went over. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: editorial discusses other military movements that could occupy Hunter for summer
snippet: editorial discusses other military movements that could occupy Hunter for summer
lead_paragraph: cial correspondent with Gen. HUNTER in South Carolina informs us that operations against Charleston are to be abandoned until the coming Fall, as the forces now in the Department are insufficient for an assault upon the city, and reinforcements cannot be had until that time; and moreover, that James' Island is to be abandoned, and our troops there are to be sent back to Port Royal. This is an unfortunate termination to the operations against Charleston, for which such extensive preparation had been made, and in anticipation of which troops had been brought from various points in the Department of the South, from as far away even as Western Florida. The country will of course be greatly disappointed at the failure of hopes which seemed to be so near realization.

abstract: The United States Vs. The Bark Empress and her Cargo This vessel was captured by the Vincennes on No. 27 1861, off the mouth of the Mississippi and libeled here as a prize. The ship's papers showed her
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Bark Empress and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured by the Vincennes on No. 27 1861, off the mouth of the Mississippi and libeled here as a prize. The ship's papers showed her to be a British bottom, employed by her owners on a voyage from England to Rio Janiero and there chartered by her master to affreighters, partly British and partly Brazilian subjects, to carry a neutral cargo "to New-Orleans [???] Mobile as may be ordered by the charterers; and if the vessel on arrival be warned off by a blockading squadron, to proceed either to New-York, Baltimore or Philadelphia, which second port of destination is likewise to be named by the charterers previous to the departure of the vessel from Rio." This charter was executed Sept. 5, 1861, it being then known to the parties and publicly notorious at Rio Janiero that New-Orleans and Mobile were under blockade by the United States. On Sept. 14, the charterers instructed the master to proceed to New-Orleans with the cargo, and if the port should be open on his arrival to deliver the cargo there, and added, "should the port be blockaded, you will be warned off, and will then proceed direct to your discharge port of New-York." The vessel sailed from Rio Sept. 18. When a few days out the master spoke a vessel by which he was informed, and also by public papers obtained from her, that all the Southern ports were blockaded. The same information was obtained from another vessel which he spoke off Cape Antonio, Cuba, some nine or ten days before he was captured. His vessel ran a direct course from Rio to New-Orleans, without deviation, and on Nov. 26, 1861, she struck on a bar in the mouth of the Mississippi, inside of the blockading squadron in the night time, and was there captured next morning by boats from the Vincennes.

abstract: About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a frame stable in the rear of No. 79 Mott-street. The flames soon spread to the cracker bakery of ROBERT C. SCOTT, a building which extended the whole width of the two lots Nos. 75 and 77 Mottstreet. From thence the fire soon communicated to
lead_paragraph: About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a frame stable in the rear of No. 79 Mott-street. The flames soon spread to the cracker bakery of ROBERT C. SCOTT, a building which extended the whole width of the two lots Nos. 75 and 77 Mottstreet. From thence the fire soon communicated to the front buildings Nos. 77 and 79, and in a very short space of time thereafter, the four-story brick building, occupied as a tenement house, and known as No. 75 Mott-street, was found to be in flames. The whole of these structures were destroyed in about two hours after the fire commenced. The firemen were prompt, and the steam fire-engines were brought into action with unusual celerity, but all efforts to save the buildings seemed useless, and when it was known that the houses could not be preserved, the principal exertions of many of the firemen were directed to the occupants in the tenement houses, all of whom were saved, though some of them were seriously injured in their attempts to escape from the burning buildings. A four-story tenement house, situated in the rear of No. 73 Mott-street, took fire, and before the flames could be extinguished, it was damaged to the extent of $2,500. A frame building in the rear of No. 84 Mulberry-street, was also destroyed. The houses in the rear of Nos. 86 and 88 Mulberry-street, were damaged to the amount of about $4,500. A two-story frame building, in the rear of No. 192 Canal-street, was totally destroyed.

abstract: In accordance with the request of the Governors of eighteen States of the Union, that an additional military force be called for, "to garrison and hold all of the numerous cities and military positions that have been captured by our armies, and speedily crush out the rebellion still in existence," the President of the United States has issued his proclamation that a force of THREE HUNDRED THOUSAND men additional to those now in the field, be at once raised for active service. "The crisis of the rebellion," as the gubernatorial memorial says, "is now at hand;" and there is no doubt that the country will speedily respond to this renewed call upon its patriotism.

abstract: The Board of Education met last evening, Mr. BENEDICT in the chair, and a bare quorum present. The report of the Committee on Sites and School-houses, in favor of purchasing lots in West ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Education met last evening, Mr. BENEDICT in the chair, and a bare quorum present. The report of the Committee on Sites and School-houses, in favor of purchasing lots in West Forty-third-street for a new school-house, at the sum of $10,400, was discussed at length, and failed of adoption for want of a constitutional vote. The Committee on Supplies reported that C.L. YOUNG & Co. had backed out of their contract to supply the schools with coal, and the Board authorized them to readvertise for proposals, but to accept no bids from C.L. YOUNG & Co. Some other routine business was transacted, and the Board adjourned to the 16th inst.

abstract: The Trustees of the First Baptist Churck of Brooklyn et al. vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Company. This was an action to recover damages for the destruction by fire of plaintiffs' church, on the 10th ...
lead_paragraph: The Trustees of the First Baptist Churck of Brooklyn et al. vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Company. -- This was an action to recover damages for the destruction by fire of plaintiffs' church, on the 10th day of September, 1848, which had been insured by defendants in 1845, for one year, for a premium of $25. At the expiration of the policy in 1846, it was renewed for one year. It was claimed by the plaintiffs that there was an agreement before this renewal that the policy should be renewed from time to time without further notice, until one party or the other should give notice of an intention to discontinue the renewal. This the defendants denied. The evidence in regard to the renewal was very conflicting. The President of the Company and the Treasurer of the Church testifying to conflicting statements. A verdict was given for the defendants, and a motion made for a new trial before Justice Allan on his minutes, which was denied, and judgment entered for defendants -- from which the plaintiffs appealed to this Court, on the ground that the Court improperly excluded the answer of one A.W. Lewis to the question, "What is meant by a permanent policy," and also improperly excluded all evidence of contracts between other parties, and the mode in which they were carried out.

abstract: The President of the United States has duly called upon the country for an additional force of THREE HUNDRED THOUSAND Volunteers to serve for three years, or for the war. The wisdom of this is ...
lead_paragraph: The President of the United States has duly called upon the country for an additional force of THREE HUNDRED THOUSAND Volunteers to serve for three years, or for the war. The wisdom of this is obvious to all. Our army in the field has been reduced by the ordinary casualties of the service, and must be recruited, and the positions captured by our arms must be held by military authority. The people appreciate these facts. They fully estimate the magnitude of the great struggle, and the sacred obligations imposed upon them, and the necessity of exerting a power that will speedily quell the rebellion, restore the rightful authority of the Government and give peace to the country.

abstract: WHERE WE STAND. - We print elsewherea Proclamation by President LINCOLN, declaring in what States and parts of States insurrection now exists. This is done in accordance with an act of the present Congress, providing that he shall make such a Proclamation on or before the 1st of July. The black roll will not convey any news to any one, and is not meant to, but this solemn marshaling of the States "now in insurrection and rebellion," like the summoning of culprits to the bar of justice, has an impressive effect. The act referred to, which was approved on the 7th of June, is entitled "An Act for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts within the United States, and for other purposes." It provides that when in any State or Territory, or in any portion of any State or Territory, by reason of insurrection or rebellion, the civil authority of the Government of the United States is obstructed so that the provisions of the act entitled, "An Act to provide increased revenue from imports, to pay interest on the public debt, and for other purposes," approved August 5, 1861, for assessing, levying and collecting the direct taxes thereon mentioned, cannot be peaceably executed, the said direct taxes, by said act apportioned among the States and Territories, respectively, shall be apportioned and charged in each State and Territory, or part thereof, wherein the civil authority is thus obstructed, upon all the lands and lots of ground situate therein, respectively, except such as are exempt from taxation by the laws of said State or of the United States, as the said lands or lots were enumerated and valued under the last assessment and valuaation thereof, made under the authority of said State or Territory previous to the first day of January, Anno Domini, Eighteen hundred and sixty-one. The second section of this act provides, that on or before the first day of July, the President, by his proclamation, shall declare in what States, or parts of States, any such insurrection exists, and thereupon the before-described lots or parcels of land shall become charged with their respective portions of said direct tax; and the same, together with the penalty, shall be a lien thereon, without any other or further proceeding whatever.

abstract: The great rebellion is tenacious of life. Though the rebels have been driven from a hundred fields, and their cause has been hopelessly broken down in half a dozen States; ...
lead_paragraph: The great rebellion is tenacious of life. Though the rebels have been driven from a hundred fields, and their cause has been hopelessly broken down in half a dozen States; though we hold possession of the whole Southern coast line, and have control of the Southern system of rivers; though we have taken numberless forts, captured the principal rebel cities, seized some of the most important railroad lines, and many of the strategic positions; though we have penetrated deep into the Cotton States; though we have, by raising troops in Kentucky, Missouri, Maryland, and other of the Slave States, divided the South against itself, and thereby weakened it more than many defeats would otherwise have done; though, in brief, the aspect of the military field is completely changed from what it was at this time last Summer, yet the rebellion still presents a powerful front. It still holds the capital which we have menaced for over a year, and JEFF. DAVIS still rules in Richmond. His army is yet numbered by the hundred thousand; his hopes of success, if dim, have yet vitality; and though he cannot now expect to capture Washington, and overthrow this Government, he still manages to stimulate his rebel followers by the belief that a Southern Confederacy can be established. The truth is, that from the beginning this rebellion was a desperate game, played by desperate gamblers, and though they may lose one stake after another, yet, their own necks being the final stake, they will struggle while there is a flicker of hope; and as hope continues to go down, they will struggle all the more desperately.

abstract: The approaching celebration of the anniversary of our National Independence promises to be the most gorgeous in display, as it certainly will be in profuseness of expenditure, of any which have ever preceded it. The Common Council, desirous of testifying ...
lead_paragraph: The approaching celebration of the anniversary of our National Independence promises to be the most gorgeous in display, as it certainly will be in profuseness of expenditure, of any which have ever preceded it. The Common Council, desirous of testifying their patriotism, by paying proper respect to the day and the occasion which has made it an anniversary throughout the world, appropriated the munificent sum of $8,000, for the purpose of displaying their attachment to the Union. Mr. EDGE, the well-known pyrotechnist of Jersey City, is intrusted with the preparation of the fireworks, which are to be exhibited in the various parts of the City, (already published in the TIMES, of Wednesday.) Of course, they will be worthy of the reputation which he has fairly earned. On yesterday the frames for the various pieces were erected at the localities designated by the Committee in charge of the matter, and they certainly give promise of a magnificent display, provided, However, the clerk of the weather will shut up the flood-gates which are tinder his control, and permit those who will have to pay the expenses, the enjoyment of the treat prepared for them. In addition to the fireworks so thoroughly distributed, music will be furnished at each place, but there are so many hearts now bowed down with grief on account of the loss of those most dear to them, on the battle-field, music would almost seem out of place.

abstract: Graphic details of recent events before Richmond, covering the period from Wednesday of last week until Monday evening last, will be found in our columns this morning, as furnished by our special correspondents, in advance of the official ...
lead_paragraph: Graphic details of recent events before Richmond, covering the period from Wednesday of last week until Monday evening last, will be found in our columns this morning, as furnished by our special correspondents, in advance of the official dispatches of the Government. A full account of Gen. MCCLELLAN's movement to the James River is given, with particulars of the heavy engagements with the enemy incident to the movement. The first of these battles was fought on Thursday near Mechanicsville; the second on Friday, near Gaines' Hill; the third on Saturday, in the front of our position; the fourth on Sunday -- a continuous skirmish in the rear, as our forces were concentrating across the Chickahominy; and the fifth on Monday, when the enemy, in great numbers, attacked our army in its new position, and were repulsed after a very severe battle, in which several of our gunboats on the James River took efficient part. These battles were all of a most severe character, in which our forces suffered heavily, but in which the losses of the enemy are believed to be much the heaviest. At the close of the battle on Monday evening, the date of our latest advices, there was a prospect that the fighting would be renewed on Tuesday. A wholesome dread of our gunboats, however, may have prompted another attempt of the rebels to harass our troops in their new position.

abstract: The "Union meeting" of Tuesday last was, to all intents and purposes, a secession gathering. Its object was to stimulate sympathy for the rebels, to create the impression that ...
lead_paragraph: The "Union meeting" of Tuesday last was, to all intents and purposes, a secession gathering. Its object was to stimulate sympathy for the rebels, -- to create the impression that they were threatened with terrible persecution in the shape of confiscating their property and emancipating their slaves, and that something must be done to ward off this calamity from their innocent and defenceless heads. The main purpose of this meeting, according to its own declarations, was to furnish this protection. The brunt of its denunciations fell -- not upon the rebels, not upon those who are waging war on the Government, who are slaying our sons and wasting our treasure in the battle-field, but upon the men who are suspected of a design to make them suffer for it. The meeting had very little to say against the Rebels, -- but a great deal to say against the Abolitionists. Its object was to excite hatred of the latter, and sympathy for the former. One utterly ignorant of current events would infer from reading the proceedings, that the Abolitionists were endeavoring to overthrow the Constitution, while the Secessionists were seeking to protect and uphold it.

abstract: THE NATIONAL ANNIVERSARY. The Committee of the Common Council, charged with the onerous duty of spending the annual appropriation of $1,000 in a patriotic manner, on the Fourth of July, have been diligently at work for two weeks past, and it is ...
lead_paragraph: THE NATIONAL ANNIVERSARY. -- The Committee of the Common Council, charged with the onerous duty of spending the annual appropriation of $1,000 in a patriotic manner, on the Fourth of July, have been diligently at work for two weeks past, and it is understood, will have completed their arrangements so as to announce them to the public before Friday next. There will probably be a display of fireworks on Fort Greene, and at some point in the Eastern District; the bells will be rung at the usual hours, and National salutes will be fired in the usual places. So far as is known, there is no probability of an oration being delivered, except on private account. The citizens of Bowronville -- a small but beautiful and enterprising village in the Eighteenth Ward -- propose to spend a much larger sum than the City authorities, in a patriotic demonstration. In the grove, near the Dutch Reformed Church, the day will be ushered in by the firing of a National salute. At 3 P.M., after a prayer, the Declaration of Independence will be read by HENRY C. WILSON, Esq., followed by an oration by Hon. HENRY B. STANTON, formerly of Kansas fame, but now of this city. Patriotic songs will be sung, and MEYER's Band will perform patriotic airs on the occasion. The people of Bowronville are determined to have their little affair come off, rain or shine, and therefore announce that in case of rain the exercises will take place in the Dutch Reformed Church. In several of the public schools, yesterday, there were exercises of a patriotic character. The friends of the teachers and scholars were invited, songs were sung, the Declaration of Independence was read, and patriotic speeches were made. Similar exercises will take place in other schools to-day.

abstract: The following is a partial list of the killed and wounded at the battles on Thursday, the 26th, and Friday the 27th ult. Most of the names were collected at Savage's Station. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to punish persons giving or offering to give considerations to Members of Congress or officers of the Government for procuring contracts, , was reported back from the Judiciary Committee. Mr. WRIGHT, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to punish persons giving or offering to give considerations to Members of Congress or officers of the Government for procuring contracts, &c., was reported back from the Judiciary Committee. Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, offered a resolution to expel Senator SIMMONS, of Rhode Island, for his connection with certain contracts. It was laid over. A resolution adjourning Congress on the 14th inst. was referred to the Finance Committee. The bill to establish the grade for line officers in the navy was recommitted, with instructions to regulate the pay. The bill authorizing an additional issue of Treasury notes was debated at considerable length, amended in some particulars, and finally passed. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: We are glad to see that Mr. FULTON, of the Baltimore American, has been released. He was sent to Fort McHenry, for the "high military offence" of having sent to the agent of the Associated Press a statement that he had consulted with the President concerning recent operations in front of Richmond. We are in no position to judge of the exigency which required such a punishment for this offence. But we know Mr. FULTON to be one of the most intelligent and conscientious members of the American Press -- one who would be among the very last to offend willfully against any regulation which the Government might deem essential to the public good. His journal has been among the ablest, steadiest and most effective advocates of the Union in the Border States. The Government, we are confident, has acted wisely in making his punishment for an assumed offence merely nominal.

abstract: Had the enemy possessed full information of the purposes of our Commanding General they could not have taken better advantage of our position than they did. The fact that our front gave way at Mechanicsville ...
lead_paragraph: Had the enemy possessed full information of the purposes of our Commanding General they could not have taken better advantage of our position than they did. The fact that our front gave way at Mechanicsville on Thursday, after making a successful stand, and fell back toward Gaines' Hill, seems to have suggested to them that a general retrograde movement was contemplated; and it became their policy to follow and light us on the retreat. With the Chickahominy in our rear, it was, of course, impossible for our army to cross, successfully, under the enemy's fire; and there is no doubt but that they expected to overtake and compel us to fight or be cut to pieces at the bridges.

abstract: OPENING OF THE NEW-YORK RACES. The second meeting of the racing campaign instituted by Mr. J.L. CASSADY, and to be continued under his auspices will take place to-morrow, the Fourth of July, on the ...
lead_paragraph: OPENING OF THE NEW-YORK RACES. -- The second meeting of the racing campaign instituted by Mr. J.L. CASSADY, and to be continued under his auspices will take place to-morrow, the Fourth of July, on the Union Course, Long Island. Mr. CASSADY has taken upon himself the laudable task of endeavoring to revive public interest in the sports of the turf in the Northern States, and under his judicious management, combined with the many improvements made on the programme of his predecessors, we think he has a fair chance of success. The old and exorbitant fee of $1 for admission to the track is to be abolished, and the moderate sum of 25 cents will purchase all the privileges of the Course, with the exception of a seat on the Grand Stand, for which the old price will be charged. Ladies, if accompanied by gentlemen, are to be admitted free, including a seat on the Stand. If such liberality does not render the race-course popular, it will be safe to conclude that all interest in the sport is past "revival," at least in this latitude. Mr. CASSADY has secured the attendance of the leading sporting men of Kentucky and Tennessee, with their studs, and the attractions of the opening meeting to-morrow are such as can hardly fail to secure a large attendance. There will be three races during the day -- one of three-year olds, two-mile heats, for which there are 12 entries; another of saddle horses, half-mile heats; and the third, last, and most important, a handicap race, two-mile heats, for which there are 13 entries, with a certainty of at least 10 starters. The following are the entries for this race, with the ages and weights to be carried: Laura Ferris, 6 years, 105 pounds; Pope Swigart, 5 years, 100 pounds; Bettie Ward, 5 years, 100 pounds; Hillsborough, 4 years, 90 pounds; West Roxbury, 3 years, 90 pounds; Reporter, 4 years, 95 pounds; Troratore, 5 years, 90 pounds; Sunshine, 3 years, 85 pounds; Miss Jessie, 3 years, 85 pounds; Cyclone, 5 years, 85 pounds; Throg's Neck, aged, 85 pounds; Revenge, 4 years, 85 pounds; and Belie, 4 years, 75 pounds. Pools for the races will be sold on each evening previous to the races by Dr. UNDERWOOD, at 754 Broadway, corner of Eighth-street. All the horses have arrived, and are at the stables of the Union Course, L.I.

abstract: We have at last full reports of recent movements in front of Richmond. We are sorry to say that they do not fully sustain the encouraging interpretation which the public sought ...
lead_paragraph: We have at last full reports of recent movements in front of Richmond. We are sorry to say that they do not fully sustain the encouraging interpretation which the public sought to put upon the brief announcement, that our right wing had been attacked and had withdrawn to the other side of the Chickahominy. We have now no room to doubt that our army has met with a very serious reverse, and that it is in a condition of peril, which, if not imminent, at least calls for the instant and energetic efforts of the Government and the country.

abstract: Mr. Prentice, of the Louisville Journal, gives this as his experience with a female rebel: "As we were passing along the street two days ago in our usual quiet way, musing upon the 'storms of State,' and pondering upon our solemn responsibility in this great crisis of the affairs of the nation and of mankind, a very pretty young woman, whom we had understood to be a fiery little rebel, and even a terrible villifier of the Louisville Journal, was about meeting us, when, turning off from the sidewalk, she protruded her red and tempting lips at us boldly and defiantly. "Oh, certainly, we will if you want us to very bad, though, indeed, this is rather too public a place," said we, with our accustomed suavity, advancing toward her with our lips correspondingly protruded, when, to our no little disappointment and suprise, she started and ran away from us as if we had been some ugly old fellow or "forty."
