abstract: It should be remembered, whatever reverses may occur during this portion of the campaign in Virginia, that the rebels have one important strategic advantage.
lead_paragraph: It should be remembered, whatever reverses may occur during this portion of the campaign in Virginia, that the rebels have one important strategic advantage. They are at the centre or on the smaller arc of the circle, while we move on the circumference. A distinguished Prussian officer, whose military criticism was quoted in these columns, indicated more than a month before the date of the event, the threatening possibility of a defeat of BANKS' corps. The position recalled to him a well-remembered campaign on the borders of his own country -- that year when NAPOLEON, holding Dresden as a centre, kept an overwhelming mass of the Allies in check, by moving out with tremendous rapidity from his centre, now upon one corps and then another, and defeating them in detail. Or better still, it might have reminded him of NAPOLEON's position in his last glorious campaign in France, before the banishment to Elba. There, moving on the smaller arc, though with a much inferior force to the whole of the Allies, he was enabled to fall upon BUTCHER's corps, and other corps with superior numbers and tremendous effect, and at one time seemed about to drive out in disgrace the enormous armies of the Allies. Owing to the nature of the country, and to Gen. MCCLELLAN's making the Peninsula his base of operations, together with the numerous railways behind the enemy's front, the rebel General has been enabled to have the advantage of a central position, while our line has necessarily been extended from the Shenandoah to the Rappahannock and the Chickaliominy. Our connections have been difficult, owing to the character of the surface, and for some unknown reason, unity of action was destroyed by the Washington authorities in the very outset by the division of the army into separate corps. The consequences have been what might be expected.

abstract: Our news from the army before Richmond is up to Wednesday evening, at which time appearances were much better than at the date of our previous advices, at the close of the sanguinary engagement of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Our news from the army before Richmond is up to Wednesday evening, at which time appearances were much better than at the date of our previous advices, at the close of the sanguinary engagement of Monday. The extraordinary series of battles which began with Wednesday morning of last week, on our right wing, and which raged almost continuously for the whole week along our entire lines, and over a distance of between thirty and forty miles, seemed to be still unfinished on Wednesday night of this week. "On Tuesday," says Gen. MCCLELLAN, "we had a severe battle, and to-day (Wednesday, 2d inst.,) we beat the enemy, the men fighting even better than before." Whether the battle was renewed yesterday, and whether this morning the strife may be still raging, we do not yet know. The main position of our army, however, at Turkey Bend, on the James River, was quite secure under the safeguard of gunboats. The good news also comes to us this morning, that by Wednesday reinforcements had arrived from Washington and we learn, too, that on Tuesday morning a heavy column of Gen. POPE's army reached Fortress Monroe, and had immediately been pushed up the James River. This body must have reinforced Gen. MCCLELLAN by Wednesday, and doubtless rendered him abundantly able not only to hold the rebels in check, but perhaps also to assume the offensive. We suppose that other of the divisions of POPE's army will at once follow that of SHIELDS', and that not less than forty or fifty thousand men altogether can be dispatched to the Peninsula from different points. From Gen. BURNSIDE, strange to say, we have as yet not a word; but he is most certainly on his march to cooperate with MCCLELLAN, if he has not, as we think he must have, joined him before this time. One of our cotemporaries, last evening, gave prominence to a story from Washington that our army had "lost its siege guns and thirty thousand men;" but MCCLELLAN himself, writing as late as Wednesday evening, says he had "lost but one gun, which had to be abandoned because it broke down;" and another account states that HEINTZELMAN captured eight guns and a whole brigade of rebels, which seems to be much more likely, judging from the latest advices. Four of the most prominent rebel Generals are reported lost to their cause -- Stonewall JACKSON, killed; BARNWELL RHETT, killed; ANDERSON, mortally wounded, and MAGRUDER a prisoner; while of our own general officers, MCCALL and REYNOLDS were reported missing on Tuesday night. The death of JACKSON, which is undoubtedly a fact, as it is announced by the Richmond papers of Monday, and confirmed from our own side, will be a tremendous blow to the rebels. Of all their Generals, he was the only one who had ever assumed the offensive with success; and the successes of their army last week were entirely owing to his quick, energetic and determined action and skillful manoeuvres.

abstract: A REMARKABLE OCCURENCY. At an early hour yesterday morning some men passing along the Canton-street mall, on Fort Greene, heard a sound coming from a well in the vicinity, which cased them to halt and make an investigation.
lead_paragraph: A REMARKABLE OCCURENCY. -- At an early hour yesterday morning some men passing along the Canton-street mall, on Fort Greene, heard a sound coming from a well in the vicinity, which cased them to halt and make an investigation. Upon looking into the well they discovered a woman sitting upon a cross-beam some 70 feet below the surface, who begged to be taken out. The Police were notified, a rope obtained, and the woman was drawn out in safety, and apparently uninjured. When asked how she got into the well, she stated that her name was CATHERINE GRIFFIN, and that she was employed as a servant at No. 85 Sands-street; that on the afternoon before she went to New-York to see some friends, and while there drank freely of intoxicating beverages. She started for home after dark, and while in a Fulton ferryboat, a young man, whom she had never seen before, induced her to walk to Fort Greene; there he attempted to take borne improper liberties with her person, when she ran away from him and accidentally fell into the place where found. This well is 80 feet deep, about 4 feet in diameter, is walled with stone, and has long been out of use, but has about 10 feet of water in it. Over the top is a stone slab, and through it a hole where a pump formerly was inserted. Over this hole there has been a stone slab, and the place has been reported several times by the Police as a dangerous nuisance. The woman was found seated upon a cross piece a few feet above the water. When the storm of Wednesday night is borne in mind, the story told by the woman that she fell to the spot where found -- a distance of 70 feet, and without receiving serious injury, the whole affair seems to be a remarkable one. The Police are endeavoring to unravel it.

abstract: The U.S. steamer Daylight, Commander [???] LOCKWOOD, from Beaufort, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday evening. She left Beaufort on June 31, at 8 A.M. She has been in commission since June 7, 1861, and during that time has been natively engaged in blockading and other service in the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron. The Daylight was flagship at the reduction of Fort Macon, and has since that time been lying at Beaufort harbor. During her cruise she has taken seven prizes, and rescued the shipJohn Clark from under the fire of the enemy's battery at Lynn Haven Bay, which she engaged and silenced. The following is a list of her officers:

abstract: A regular meeting of the Chamber was held yesterday, PELATIAH PERIT in the Chair. The following new members were admitted: Morris Franklin, Geo. G. haven, Oliver Harriman, Edward S. Jaffray, Alfred Lockwood, James Low, Henry N. Titus, Christopher V. Wemple.
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Chamber was held yesterday, PELATIAH PERIT in the Chair. The following new members were admitted: Morris Franklin, Geo. G. haven, Oliver Harriman, Edward S. Jaffray, Alfred Lockwood, James Low, Henry N. Titus, Christopher V. Wemple. A report from Judge MARTIN, in relation to the Commercial Convention held in Glasgow last year, was read and referred to a Committee consisting of Messrs. J.D. Jones, M.H. Grinnell, F.S. Lathrop, C.H. Marshall and Thomas Tileston.

abstract: -- The City took the news yesterday with admirable spirit. The Stock market tumbled head over heels, it is true, but this amounts to nothing. It was only a panic among the bulls who had been speculating for a tremendous rise, and scattered in every direction when the wind blew from the other quarter. They were in very much the same condition as the sutlers at the White House when told that the rebel cavalry were coming. They abandoned their supplies and rushed pell-mell on board the first gunboat that offered shelter.

abstract: editorial disappointed by Hunter plan
snippet: editorial disappointed by Hunter plan
lead_paragraph: -- An arrival on Monday from Port Royal announce that Gen. HUNTER has determined to evacuate James Island. This unhappy issue of the promising attempt for the reduction of Charleston is deeply painful. That city has so much to answer for in the present state of our national affairs, and has been to such an extent the prime mover in the rebellion, that we should have felt a peculiar pride in its capture. It would have been, moreover, but justice, that the seat of the war should be transferred to that Capital city of the treason. But the attempt fails, and we have only to resign ourselves to the disappointment for a while longer.

abstract: Rev. R.B.C. HOWELL., Dr. SEHON, Dr. FORD, Dr. SAWRID, Dr. BALDWIN and Rev. W.H. WHARTON, appeared on yesterday morning at the Executive office, according to appointment at the previsous interview. Rev. W.H. WHARTON appeared separately from the others, and held an interesting conversation with the Governor.
lead_paragraph: Rev. R.B.C. HOWELL., Dr. SEHON, Dr. FORD, Dr. SAWRID, Dr. BALDWIN and Rev. W.H. WHARTON, appeared on yesterday morning at the Executive office, according to appointment at the previsous interview. Rev. W.H. WHARTON appeared separately from the others, and held an interesting conversation with the Governor. In consequence of bad health he was paroled for some days. The others were sent without parley, under guard, to the Provost-Marshal. Lieut.-Col. MCCLAIN, who is acting in the absence of Col. MATHEWS, with instructions to that officer to release them, provided they would give evidence of their loyalty by taking the oath of allegiance, and giving bond for $5,000 each for its faithful observance. If they should decline taking the oath, to send them to the Penitentiary, to remain there until arrangements should be made to convey them South across our lines; with the warning that if they attempted to return they would be regarded and dealt with as spies. The parsons all declining, they were immediately sent out to Mr. CAVERT's boarding-house.

abstract: editorial on day
snippet: editorial on day
lead_paragraph: "Through the thick gloom of the present I see the brightness of the future as the sun in heaven." We shall make this a glorious and immortal day. When we are in our graves our children will honor it. They will celebrate it with thanksgiving, with festivities, with bonfires, with illuminations. On its annual return they will shed tears, not of subjection and Slavery, not of agony and distress, but of exultation, of gratitude and of joy."

abstract: To-day the Army and Navy quarters in the vicinity of New-York, take a holiday to celebrate the glorious "Fourth." The Army salute will be fired from Fort Columbus, the Navy one from the Cobb dock at the Navy-yard, the receiving ship North Carolina not being used as a "celebrator" any more.
lead_paragraph: To-day the Army and Navy quarters in the vicinity of New-York, take a holiday to celebrate the glorious "Fourth." The Army salute will be fired from Fort Columbus, the Navy one from the Cobb dock at the Navy-yard, the receiving ship North Carolina not being used as a "celebrator" any more. The French frigate Gasendi has arrived in time to fire a salute, which she will do at noon, it being the duty of Commodore PAULDING to inform the commanding officer of that vessel beforehand, of the jubilee, which we presume he did. The frigate Sabine, 50, the steam corvette Aidrondack, the North Carolina, Connecticut, Supply and Relief, will dress ship and air their buntings. The marines and sailors will have their extra dinners, but it is not certain whether at their own or Uncle Sam's expense. All recruiting business stops to-day.

abstract: That despondent class of the community, which seemed to have made up its mind that New-York had sent about all its spare material in the way of soldiers to the war, will find its gloomy conclusions and predictions speedily proved false and unfounded.
lead_paragraph: That despondent class of the community, which seemed to have made up its mind that New-York had sent about all its spare material in the way of soldiers to the war, will find its gloomy conclusions and predictions speedily proved false and unfounded. Those who have had most experience in the recruiting business declare that never before did the prospects of rapidly filling up a large requisition for new troops look so favorable. Officers who have used their personal influence in the organization of regiments that they were unable to accompany into active service, and who are again aroused by the exigency of the moment to renewed exertion, say that men come in with remarkable readiness -- men, too, of a tone and quality such as it was thought bad been wholly absorbed by earlier regiments. They assert that even during the excitement which ensued upon the disaster of Bull Run, there was not a better feeling demonstrated nor more anxiety to join the army than now. This is contrary to general expectation, but it is an indisputable and encouraging fact.

abstract: We have official advices from Gen McCLELLAN'S Army up to 5 o'clock, P.M., of Wednesday. A dispatch from the General himself was received at the War Department, yesterday afternoon, ...
lead_paragraph: We have official advices from Gen. McCLELLAN's Army up to 5 o'clock, P.M., of Wednesday. A dispatch from the General himself was received at the War Department, yesterday afternoon, which states that he had succeeded in getting his army to the banks of the James River, with the loss of only one gun, which had to be abandoned on account of its becoming disabled; that the wagon train, with the exception of one wagon was in a safe position; that we had a severe battle on Tuesday, and that we beat the enemy on Wednesday. And what is of more importance, Gen. MCCLELLAN announces that reinforcements from Washington had already arrived. These reinforcements,together with those under Gen. SHIELDS, which embarked at Annapolis and arrived at Fortress Monroe on Tuesday, will be sufficient to insure Gen. MCCLELLAN in his new position, if not to enable him immediately to follow up his success of Wednesday, and push straight on to Richmond. The fight of Monday, partially described by our correspondents in yesterday's TIMES, was of the most desperate and determined character. In fact, the fighting of the entire seven days may be thus characterized. The consequent loss of life has been most fearful, but on the rebel side particularly so. The entire losses on both sides, in killed, wounded and missing, are estimated in one account at forty-five thousand, of which our proportion is but fifteen thousand, leaving thirty thousand for the rebels. Among their losses in killed are Gen. "Stonewall" JACKSON and Gen. BARNWELL RHETT, of South Carolina. Gen. MAGRUDER is also reported to have been taken prisoner. Many wounded prisoners have been captured on both sides. On the whole, it appears from the latest accounts that the advantages of the fighting have been on our side, though fighting against fearful odds. The number of the rebels is estimated at one hundred and eighty-five thousand, including a large part of BEAUREGARD's army, while against this enormous force we had opposed not more than ninety-five thousand effective men.

abstract: The TIMES published yesterday morning thirteen columns of most important and interesting intelligence from our correspondents with the Army of the Potomac, in advance of all our contemporaries.
lead_paragraph: The TIMES published yesterday morning thirteen columns of most important and interesting intelligence from our correspondents with the Army of the Potomac, in advance of all our contemporaries. According to its usual practice of bragging loudest when they are beaten the most, our neighbors of the Herald will probably devote their entire editorial page this morning to proving that it is the only enterprising newspaper on the continent! We should not be at all surprised if its circulation (on paper) should reach 150,000!

abstract: The Sunday newspaper train on the Hudson River Railroad has evidently proved a decided success. The demand for news along the line of the railway on Sunday exceeds the anticipations of the projectors of the movement, and the more enterprising of the Sunday Press are reaping a harvest in the demand made for papers at the various stations. It is expected the Sunday train will be a permanent institution, and one which the people inhabiting the suburbs will not willingly do away with.

abstract: -- The Herald pretends that it received its correspondence from the Army of the Potomac, but "withheld it at the request of the War Department." This is all moonshine. The War Department made no such request. On the contrary, the Herald, in common with the TIMES and all other City papers, was officially informed two days ago that the restrictions imposed by the Government on news coming by telegraph did not apply to news coming by mail. And the reason given for the distinction was, that as the telegraph was under military control the Government made itself, to a certain extent, responsible for whatever it permitted to go over the wires; -- whereas it could not be held responsible for anything that came by mail.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, two motions to adjourn over the Fourth -- one to Monday, and the other to Saturday -- were defeated. The House bill in relation to alterations in certain Judicial Districts was passed. The bill to establish Provisional Governments in insurrectionary districts was postponed until to-day, after brief consideration. The bill to provide a Government for the Territory of Arizona was postponed until next December. A joint resolution adjourning Congress on the 16th inst. was introduced and laid over. The bill relating to the Judiciary, providing certain rules in regard to State laws being regarded as decisions in common law in the United States Courts, was considered. An amendment was moved by Mr. SUMNER, that no evidence be excluded on account of color. On a vote being taken no quorum was found to be present. A motion was made to adjourn, but failed. A quorum was then obtained, and the amendment was rejected. The Senate spent the rest of the day in Executive session.

abstract: To-day is the Eighty-sixth Anniversary of our National Independence. Notwithstanding the war and the great interest our citizens feel therein, arrangements for the proper celebration of the day have not been forgotten.
lead_paragraph: To-day is the Eighty-sixth Anniversary of our National Independence. Notwithstanding the war and the great interest our citizens feel therein, arrangements for the proper celebration of the day have not been forgotten. At sunrise a salute will be fired at the Battery, and the National Standard hoisted; at noon a National salute of 34 guns will be fired. At 8 o'clock A.M., those regiments forming a part of the First Division, not absent at the seat of war, will form a line on Fourteenth-street, near Broadway. abstract: CONCERT BY THE GRAMMAR AND PRIMARY SCHOOLS OF THE 20TH WARD.
lead_paragraph: CONCERT BY THE GRAMMAR AND PRIMARY SCHOOLS OF THE 20TH WARD. -- Wednesday night, raining as it was, could in no wise defer the friends of the soldiers from patronizing an entertainment prepared for the benefit of widows and orphans made desolate by the war; and the Academy of Music could never hold forth more popular inducement to the lovers of music and poetry than drew the tremendous audience that witnessed it. Six departments of the public schools of the Twentieth Ward were represented, comprising in all six hundred well trained performers. Drills, tableaux and music, vocal by the young ladies and gentlemen, and instrumental by Dodworth's Band, made up the main attraction. To enter into detail of the excellent manner in which each and every one of these performances was conducted is unnecessary, but the military evolutions, first by the boys of Grammar School No. 32, and afterward the "Zouave Drill," by the young ladies of Grammar School No. 33, were so remarkably appropriate, and elicited such unqualified applause, that great praise must be accorded to their instructors. The "Wreath exercise" was also a peculiar feature of the entertainment, and one which exhibited striking perfection in methods of the drill. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and numbers of distinguished persons were present. The "Tableaux" at the close depicted: "The Seasons." "Taking the Veil." "The Sculptor's Dream," and best of all "The Wounded Soldier." The pupils were at each divertissement costumed in character. The exercises continued till a very late hour, and the Committee of Arrangements must certainly find their exchequer amply filled. Much good may it do the widows and the orphans of our self-sacrificing soldiers.

abstract: The people living on the line of the Charleston road are kept in terror by recent raids in that vicinity. A highly-respectable citizen, who lives about fifteen miles from town, and formerly one of our leading merchants, informs us that on Wednesday JACKSON's cavalry made its appearance in force along the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, and for the avowed object of burning the cotton and punishing all who had failed to conduct themselves to their liking. The cavalry force under JACKSON was large, and seemed to be bound for District No. 9, a district in which there was considerable cotton, none of which the Confederates had had time to burn before the occupation of Memphis. This District is reached by the Macon road, and is said to contain about fifteen hundred bales of cotton. This, or at least the larger portion of it was destroyed by the Confederates on Wednesday. Two persons who were up there buying cotton were arrested and taken off as prisoners. Two other merchants of Memphis, who were also out there, were arrested and taken South. And our informant states that the Confederate cavalry threatened to take as prisoners and to destroy all the property of all persons who, on any pretext, should come to the City of Memphis. They also stated that their intention is and will be to destroy the railroad and telegraph every time they are repaired, and to prevent the working of either. Our informant, who resides in that section, is fearful that their threats will be carried out, and if they should be, he anticipates the worst possible results to his property. Though a Southern man himself, he don't like the cotton-burning scheme, nor does he see the propriety or justice of a guerrilla warfare on those whose necessities require them to obtain their supplies from Memphis.

abstract: We have heard some few persons since the arrival of the unfavorable news from the army of the Potomac, who either from sympathy ...
lead_paragraph: We have heard some few persons since the arrival of the unfavorable news from the army of the Potomac, who either from sympathy with the rebels, or faint-heartedness, treated the matter as decisive of the question, and declared their opinion that it was all of no use for us to try to fight further, that the new volunteers would never be furnished, and that we might as well make up our minds to accept the fact of the Southern Confederacy with the Ohio River, and the Southern line of Pennsylvania for its northern border. This seems quite too great a conclusion to draw from any facts which we have. If MCCLELLAN's army were annihilated, the Monitor taken, Fortress Monroe strictly besieged, and the rebel cannon thundering upon Washington, it would still be, we think, too great a conclusion to draw. We would be still too mighty, too high-spirited a people to yield to such dishonorable terms. For consider what this involves. It involves first and foremost the surrender of the Mississippi which has been opened by our gallant tars amid storms of shot and shell, and the crash of iron prows against wooden walls. It involves giving up to the tender mercies of the rebels not only the scattered Unionists who have made themselves known under the protection of our flag, even in the regions where secession was most poisonous, but the masses of those who have endured so long in East Tennessee, who have fought so gallantly and well in Kentucky, Missouri and Western Virginia. It involves giving up the City of Washington with all its public buildings. It involves giving up Mount Vernon, so that we and our children will need Confederate passports to enable us to stand by the tomb of WASHINGTON. It involves the triumphant sheers of the London Times and the continuous outcry against us and against free institutions of all those who hate them and hate us because we love them. It involves the triumph at home of VALLANDIGHAM and COX, and the two WOODS and those who follow them, whether covertly or openly. It involves endless disgrace and degradation for us in the future, endless strife and confusion, endless war and disturbance, the downfall of American ideas, the overthrow of republican institutions, the turning back of the shadow upon the dial of human progress. We have no fear that any thought of accepting such results will be allowed to dwell for an instant in the minds of our people. As long as our fleets hold the sea, and our gunboats hold the rivers -- as long as the ports and the forts of the Southern harbors remain in our possession, and the rebels are shut out from any but clandestine commerce -- as long as their currency is shinplasters, at fifty per cent, discount, while ours is bank bills and United States notes, at par -- as long as our army is an army of volunteers -- why should we give ourselves up to such gloomy anticipations. Such disgrace is not yet in store for us. When salt is not to be had, and pins and needles are not to be bought in the stores of New-York; when our soldiers are on half rations and without uniforms; when want and distress fill the land and stand in every door and when President LINCOLN shall acknowledge, as JEFF. DAVIS has done, that without conscription it is impossible to keep our armies in the field, then, and not till then, will we begin to talk about giving up our hope of a restored Union of one free people, sweeping from the Lakes to the Gulf, and from the Atlantic to the Pacific. Till then, let us close up our ranks, and stirfen every muscle and sinew, and steel every heart, for a renewal of the struggle. Let us again in the future, as we have in the past, welcome self-denial, and make exertion and trial our companions. Let us call up the old associations which have ma de this day a day of remembrance, and let us show that even the bloody fields of the past year have not drained the land of heroes or chilled the love of the people for our flag "Old Glory," or for the Union which it has floated over so long, or the principles and hopes which have made it so glorious.

abstract: The first races of the New-York Spring Running Meeting were run on Friday at the Union Course. The day was in every way favorable, and aside from the fact that the National Holiday placed it in the power of many to attend, the mere pleasure of the drive was in itself a sufficient inducement to hundreds who ordinarily would not think of going to such a gathering.

abstract: About 11 P.M., on the night of the 3d, JAMES GIVEN was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, with a serious laceration of the arm, received while engaged in a street fight at the corner of Franklin and Greenwich streets. Officer MARSH, of the Fifth Precinct, conveyed him to the Hospital......Councilman ANTHONY MILLER, while walking through Houston-street, was struck on the head with a club, in the hands of some person to him unknown, and very dangerously injured. He was immediately conveyed to he City Hospital. The person who made the assault escaped......Early Friday morning, JOSEPH WHITSON was severely wounded in the hand by the premature discharge of a pistol, on the corner of Broadway and Fulton-street. He went himself to the New-York Hospital.... PATRICK JENNINGS was seriously wounded by a powder-horn explosion in Duane-street. Taken to New-York Hospital.... JAMES THOMAS was much injured by an explosion of powder, in Ludlow-street, between Hester and Canal streets. His left arm is much shattered, and his face considerably burned. Officer CAMPBELL, of the Tenth Precinct, conveyed him to the New-York Hospital....BENJAMIN ASHLEY received a gun-shot wound in the leg, in White-street, near Broadway. Officer BELL, of the Fifth, took him to the Hospital....MICHAEL DUBOIS was dangerously wounded in the groin by the premature discharge of a pistol Ho was conveyed to the Hospital....CHARLES LAIRD was very dangerously stabbed by GEORGE SMITH, at No. 25 Rose-street. The parties became involved in a quarrel, when SMITH drew a sheath knife and plunged it into LAIRD's abdomen. The wounded man was conveyed to the New-York Hospital. The offender has not yet been arrested....JOHN MATHEWS was shot in the hand, by the premature discharge of a pistol. Taken to the Hospital....MATHEW NORMAN was injured in the arm by powder explosion at the corner of Elm and Hester streets, and taken to the Hospital....JOHN SHAY was seriously burned about the face and eyes by an explosion of powder.... JAMES NAURY was taken to the Hospital by officer HYDE of the Sixth Precinct, suffering severely under the effects of a dangerous gunshot wound in the groin, received at No. 11 Mulberry-street....WM. GARLAND was shot in the hand on the corner of Washington and Tenth streets, and taken to the New-York Hospital....WILLIAM MCLAUGHLIN received a severe wound in the chest, while engaged in a light in Oliver-street, near Oak.... The fourth Precinct Police conveyed him to the Hospital....ROBERT CORDIAL was stabbed in the abdomen while engaged in a fight last night in Mott-street, near Prince....OTTO SCHEILHORN was horribly beaten and bruised by some parties in Houston-street. He was conveyed by the Police to the New-York Hospital, in an insensible condition. ....THOMAS MURPHY, of No. 140 Cherry-street, received a pistol-shot wound in the right side, from a pistol in the hands of some party unknown. Some persons were engaged in firing at a mark in a yard in the rear of the above number, when the ball went through the boards and lodged in MURPHY's side. He was taken to the Hospital......JOHN DAY had his hand seriously injured by the premature explosion of a pistol. He was taken to the City Hospital......JOHN ZEIGLER, a baker in the Seventeenth Ward, loaded a pistol with buck-shot and fired it off in a careless manner. One of the balls struck a woman behind the left ear, injuring her seriously. The offender was arrested......A boy in the same Ward loaded his pistol with small marbles, and fired it off at random. One of the balls struck a woman between the eyes, and inflicted a dangerous wound......SARAH MOTT, a girl four years of age, residing at No. 218 Stanton-street, was severely wounded with a ball from a small cannon, fired by JACOB SIMMONS and JOHN FLAMENT. They were arrested and locked up...... HENRY CAMBER, of No. 92 Sheriff-street, was severely wounded by the premature explosion of a pistol which he was handling in a careless manner...... Late Friday evening, a little girl named SEDONIA TATERSIA, residing at No. 270 First-avenue, while looking at the fireworks from the roof of the above number, fell therefrom to the sidewalk, and was instantly killed ......Quite a number of fires occurred during the day and evening, but generally the damage was trifling, having been extinguished in most cases without the aid of the firemen.

abstract: Ten thousand rebel prisoners have been removed to Chicago from Camp Randall, Wis., and Camp Butler, Springfield, Ill., as the former city has been proved highly salubrious. Mr. GAZE, of the Tremont House, and Mr. TUCKER, of the Briggs House, have contracted to feed these ten thousand mouths for 10 3/4 cents a day. Last year the same service was rendered to our volunteers in this City, for 35 cents a head.
lead_paragraph: Ten thousand rebel prisoners have been removed to Chicago from Camp Randall, Wis., and Camp Butler, Springfield, Ill., as the former city has been proved highly salubrious. Mr. GAZE, of the Tremont House, and Mr. TUCKER, of the Briggs House, have contracted to feed these ten thousand mouths for 10 3/4 cents a day. Last year the same service was rendered to our volunteers in this City, for 35 cents a head.

abstract: The eighty-sixth anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in Jersey City in a manner becoming the occasion. The day was ushered in with the ringing of bells and the firing of a salute of thirty-four guns from the foot of York-street.
lead_paragraph: The eighty-sixth anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in Jersey City in a manner becoming the occasion. The day was ushered in with the ringing of bells and the firing of a salute of thirty-four guns from the foot of York-street. At 11 o'clock public exercises were held, under the auspices of the Common Council, in the First Presbyterian Church, corner of Washington and Sussex streets. A highly patriotic and eloquent oration was delivered by CHARLES H. WINFIELD, Esq., and the Declaration of Independence read by Mr. GEORGE H. LINSLEY. A prayer was offered by Rev. C.K. IMBRIE, and National hymns sung by a large and efficient choir, under the direction of Mr. SAMUEL D. MAYER. The interior of the edifice was handsomely decorated with American flags. A large and enthusiastic audience was present.

abstract: The sufficient muster of militia regiments were on hand to make quite a creditable, if not imposing, military display; and when it was reflected that the comparative paucity of numbers which paraded was caused by the rush of our best drilled and favorite corps such as the Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Twelfth, Second, Eleventh, Seventy-first, Seventy-ninth, Sixtyninth, Twenty-second, Thirty-seventh and Fifty-fifth.
lead_paragraph: The sufficient muster of militia regiments were on hand to make quite a creditable, if not imposing, military display; and when it was reflected that the comparative paucity of numbers which paraded was caused by the rush of our best drilled and favorite corps -- such as the Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Twelfth, Second, Eleventh, Seventy-first, Seventy-ninth, Sixtyninth, Twenty-second, Thirty-seventh and Fifty-fifth -- to defend the honor of their flag and the Union in actual or prospective conflict with the rebels, a fueling of pride rather than regret filled every breast -- pride at the knowledge that New-York could rely on some of the best and bravest of her sons in the hour of trial and danger to the country.

lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- During the week ending yesterday there were 97 deaths in this city -- males, 42; females, 55 -- from the following causes: Dropsy, suicide, burns, erysipelas, measles, disease of the liver, intemperance, casualty, premature birth, typhus fever, disease of the heart, inanition, cyanosis, diphtheria, epilepsy, dysentery, drowned, puerperal fever, nervous fever and scalded -- one each; unknown, bronchitis, whooping cough, paralysis, apoplexy, inflammation of the brain and disease of the kidneys -- two each; hydrocephalus, scarlet fever, diarrhea, inflammation of the bowels and croup -- three each; marasmus -- four; congestion of the brain and inflammation of the lungs -- five each; convulsions -- six; cholera infantum and debility -- seven each; still-born -- five. Fifty-four of the ninety-seven who died were five years old and under.

abstract: Were we to suppose an intelligent mandarin and a cultivated Brahmin to visit Europe at the present time, and to correct their previous ideas of American institutions and character by the light of leading French and English newspapers, the impressions they would receive would be whimsically different from those we have been accustomed to entertain, and to teach to our children.
lead_paragraph: Were we to suppose an intelligent mandarin and a cultivated Brahmin to visit Europe at the present time, and to correct their previous ideas of American institutions and character by the light of leading French and English newspapers, the impressions they would receive would be whimsically different from those we have been accustomed to entertain, and to teach to our children. They would discover that our Government, founded in wrong, and adroitly adjusted so as to produce the largest amount of misery and suffering to the greatest number of people, outstripped in tyranny and wickedness any that even their own extensive experience could parallel. They would learn that a few artful persons by conspiring to keep the price of labor very low as compared to fortunate Europe, had contrived to divert the bulk of the earnings of the masses to their own overflowing coffers. They would realize how, by dint of heavy taxes, large standing armies, an expensive system of Government, a vast array of aristocratic sinecures, and a stupendous scheme of imposts to meet the luxurious demands of political drones, we had ingeniously managed to evade that first principle of an enlightened Government which aims to dispense the greatest happiness to the greatest possible number. To them WASHINGTON would appear as a mercenary adventurer, FRANKLIN a scientific charlatan, and ABRAHAM LINCOLN a designing monster of unheard-of and atrocious wickedness. They would understand, furthermore, by what entirely magnanimous and generous motives English and French leaders of opinion are actuated in their treatment of the "American question." They would see how truly anxious those leaders are for the happiness and prosperity of the United Republic; and would become convinced that the warmest desire of their hearts is to see the civil war ended by a happy reunion of all the States under the old Stars and Stripes. It would become evident to our Oriental friends that nothing would be so supremely disgusting to NAPOLEON or PALMERSTON as to see two weak Anglo-Saxon nations on this continent exhausting each other by chronic warfare, and either of which France or England could bully at pleasure, rather than one powerful Commonwealth, fast getting into a position to keep both in order.

abstract: The students or scholars as they may be more properly termed, attached to the Cooper Institute held their anniversary meeting yesterday evening, which was attended by a large number of interested and delighted friends.
lead_paragraph: The students or scholars as they may be more properly termed, attached to the Cooper Institute held their anniversary meeting yesterday evening, which was attended by a large number of interested and delighted friends. It was nominally called a meeting of the "Cooper Union Debating Society," but in reality a social gathering of the scholars and their friends. The exercises, for which we have space for but brief notice, were opened by an address from G.T. CHAPMAN, the President, which was followed by the reading of the Declaration of Independence, by J. abstract: The news of the last week will be memorable forever in the minds of the people and in the annals of the country. It has been a scarlet record a record of blood and disaster, and finally of hope, on the Peninsula; a record of the most intense anxiety, of tears and bereavement, here and throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: The news of the last week will be memorable forever in the minds of the people and in the annals of the country. It has been a scarlet record a record of blood and disaster, and finally of hope, on the Peninsula; a record of the most intense anxiety, of tears and bereavement, here and throughout the country. Last Sunday we had not the slightest glimpse of the dread doings of the combatants on the Chickahominy during the previous three days -- not a word of the battle and retreat of Thursday -- not a hint of the gory tragedy of Friday -- no news of the movements of our gallant but decimated army on Saturday. The people went to church, and kept holiday as usual. The black curtain was unlifted. Many wives even then were widows, and they knew it not; many brave fellows, of whom their friends were proudly speaking, or looking joyfully forward to the day of their homeward return crowned with victorious laurels, were already sleeping their last sleep, unshrouded, by the marshy banks of the Chickahominy, or, wounded and maimed, were prisoners in the hands of the Southern rebels. But of all this New-York last Sunday knew nothing; of it all, these wives, brothers, children and friends were as ignorant as though it had not been.

abstract: The Senate was in session about half an hour on Friday, but did no business of importance. In the Senate yesterday, a resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for the reports of Col. CANBY, relative to operations in New-Mexico, was adopted.
lead_paragraph: The Senate was in session about half an hour on Friday, but did no business of importance. In the Senate yesterday, a resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for the reports of Col. CANBY, relative to operations in New-Mexico, was adopted. The bill to abolish certain posts of delivery in the Mississippi Valley was passed. A bill for the collection of the revenue on the Northern, Northeastern and Northwestern frontiers was passed. The bill making appropriation for the payment of certain bounties was passed. The other business done was principally of local interest.

abstract: NYC and elsewhere
snippet: NYC and elsewhere
lead_paragraph: The Eighty-sixth Anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in this City and vicinity on Friday, in the usual manner, and with more than the usual significance. The military display was, of course less ample than in former years, but the people were satisfied to let that portion of the programme come off in presence of the enemies of the country. The other demonstrations were in no way inferior to those of past years, but were entered into with a patriotic spirit and a meaning such as has not been felt since the revolution. Below will be found a full account of the doings of the day in this City, in Brooklyn, in Newark, in Bridgeport, Conn., and other places.

abstract: While the grand drama now enacting in the United States still arrests the attention of Christendom, another is rising to the grandeur of a spectacle worthy of the world's deepest interest. Subsidiary, but scarcely secondary to the struggle in progress on the soil of our country, is the ullentat of monarchical intervention on the soil of our neighbor Mexico.
lead_paragraph: While the grand drama now enacting in the United States still arrests the attention of Christendom, another is rising to the grandeur of a spectacle worthy of the world's deepest interest. Subsidiary, but scarcely secondary to the struggle in progress on the soil of our country, is the ullentat of monarchical intervention on the soil of our neighbor -- Mexico. One brief year which has seen this Union of Republican States plunged into the depth of danger, and reviving in remarkable strength, has, also, seen the fleets and armies of a most powerful monarchical coalition hurled against the breast of a weak and distracted American Republic, to be there dashed to pieces, first, by dissension, and then by positive military defeat. Who does not remember the pomp and circumstance with which the flotilla of Spain, bearing her choicest legions, led by her most distinguished General, sailed from the port of Havana, a few months ago, for Vera Cruz? The Cuban papers swelled to bursting with the pompous announcements that heralded the departure of Her Catholic Majesty's forces, and the turgid predictions of what they were to achieve.

abstract: The United States vs. 1,406 Boxes of Sugar marked L.V.H. & Co. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the sugar for alleged violation of the revenue laws, The sugar was shipped in Havana by Sama Sotolongo & Co., consigned to L. Van Horn & Co., by the ship Kerelan, and arrived here Dec. 23, 1861. In the invoice all the sugars except 14 boxes were described as Quebrado sugars. The 14 boxes were described as Cucuruchos. Van Horn & Co., the claimants, entered the sugars, using this invoice; and in the entry they described all the sugars as raw sugars, and paid duty thereon at the rate of two cents a pound. By the then existing tariff of Aug. 5, 1861, sec. 1, a duty was imposed "On raw sugar, commonly called Muscovado or brown sugars, and on sugars not advanced above No. 12 Dutch standard by claying, boiling, clarifying or other processes, two cents a pound; and on white and clayed sugar, when advanced beyond the raw state above No. 12 Dutch standard by clarifying or other processes, and not yet refined, 2 1/2 cents a pound."
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 1,406 Boxes of Sugar marked L.V.H. & Co. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the sugar for alleged violation of the revenue laws, The sugar was shipped in Havana by Sama Sotolongo & Co., consigned to L. Van Horn & Co., the claimants, entered the sugars, using this invoice; and in the entry they described all the sugars as raw sugars, and paid duty thereon at the rate of two cents a pound. By the then existing tariff of Aug. 5, 1861, sec. 1, a duty was imposed "On raw sugar, commonly called Muscovado or brown sugars, and on sugars not advanced above No. 12 Dutch standard by claying, boiling, clarifying or other processes, two cents a pound; and on white and clayed sugar, when advanced beyond the raw state above No. 12 Dutch standard by clarifying or other processes, and not yet refined, 2 1/2 cents a pound."

abstract: Editorial urges reform in military medical staff with call for more troops
snippet: Editorial urges reform in military medical staff with call for more troops
lead_paragraph: Now that the President has called for three hundred thousand more troops, of which NewYork will be expected to furnish, probably, about fifty thousand, it is to be hoped that some little care will be bestowed upon furnishing decent medical attendance for the sick and wounded. It is notorious that our brave fellows in the field have, since the commencement of the war, suffered severely for want of medical officers enough to care for them properly, and from the utter incompetency, in many cases, of the persons appointed as Surgeons and Assistant Surgeons in the different regiments. If the facts in the case could all be made known, the public mind would be shocked beyond measure at the state of things which has existed and still exists. Quacks of all sorts, apothecary's boys, and even barbers and others, wholly destitute of professional knowledge, actually hold the posts of Surgeons and Assistant Surgeons to regiments, and even of Medical Directors of brigades. How many deaths and useless mutilations have occurred in consequence, it would be difficult to estimate; but that the number is large, admits of no doubt.

abstract: The truly brave are always good. We are glad to record an instance of kindness which has just come to our knowledge. Among those who adorned the society of the South was Miss. VICTOR, Principal of St. Marry's Female Academy at Baton Rouge, La. She is a Northern-born lady, of excellent standing as a...
lead_paragraph: The truly brave are always good. We are glad to record an instance of kindness which has just come to our knowledge. Among those who adorned the society of the South was Miss. VICTOR, Principal of St. Marry's Female Academy at Baton Rouge, La. She is a Northern-born lady, of excellent standing as a teacher, and before secession madness rendered the Southern people oblivious to generous impulses, was a courted member of society. The lady was true to her Northern birth, and, of course, received the favors of old friends and the hate of those irresponsible creatures in the South whose malice was only exceeded by their ignorance. Enough to say, the lady suffered so much at the hands of the Secessionists, that she welcomed the advent of Commodore FARRAGUT's fleet.

abstract: The National Anniversary was celebrated in this city, on Friday, in about the usual manner. The city authorities being limited to $1,000, of course their demonstration is never a very extensive one. On this, as on former occasions of the kind, it was limited to the firing of salutes, morning, noon and night; the...
lead_paragraph: The National Anniversary was celebrated in this city, on Friday, in about the usual manner. The city authorities being limited to $1,000, of course their demonstration is never a very extensive one. On this, as on former occasions of the kind, it was limited to the firing of salutes, morning, noon and night; the ringing of the bells for half an hour at three different times, and a meagre display of fireworks on Fort Green, in the Western District, and at the Union Base Ball grounds in the Eastern District. The vast multitude of men, women and children who assembled on Fort Greene in the evening was the feature of the day, and that which elicited the most attention and comment. The formation of the ground -- rising gradually, as it does, from the Canton-street plateau to the highest point of land in the Park -- is peculiarly adapted to set off an assemblage of people to the best advantage; and when occupied, as it was on Friday evening, by not less than 50,000 persons, representing all nationalities, every class of the population, the old, middle-aged and the young, standing at the lower end of the plateau, where the eye could take in the whole at one sweep, the view presented was magnificent, one long to be remembered and one worth traveling a long distance to see. This mass of people came upon the ground, remained for nearly two hours and then dispersed, without any disturbance or unruly conduct, whatever. There was also a very large and orderly gathering at the exhibition of fireworks, by the authorities, in the Eastern District. A band of music was stationed at each place, and at intervals popular and patriotic airs were performed. The only military parades were independent companies and those composed of juveniles.

lead_paragraph: The commemoration of the Fourth at Bridgeport was conducted with unusual spirit and success. The morning was ushered in by the ringing of the church bells and artillery salutes, and at 10 A.M., the streets were thronged with immense crowds, gathered from far and near, to witness the visit of Gov. BUCKINGHAM and his Staff, and the fine procession of military, firemen, civic societies, etc., which, at that hour, began to march through the city. At 2 P.M., the procession halted in front of the Courthouse, where a prayer was offered up and the Declaration of Independence read.

abstract: -- Col. Albert Magilton, of the Fourth Pennsylvania Reserve Regiment, who was among the killed in the battle at Mechanicsville, was a native of Philadelphia. He was educated in the Ringgold Grammar School, Moyamensing, entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1842, and on his graduation in 1846 was breveted a Second Lieutenant in the Fourth Artillery. In this capacity he served in the Mexican war with such distinguished gallantry that he won the brevet of First Lieutenant for bravery at Contreras and Cherubusco. Subsequently to the Mexican war he saw long and arduous service in the Indian country, which wearisome and unprofitable duty becoming monotonous, he resigned his commission and returned to Philadelphia to reside in 1857. Here the civil war found him in 1861, and he was elected Lieutenant-Colonel of the Fourth Reserve Regiment, (Thirty-third Pennsylvania Infantry,) of which regiment he became Colonel, upon the resignation of Col. William B. Mann, Col. Magilton had done much to bring his regiment into an efficient condition, and was esteemed as an accomplished and skillful soldier. His loss will be severely felt.
lead_paragraph: -- Col. Albert Magilton, of the Fourth Pennsylvania Reserve Regiment, who was among the killed in the battle at Mechanicsville, was a native of Philadelphia. He was educated in the Ringgold Grammar School, Moyamensing, entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1842, and on his graduation in 1846 was breveted a Second Lieutenant in the Fourth Artillery. Here the civil war found him in 1861, and he was elected Lieutenant-Colonel of the Fourth Reserve Regiment, (Thirty-third Pennsylvania Infantry,) of which regiment he became Colonel, upon the resignation of Col. abstract: Henry M. Prowett vs. Washington Rodman, et al. This was an action to determine the heirship to certain real estate, under a devise from Thomas Mackaness.
lead_paragraph: Henry M. Prowett vs. Washington Rodman, et al. -- This was an action to determine the heirship to certain real estate, under a devise from Thomas Mackaness. The testator died in 1807, leaving three daughters -- Elizabeth, then Mrs. Harvey; Mary, then Mrs. Prowett, and Margaret, afterward Mrs. Ludlow. Elizabeth died, leaving two children -- Mary, afterward Mrs. Rodman, and one of the defendants in this action, and Thomas M. Harvey. Mary Mackaness outlived all her children, and died in 1837, leaving grandchildren. Margaret died, leaving one child -- Elizabeth Christie, one of the defendants. By the second article of this will, the testator devised in trust to his daughter Mary certain real estate situate in Barclay-street, in this City. In the same article are also these words: "And in case my daughter, Mary Prowett, shall leave a child living at the time of her death, then I give and devise in trust, for her use and benefit during her natural life, and to her child or children after her decease; to my daughter Elizabeth Harvey, and my daughter Margaret Thornton Mackaness, their heirs and assigns forever, in equal parts to be divided." One of the defendants, as heir of Mary Rodman, claims one-half of the estate, as the sole surviving child of Elizabeth Harvey; and Elizabeth Christie claims the other half, as the sole surviving child of the testator's daughter Margaret.

lead_paragraph: SIR: "Long looked for come at last; "you are not any less welcome because of your delay. Hope you will be pleased with these parts; but no doubt you will be more hospitably received down in Georgia; so come along. I did say, a month ago, that you would never take the Gap, and that I would sign any papers you might "fetch along." I meant, of course, while we were here, and you must excuse me for leaving before your arrival. Please have published in all the Northern journals that we were most completely routed; that you killed 5,000 and wounded 25,000 of our brigade, besides capturing all our army, ammunition, knapsacks, blankets, camp and garrison equipage, besides over 50 pieces of artillery, and all the wagon trains. Do, if you please, and you will only be saving what we know to be false -- that's all. But, my dear General, it is hard, I admit, to leave this most defensive for such a cowardly army to occupy.

abstract: The display of fireworks in the evening exceeded in taste and magnificence any exhibition within the memory of the "oldest inhabitant" of Manhattan Island. The TIMES has already published a complete list of the pieces which were to be exhibited, and to repeat them now would occupy more space than can be well afforded.
lead_paragraph: The display of fireworks in the evening exceeded in taste and magnificence any exhibition within the memory of the "oldest inhabitant" of Manhattan Island. The TIMES has already published a complete list of the pieces which were to be exhibited, and to repeat them now would occupy more space than can be well afforded. At the City Hall the display was really worth the attendance of the tens of thousands assembled to witness it. A fine band of music was on duty, as at every other place where fireworks were exhibited, and kept down the impatience of the thousands who had come to see only the fireworks. The entire exhibition proved the correctness of the Committee's judgment in awarding to Messrs. EDGE the duty and honor of preparing them. Having already published a list of the pieces intended to be presented, it is only necessary now to say that the entire programme was carried out to the letter, and to note those which received the most popular applause. All of the pieces were really magnificent, but those which elicited the greatest applause were the engagement between the Monitor and Merrimac, and the closing piece, a temple of Liberty, with Gen. MCCLELLAN as the centre piece, which was really a chef d'oeuvre of pyrotechnic art. At all the other places named by the Committee who had this special matter in charge, the programme was carried out to the intense delight of thousands.

abstract: The young Randall's Islanders were duly impressed with the importance of the occasion by a cheering visit from the Commissioners, a speech by Mr. DRAPEB, a rousing feast at noon, and a brilliant display of fireworks at night. Older characters were entertained as well, and the neat little steamer Bellevue made a pleasure trip to Fort Schuyler, bearing upon her gaily-trimmed decks a group of officials attached to the various Institutions. The matrons found it a real treat, and it was more than a mere relaxation to many a trusty keeper.

abstract: That most humanely governed institution, under the guardianship of Dr. RANNEY, was also the scene of cheerfulness, though of a more subdued character than might obtain elsewhere, inasmuch as the minds here brought for healing care are not benefited by any exciting surroundings, therefore fireworks were tabooed, and music, soothing to the soul, together with...
lead_paragraph: That most humanely governed institution, under the guardianship of Dr. RANNEY, was also the scene of cheerfulness, though of a more subdued character than might obtain elsewhere, inasmuch as the minds here brought for healing care are not benefited by any exciting surroundings, therefore fireworks were tabooed, and music, soothing to the soul, together with speechifying upon the spirit of the occasion by the inmates, took their place. Dr. RANNEY, also, made a few remarks calculated to do good where any impression would find a place. At the various correctional institutions, the prisoners were allowed every privilege consistent with their positions.

abstract: The Society of Tammany, or "Columbian order," celebrated the day in accordance with the ancient custom and with the undiminished zeal and patriotic fervor of former years. lead_paragraph: The Society of Tammany, or "Columbian order," celebrated the day in accordance with the ancient custom and with the undiminished zeal and patriotic fervor of former years. Early in the day the sachems, warriors and chiefs, began to gather around the old wigwam, and by 12 o'clock, the time fixed for throwing open the doors of the council chamber, a sufficient number had collected to occupy all the seats and fill the available standing places in the large hall. The chamber was appropriately decked for the occasion, with the flags of all nations, and the portraits and busts of departed statesmen, both Democratic and Whig, adorned its walls. The Sicilian Band discoursed inspiring music from the balcony and thus whiled away the time until 1 o'clock, the hour for commencing the ceremonies, when Grand Sachem NELSON J. WATERBURY ascended the platform, followed by other Sachems and warriors, among whom we noticed the old war-horse, Supervisor PURDY; Judge DALY, the orator of the day; AUGUSTE BELMONT, ANDREW J. GREENE, Judge HILTON, RICHARD B. CONNOLLY, Alderman BOOLE, and others, besides many who are not known as thorough-bred warriors, such as JAS. BROOKS, and Her Majesty's late counsel. EDWIN JAMES, Esq. Judge MCCUNN, though one of the Committee of Arrangements, and Vice-President of the Order, did not take a seat upon the stand, but occupied a bench in the back part of the audience, where he remained throughout the entire ceremonies, immersed in VICTOR HUGO's fascinating novel, Les Miserables.

abstract: Editorial on need for better NY-Washington, DC, system
snippet: Editorial on need for better NY-Washington, DC, system
lead_paragraph: There is a popular outcry for better railroad facilities and a rate of forty or fifty miles an hour, between New-York and Washington. That every person, package and letter transported between the metropolis and the capital of America, should, in this steam-propelled age, be dragged for two hours round the streets of Philadelphia and Baltimore by horses, and boated across bridged rivers, when the express trains between London and Edinburgh, for instance, accomplish the journey of 400 miles in ten hours, is quite incompatible with the spirit and intentions of the people. Whereupon Congress is called upon to remedy the evil by legislation, and a score of schemes are urged -- schemes diverse enough in engineering demerit, certainly, but irregularly alike, in that they are all based upon pecuniary aid from the Government, and that they all propose to furnish a higher speed and cheaper fares, with a loss cost for road and equipment, than any present lines. Now, any suggestion other than to heap obstacles and punishment upon the local monopoly, has invariably been denounced as sympathy in its behalf; but this treatment has never remedied its abuses, and never will. It is simply kicking against the goads. Accommodation is what the public want, and, until they take comprehensive views of the case and act upon them coolly, with nothing but their great want in view, they will only make matters worse.

abstract: Craneville, N.J., on Friday, presented a scene which would have done credit to the olden times of '76. A beautiful orchard was selected for the grand exercises of the occasion, where a stand for the orator and seats for the vast assemblage were tastefully and conveniently arranged. The Declaration of Independence was read by NATHANIEL WILLIAMS, Esq., after which the orator of the day, Dr. W.E. BLAKENEY, delivered an eloquent and impressive oration. J.S. FERRIS, Esq., Marshal, and S. CAHILL, Esq., Chairman Committee of Arrangements, did themselves great credit in the performance of their duties.

abstract: AN ALLEGED MURDER IN GOERCK-STREET. -- A man named PATRICK MCGINNIS, whose residence was at No. 73 Goerck-street, was severely injured at a late hour on Friday night. He was immediately taken by the Thirteenth Precinct Police to Bellevue Hospital, where he died yesterday. At the time the injured man was found by the Police Officers, it was supposed that he had received his injuries by reason of having fallen against an iron railing, and one person who pretended that he saw the accident, so informed the Police. The case was, therefore, reported as a case of accident. Soon, after the man died, however, three parties appeared at the Station-house of the Thirteenth Precinct, and stated that they were ready to testify that the case was one of murder. They said they saw the party who inflicted the wounds; that the injuries were produced by repeated blows upon the unfortunate's man's head with a cane. A post-mortem examination developed the fact that there were two severe wounds upon each side of the head, near the crown, and that the skull was fractured in several places. Late yesterday afternoon, Coroner COLLIN proceeded to the Dead-house of Bellevue Hospital, for the purpose of holding an inquest upon the body, but up to a late hour last evening no report of it was received, and the presumption is that the investigation was adjourned, in order to obtain further testimony.

abstract: The exercises at this pleasant little place were commenced at sunrise by the ringing of bells and the firing of national salutes at different points in the city. At 7 o'clock the Fire Department and Military, comprising the First Regiment National Guard and the Putnam Horse Guard, formed on Park Place, the right resting on Centre-street. Maj.-Gen. RUNYON...
lead_paragraph: The exercises at this pleasant little place were commenced at sunrise by the ringing of bells and the firing of national salutes at different points in the city. At 7 o'clock the Fire Department and Military, comprising the First Regiment National Guard and the Putnam Horse Guard, formed on Park Place, the right resting on Centre-street. Maj.-Gen. RUNYON acted as Grand Marshal, assisted by a number of Aids. The procession moved at about 7 1/2 o'clock, marching through Park-place to Broad-street, up Broad to State, thence into Washington, down Washington to Spruce, through Spruce to Broad, up Broad to Kinney, from Kinney into Mulberry, up Mulberry to Market, up Market to Broad, down Broad to the Methodist Episcopal Church, where a crowd had collected awaiting its arrival. The military appeared to decided advantage -- the glittering helmets of the cavalry, who headed the parade, glancing in the bright sunlight, and the polished muskets of the infantry flashing as they passed through the pleasant shady streets. Many of the windows on the route were filled with ladies, who welcomed the soldiers with waving of hands and handkerchiefs. Between 9 1/2 and 10 o'clock the procession halted before the church. After a short delay, during which the soldiers displayed their efficiency in the manual of arms, the doors were thrown open to the public, and the building was quickly filled. The decorations of the house were exceedingly simple, two Union flags being crossed above the pulpit -- only these. While the audience were being seated the band played a March, which was well executed. An earnest prayer was made by Rev. J.P. Wilson, D.D., after which the choir sang "Hail Festal Day." The Declaration of Independence was next read by Mr. W.R. HOWELL, when the choir again sang, this time "The Ship of State," which was received with enthusiasm. Hon. JAS. BROOKS was then introduced as the orator of the day. Mr. BROOKS regretted not being more thoroughly prepared -- the present serious aspect of affairs had so preyed upon his mind that he felt almost indisposed, and incapable of the task before him. Our country, he said, had been cradled in adversity. From a glance at its earlier history, the speaker turned to a more lengthy consideration of the period following the Declaration of Independence, and to subsequent events in its annals, whereby, for a time, the continuance of the Union seemed endangered; not forgetting to indulge in a sneering remark relative to the old "Bay State," and similar in style to many of those which formed the staple of his speech at the "Cooper Institute" in this City, a few nights ago, wherein he aimed the barbed arrows of his hate at all New-England. It is but justice to the people of Newark to say that the slur was not appreciated. Whatever may be the opinion of some, Mr. BROOKS declared it to be his, that the South are without cause in this quarrel, and utterly undeserving of sympathy. Rebellion must be met with a bold front. Before determined resistance it would succumb; and by the time another Anniversary of this, the National Sabbath of our land, he devoutly honed to see these thirty millions of Americans once more a united and happy people.

abstract: There are certain axioms constantly uttered about particular peoples and their internal affairs which intelligent persons about as constantly doubt or disbelieve.
lead_paragraph: There are certain axioms constantly uttered about particular peoples and their internal affairs which intelligent persons about as constantly doubt or disbelieve. A foreign observer is necessarily ignorant of every nation but his own; and even of their own people, how few can ever give us unbiased and well-considered judgments. Doubtless when educated Frenchmen hear of the tendency toward royalty or despotism in this country, they receive the dogma with as much faith as we do the accounts of revolutionary movements in France, or of the popular hatred, still supposed to exist there toward England, or of the sentimental friendship for America. We read here continually such utterly false and crude theories and statements of fact, made by European critics and observers, in regard to this country, that we have become rather skeptical as to similar statements, made with such confidence about foreign countries. It is accordingly an incredible relief to obtain, at length, a trustworthy witness with reference to the internal condition of a European Power. Above all do we value his testimony now, when the necessities and the interior affairs of our country are to determine the future relations of the North American Continent with the world.

abstract: are not very lucid. The first dispatch from the Southwest announced with Caesarian brevity, that "Vicksburgh is ours;" but the subsequent dispatches of Saturday, dated at Cairo, though in many more words, did not tend to confirm the literal correctness of the first report. They spoke of the town having suffered greatly from the bombardment which had been opened upon it by Commodore FARRAGUT, and further announced that "seven hundred more shells had been ordered from New-Orleans to reduce the place to ashes." The dispatch also stated that Gen. BUTLER had ordered five thousand negroes to go to work and change the channel of the Mississippi River at Vicksburgh, that so the contumacious place might be transformed into an inland town. It may be that all these statements are correct, though how BUTLER communicated his orders to the bombarding fleet does not appear; and whether it would have been necessary to have done all these things if the place was ours, is quite problematical. Altogether, the chances at present seem to be that Vicksburgh is not yet literally ours.

abstract: AN OUTRAGEOUS THEFT A WOUNDER SOLDIER ROBBED OF OVER $300. A boy named THOMAS SAVAGE, aged 16 years, who says he is a butcher by occupation, was brought before Justice BRENNAN at the
lead_paragraph: AN OUTRAGEOUS THEFT -- A WOUNDER SOLDIER ROBBED OF OVER $300. -- A boy named THOMAS SAVAGE, aged 16 years, who says he is a butcher by occupation, was brought before Justice BRENNAN at the Tombs, yesterday, upon the charge of having robbed a wounded soldier of all the money he had, which was the sum of $307. The soldier's name is JACOB BERGMAN. He arrived in this City on Saturday, direct from the army of the Potomac, where he was engaged in the six successive battles recently fought in front of Richmond, and on the banks of the Chickahuminy and James rivers. In the last action he was so seriously wounded that it was thought advisable to send him home. Before leaving, however, he obtained from the proper officer a discharge, which states, among other things, that he has served bravely, and with credit to himself, in MCCLELLAN's army for the last ten months. All arrearages of pay were received by him in the shape of three $100 Treasury notes and a few notes of a smaller amount. Upon the arrival in[???] at a public [???] morning, while [???] fellow-boarders asked for the [???], and while he was feeling in his [???] for this article, he accidentally let fall his pocketbook, which contained his hard earnings. He did not notice it at the time but about half an hour after he discovered the loss and gave an alarm. The doors of the house were immediately closed, to prevent any one from escaping, and it was proposed that a search should be instituted. As soon as a proposition for a general search was made, young SAVAGE was the first to accede to it, and his apparent anxiety to have a general overhauling of all pockets completely deceived those who might otherwise have had some suspicion that he was the guilty party. In the meantime, some person had kindly volunteered to obtain the services of Capt. PETTY, of the Fifth Precinct, and he was soon in attendance. Under his directions all the persons in the room were carefully and thoroughly searched, but no clue to the missing money could be obtained, until the last one of the party had been examined. On account of the active part which SAVAGE had taken in the affair, and the great anxiety which he manifested in the recovery of the money no suspicions were entertained that he could be the guilty man, and he was, therefore, left to be examined last. An examination of one of his boots revealed the three $100 Treasury notes, and under the canvass lining in the lower part of one leg of his pantaloons there were found the other $7 in small bills. The pocket-book he had managed by some means to throw into a neighboring vault. Justice BRENNAN committed the accused for trial. Capt. PETTY and his men were very active and energetic in their efforts to recover the money, and to bring the offender to justice.

abstract: Editorial urges harmony among radicals and conservatives during crisis
snippet: Editorial urges harmony among radicals and conservatives during crisis
lead_paragraph: Up to the present moment, this great Republic has been fighting the rebellion of the Southern States with not a moiety of its strength, and with divided counsels. Not because the loyal people do not feel patriotic -- not because they are indifferent to the result of the contest -- not because they do not earnestly desire the restoration of the Union and a return to the blessings of peace. All these sentiments are fervently entertained by the loyal millions of the nation. But what our people do lack is a just appreciation of the magnitude of the work before them, and of the absolute necessity of entire harmony, and of the quick, active and resolute cooperation of all classes in the support of the war.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN'S Address to his soldiers, published in the Times this morning, does not read like the bulletin of a defeated General.
lead_paragraph: Gen. MCCLELLAN's Address to his soldiers, published in the Times this morning, does not read like the bulletin of a defeated General. On the contrary, he congratulates his men on the fact that they have executed a successful movement in the face of the enemy; and that they have saved all their material, all their trains, and all their guns except a few lost in battle -- taking in return guns and colors from the enemy. He further announces that he is now fully prepared for the enemy, who will find, when they again attack him, that their repulse will be converted into a final defeat. Richmond, he says, shall be entered by the "Army of the Potomac."

abstract: At a meeting held in the Baptist Church, Owego, Tioga County, N.Y., July 4, 1862 the following Committee was named by the Ministers of the Gospel present, to act with the Sanitary Commission of...
lead_paragraph: At a meeting held in the Baptist Church, Owego, Tioga County, N.Y., July 4, 1862 the following Committee was named by the Ministers of the Gospel present, to act with the Sanitary Commission of New-York City, viz.: Hon. John M. Parker, Hon. H.L. Bean, Wm. P. Stone, F.E. Platt, F.L. Jones, Geo. Truman, F.H. Pumpelly, Hon. Thomas Farrington, Jas. S. Thurston, Sylvanus Fox, Thos. C. Platt, C.A. Winthrop, W.L. Hoskins, Wm. Smyth. In addition to the above, the clergymen and physicians of the village are ex-officio members of the Committee. The Committee having met at the office of Judge FARRINGTON, on the afternoon of the same day, organized by electing Hon. JOHN M. PARKER Chairman, WM. SMITH Recording Secretary, and JANES S. THURSTON Corresponding Secretary. The purposes intended by the formation of this Committee were informally discussed for a short time, when Hon. H.L. BEAN, President of the village, moved the following resolution, which was adopted:

abstract: The United States sailing frigate Sabine, 50 guns, left the Brooklyn Navy-yard on Saturday for Newport, and other places, to fill up her crew. She has been in commission for some months, and was ordered to Fortress Monroe some time since, but her crew being wanted for steamers, she had to remain here. We have twice printed a list of her officers.

abstract: At the Tabernacle, last evening, Rev. Dr. THOMPSON delivered a sermon in favor of Emancipation. The passages of Scripture upon which the discourse was founded are the 22d chapter of Exodus, the 21st verse: "Thou shalt neither vex a stranger nor oppress him; for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt;" -- and Jeremiah, the 21st chapter and 12th verse: "O, house of David, thus saith the Lord: Execute judgment in the morning, and deliver him that is spoiled out of the hand of the oppressor, lest my fury go out like fire, and burn that none can quench it, because of the evil of your doings." The graphic account which Mr. THOMPSON gave of his recent visit to the Shenandoah Valley, cannot be reproduced save by himself. It is gratifying to learn from so high a source of the enthusiasm of our troops in the cause in which they are enlisted, and that frightful wounds, and even the near approach of death, cannot stem the ardor of the brave fellows. "And when such men suffer, shall I be silent!?" asked the minister of his hearers. Mr. THOMPSON spoke with fervor, and did not forget to pay his respects to the meeting held last week at the Cooper Institute. He was glad to know that Mr. COOPER had not countenanced it, and hoped that he would fumigate his basement. We can deal with traitors in Virginia, said he, but not with these in our midst. A graceful tribute was paid to the energy and wisdom of President LINCOLN, and the sermon closed with a glowing picture of the happiness and prosperity which awaits our country when the war shall have annihilated Slavery.

abstract: A notice in the NEW-YORK TIMES and other daily papers having attracted my attention, viz.: "Volunteer Watchers wanted at the Hospitals for Sick and Wounded Soldiers," I gave my name, and had the good fortune to attend at the Hospital corner of Sixth-avenue and Fifty-first-street last Sunday evening and night. My object in this communication is to call the attention of our young men to the importance of this work. Many of us, as is the case with myself, are unable to take part in the great struggle actively in the field; but one night a week in the hospitals is a very small sacrifice of personal comfort, and the satisfaction that will be experienced will amply reward the volunteer.
