abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to change the place of holding the U.S. Circuit Court for Western Tennessee, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to change the place of holding the U.S. Circuit Court for Western Tennessee, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee. A bill was also reported from the Judiciary Committee to amend the act to prohibit the Slave-trade, so as to authorize the President to make arrangements with foreign countries, and especially with Denmark, for the colonization of recaptured Africans. A bill to provide for the employment of persons of African descent in building intrenchments, and for other war purposes, was introduced from the Military Committee. A bill to provide another punishment for treason was introduced by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and referred to the Judiciary Committee. The resolution introduced several days ago, in relation to the quorum of the Senate, was laid on the table, after some debate. The Naval Grade bill was passed. The Post-route bill, providing for a bridge across the Ohio River at Steubenville, was passed. The bill introduced on Tuesday by Mr. WILSON, amendatory of the act of 1795, authorizing the President to call out Militia, &c., was taken up, and was debated at considerable length. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, offered an amendment, in effect authorizing the enrollment of colored persons in the service of the Government. Mr. KING, of New-York, wished to amend by authorizing the employment of colored persons only in building intrenchments, &c., and declaring such persons so employed free. Objections were advanced by Messrs. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, CARLILE, of Virginia, and other Border-State men. The subject was not disposed of when the Senate went into Executive session.

abstract: THE KINGS COUNTY MEDICAL SOCIETY AND DR. REA, THE COLORED M.D. A meeting of the Kings County Medical Society was held on Tuesday evening, at the Brooklyn Institute, when, after the...
lead_paragraph: THE KINGS COUNTY MEDICAL SOCIETY AND DR. REA, THE COLORED M.D. -- A meeting of the Kings County Medical Society was held on Tuesday evening, at the Brooklyn Institute, when, after the transaction some preliminary business, the case of Dr. REA was called up for consideration. The facts of this case are about as follows: Dr. REA, a well known physician, having an extensive practice in the Eastern District, and said to be a highly educated and scientific man, applied to be admitted as a member of the Kings County Medical Society. The application was duly presented, and referred to the Committee of Censors, and that body reported in favor of admitting the applicant. Just as the vote was about being taken, a discovery was made that Dr. REA was only three-fourths white -- the other fourth being the same as the ancient Adam is supposed by many to have been -- black. Here was a dilemma. Some members were indignant, others opened their eyes in astonishment, while a few took the matter like philosophers and laughed. After one of the astonished members had recovered his consciousness, he moved to lay the matter upon the table. There it was laid, and the Society adjourned. The next meeting was held on Tuesday night, as we have said above, when something more than an hour was wasted on an effort to dodge the direct question before the Society -- to admit or reject the applicant. The majority, if not all of those present, would doubtless have voted against the applicant had the question been put to a vote; but they hesitated to do this, because they know that Dr. REA can compel them to admit him if he so elects. The subject, however, was discussed very dispassionately, and with a full consciousness of all the embarrassments surrounding it; yet there was apparently a general desire to get rid of direct action by showing that the application of Dr. REA was not legally before the Society. One member moved that a Committee be appointed to request Dr. REA to withdraw his application. This was at once declared to be impossible, because -- he is only three-fourths white. The motion was voted down. Another member alleged that the Committee of Censors had not been legally organized, and therefore Dr. REA's application was not legally before them. The censors did not know, but supposed they were organized properly. Another said the applicants named had not been filed at the County Clerk's office, as required by both a State law and a law of the Society, where physicians receive their diplomas from institutions outside of the State. The censors had never heard of this law before. An indignant member said that he could show by science that this was a white man's Society, and that no colored man could be admitted. After setting forth in eulogistic terms the position of the Society -- he said -- admitting a colored man would be to a certain extent amalgamation, and amalgamation had a tendency to deteriorate -- therefore, a colored man could not be admitted. The speaker apologized to the society for tendering his views -- being the youngest member and took his seat. The Society was not prepared to consider the scientific part of the question. A member said that Dr. REA could be rejected because he kept a drug-store and sold quack medicines. It was suggested that several members in good standing were guilty of just the same thing. The answer to this was that two wrongs cannot make a right; that if the laws had not heretofore been strictly enforced they should be now. A proposition was made to drop the subject, and take no further action until compelled to do so. This met with no favor. A motion to lay the whole matter on the table was lost; a motion to refer the whole subject back to the censors was also rejected, it was finally referred to a Committee of three, consisting of Drs. SMITH, NORTH and SCHAPPS -- to investigate and report as to the legal qualifications and status of Dr. REA, with a view to find some good reason for rejecting the applicant, other than the color of his skin. The sensitiveness of the public mind upon the negro question, was characteristically illustrated by one of the most learned and respected medical gentlemen present at the above meeting. He made the closing speech, reminding the members that this was a scientific Society, and therefore it was their duty not to let what transpired there "leak out" and get into the papers, as the public had nothing to do with their affairs.

abstract: editorial on campaign for Stanton removal; editorial on campaign for his removal
snippet: editorial on campaign for Stanton removal; editorial on campaign for his removal
lead_paragraph: A very fierce crusade has been opened upon Secretary STANTON. Journals of all sorts, those which have been most clamorous, as well as others which have been more serviceable, in support of the Government, demand his instant removal. Perhaps they will get it, and perhaps not. Much of their abuse passes over Mr. STANTON's head and lights on the President. Probably that is the intention of some among them, though we believe they do not propose to remove the President.

abstract: The papers of yesterday announced the death of Mr. EDWARD C. WEST, Surrogate of the City and County of New-York, a position to which he was elected three years since, beating ALEX. W. BRADFORD Esq., the then incumbent, and acknowledgement by general consent to be the ablest officer who ever held the position. Mr. WEST, who was yet in the prime of life, has been in ill health almost from the day of his accession to office, and about a year since he went to Europe in the hope of reestablishing his failing health. He did not succeed, as his decease in the very prime of life attests. Mr. WEST graduated from the office of FRANCES B. CUTTING Esq., and acquired a fair but not leading reputation, and it was a matter of surprise to the [???] at large how he succeeded in defeating Mr. BRADFORD. In politics he was a Tammany Democrat of the straitest sect, and owed his [???] to his friends in that party. In private life M. WEST was [???] and kind, and had won a large circle of friends, who will mourn his early death. In accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, his place will be filled by Hon. CHAS. P. DALY, First Judge of the County.

abstract: Editorial questions rumor that Butler is at work diverting Mississippi River at Vicksburg
snippet: Editorial questions rumor that Butler is at work diverting Mississippi River at Vicksburg
lead_paragraph: Gen. BUTLER, having straightened up things generally in New-Orleans, has, it seems, set to straightening the Mississippi River. It was ALPHONSO, of Castile, we believe, who thought he could have given Providence some useful hints, had he been consulted in the framing of things. Gen. BUTLER goes a step further, and is determined to improve what is done: so he starts by mending the crooked ways of the Father of Waters. The story, as it comes to us, is so odd an affair, that we hardly know whether to believe it or not; but it reports that a canal is being cut across the neck of land opposite Vicksburgh, which will take the Mississippi several miles out of its present route, and leave Vicksburgh an inland town. It is well known that directly opposite this point the Mississippi makes an easterly bend of fourteen miles, returns on itself, and leaves a narrow peninsula of about three-quarters of a mile in breadth. Across the neck of the peninsula it is that the canal is being cut. Several thousand negroes are reported to have been at work on it for some time, and when completed, as it is to be immediately, it is expected that the Mississippi will leave its present bed, and cut a wide channel during high water; while Vicksburgh, from being a river town, will wake up and find itself half a dozen miles off in the interior!

abstract: I have endured the hardships of hunger and unremitting fatigue for the past week, and with the exception of unstrung nerves, caused by loss of rest,...
lead_paragraph: I have endured the hardships of hunger and unremitting fatigue for the past week, and with the exception of unstrung nerves, caused by loss of rest, I am perfectly well. Last night I slept for the first time under a tent; before that I have caught a wink occasionally on the bare ground, without blanket or overcoat. We have fought every day, and marched every night. I have lost in killed and wounded in my brigade over eight hundred -- nearly one-third. I have but one Colonel left, two Lieutenant-Colonels, and two Majors. The Fifth Maine Regiment has not got a single field-officer left. My horse was wounded, but I am thankful to say I am uninjured. I led on Friday each one of my four regiments to the charge separately. Here is where all my field-officers were killed or wounded. We have a good position here, but expect a fight before night. Our men are heroes, and it would make your heart bleed with sympathy and pride to see them enduring such untold fatigue without food or rest and to see their light hearts and smiling faces, whenever I ride among them. The enemy have three men to our one, and yet our noble army are confident that we could beat them in an open field, although the enemy fight like devils, and with a hate that is unaccountable."

abstract: The Senate has taken refuge from the perplexities of confiscation in another Committee of Conference. The House bill is too peremptory and stringent for the views of the Senators; the Senate bill is too lenient and impracticable for the sense of the House. Neither body shows the slightest disposition to recede. The vote by which the Senate, on Tuesday, declined doing so, showed the Chamber to be two to one against concession. Evidently the best thing to do in the circumstances is to dismiss the subject altogether. The policy, however modified, is a doubtful one. The measure is vindictive rather than preventive, and so offends a prime element of the doctrine of punishments. And Government while itis known to have this unexercised power of confiscation in its hands, operates as effectually upon the tears of doubtful rebels as if the power were embodied in a statute. These plain considerations, added to the deficient time, and the apparently irreconcileable breach between the two branches of Congress, strongly suggest the wisdom of passing the business by. If the discussion must be had, the cool weather of the Winter session will serve better.

abstract: Thomas C. Cardivell vs. John J. Hicks. In this case the plaintiff had a demand against one Wirgman for about $250 money collected by Wirgman for him...
lead_paragraph: Thomas C. Cardivell vs. John J. Hicks. -- In this case the plaintiff had a demand against one Wirgman for about $250 money collected by Wirgman for him -- which he discharged, taking of Wirgman the defendant's note for $517 50, and paying to him (Wirgman) the balance of the note over and above enough to discharge the plaintiff's claim, in money, before maturity. The plaintiff sued upon the note, the defence being that there was fraud in the inception of the note, and the proof being that it was diverted from the use for which it was made.

abstract: Response in NY and elsewhere to new call for troops noted
snippet: Response in NY and elsewhere to new call for troops noted
lead_paragraph: The order on the subject of recruiting for the President's new requisition, issued yesterday from the office of the State Adjutant-General, does not appear to be received with that enthusiasm which, under the circumstances, is desirable. So far from enthusiasm indeed, its effect has been to create in the minds of those who were exerting themselves to raise fresh companies a feeling of deep dissatisfaction, not unmingled with bewilderment concerning its exact intent. With an appearance of explanatory minuteness, the order is in reality vague to a degree. Were this vagueness the mere blundering of literary incapacity, the mischief it is causing might be explained away and remedied; but there is a wide-spread impression that its composition is the result of purpose; that it is the germ of an astute scheme, whereby those who do all the work of enlistment and organization will eventually be thrust aside for the advancement of political pets.

abstract: -- With this attractive title, an association was some time since formed, the beneficient effects of whose workings is to accrue to the orphans of our patriots. A meeting of its members occurred last evening, in Room No. 20 Bible-house. Dr. JOSEPH RICHARDS presided. The report of the Committee on Organization was read by the Chairman. The Secretary, Dr. DAVID HOLTON, made some remarks explanatory of the plan of action desirable to be pursued at the present time, and a Constitution was presented, which will be adopted, and the election of officers ensued. Congress has just passed a bill granting lands for "Agricultural Colleges" in each State, and the Committee will establish in connection therewith "Experimental Farms," under the general patronage of the Government. What are denominated "Prize Positions" seem to be the feature of the Association, and such pupils as display talent are to be placed in proper spheres for its development. The idea of the name "Reward," was to prevent the appearance of pauperism attaching to the pupils, inasmuch as no such reality exists. The large number and influential character of those interested in the establishing of the several departments of the Institute, prove that it is in the hands of a class who deem it a privilege, and not an act of charity, to serve the orphans of our patriotic soldiers with education and honors, by the outlay of means, energy, and all the influence at their command.

abstract: The adjourned meeting of the grain merchants was held, yesterday, at the Produce Exchange. Mr. ALBURTIS, Chairman, called the assemblage to order,...
lead_paragraph: The adjourned meeting of the grain merchants was held, yesterday, at the Produce Exchange. Mr. ALBURTIS, Chairman, called the assemblage to order, and remarked that the object of this meeting was to hear the report of the Committee, appointed at the previous meeting, held on Tuesday. He hoped the Committee would immediately report. The Secretary, Mr. HERRICK, Jr., said he had received no written report. Mr. TOMPKINS, on behalf of the Committee, was repeatedly called for, but did not respond. The Chairman then said that probably the Committee had not completed its labors, nor prepared any report. He would like to know what the meeting desired to have done. Calls were made for Mr. BARBER, who promptly appeared and explained verball what progress the Committee had made. He said that the Committee, as such, had had no meetings, but some members of it, including himself, had attended the laborers' meeting at Tammany Hall, Tuesday night, and had endeavored to ascertain the actual grievances of the shovelers, and what they wanted to have done for them. He had spoken to the laborers in a conciliatory manner, and was very cordially received. He repeated the substance of his remarks on the occasion referred to, which have been already published in the TIMES. Mr. BARBER added that, as a merchant, he was sorry that the resolutions of Tuesday had been adopted by the merchants. There was really no necessity for taking such action. It was not all dignified nor wise for the merchants of New-York to do anything under the circumstances that had any appearance of defiance or intimidation. The laborers were acting in a most orderly and unobjectionable manner. As far as they were right, he was with them; but any opposition to the working of the elevators he considered decidedly wrong, and he had so stated to the meeting at Tammany Hall. He had been assured there that the men did not propose to prevent the working of the elevators, nor to interfere with any other laborers, who might be employed in connection with them. He believed that the laborers had real cause for complaint, and that they obgnt not to be treated in a hostile manner. He would say that he believed that the Committee of merchants appointed on Tuesday could speedily settle all difficulties, if they honestly and energetically set about doing so. The fact was, according to Mr. BARBER, the actual trouble was between the elevators and the stevedores, and that it was not properly the business of the merchants to have anything whatever to do with the quarrel. He ought as appropriately bring his private business troubles before a meeting of merchants. Such conduct, however, would be promptly and quietly denounced. As he understood the matter, the stevedoers had been in the habit of receiving fifty cents per one hundred bushels, for the work that they were required to perform. The elevators now share the labor, and the proprietors of the machines get thirty-seven and a half cents, while the stevedores are paid only the additional twelve and a half cents per one hundred bushels. He did not think this a fair division, and the merchants, he felt assured, would not suffer themselves to be made a party to such a manifest injustice. He had no more to say, and he believed that had the airy report been prepared by the committee, no more could have been said in it.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: The Seventeenth Annual Commencement of St. John's College, at Fordham, took place yesterday, and, as usual, was attended by a large concourse of its friends and patrons from this City and vicinity. According to the custom of former years, the exercises were held in the open air, beneath a large awning suspended from the branches of the stately old elms that adorn the college grounds. Very Rev. WM. STARR, Vicar-General, presided on the occasion, and around him were seated upon the platform the faculty of the College, and a large number of the distinguished clergy, among whom we noticed Very Rev. JOHN TURNER, of Brooklyn; Very Rev. J.P. MORAN, of Newark; Father JAMES HUGHES, of Hartford; Father J. O'BRIEN, of New-Haven; Father JAMES HASSAN, of Georgia; Fathers J. BRENNAN, W.J. QARTERS, S. MALONE, P.A. GAYNOR, of New-London; T.J. SMITH, of Niagara Falls; J. BOYCE; O'REILLY, late Chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, D. NELLIGAN, and others.

abstract: To-day another new Man-of-war will be added to our navy afloat. The new steam frigate Monongahela is to be launched at Philadelphia, and the ...
lead_paragraph: To-day another new Man-of-war will be added to our navy afloat. The new steam frigate Monongahela is to be launched at Philadelphia, and the veteran Commodore STEWART, who has presided at the "baptism" of so many naval vessels, will be one of the chief officers. The Monongahela is one of the six frigates ordered by Congress. The dimensions according to which she was to be constructed were: length over all, 235 feet; extreme breadth of beam, 33 feet 3 inches; depth of hold, 17 feet 10 inches; measurement, 1,600 tons. She may vary a trifle from these figures.

abstract: Editorial on European intervention panic precipated by press
snippet: Editorial on European intervention panic precipated by press
lead_paragraph: The panic-mongers are doing a pretty good business just now. They have convinced Wall-street at least that foreign intervention is certain to take place immediately, and that the end of the rebellion is therefore indefinitely postponed. Some of these pleasant patriots accomplish their object by depreciating the Government currency -- others by damaging the Administration: but quite a large proportion of them will not be satisfied until their predictions have secured their own fulfillment.

abstract: ENLISTMENT MUST BE HASTENED.  Nearly a  fortnight has already passed away (it was on the 1st of July) since the President issued his proclamation calling for three hundred thousand more troops.
lead_paragraph: fortnight has already passed away (it was on the 1st of July) since the President issued his proclamation calling for three hundred thousand more troops. A fortnight in time of war and at such a crisis of the war as this, is a period in which a great deal of work should be accomplished. Had the matter been properly pushed, and actively taken hold of by the patriotic people throughout the country, a hundred thousand of the three hundred thousand men should by this time have been in the field. Particularly in the great cities of the North and West, where popular enthusiasm rapidly shapes itself into practical action, and where it is possible to bring men together and organize them at once, should volunteering have gone on with a speed and spirit that by this time would have put at least half the quota required in readiness for movement. Delay is infinitely perilous, and the loss of a month may involve the waste of a year.

abstract: The first thought naturally, after the apparent reverse before Richmond, is that now, without doubt, Great Britain will intervene and recognize the Confederacy and so, to the storm and havoe on land, will be added tempest and destruction on the sea.
lead_paragraph: The first thought naturally, after the apparent reverse before Richmond, is that now, without doubt, Great Britain will intervene and recognize the Confederacy and so, to the storm and havoe on land, will be added tempest and destruction on the sea. We conceive, without giving England credit for either generosity or justice, that this is a mistaken conclusion and a groundless fear. The series of bloody battles, which terminated on the James last Tuesday, though dividing losses to both sides about equally, will, of course, be reckoned in England as a Confederate victory. The popular idea will be, that our Government, having possession of the telegraph, and exercising censorship over the Press, has concealed the worst, and the Tory organs will interpret every event in the most unfavorable light. There will be little doubt that the Southern Confederacy will now in time establish its own independence.

abstract: Lieut. TWADDLE, formerly Sergeant of the Eighteenth Precinct Police, but late Lieutenant of Company F, Thirty-second Regiment, N.Y.S.V., was mortally wounded at the Battle of West Point, while leading forward his Company to the charge. He died at Washington, and his body arrived in this City yesterday morning, in charge of Sergeant VOSBURGH, of the Eighteenth Precinct. The funeral will take place to-morrow, at 2 o'clock P.M. Lieut. TWADDLE was one of four brothers who joined the Union army, all resigning lucrative positions to do so. He has been the first to fall, and will be buried under honors, as will be seen by the following order issued from Police Headquarters last evening:

A man named JOHN CAREY, residing in Cherry-Sincer, New-York, was taken to the Long Island College Hospital yesterday, having been seriously injured at the Atlantic Basin, by a stone falling upon his head, while removing ballast from the head of a [???].. THOMAS TAGGART, 8 years old, was drowned yesterday while bathing in Bushwick Creek.... A man named BRANNAN was killed at the Navy-Yard on Wednesday evening, by a "shoe" falling upon him in the dry-dock....JAMES BUCKLEY, laborer, had one of his shoulders dislocated, and was otherwise seriously injured on Wednesday, while at work in a [???] on Smith near Deane-street, by a bank of [???] falling upon him....MARY E. BLOODGOOD, 7 years old, was fatally injured on Wednesday evening by falling from an upper window at No. 2 Franklinspace, to the sidewalk....The body of a boy was found near the foot of Joralemon-street; as the body a as naked it is supposed the boy was drowned while bathing.

abstract: It is remarkable how consistent is the logic of prejudice. The London Times has either taken up or has assumed the theory that the Government of this country is a disorganized mob, waging a causeless war to gratify the popular love for power or popular vindictiveness.
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable how consistent is the logic of prejudice. The London Times has either taken up or has assumed the theory that the Government of this country is a disorganized mob, waging a causeless war to gratify the popular love for power or popular vindictiveness. Everything is represented as in a chaos or as falling into indistinguishable ruin. No one knows what he is fighting for or what will be the result when it is all over. It is a kind of "invasion of barbarians" over the civilized and luxurious regions of the South, and the only effect will be a military despotism through the whole country, or society reduced to a chaotic condition. Holding these as the major premises, a logical conclusion would be that any civilized and well-to-do Provinces in the neighborhood of such a barbaric and chaotic Power would naturally be the first victims when "the brawls" here were over. The 700,000 freebooters or mercenaries gathered on the soil of the Union, for the purpose of plunder and glory, would at once, after the war, be dispatched to ravage and devastate these unfortunate neighbors. So intimates our London cotemporary. But, unfortunately, a few weeks since, the bill for the more efficient arming of the Canadian militia was brought up before the Provincial Parliament for a second reading, and yet, with all these horrors in view, with the seven hundred thousand Yankees hungry for the wheat and rye fields of the Canadas, it was quietly tabled. Nobody seemed to think of war, or that there was the slightest danger of collision with the National Union. They evidently felt that they could appropriate a few scores of millions better to railroads and canals than to feeding and arming useless soldiers. The London journal, true to its logic, cannot understand this. It indicates to the Cockney mind that the Canadas do not mean to arm themselves, because they expect the British Empire to defend them. It shows "the evils of dependence;" and the unfortunate Provinces, who could not possibly fall into a quarrel, except as appanages of Great Britain, are coolly informed that if they are invaded by those 700,000 mercenaries, they must defend themselves; that Great Britain has not the power or the will to uphold them against the American Union.

abstract: It will be recollected that it was stated, with great precision of detail, that on Saturday evening last, we had brought the enemy to bay on the south side of the Chickshominy, and that it only remained.
lead_paragraph: It will be recollected that it was stated, with great precision of detail, that on Saturday evening last, we had brought the enemy to bay on the south side of the Chickshominy, and that it only remained to finish him in a single battle. Such in fact appears to have been the situation then. The next morning, however, it was perceived that our suppose resources of generalship had given us too much confidence; that the enemy had managed to extricate himself from the critical position, and having massed his forces, had successed under the cover of the night, in opening a day to the James River.

abstract: The report of Hons. JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN, who were commissioned by the Secretary of War, Mr. STANTON,  to audit and adjust all contracts, orders and claims on the War.
lead_paragraph: The report of Hons. JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN, who were commissioned by the Secretary of War, Mr. STANTON, to audit and adjust all contracts, orders and claims on the War Department in respect to ordnance, arms and ammunition," will prove to be a most valuable guide book in the future administration of the Government, if we can rely on its lessons being taken to heart. This Commission was appointed and met on the 17th of March, and their report was rendered to Congress on the 1st of July. The work of examining and settling the contracts was of three and a half months' duration -- the Commission laboring faithfully the whole time. The summing up of their work is thus presented by the Commissioners in their report:

abstract: The Military Committee of the Fourth Senatorial District, appointed by the Governor, held its first meeting yesterday afternoon, at the Astor House. There was a full attendance, every member of the Committee being present. After deliberate and harmonious discussion, the meeting adjourned to Saturday, at 1 o'clock, when some suitable person will be nominated to take command of the regiment. In the meantime, applications for that position may be made to the Chairman, Hon. R.B. WOODRUFF, at the Astor House, which will be carefully and candidly considered by the Committee at the meeting on Saturday.

abstract: Editorial discusses quality of audacity in war; Editorial on coin shortage in NYC as result of war; Editorial on results of Government probe of War Dept. contracts
snippet: Editorial discusses quality of audacity in war; Editorial on coin shortage in NYC as result of war; Editorial on results of Government probe of War Dept. contracts
lead_paragraph: In a civil war audacity is everything. Perhaps nowhere are single battles reduced to a perfect science. Much of the issue depends always on the imagination and fears of either side. When the presence of NAPOLEON was reckoned by his adversaries as equal to a corps of forty thousand men, it was not merely his strategical combinations that they were regarding, but the moral effect he produced both on the spirits of his own men and of those opposed to him. When this same great leader lays down as a maxim of war that you should always, in your public estimates, double your own force and halve the force of your enemy, he has in view especially the effect on the imaginations of men. It is true, in the long run, that war is a contest of science and wealth, and no weak Power can, after a length of time, overcome a strong one, where both are equally in earnest. But in portions of a campaign this may not be the fact, and especially in a struggle between volunteer armies.
headline: {'main': 'Audacity as a War Energy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Audacity as a War Energy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FUNERAL OF LIEUT. CHAZOTTE. The funeral of Lieut. ADOPLLIUS I. CHAZOTTE, of Company F. Seventh Regiment. New-Jersey Volunteers, who was killed in the battle at Machanicsville, took place yes-...
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF LIEUT. CHAZOTTE. -- The funeral of Lieut. ADOPLLIUS I. CHAZOTTE, of Company F. Seventh Regiment. New-Jersey Volunteers, who was killed in the battle at Machanicsville, took place yesterday afternoon, from St. Mathew's Episcopal Church, Sussex-street, Jersey City. The services were conducted by the Rector, Rev. I BRINTON SMITH, and the edifice was crowded with a deeply affected congregation. Besides the usual funeral services, according to the ritual of the Episcopal Church, a very impressive discourse was delivered by the rector. At the conclusion of the exercises, the body was borne to the bearse, and the cortege wended its way to New-York Bay Cemetery, where the remains were in-interred. The Independence Guard, Capt. FRED. CRAIN, attended by a line band, acted as an escort, and Col. SPEER and the staff officers of the Second Regiment, N.J.S.M., were pall-bearers.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, instructions to the Generals -- relative to freeing the slaves of rebels -- were laid before the Senate by the War Department. The House joint resolution, authorizing the Secretary of War to furnish extra clothing to wounded and other soldiers, was passed. The bill relative to the abstracted Indian Trust bonds was passed. A bill to define the number of Major and Brigadier Generals in the army was introduced, and referred to the Military Committee. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, called up his resolution calling for the correspondence between Gen. MCCLELLAN and the War Department, and modified it so as to request the President to furnish the information, if not incompatible with the public interests. A long and warm debate as to the propriety of such an inquiry at the present time took place, at the end of which the resolution was passed -- 39 to 6. The bill amending the Militia act of 1795, introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, was then considered, and after considerable debate, the first section, authorizing the President to receive persons of African descent into the service of the United States, was adopted, with an amendment that all loyal masters shall be compensated. On the second section, giving freedom to such colored persons and their families, the Senate debated itself out of a quorum, and adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, instructions to the Generals -- relative to freeing the slaves of rebels -- were laid before the Senate by the War Department. The House joint resolution, authorizing the Secretary of War to furnish extra clothing to wounded and other soldiers, was passed. The bill relative to the abstracted Indian Trust bonds was passed. A bill to define the number of Major and Brigadier Generals in the army was introduced, and referred to the Military Committee. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, called up his resolution calling for the correspondence between Gen. MCCLELLAN and the War Department, and modified it so as to request the President to furnish the information, if not incompatible with the public interests. A long and warm debate as to the propriety of such an inquiry at the present time took place, at the end of which the resolution was passed -- 39 to 6. The bill amending the Militia act of 1795, introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, was then considered, and after considerable debate, the first section, authorizing the President to receive persons of African descent into the service of the United States, was adopted, with an amendment that all loyal masters shall be compensated. On the second section, giving freedom to such colored persons and their families, the Senate debated itself out of a quorum, and adjourned.

abstract: editorial asks information on military operations in New Mexico
snippet: editorial asks information on military operations in New Mexico
lead_paragraph: It is some days since a resolution, calling for official reports of military operations in New-Mexico, was adopted in the Senate -- a resolution still without an answer. Congress is preparing for adjournment on Monday. Should the War Department decline to respond to the Senate, or should its response come too late, one of the most brilliant chapters in the history of a war, of which the history at times is anything but brilliant, will, as far, as Government can effect it, be effaced.

abstract: The steamship City of New York, from Liverpool on the 2d, vid Queenstown on the 3d inst., was boarded off Cape Race at 10 A.M. yesterday. Her advices are two days later than the Great Eastern's. The political news is unimportant.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of New York, from Liverpool on the 2d, vid Queenstown on the 3d inst., was boarded off Cape Race at 10 A.M. yesterday. Her advices are two days later than the Great Eastern's. The political news is unimportant. The sales of Cotton on Thursday were 20,000 bales. The market closed buoyant, but prices were unchanged. Flour and Wheat were quiet and unchanged, but firm. Provisions were dull and nominal. Consols were quoted 91 3/4@91 2/8. Illinois Central Shares, 48 1/2 discount: Eries, 29 1/2.

abstract: the Cremorne Gardens, corner of Fourteenth-street and Sixth-avenue, is preparing a novelty that will astonish the natives. By a process known only to the inventor, a liquid fire is prepared, which is forced through the tubes of the fountains, and is thrown into the air precisely as water is usually done, and falling back into the basin, the water is constantly cream, with boiling, hissing flames, emitting an intensely bright light, and presenting a very novel and pleasing effect. This new feature, added to the multitude at other attractions, will undoubtedly increase the throng that make the Cremorne Garden their favorite evening resort.

abstract: Editorial on shortage of small change in NYC as result of war
snippet: Editorial on shortage of small change in NYC as result of war
lead_paragraph: change difficulties are working great injury to the retail trade of the City, and giving insufferable annoyance to all parties, whether buyer or seller. Gold, silver and nickel have all become so highly appreciated that, in purchasing a cheap dinner or a cigar after it, a pound of sugar, a yard of cotton cloth, or such like articles, the discount on a dollar bill, or a five-dollar bill, is often greater than the value of the article purchased, and hence the seller, in furnishing gold, silver or nickel change, actually loses more than the value of the goods sold. The various expedients adopted to obviate the difficulty give almost as great annoyance as the original trouble itself. The private shinplaster system is the worst. A person may come down town in the morning with five dollars in bills in his pocket, and after making half a dozen trifling purchases, may find himself with four dollars of shinplasters, which are worthless except at the places where they were issued, which he may not want to visit again in a month. Postage stamps for change are also a great annoyance, particularly in these dog-days, as they stick to the fingers, to the portmonnaie and to everything, and quickly get torn, dirty, wasted, uncurrent and worthless. It has been proposed that the City authorities issue paper change of the denominations of ten, twenty-five and fifty cents, which might be made universally current -- in other words, a sort of legal tender. It is said that the New-England banks are preparing to issue bills for twenty-five and fifty cents; but they could not supply us with this currency, even if we wanted it. Probably the best mode of relieving the difficulty at present is that adopted in some establishments on Broadway, namely, for the storekeeper to charge the current premium for specie when it is paid out, and allow the premium when specie is received. This mode also has its troubles; and in the daily fluctuations in the price of gold, silver and nickel, would necessitate a good deal of sharp calculation. But, in lieu of something better, it is the most equitable and convenient way of relieving what, after all, is only a temporary annoyance.

abstract: Samuel Harlan et al. vs. The steamship Nassau. This case came up on a motion by the libelants for an interlocutory sale of the vessel as perishable.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Harlan et al. vs. The steamship Nassau. -- This case came up on a motion by the libelants for an interlocutory sale of the vessel as perishable. The libel was filed to recover about $10,000 for repairs and supplies alleged to have been furnished to the vessel by the libelants. The U.S. District-Attorney intervened in the cause, and in answer to the motion informed the Court that the vessel and cargo are under capture by the United States as prize of war, and were committed to the custody of the Prize Commissioners in this port as such, on the 2d of June last, by a prize master having brought the said vessel from sea into this port for that purpose -- and the District-Attorney presented a certificate of the Prize Commissioners, under their seal of office, verifying the fact, and objected to the competency of any private suitor to interfere with or molest such military possession except through the authority of the Prime Court.

abstract: The risting iron-clad navy of the United States, and the late message of Secretary WELLES apropos of this subject, naturally begin to make a good deal of sensation in England. They wonder why we should build these ships, and they wonder what we are going to do with them after they are built. This ingenuousness is beautiful. Pray, what is the Warrior or the Black Prince for? And why is the British Admiralty now busy constructing COLE's cupola ships, and imitation Monitors in all its dockyards and arsenals? Our iron-clads, they argue, cannot be for putting down the rebellion, seeing that the National Government is mistress of the coast, seas and rivers. They must, therefore -- so leap these nimble logicians -- be to meet a European foe, and, if so, what? We hardly care to follow the journals into their ingenious stretches of speculation as to the Power against which our new naval enginery will be directed. They are quite too fast. It does not follow because we are getting ready our war thunderbolts that therefore we are about to launch them. But it does follow, with all the certainty of a moral law, that the existence of this iron navy, (stronger than that of both France and England combined,) will be one of the most powerful persuaders of peace. We shall not have half the use for our fleet existent that we would have for it non-existent. Neither are the peaceable speeches of John Bull at all to the purpose. Why build these iron ships he asks; if you do not attack me, depend on it I wont attack you. Very fine words, John; but they don't butter our parships. We believe all you say. It is gospel truth, no doubt. But, meanwhile, we push on our iron-clads.

abstract: -- A correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial writes regarding Gen. McClellan: "He enjoys the confidence of thorough military men. That the troops have confidence in him is also true. Upon this latter point I lay but little stress, because commanders are generally popular with their soldiers. I have seldom read of a General commanding a large army who was not cheered enthusiastically, and praised by his men. But I sincerely believe that McClellan is really popular with the army. I express these sentiments very freely, partly because I have no favors to ask, partly because I never worship any man. I endeavor to state my convictions. In these premises I cannot say that I have any definite convictions respecting Gen. McClellan's military genius. In the midst of his recent terrible trials, although he was evidently troubled, he was constantly calm and self-possessed. I watched him closely, and I could not discover that he lost his presence of mind at any period. Those most intimately connected with him assured me that his mind was constantly serene. Of course I cannot determine how much he relies upon the opinions of others. I only know that he frequently consults those who are regarded as among the best military minds of the army. No man could devote himself more incessantly to his duties than he. He is an incessant, sleepless and rapid worker. These are my opinions frankly."

abstract: A serious though happily not fatal casualty occurred Thursday, on the New-Jersey Railroad. The 11 P.M. mail train for Philadelphia and Washington, at a point midway between the Hackensack Bridge and Newark, was precipitated violently from the track. The engine and tender, after running about fifty yards, were hurled into the ditch, while the rest of the train, running ahead some distance, were wrenched right and left, and huddled up in a heap. The baggage cars were tossed off and twisted round like chips, the first passenger car was thrown across the track at right angles, the two hind cars fortunately remaining on the track. Considering the extraordinary violence of the catastrophe it seems miraculous that no fatal casualties resulted. The engineer, who went with the engine into the gully, was battered about the head; one of the brakemen was badly hurt in the leg, and a lady (the wife of the conductor,) received a violent shock by being thrown across the seat, resulting, it was feared, in the breaking of three of her ribs. These were the only accidents of any moment that occurred, and Dr. WHITE, of Fairhaven, who was on the train, kindly rendered every assistance in his power. It was at first thought that the accident was caused by the breaking of the engine's axle, or the giving way of one of the truck wheels; but on examining the point at which the train was hurled from the track, it was found that a tie had been laid across it. Further on, nearer Newark, several other ties were found placed across the track; so that there is no doubt it was the diabolical inspiration of some fiendish mind. The bewildered passengers, emerging from the cars, were struck with horror at the wreck around them, and all agreed that nothing short of a miracle bad saved them from destruction. After being compelled to stay several hours on the scene, a prey to the multitudinous mosquitoes of the salt marsh, a train was at length procured for Newark, and about 3 o'clock yesterday morning they passed on their way to Philadelphia. This is the second disaster that has occurred on the New-Jersey Railroad during the present week -- that of Sunday last having resulted in the death of two persons. Considering the circumstances of yesterday's accident, however, it would not appear that in this case blame rests either on the Company or the engineer. The train was going at a moderate speed, the customary vigilance was used, and the obstructions seem to have been placed on the track but a moment before the train passed. The Company has offered a thousand dollars reward for the apprehension of the guilty person. A suspected individual was arrested yesterday afternoon, but was, we believe, discharged.

abstract: RICHMOND. -- It is very evident, from the extracts we have given from Southern journals, that the results of the battles before Richmond have by no means equaled the expectations of the rebels. They counted confidently on the complete annihilation of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army, and are amazed at the generalship which saved it from destruction.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND. -- It is very evident, from the extracts we have given from Southern journals, that the results of the battles before Richmond have by no means equaled the expectations of the rebels. They counted confidently on the complete annihilation of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army, and are amazed at the generalship which saved it from destruction.

abstract: The funeral ceremonies of the late EDWARD C. WEST, Surrogate of the County of New-York, took place yesterday at 3 o'clock P.M., at the residence of the deceased, No. 107 Lexington-avenue.
lead_paragraph: The funeral ceremonies of the late EDWARD C. WEST, Surrogate of the County of New-York, took place yesterday at 3 o'clock P.M., at the residence of the deceased, No. 107 Lexington-avenue. The universal esteem in which Mr. WEST was held was manifested by the large attendance of distinguished citizens. There were many well-known members of the Bench, the Bar and the City and County Governments present. Mr. WEST's old associates of the Ten Governors were well represented. The Catholic funeral service was read by Rev. Father CLOUGHRY, The pall-bearers were Messrs. J.S. Shulley, E.R. Tremain, C.H. Glover, W.C. Russell, R.J. Dillon, Isaac Bell, Jr., P. McElroy, S. Van Cott, J.T. Brady, A.W. Bradford, Dr. W. Sanger, R.B. Conolly. The remains were inclosed in a cloth-covered coffin, the plate bearing the inscription, "EDWARD C. WEST, died July 8, 1862, aged 44 years, 2 months and 16 days." The body was interred in Greenwood Cemetery.

abstract: -- In addition to the official declaration of Lord PALMERSTON, we copy an important article on intervention from the London Saturday Review. That journal has been the steadiest and most bitter of all the enemies of the United States Government during its contest with the rebellion: yet it protests with vehemence, and for strong reasons, against any interference, or mediation even, in the affairs of this country. This shows clearly that sympathy with secession in England is one thing, and a disposition to intervene in aid of it is quite another. The one is safe and cheap: -- the other would be full of danger, and would involve England in enormous expense. England and France, moreover, can get along very well together while nothing but talking is to be done: but any attempt to fight side by side in a war with the United States, would utterly destroy the entente cordiale which now exists between them. Even the paltry Mexican quarrel has very nearly done so already.
lead_paragraph: -- In addition to the official declaration of Lord PALMERSTON, we copy an important article on intervention from the London Saturday Review. abstract: It is well that the plan of a joint mediation between the American belligerents failed even before it  was formally proposed. The project would have been objectionable even if the time had been more opportune for pacific negotiations; and in the present temper of the Northern population any amicable settlement seems to be out of the question.

abstract: "The week closes under the stagnancy applicable to the season. The usual winding up of a business year is attended with a general exodus of transient and permanent dealers and traders, with thousands of citizens and resident population leaving for Summer resort North, South, East, West and Europe.
lead_paragraph: "The week closes under the stagnancy applicable to the season. The usual winding up of a business year is attended with a general exodus of transient and permanent dealers and traders, with thousands of citizens and resident population leaving for Summer resort North, South, East, West and Europe. The present time contrasted with the close of a season's business after the receipts, sales and export of the products of the Mississippi Valley, to the amount of $150,000,000 to $185,000,000, is so very gloomy and unfavorable, that we have no inclination to indulge in extended remarks on the unfortunate position of commerce, finance and trade, with social and political adjuncts, at this nominal close of the season.

abstract: We, publish in another column a call for a meeting in Union-square on Tuesday afternoon next, at 11 o'clock, to be composed of citizens of all parties who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war for the suppression of the rebellion. The call is headed by Mayor OPDYKE ...
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a call for a meeting in Union-square on Tuesday afternoon next, at 11 o'clock, to be composed of citizens of all parties who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war for the suppression of the rebellion. The call is headed by Mayor OPDYKE, who will act as Chairman on the occasion. A Committee has been dispatched to Washington to invite President LINCOLN to be present, and there is a probability that his answer will be favorable.

abstract: Much dissatisfaction has been recently expressed by the principal grain merchants, especially the receivers, in consequence of the arbitrary action of self-constituted Boards of Grain Measurers.
lead_paragraph: Much dissatisfaction has been recently expressed by the principal grain merchants, especially the receivers, in consequence of the arbitrary action of self-constituted Boards of Grain Measurers. The principal cause of complaint has been the utter want of system in deciding on the quality and condition of lots of wheat and corn offered for sale. The measurers have been under no legal responsibility to act impartially between buyers and sellers; and it is alleged by some of the principal receivers that partial, injurious and unjustifiable opinions of quality and condition have been frequently rendered. Yet these opinions were final, as there has existed no properly organized Committee to hear appeals. To do away with this source of trouble, the principal receivers, and some of the measurers, yesterday, affixed their signatures to the following call for a meeting:

lead_paragraph: The Citizens of New-York, of all parties, who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war and the suppression of the rebellion, are requested to meet on Union-square, on Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to express, without reference to any party question whatever, their undiminished confidence in the justice of our cause,and their inflexible purpose to maintain it to the end, and to proffer to the Government all the aid it may need to the extent of all their resources.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic Union meeting was held at Union Hall, in the Fourth District, on Saturday evening last. The meeting was called to order D.S. DEWEES, Esq., who nominated EDWIN WHITE, Esq., as Chairman of the meeting. The following named gentlemen were appointed Vice-Presidents: ROBERT WATSON, C. AUCH, W.A. BILLS and WM. MCDUFF, L.M. DAY, Esq., was appointed Secretary. Able and eloquent addresses were made by the President, by Judge HIESTAND and D.S. DEWEES, Esq. The meeting was characterized by great unanimity of feeling, and the addresses of the several gentlemen received with universal demonstrations of appreciation.

abstract: editorials porpose solutions to shortage

lead_paragraph: -- The annoyance arising from the present scarcity of "change" may be obviated without resorting to the questionable expedient of debasing the standard of our coinage. It arises not from any want of current money, but from a lack of that which represents the fractional parts of a dollar.

abstract: The correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Earl RUSSELL on the above subject is published. On the 24th April Mr. ADAMS opened the correspondence with a letter in which he transmitted certain depositions relating to the seizure.
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Earl RUSSELL on the above subject is published. On the 24th April Mr. ADAMS opened the correspondence with a letter in which he transmitted certain depositions relating to the seizure. Mr. ADAMS contended that the act committed by Capt. WILSON, the master of the neutral vessel, entailed her confiscation and that of the cargo, and asked that directions might be given for their restoration. On the 7th of May Earl RUSSELL replied that, having taken the opinion of the Law Officers of the Crown, the Government were unable to comply, inasmuch as acts of forcible resistance to the rights of belligerents on the high seas were not cognizable by the municipal law of England, however punishable, as offences against international law in the Prize Courts of the captor administering such law.

abstract: -- We trust that Congress will adjourn as speedily as possible, if its time is to be spent in such mischievous and discreditable wranglings as marked the debate of Thursday in the Senate. It is idle for Senators to complain of divided counsels in the army, when they thus set the example of snarling over the merits and claims of particular Generals. What they say on the subject would be of but little consequence, perhaps, if it did not go forth to the country and stir up similar dissensions among the people. If it were the distinct and deliberate object of Senators to discourage enlistments, they could not have taken a more effectual means of doing so than by denouncing those who have in charge the actual conduct of the wear.
lead_paragraph: -- We trust that Congress will adjourn as speedily as possible, if its time is to be spent in such mischievous and discreditable wranglings as marked the debate of Thursday in the Senate. abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the Secretary of the Navy to accept the title to League Island, below Philadelphia, was passed, with an amendment directing a previous survey of the harbor of New-London and of Narragansett Bay, to ascertain their relative excellences for the location of a naval depot. The resolutions calling for further evidence and the documents connected with the report of JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN, were passed. The bill amendatory of the Militia Law of 1795 was again considered, the question being on striking out the words "mother, wife and children," in the second second section, which provides for freeing those persons of African descent employed by the Government. The proposal to strike out was rejected Mr. PROWNING, of Illinois, then offered another amendment, that such mother, wife or children shall not be freed unless they owe service or labor to the rebels. The debate continued at great length, and until the Senate found itself without a quorum. During the proceedings reports were made from the Committees of Conference on the Pension bill and the Tariff bill, which were both agreed to.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the Secretary of the Navy to accept the title to League Island, below Philadelphia, was passed, with an amendment directing a previous survey of the harbor of New-London and of Narragansett Bay, to ascertain their relative excellences for the location of a naval depot. The resolutions calling for further evidence and the documents connected with the report of JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN, were passed. The bill amendatory of the Militia Law of 1795 was again considered, the question being on striking out the words "mother, wife and children," in the second second section, which provides for freeing those persons of African descent employed by the Government. The proposal to strike out was rejected Mr. PROWNING, of Illinois, then offered another amendment, that such mother, wife or children shall not be freed unless they owe service or labor to the rebels. The debate continued at great length, and until the Senate found itself without a quorum. During the proceedings reports were made from the Committees of Conference on the Pension bill and the Tariff bill, which were both agreed to.

abstract: THE SCARCITY OF CHANGE A SENSELESS PAN10. The obange panie which has so suddenly come over this community, continues unabated, and apparently absorbs the entire attention of the people to the exclusion of the war, the condition of the army.
lead_paragraph: THE SCARCITY OF CHANGE A -- SENSELESS PANIC. -- The obange panie which has so suddenly come over this community, continues unabated, and apparently absorbs the entire attention of the people to the exclusion of the war, the condition of the army, the new call for troops, the doings of Congress, or even the policy to be pursued with regard to the negro. The flood of manuscripts that has poured into this office, containing suggestions, recommendations and remonstrances, in relation to the subject, well nigh rival the deluge of skinplasters, and promises to pay, that have been emitted from the thousand and one marts of trade and traffic, and scattered broadcast over the City. One man sends word that he will give and take postage stamps in change, but unfortunately for his suggestion, the postage stamps have to be paid for in specie, and are a very troublesome and inconvenient medium of change after you get them. Another proposes that the Government shall issue fractional bills of almost every conceivable amount, but before the Government could get the new bills into circulation, it is to be hoped the panic -- for it is nothing but a panic -- will have subsided. So far as this City is concerned, however, a plan is set forth in our editorial columns to-day, which could be speedily put in operation through the agency of the City Chamberlain, and which would promptly remedy the evil. Until this or some other plan is adopted, the best thing every citizen can do is to refrain from adding to the panic by telling everybody he meets what a heavy premium silver commanded yesterday and to-day, to stop hoarding up what little he may get hold of, and to "indignantly frown," in the language of WASHINGTON, upon the whole crew of miserly bipeds who insist upon thrusting upon him their dirty shipplasters in change, when heaps of silver lie in their drawers which they have received from their customers. Nothing can be clearer than that a keeper of an eating-house or drinking-saloon, or dealer in any commodity, is morally bound to pay out silver in change so long as he has the article on hand which he has received from his customers. When he is out of charge, and is compelled to purchase it at 10 or 12 per cent, premium, then he may be excused for giving instead a promise to pay; but as it is now, they take all the change they can get from their customers and pay out none. What do they do with it? If they sell it to the brokers and pocket the premium, they are miserly scoundrels, and ought to be robbed. If they hoard it up for fear it may be still scarcer, they are only adding to the panic, and increasing the very scarcity they profess to lament. There is ample gold and silver in this City and throughout the country (at least in the loyal portion of it) for all the purposes of business, and there can be no doubt that if every business man and citizen would commence to-day and pay out freely what specie he has in his possession, as occasion requires, in less than three weeks it would be as plenty as it was two months ago.

abstract: The speculators in shinplasters, the purchasers of proscribed Confederate notes, and the traders in politics, were in a high state of excitement yesterday over the publication of a statement to the effect that the "authorities" at Richmond "had received official notice of the recognition by France of the Government of the Confederate States of America." This was put forth, without comment, in an extra of the National Advocate. The editor of that paper does not believe a word of this falsehood. He cannot have forgotten our statement of the French Emperor's policy, in regard to our civil troubles, made ten days ago. But it served his purpose to produce a panic in the market, which he did; and we presume he took advantage of it.
lead_paragraph: The speculators in shinplasters, the purchasers of proscribed Confederate notes, and the traders in politics, were in a high state of excitement yesterday over the publication of a statement to the effect that the "authorities" at Richmond "had received official notice of the recognition by France of the Government of the Confederate States of America." But it served his purpose to produce a panic in the market, which he did; and we presume he took advantage of it.

abstract: The National Advocate says: "The friends of the Union, residing in Louisiana, are not satisfied with President LINCOLN's continuing Gen. PHELPS in command. They consider him an enemy to the Constitution of the United States, and therefore it is impossible for him to harmonize with our citizens, who are determined to maintain their rights as defined in that sacred charter; while Major-Gen. BUTLER and Gen. SHEPLEY are taking great pains to protect us in our rights, as an evidence of which we have Gen. BUTLER's order that none save those employed should be received or be allowed to remain within the lines of the army, and Gen. SHEPLEY's order warning the marines of the consequences which would attend their aiding the escape of slaves.

abstract: THE LATE BATTLES. -- The best item of good news which the President brings back with him from the Peninsula is one to the effect that the rumors of losses in the late battles were greatly exaggerated; and the telegraph attributes to him a statement that the entire losses on our part, in the several engagements, do not exceed, in killed, wounded and missing, ten or eleven thousand. This is certainly much more like the truth than the preposterous rebel statements of sixty thousand Union loss, thirty thousand of whom were captured; or than the sensation estimate published here last week, among the contradictory and absurd statements then hourly given, that our gross loss would amount to thirty thousand! All sorts of wild and extravagant rumors are sure to follow on the heels of a battle; and, though it is a fact that nearly all the first estimates of losses in previous battles in Eastern Virginia have been underrated, yet, considering all the circumstances, there is nothing more likely than that they should be greatly overrated by rumor in this instance, and there is nothing more certain than that such was the case. As the President undoubtedly had means of information on this subject not open to the general public, it would be greatly reassuring, and would do much to relieve depression, of feeling, if he would cause some accurate and official statement to be made as to what our losses were in the seven days' engagement.
lead_paragraph: THE LATE BATTLES. -- The best item of good news which the President brings back with him from the Peninsula is one to the effect that the rumors of losses in the late battles were greatly exaggerated; and the telegraph attributes to him a statement that the entire losses on our part, in the several engagements, do not exceed, in killed, wounded and missing, ten or eleven thousand. This is certainly much more like the truth than the preposterous rebel statements of sixty thousand Union loss, thirty thousand of whom were captured; or than the sensation estimate published here last week, among the contradictory and absurd statements then hourly given, that our gross loss would amount to thirty thousand! All sorts of wild and extravagant rumors are sure to follow on the heels of a battle; and, though it is a fact that nearly all the first estimates of losses in previous battles in Eastern Virginia have been underrated, yet, considering all the circumstances, there is nothing more likely than that they should be greatly overrated by rumor in this instance, and there is nothing more certain than that such was the case. As the President undoubtedly had means of information on this subject not open to the general public, it would be greatly reassuring, and would do much to relieve depression, of feeling, if he would cause some accurate and official statement to be made as to what our losses were in the seven days' engagement.

abstract: Advices from Europe one day later have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Norwegian. The political news is unimportant. The shipping at Liverpool on the Fourth of July was gaily decked with flage.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe one day later have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Norwegian. The political news is unimportant. The shipping at Liverpool on the Fourth of July was gaily decked with flage. The Cunard and other transatlantic steamers had all their bunting flying. The sales of cotton in the Liver pool market for the week added up to 105,000 bales. Prices were 2d.@2 1/2d. higher than the last authorized quotations. The sales on Friday amounted to 12,000 bales, the market closing with a still upward tendency. Breadstuffs were quiet and unchanged. Provisions were dull. The Paris correspondent of the Times says dissatisfaction at the Mexican policy is openly expressed, and letters from Mexico convey the same feeling. LORENCEZ's official report of the Guadalupe affairs, admits his defeat, owing to illusions and false information. Other Continental news is unimportant.

abstract: The army was yesterday taken by surprise by a most unexpected visit by President LINCOLN. At 3 o'clock a rumor ran through the camp that "Uncle ABRAHAM" had arrived, and that be would review the army at once. At 4 o'clock a salute of 22 guns fired.
lead_paragraph: The army was yesterday taken by surprise by a most unexpected visit by President LINCOLN. At 3 o'clock a rumor ran through the camp that "Uncle ABRAHAM" had arrived, and that be would review the army at once. At 4 o'clock a salute of 22 guns fired near the north part of the encampment roused every soldier and officer from his reverie. The first impression naturally was that the enemy had attacked our right flank, but the soldier's ear soon detected the absence of that peculiar sound which distinguishes a blank cartridge from the screaming shell; and when he had counted 22, the matter was explained. It was the salute for the President of the Untied States. Immediately bugles sounded and drums beat throughout the camp as if by one spontaneous impulse, and almost before the echo of the salute had died away, long columns of troops were observed marching from their several encampments and taking their places in regimental lines for review. The day had been intensely hot, but the sun had already begun to decline, and the soldiers moved with an alacrity which showed how gratifying it was to them to receive a visit from the Chief Magistrate at this time.

abstract: Lieut. Worden, of the Monitor, had a most enthusiastic reception at Grand Rapids, on Wednesday evening July 2.
lead_paragraph: -- Lieut. Worden, of the Monitor, had a most enthusiastic reception at Grand Rapids, on Wednesday evening July 2. The exercises were at Lutte's Hall, which was tastefully decorated. Lieut. Worden was introduced to the immense company by P.R.L. Pierce, Esq., and responded briefly to a congratulatory address. The most interesting incident is thus described by the Eagle; "The feature of the evening, and the best conceived and finest executed scene of the kind that we ever witnessed, was next presented by thirty young ladies and little girls, all of whom were very [???] attired in pure white, and ornamented with festoons and wreaths of flowers, tastefully arrangement on their dresses and heads. This [???] of beauty and loveliness, all unexpected to the majority present, came upon the stage, the parties composing it each having in her hand a bouquet or wreath, or both, of sweet flowers, and slowly encircled the Lieutenant, who had been seated near the centre of the platform. The ladies then moved in single file slowly around the hero, singing some beautiful lines prepared for the occasion, a welcome to the brave, a requiem for the dead, and a prayer for the future of the patriot hero, casting at his feet, as they passed turn in front, bouquets, wreaths and garlands of lovely flowers, until he was half buried beneath the sweet [???] of love."

abstract: debate continues
snippet: debate continues
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 30th ultimo, Lord BROUGHAM, who was almost inaudible in the reporters' gallery, called attention to the civil war in America, which he deeply deplored, and the consequences of which were now being felt all over the civilized world. At the same time, he thought it impossible for Her Majesty's Government to interfere; but he expressed an earnest hope that the American people would themselves see the suicidal character of the contest in which they were engaged, and come to some amicable arrangement before they entirely alienated from them the feelings of respect and affection with which they had hitherto been regarded by the great European nations.

abstract: According to the letter of our correspondent at Paris the difficulties of the French Emperor arising out of the Mexican question are just beginning. Nothing could be easier than to arrange with England and Spain a three-sided treaty, big with ambiguities. From idle French squadrons and idle French battalions the material of the expedition could be drawn with the utmost ease. Even M. FOULD, fresh in the Bureau of Finance, and therefore fertile of economical projects, could not find it in his heart to object to the insignificant expense proposed by the Emperor as the price of so much glory. Everything in the career of the great French statesman was prosperous in the extreme, insomuch that nothing short of Providential interposition appeared likely to save Mexico from subjugation and the rule of a mongrel Prince, chiefly of the Hapsburgian breed. The tide of success had no turn, notwithstanding the withdrawal of the Spanish and British contingents. The French, relieved of treaty obligations, had only to march from Vera Cruz to the capital, there to dictate terms of peace, and settle the conditions upon which Mexico might resume her autonomy. The thing was in the last degree feasible. What Gen. SCOTT with his volunteers had done would be child's play to the veterans of Magenta and Solferino. The whole scheme of the expedition was therefore free from any possibility of failure.

abstract: The bill reported yesterday from the House Committee on Ways and Means is a very important one, and provides for changes which will have an important bearing on the stability and popularity of the National currency. Its main features, as telegraphed this morning, appear to be two: 1. The establishment of a Bureau, under direction of the Secretary of the Treasury, charged with the execution of all laws respecting the issue and circulation of a National currency; and 2. The formation of local associations, or banks, for carrying on the business of banking with United States stocks as a basis -- banking institutions already in existence having also the right to avail themselves of the advantages of the act.

abstract: We observe that Lord PALMERSTON has again repeated, for the fifth or sixth time, the declaration that the British Government has no thought of interfering or intervening in any way in American affairs. Some of our neighbors are disposed to cavil at his use of the words "at present" in this connection, insisting that, thus guarded, his denials amount to nothing. But the reason on which he rests the official repudiation of any such intention ought to put this matter at rest. He says that no foreign interference whatever can be of the slightest use, or can have any other result than to make matters worse, until both parties see that their real interest lies in peace. Whenever that time comes, then foreign proffers of mediation may be of service. Until then, they would only aggravate matters by exasperating both parties.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, proceedings were commenced with an Executive session.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, proceedings were commenced with an Executive session. When the doors were opened, the resolution declaring the meaning of the act authorizing the President to take possession of all the railroads and telegraph lines, was passed. It was subsequently passed in the House. The report of the Committee of Conference on the Confiscation bill was concurred in, after some opposition, 27 to 13, and the bill therefore stands passed in both houses. The report of the Conference Committee on the bill changing certain judicial districts, was concurred in. The House bill to prevent the imprisonment of soldiers in the penitentiaries, excepting for certain criminal offences, was passed. The resolution requesting the President to have prepared a statement of the trade and commerce of California, Oregon and Washington Territory, was adopted. The bill providing for the election of Representatives in Congress by single districts, was passed. The resolution in relation to the number of Senators constituting a quorum, was debated at considerable length, and its consideration was finally postponed until Monday. A resolution fixing the time for adjournment on Wednesday, the 16th, was reported from the Committee on Finance, and agreed to by 29 to 10. The bill providing for the extension of the Territory of Nevada was passed. At 5 o'clock a recess was taken until 7. The bill providing for the better security of passengers on steamboats, was passed. After an Executive session, the Senate then adjourned.

abstract: We Americans are so frequently charged by foreigners with vices and weaknesses we are quite guiltless of, that it becomes as refresh
lead_paragraph: We Americans are so frequently charged by foreigners with vices and weaknesses we are quite guiltless of, that it becomes as refreshing as it is unusual when we may candidly plead guilty to some particular fault, and frankly admit there is room for improvement. It is certainly true, for example, that, as a people, we are too excitable. We have not attained that enviable philosophy which would enable us to bear adversity with cheerfulness, and success without elation. Whether it arises from the admixture of a large proportion of the Celtic element in the national organization, or is to be traced to climatic influences, we have lost a portion of that steadiness and imperturbability which distinguished the Revolutionary Fathers. It may be that we have gained in enterprise and audacity what we have lost in equanimity; we may have more elans and less obstinacy; yet we confess to an abiding faith in the staunch old characteristics, and regard it as an atoning feature of the present war that it is likely to foster and strengthen those solid qualities which went so far toward ennobling the character and establishing the success of our ancestors.
