abstract: MRS. MARY REAL. This lady was called upon this morning to plead to the indictment charging her with the willful murder of her husband.
lead_paragraph: MRS. MARY REAL. -- This lady was called upon this morning to plead to the indictment charging her with the willful murder of her husband. She appeared in Court, attended by her counsel, Mr. EDWIN JAMES and Mr. THOMAS DUNPHY, with whom she was in constant conversation. She was attired in a gray traveling suit and dark blue veil, which she kept over her face during her presence in Court She is 24 years of age, possessed of a graceful figure, interesting appearance, and modest demeanor, and would indicate the opposite to that of being one capable of inflicting the summary punishment which deprived a heartless and relentless husband of his life. The plea of not guilty was put in to the indictment, and Mr. EDWIN JAMES, her senior counsel, then moved that the indictment be removed into the Oyer and Terminer, as the defendant was desirous that she be tried before the highest tribunal in the country, which was granted by his Honor Judge MCCUNN. Mrs. REAL's exemplary conduct, modest manner and uncomplaining suffering, have established for her in the minds of all who see her, a character deserving of respect and sympathy; while the unpublished persecutions which have attended her daily life during the dread "four years" entitle her to the support of every honest man and virtuous woman. It is understood that District Attorney HALL will conduct the prosecution in person, and that he will decline all outside aid, even though such may be tendered by those whose revenge might be gratified by a conviction.

lead_paragraph: We learn from Capt. abstract: MORTALITY. There were 115 deaths in this city during the week ending yesterday, from the following named diseases: Asphyxia, unknown, disease
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- There were 115 deaths in this city during the week ending yesterday, from the following named diseases: Asphyxia, unknown, disease of the kidneys, disease of the heart, softening of the stomach, palsy, erysipelas, 1 each; burns, smallpox, disease of the liver, delirium tremens, casualty, diphtheria, inflammation of the bowels, scarlet fever, coup de soliel, inflammation of the lungs, bronchitis, dropsy, 2 each; croup, congestion of the lungs, hydrocephalus, measles, premature birth, cancer, 3 each; drowned, diarrhoea, 4 each; debility, marasmus, 6 each; consumption, 7; convulsions, congestion of the brain, cholera infantum, 12 each. Males, 63; females, 52. Seventy of those who died were five years of age and under.

abstract: Editorial on war and slavery as its cause
snippet: Editorial on war and slavery as its cause
lead_paragraph: The belief that wrong-doing in the long run meets with punishment, has been generally accepted by mankind. Now and then, it is true, there are found instances of the seeming prosperity of the wicked, so lung continued and so fair as to raise a doubt in the minds of some whether that is a law of the Universe. Even King David was afflicted with such doubts sometimes, but he speedily put them to flight; and the race of man on a whole have accepted it as a fact, that any one who sets the currents of his life running counter to those great currents of right and justice which flow from under God's throne, will surely come to overthrow. No matter how long he may seem to succeed, no matter what props and bulwarks he may build up beneath and around him, yet in the end God is too strong for him. This conviction is expressed in the lines of the poet:
headline: {'main': 'The Lesson for the Day.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lesson for the Day.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial attacks pessimists ("croakers") who are again at work
snippet: Editorial attacks pessimists ("croakers") who are again at work
lead_paragraph: The croakers are abroad again, and as thick as ever. There are two kinds of them. There are the malignant croakers, who do their work with a hearty desire to work evil, who, like the Herald, loudly proclaim disaster, and threaten dissension and consequent defeat, because they desire the disaster and defeat, and think this is the surest way to secure it. And then there are the melancholy croakers -- the men who desire most earnestly that affairs shall move successfully, and are willing even to take hold to help attain success, but who are cast down and dismayed by any adverse wind. These men go about our streets with long faces, talk in lugubrious tones, shake their heads and say they begin to doubt whether the rebellion will ever be put down. They dwell with great emphasis upon this or that failure of the Administration, or of some General to have done what they think should have been done, and if one of a more cheerful turn is disposed to look at things more favorably, and to think that even our mistakes may have not been unproductive of good, they are mad. They will not look at the deadly wounds on every side of the trunk of the rebellion, but because it still stands upright, they groan out, "We shall never cut it down," and they complain of the dullness of the axe, and wonder why the blows were not struck upon the one side of the tree instead of the other, and why John or Thomas was not allowed to hold the axe, instead of James or Dick, and they descant upon their own improved method of wood-cutting, and insinuate that this man or that is thinking of something else besides chopping, or quite possibly does not wish the tree to fall -and so they spend their time and their energies in croaking, croaking.
headline: {'main': 'A Counterblast to Croaking.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Counterblast to Croaking.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The refusal of large numbers of laborers to work in connection with the floating elevators has been the source of so much embarassment, expense and loss to the brokers, who purchase grain to fill foreign orders.
lead_paragraph: The refusal of large numbers of laborers to work in connection with the floating elevators has been the source of so much embarassment, expense and loss to the brokers, who purchase grain to fill foreign orders that the latter have finally concluded to abstain from operating freely at present, and to advise their principals not to send them any more orders for immediate execution until shippers can obtain some assurance of the prompt and regular delivery of such lots as may be bought by them. It is now almost impossible to have grain transferred from the boats and barges in which it comes forward from the interior, to the vessels which take it away to Europe. Under these circumstances, the leading brokers have agreed to transmit to their principals copies of the following memorial:

abstract: In the batch of New-Orleans papers received by us yesterday, there is great complaint made of the scarcity of flour, the high price of bread, and the lack of provisions generally in that city. There were two or three causes which prevented a large supply of these necessaries from being forwarded at once to New-Orleans from the North when the port was opened to commerce. One was that there was a general impression that the Mississippi River would be opened immediately, and that abundant supplies, indeed a glut, of everything in that line would be sent down the river from the Northwest. The others were the deranged condition of the Southern currency, and the supposed adverseness of the people to trade with the Yankees. The obstinacy of Vicksburgh, however, has, up to this time, kept the Mississippi closed to commerce, and while there is a plethora of flour and all small grains on the upper line of the river, the people at its mouth are starving. Even after Vicksburgh does fall, there is likely to be great difficulty in peaceful steamboats navigating the Mississippi for some time, as there appears to have been a system of guerrillaism inaugurated there, in which the guerrillas operate with pieces of flying artillery on the river banks. This it will take some time to root out. As for the other obstacles in the way of trade with New-Orleans, the currency difficulty is certainly bad enough, but it is found that enough respectable current funds still circulate to purchase supplies; and the people are not at all adverse to procuring them from whoever has them to sell. Now that these things are known in the North, an abundance of flour and other necessaries will doubtless at once be shipped for the relief of the breadless people of the Crescent City.
lead_paragraph: In the batch of New-Orleans papers received by us yesterday, there is great complaint made of the scarcity of flour, the high price of bread, and the lack of provisions generally in that city. As for the other obstacles in the way of trade with New-Orleans, the currency difficulty is certainly bad enough, but it is found that enough respectable current funds still circulate to purchase supplies; and the people are not at all adverse to procuring them from whoever has them to sell. Now that these things are known in the North, an abundance of flour and other necessaries will doubtless at once be shipped for the relief of the breadless people of the Crescent City.

abstract: CITIZENS OF CONNECTICUT: You are again called upon to rally to the support of the Government. In the name of our common country, I call upon you to enroll your names for the formation of six or more regiments of infantry to be used in suppressing the rebellion. Our troops may be held in check and our sons die on the battle-field -- but the cause of civil liberty must be advanced -- the supremacy of the Government must be maintained. Prompt and decisive action will be economy in men and money. By our delay the safety of our armies, even of the nation, may be imperilled. The rebellion, contending with the desperation of a hopeless and wicked cause, must be met with equal energy. Close your manufactories and worskshops -- turn aside from your farms and your business -- leave for awhile your families and your homes -- meet face to face the enemies of your liberties. Haste and you will rescue many noble men now struggling against superior numbers, and speedily secure the blessings of peace and good government.

abstract: Editorial lauds report Government has made arrangements for general exchange of prisoners
snippet: Editorial lauds report Government has made arrangements for general exchange of prisoners
lead_paragraph: -- The announcement that the Government has at last made arrangements for a general exchange of prisoners, will cause the greatest joy throughout the whole country -- the capture of Richmond hardly greater. The Administration has had its own difficulties in coming up to the adoption of this policy-difficulties that we can appreciate, and which have made the people forbearing under extraordinary trials. But the good to be effected by an exchange really so far exceeds any advantage that could be gained by retaining the rebel prisoners in our hands, that we can readily sacrifice all other considerations. When this measure takes effect, one of its first rewards will be an immense stimulus to volunteering: we think it good for a hundred thousand men.

abstract: The United States steamer Albalross, from Georgetown, S.C., 5th of July, arrived at Boston on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Albalross, from Georgetown, S.C., 5th of July, arrived at Boston on Tuesday evening. It is presumed she returned to discharge her crew, who are "one year's men." The Albatross left at Georgetown the United States steamer Western World, bark Gem of the Sea, and prize schooner Louisa, the latter about to sail for Boston. All was quiet at Georgetown.

abstract: -- It is expected that the approaching commencement of this institution will be of unusual interest. Addresses will be delivered during the week by Rev. Drs. KENDALL and PARKER, of New-York, and Hon. C.B. SEDGWICK, of Syracuse. On Wednesday, July 16, the fiftieth anniversary of the college will be celebrated. An Address of Welcome will be given by Hon. WM. J. BACON, of Utica; the Historical Discourse by President FISHER, and the Jubilee Poem by Rev. Dr. KENDRICK, Professor of Greek in Rochester University. To be followed by a collation in the tent of the New-York State Agricultural Society, which has been loaned for this purpose, Thursday, July 17, will be commencement day.

abstract: in another column a brief but extraordinary article concerning Gen. MITCHEL, from the Louisville Journal; and as it is understood
lead_paragraph: in another column a brief but extraordinary article concerning Gen. MITCHEL, from the Louisville Journal; and as it is understood that on account of certain charges made by his superior officer, he had resigned his command, and that, upon notification of his resignation reaching Washington, he was summoned to that place, it is to be hoped that an immediate investigation will be made into the case, so that a gallant officer may be exculpated from insinuations and charges which, we have no doubt, are false. The statements put forth so far will astonish the public; and that they should be made, and copied and reechoed by other Western journals, will produce throughout the country a feeling of profound sorrow. The Louisville paper makes no specifications, gives no details, nor does it, nor any other of the Western journals, furnish any facts upon which a public judgment can be formed respecting the alleged delinquencies of Gen. MITCHEL. It merely speaks of his conduct in North Alabama as being "injurious to the Government and disgraceful to humanity;" that he has "perpetrated deeds of cruelty and of guilt, the bare narration of which makes the heart sick;" that "his villainous misconduct is a national calamity" -- it calls upon the Government to exercise upon him vengeance without mercy, and it applies epithets, and indulges in other strong talk, which we would not reproduce but that it has been extensively copied and has done damage in the West, and that we desire that the case may be promptly and officially settled, before the public service is further injured. No one who knows Gen. MITCHEL will place the slightest belief in the statements as they now stand. As an officer, a man, a gentleman, a savan and a conservative politician, he has been honorably known, and eminent in society and throughout the country and the world. His personal character alone is a complete shield against any imputations affecting himself individually.

abstract: -- Major Charles Clendinen died at his residence, near Point Pleasant, in Mason County, Western Virginia, a few days ago. He was 73 years old. Major Clendinen was born in the fort, or block-house, near where the town of Charleston, (Kanawha County,) now stands. He was Captain in the service of the United States in the war of 1812, and acquitted himself with much credit. He was regarded as a good disciplinarian, in consequence of which he was appointed Brigade Major in the Virginia Militia, which commission he held until the office was abolished. Major Clendinen represented his county in the councils of the State on several occasions, with credit to himself.
lead_paragraph: -- Major Charles Clendinen died at his residence, near Point Pleasant, in Mason County, Western Virginia, a few days ago. He was 73 years old. lead_paragraph: The undersigned, in assuming command of this post, orders that all officers and soldiers under his command shall pay due respect to all persons and property, any violation of which will call for severe and immediate punishment. But, whilst affording all protection to the persons and property of those living within this military district, he also requires the observance on their part of neutrality, and peaceful performance of their civil duties.

abstract: The United States vs. The Schooner Jesse J. Cox and her Cargo. This vessel was captured by the gunboat cayaga, March 25, 1862, in the Gulf of Mexico, about 200 miles out of Mobile.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Jesse J. Cox and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured by the gunboat cayaga, March 25, 1862, in the Gulf of Mexico, about 200 miles out of Mobile. No one appeared as claimant of vessel or property. The papers found on board showed that the vessel was registered at Mobile, March 17, 1862, as the property of residents of Mobile. Shipping articles were filed there for a voyage from Mobile to a place left blank. The manifest was from Mobile to Havana. Her cargo was cotton and turpentine, belonging to the owners of the vessel. She sailed from Mobile under the Confederate flag. She was taken to Ship Island after her capture, and, after appraisement, appropriated to the use of the Government. The cargo was forwarded to this port.

abstract: We have no later intelligence from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning. The supposition expressed in dispatches, yesterday, that there had been another great battle, was, doubtless, incorrect. An explanation of the announcement of Gen. McCLELLAN, that the enemy had retreated, will probably be found in the fact that the rebel army, for lack of transportation, has been forced to fall back near its base of supplies.
lead_paragraph: We have no later intelligence from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning. abstract: This subject is evidently a perplexing one to all classes. The Commercial Bulletin, of July 3, says:
lead_paragraph: This subject is evidently a perplexing one to all classes. The Commercial Bulletin, of July 3, says: "Some of our friends are quite alarmed at the apparent danger of our supplies of food being cut off by Gov. MOORE's embargo preventing receipts from the interior, and the expectation of arrivals from the West preventing shipments to this port by sea. The subject gives us no uneasiness. The scarcity will be temporary. Salt provisions of all kinds are more plentiful than they were a few weeks ago. Mess Pork, which sold at $50 to $60 per barrel, can now be had at $20. Clear Bacon Sides, which readily commanded 30c. per pound, now sells at 16c. Bacon Hams have also greatly declined.

abstract: The case of SAM, a slave claimed by Mr. LANOLES, was set down for hearing on July 1. SAM claiming to have been sold in 1858, on condition that he was to be set free in three years, but as he and his friends
lead_paragraph: The case of SAM, a slave claimed by Mr. LANOLES, was set down for hearing on July 1. SAM claiming to have been sold in 1858, on condition that he was to be set free in three years, but as he and his friends totally failed to prove that the terms of sale had been compiled with by the man who thus wished to emancipate him, he was remanded to the custody of his master.

abstract: The Shoe and Leather Bank vs. John Thompson. This is an action for libel brought by the plaintiffs against the defendant, who is publisher of Thompson's Bank Note and Commercial Reporter.
lead_paragraph: The Shoe and Leather Bank vs. John Thompson. -- This is an action for libel brought by the plaintiffs against the defendant, who is publisher of Thompson's Bank Note and Commercial Reporter. The complaint alleges that the defendant has published in his paper several items manifestly calculated to affect the plaintiffs' credit as a banking institution. Among other items published, as alleged, was the following: "We would observe to those interested that we see no reason why the Shoe and Leather Bank may not at any time be closed by an injunction." "After promising to quote the Merchants' Bank, at Trenton, I was informed that legal proceedings against the Shoe and Leather Bank were already under advisement."

abstract: GENERAL ORDER. NO. 17. The legislative power of the City of New-Orleans has heretofore been vested, by law, in a Board of Aldermen and a
lead_paragraph: GENERAL ORDER. NO. 17. -- The legislative power of the City of New-Orleans has heretofore been vested, by law, in a Board of Aldermen and a Board of Assistant Aldermen, who together formed the Common Council of the city. This power is now suspended. The seats of the Aldermen and Assistant Aldermen have all been vacated; one class of them by the expiration of their term of office, and the remainder by their neglect to take the oath of allegiance to the United States, as required by General Order No. 41 of the Commanding-General of this Department.

abstract: In the Matter of Frederick J. Conant, a Bankrupt, and on petition of Mary T. Taggard et al.--This case came up on petition to the equity jurisdiction of the Court to set aside a sale made by the General Assignee in Bankruptcy in the case. The petition was
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Frederick J. Conant, a Bankrupt, and on petition of Mary T. Taggard et al.--This case came up on petition to the equity jurisdiction of the Court to set aside a sale made by the General Assignee in Bankruptcy in the case. The petition was filed Aug. 3, 1861. It set up that a portion of the bankrupt's real estate was sold on Aug. 23, 1843, at public auction, under a decree of the Court of Chancery of the State of New-York, at which one William Taggard became the purchaser; that the deed was executed to Taggard, and that the consideration for such purchase was thereafter claimed by and paid over to W.C.H. Waddell, the General Assignee in Bankruptcy, as proceeds of the estate, and that Taggard took possession of said real estate and held it till his decease, Feb. 18, 1851; that afterwards, on Oct 15, 1858, the General Assignee, without notice to the petitioners, who are the wife and children of Taggard, sold this same property to John D. Brown, who thereupon conveyed it to Fernando Jones. The petition then prayed that this sale of Oct 15, 1858, should be set aside. The papers were served on Waddell and also on Brown and Jones, and answers were put in by them, averring that the transaction was in good faith, and denying the validity of the sale by order of the Court of Chancery, and also the title of the petitioners. The objection was first taken that by the statute this application should have been made within two years from the sale. This question was, by the District Court, adjourned to the Circuit Court, and Judge NELSON there decided that the short bar of two years mentioned in the statute did not apply, having no reference to suits growing out of the dealings of the Assignee with the property in his hands, and the case now came up for hearing in the District Court.

abstract: When, a few days after the capture of NewOrleans, a part of our fleet ascended the Mississippi River as far as Baton Rouge, and
lead_paragraph: When, a few days after the capture of NewOrleans, a part of our fleet ascended the Mississippi River as far as Baton Rouge, and took military possession of the State Capitol and the various insignia of State authority, our naval officers failed to get hold of the body of the gubernatorial functionary who, in his sacred person, represented more immediately the sovereign power of Louisiana. The Governor had skedaddled. To what spot he had wended his fugitive footsteps, no man could tell. The only thing known was that he had jumped on board of a steamboat when he heard of the approach of our fleet, and fled up the river as fast as high-pressure and pitch could carry him -- having, in his progress, ordered the steamboat's cargo of a dozen or twenty hogsheads of sugar to be thrown overboard, so that nothing might impede his getting safely away from the naval furies whom he imagined to be in pursuit. This unheroical flight from his capital, without an effort to defend it, furnished such a piece of practical ridicule on all his previous heroics, that for over two months, or ever since the close of last April, he has kept himself hid from public view. His own subjects and slaves knew not where he was; and even Gen. BEN. BUTLER, who knew almost everything else, was in the dark on this point. The fugitive Governor has at last been found out -- discovered by a proclamation addressed "to the people of Louisiana," and dated from the town of Opelousas, close to Crocodile Bayou, and upwards of two hundred miles nearer to Mexico than the city of New-Orleans. This much at least is gained: the citizens of his own State, and mankind generally, know where Gov. MOORE is. It must have been very discreditable to his dignity, as well as prejudicial to his authority, to have remained so long hid away; but whether his being found out will add to his dignity or restore his jurisdiction, remains to be seen. One thing is sure, he has at least got beyond reach of those gunboats which erst so terrified him at Baton Rouge.

abstract: The Citizens of New-York, of all parties, who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war and the suppression of the rebellion, are requested to meet on Union-square, on
lead_paragraph: The Citizens of New-York, of all parties, who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war and the suppression of the rebellion, are requested to meet on Union-square, on Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to express, without reference to any party question whatever, their undiminished confidence in the justice of our cause, and their inflexible purpose to maintain it to the end, and to proffer to the Government all the aid it may need to the extent of all their resources.

abstract: -- The importance of the advance of Gen. HATCH to Culpepper Courthouse will be seen at a glance. We judge this is the initiatory movement of Gen. POPE, who it will be remembered, is authorized to operate against Richmond. A movement a little further south to Gordonsville will prevent all danger to the Valley of Virginia and to Washington, while it will menace the rebel Capital from a capital point. We look for rapid and dashing operations from Gen. POPE, now that he has gathered his scattered forces. If he could but "bag" the entire rebel army!

lead_paragraph: Of the sick and wounded soldiers who arrived here last evening from the Peninsula upon the Empire State, from Fortress Monroe, one hundred and twenty-five were placed on a tug and landed at the foot of Montague-street, and by means of litters and a Massachusetts ambulance, immediately transferred to the Long Island College Hospital, on Henry, near Pacific-street. The boat landed at about 6 o'clock P.M., and the Trustees of the College only had ten minutes notice, and then it was only to provide for ninety-six, but so complete were the arrangements of the Hospital, and so zealous were all connected with it and other citizens to do for the soldiers, that by 10 3/4 o'clock P.M., the whole 125 had been supplied with medical aid, food, and in many instances clothing, and these noble fellows, for the first time in many weeks, were prepared to take a comfortable night's rest.

abstract: Editorial links Lyons return to England to Parliament declaration of non-intervention; Editorial on planned pro-Union meeting, NYC; Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Editorial links Lyons return to England to Parliament declaration of non-intervention; Editorial on planned pro-Union meeting, NYC; Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: -- It isdeserving of notice that the late emphatic declarations in the British Parliament against intervention, are coincident with the arrival of Lord LYONS in England. We ventured to predict, at the time of his departure, that the visit of the British Ambassador would work important changes in the ideas of his Government with regard to American affairs. The anticipation is fully realized. Since then the official spokesmen in both Houses of Parliament -- Earl RUSSELL in the Lords and Lord PALMERSTON in the Commons -- have, on several occasions, made emphatic declarations against any interference in the issue of our civil war. And what is really notable in these later declarations is, that they rest on much higher grounds than those that formerly came from the same sources. When Lord PALMERSTON, on the 30th ult., was asked by Mr. HOPWOOD, "whether the Government intended to take any steps to endeavor to put an end to the civil war in America," he not only stated that they had no such intention, but added the significant remark, that the House must see that "any interference could only tend to the aggravation of the sufferings of those who were now experiencing such great privations."

abstract: -- The Herald is trying its best to get up a great scare about an iron-clad Merrimac number two, which the rebels have at Richmond, and which is "in a few days to make a raid upon our gunboats." It happens that there are obstructions in the James River between Richmond and our gunboats -- obstructions which, according to the testimony of the engineers, it would take weeks to clear away. The hero of Plum Gut forgets that when the James is opened for Merrimac number two to come down, it will also be opened for our iron-clads to go up.

abstract: The great want of the country now is armed men. Every man who can possibly leave his affairs, and who has no family dependent on him, should now shoulder his musket and
lead_paragraph: The great want of the country now is armed men. Every man who can possibly leave his affairs, and who has no family dependent on him, should now shoulder his musket and come forward to save the Republic. There is no use in disguising the danger. The rebels have pulled the last cord; they have made a levy en masse; they have utterly exhausted their country in raising the immense army before Richmond; for, wise in their generation, they know that within three months it will be decided in battle whether the American Union is still sound and vigorous, or is a thing of the past. In courage and skill, there is little difference between the combatants. The great distinction will be in the number of men at vital points. If we can gather 200,000 effective, drilled men at Richmond before next Autumn, we shall break the Confederacy; if not, they break us, or plunge us into unknown years of useless warfare.

lead_paragraph: -- The press of the bounteous CARLETON favors us with Our Flag, a poem tn four Cantos, by T. H. UNDERWOOD. The author of this tragic-heroic Poem has attained some celebrity among us as a political speaker and writer of the Southern Anti-Slavery School. On the rostrum, he is impassioned and eloquent; at the counsel table he is said to be firm, deliberate and far sighted; beside the Heliconian Spring we find him uniting all these gifts with a brilliant imagination and infinite fervor and pathos.

abstract: In the Senate,on Saturday, proceedings were commenced with an Executive session. When the doors were opened, the resolution declaring the meaning of the act authorizing the President  to take possession of all the railroads and tele
lead_paragraph: In the Senate,on Saturday, proceedings were commenced with an Executive session. When the doors were opened, the resolution declaring the meaning of the act authorizing the President to take possession of all the railroads and telegraph lines, was passed. It was subsequently passed in the House. The report of the Committee of Conference on the Confiscation bill was concurred in, after some opposition, 27 to 13, and the bill therefore stands passed in both houses. The report of the Conference Committee on the bill changing certain judicial districts, was concurred in. The House bill to prevent the imprisonment of soldiers in the penitentiaries, excepting for certain criminal offences, was passed. The resolution requesting the President to have prepared a statement of the trade and commerce of California, Oregon and Washington Territory, was adopted. The bill providing for the election of Representatives in Congress by single districts, was passed. The resolution in relation to the number of Senators constituting a quorum, was debated at considerable length, and its consideration was finally postponed until Monday. A resolution fixing the time for adjournment on Wednesday, the 16th, was reported from the Committee on Finance, and agreed to by 29 to 10. The bill providing for the extension of the Territory of Nevada was passed. At 5 o'clock a recess was taken until 7. The bill providing for the better security of passengers on steamboats, was passed. After an Executive session, the Senate then adjourned.

abstract: -- The Editor of this paper was waited upon on Saturday by a gentleman desiring to have his attention directed to some recruiting officer whose honesty and energy could be properly warranted. He only needed to have these qualities verified to justify himself in placing $300 in the hands of the officer, to be used in procuring recruits for the Union army. It was our good fortune to be able to point out a perfectly safe trustee of this patriotic charity; and it will at once do its beneficent work.

abstract: "A party of scouts from this brigade, when near Bealstown, a few days since, captured two secession soldiers; at least, the two prisoners gave themselves up to our men. They stated that they left Richmond
lead_paragraph: "A party of scouts from this brigade, when near Bealstown, a few days since, captured two secession soldiers; at least, the two prisoners gave themselves up to our men. They stated that they left Richmond some four weeks since. One of them, an Irishman, but from Missouri, was a marine in the Confederate service, and has been present at a number of the bombardments in the South. He was also in the Merrimac in her encounter with the Monitor. He is a very intelligent man, and relates much of interest concerning the Southern movements. He says that the force of rebel soldiers in and around Richmond is very heavy; that the rebel leaders feel the great importance of holding their capital, and that they are using every means to make themselves successful.

abstract: The Union meeting called for Tuesday at Union-square, offers some important and suggestive differences from that held in the same place a year ago last April. The hurricane of
lead_paragraph: The Union meeting called for Tuesday at Union-square, offers some important and suggestive differences from that held in the same place a year ago last April. The hurricane of indignation, horror, and wrath, which swept over the North upon the fall of Sumter, was as much an explosion of passion as of patriotism. Men of all creeds and parties and antecedents were equally carried away by the wrong done the flag, and the danger brought by bad men upon the Union; and all hastened to the great Union rally, to find in the mouth of some one the expression of the overheated sentiments for which themselves could find no utterance. It was possible for a man to have taken a fervent and even enthusiastic part in the meeting of April, 1861, without a spark of true and generous patriotism kindling in his heart. This has been capitally proved by several who took part in the late meeting at Cooper Institute -- a gathering expressly intended to neutralize the expiring effect of the impulse given the popular heart a twelvemonth and more ago.
headline: {'main': 'The Meeting To-Morrow Night.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Meeting To-Morrow Night.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Military hospitals in NY described
snippet: Military hospitals in NY described
lead_paragraph: The Ladies' Home for Sick and Wounded Soldiers, situated on the corner of Lexington-avenue and Ffty-first-street, has been in operation about two months. The dedication of the place to its present philanthropic use was made on the 2d of last May, in the presence of a large number of ladies, the Mayor, the Common Council, and many prominent citizens. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and made one of his happiest speeches on the occasion.

abstract: Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL played "Fanchon, the Cricket," every night for a month--a remarkable, if not an unprecedented thing for a star to do, with a by no means powerful drama of French extraction.
lead_paragraph: Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL played "Fanchon, the Cricket," every night for a month -- a remarkable, if not an unprecedented thing for a star to do, with a by no means powerful drama of French extraction. Since the completion of the month, it has been repeated twice by special request; and, judging from the audience it drew on Thursday, it will most likely be done again before this week is through. Of course the success of the piece is due to the strikingly original performance of the character of the heroine by Miss MITCHELL. It is so seldom we come across an actress who has individuality and unconventional intelligence, that when one suddenly drops upon the stage before us, we feel like cherishing the rara avis, and making as much of it as we can. It was the secret of MATILDA HERON's triumph. It is the secret of Miss MITCHELL's. More finished actresses than they are plenty -- actresses who have achieved the dead level of mechanical perfection; but whilst these never rise above that level, and can only have their talents recognized as a necessary contribution to a good stock company, one spark of originality, of genius, gives its possessor the right to rank as a star, and to receive a certain amount of popular support, on his or her own merits, even though unassisted by any company worth mentioning. The most surprising circumstance about Miss MITCHELL's relations with the public is that she should have remained so long contented with the plaudits of provincial crowds, when she unquestionably had it in her power to make a Metropolitan reputation. Henceforth it is to be hoped she will visit New-York with frequent regularity.

abstract: Of the sick and wounded soldiers who arrived here last evening from the Peninsula upon the Empire State, from Fortress Monroe, one hundred and twenty-five were placed on a tug and landed at the foot of Montague-street, and by means of litters and a Massachusetts ambulance, immediately tranferred to the Long Island College Hospital, on Henry, near Pacific-street. The boat landed at about 6 o'clock
lead_paragraph: Of the sick and wounded soldiers who arrived here last evening from the Peninsula upon the Empire State, from Fortress Monroe, one hundred and twenty-five were placed on a tug and landed at the foot of Montague-street, and by means of litters and a Massachusetts ambulance, immediately tranferred to the Long Island College Hospital, on Henry, near Pacific-street. The boat landed at about 6 o'clock P.M., and the Trustees of the College only had ten minutes' notice, and then it was only to provide for ninety-six, but so complete were the arrangements of the Hospital, and so zealous were all connected with it and other citizens to do for the soldiers, that by 10 3/4 o'clock P.M., the whole 125 had been supplied with medical aid, food, and in many instances clothing, and these noble fellows, for the first time in many weeks, were prepared to take a comfortable night's rest.

abstract: Capt. E. GEORGE BREWSTER, of Company C, First Regiment New-Jersey Volunteers, who fell at the battle of Gaines' Mill, Va., on Friday, June 27, deserves more than an ordinary passing notice. A direct descendant of Elder BREWSTER, of the Mayflower, he inherited a love of country, a devotion to the Union, a high regard for things sacred and noble common to few. Capt. BREWSTER was a native of Scio, Allegheny County, New-York, where in his boyhood days he was beloved for his gentle, kind and amiable qualities of heart. As a graduate of the Alfred Academy, for meritorious attainments, he had few superiors. As the years of his boyhood rolled away he went to New-York City, where he for several years occupied a very honorable position in a prominent mercantile house, whose confidence he ever enjoyed; but the troublous times of 1857 and '58 caused revulsions and changes in business, which brought Capt. BREWSTER into the establishment of the Messrs. SCRANTON, at Oxford Furnace, N.J., at which place he resided when the first call for troops was issued. Capt. BREWSTER at once enlisted as a soldier in a company organized at Oxford Furnace, under command of Capt. ROBERT MCALLISTER, now Lieutenant-Colonel of the First New-Jersey, and the company proceeded to Trenton, N.J.; but although this company had been nominally accepted, they, with two others from the same County, (Warren,) could not go in Gen. RUNYON's Brigade, as it had already forty companies. The company, after remaining at Trenton a few days, was disbanded, and the soldiers honorably discharged, many of them going to other States and enlisting. Capt. BREWSTER and a few others, waiting for another call for troops, which soon followed, joined Company C, First Regiment. New-Jersey Volunteers, of which he was made Sergeant, and soon after promoted to a lieutenancy: and upon the promotion of Capt. WM. BIRNEY to the Majority of the Fourth New-Jersey Volunteers, he was unanimously chosen Captain. Possessing an ardent nature, a generous soul, and a tall, commanding form, he carried an enthusiasm into the ranks such as few men can excite; the writer of this once heard his General remark before a large party of officers that he considered Captain BREWSTER one of the finest line officers in the brigade. That he gave his services and his life to his country from high and noble convictions of duty, there is not a doubt. A large circle of relatives and friends mourn their early loss; it is not known that he ever had a single enemy.

abstract: The gentler sex cannot well mow hay, shoe horses and build fences; but they can milk cows, feed chickens and keep the farm-yard in order. They cannot be expected to handle
lead_paragraph: The gentler sex cannot well mow hay, shoe horses and build fences; but they can milk cows, feed chickens and keep the farm-yard in order. They cannot be expected to handle the musket, camp out in swamps, or shoot rebels; but they are entirely equal to the task of handling laces and ribbons, and selling needles and pins. In a time of war like the present, no man should be found doing work which can be readily and properly performed by a woman. There is a double reason for this assumption; for not only does the female substitute release another soldier to fight for his country, but there are hundreds of the wives and sisters of men already fighting or slain who would gladly earn bread for themselves and little ones behind the counters which men now exclude them from. There are thousands of putty-faced, dainty-fingered gentry in our large cities who should forget the mysteries of silks and muslins for a while, to grow familiar with knapsacks and bayonets. There have been times of great emergency, in European cities, when masculine venders of feathers and frippery have been hooted from their shops, and forced to take up the musket. As a consequence of pressing military necessity, far more women find employment in selling dry goods and lighter wares, in the Old World, than with ourselves. It is rare in passing through a Parisian Boulevard or Passage to see males serving in the shops; in a country like ours, where there is so much for strong hands to do, and so little for feebler ones, it should be still rarer. Even in time of peace the system of exclusively employing men in retail shops is objectionable enough; but in time of war, and such a war as that which now threatens our National existence, such a system becomes a distinct nuisance and should be abated. A reform should be effected in this matter, and there will be no time more favorable than this to inaugurate it. Many a husband, son and brother will fall in the existing struggle, leaving females behind partly or wholly unprovided for. Whenever a clerk or other employe now enters the army or navy, the niche should be promptly filled by a woman. In nine cases out of ten, the females, after a little experience, will do the work quite as well as the males, and the public interest will unquestionably be promoted by the measure. Moreover, the interests of employers will ultimately be furthered by the change, for if women do less work, they are paid by lower wages; and it is only a fair tribute to the gentle sex to acknowledge that it has been satisfactorily demonstrated that, as shop-tenders and receivers of money generally, their average integrity is superior to that of the men. Thousands of dollars, in goods and cash, are yearly absorbed by dishonest clerks and shopmen, to be used in purchasing gratifications which have no temptation for women. Now that taxation is to become heavier than we have ever known it, this consideration of itself is a highly important one. Another point which addresses itself to the thoughtful and humane, lies in the obvious circumstance that the more we multiply the avenues for female employment, the more we reduce excuses for the cancerous "social evils," that problem which is so universal and so difficult of solution.

abstract: TLES.--We learn from the Richmond papers some facts in relation to the late battles,from which we draw conclusions of interest. The
lead_paragraph: TLES. -- We learn from the Richmond papers some facts in relation to the late battles,from which we draw conclusions of interest. The Richmond Examiner, for instance, complains of the lack of attention to the wounded, and declares that "the houses prepared for hospitals were not capable of accommodating one-fourth of those requiring attention." Now, the rebel authorities knew the number of their soldiers and the number of ours. They have had experience in such things, and whatever complaint we have had to make against them for neglect of our wounded, this is the first we have heard of their neglecting their own. The conclusion which we draw from it is, that their loss was very largely in excess of what they had anticipated; and if we estimated our wounded in advance at 15,000, without knowing how many troops the rebels had to fight us, they could hardly have estimated theirs at less. Four times 15,000 are 60,000; but we can hardly believe that there was any such result as that.

abstract: Major MALLORY, of the Harris Light Cavalry -- one of the best cavalry regiments in the service -- is now in this City on recruiting duty. The "Harris Light" has seen considerable service since the war commenced, and has earned an enviable reputation for discipline, honesty and sobriety in camp, as it has for valor on the field. Col. DAVIS, the present commanded, was one of the first volunteers in response to the President's, proclamation, going from this City as Mayor of DURYEA's Zouaves -- which regiment he assisted materially in raising and organizing -- and taking [???] in the action of Big Bethel. The headquarters of the recruiting-officer for the regiment are at No. [???] Broadway.

abstract: The Citizens of New-York, of all parties, who are for supporting the Government in the prosecution of the war and the suppression of the rebellion, are requested to meet on Union-square, on Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to express, without reference to any party question whatever, their undiminished confidence in the justice of our cause, and their inflexible purpose to maintain it to the end, and to proffer to the Government all the aid it may need to the extent of all their resources.

abstract: Henrietta Hofheimer vs. John Moette. This was an action to recover damages to the amount of $500. The complaint alleged that on the 5th of June last the defendant besmeared the plaintiff with soft soap, and used abusive language toward her. The defence was a general denial of the plaintiffs' charges, and a counter allegation that the plaintid provoked his conduct, such as it was, by sweeping dust on the defendant's head.

abstract: [???] The eleven-million swindle, known as the Corwin Treaty with Mexico, has been moved to the table of the Senate. There it will, of course, He in eternal slumber. What new direction the energies of those who devised that scheme of public theft may take. It is impossible to conjecture; but we venture to say the wants and woes of Mexico will no longer be used as a pretext. Twice tried and twice defeated, the attempts of these gentlemen upon the public treasury must seek some better disguise. Besides, Mr. SIMMONS, of Rhode Island, is no longer at their service.

abstract: -- A Washington correspondent of the Boston Traveller writes: "Ben. Wood will escape from the Judiciary Committee without serious damage. Ben, is a sharp fellow and has not been blundering. The attempt was made to prove that he had been trying to communicate with Richmond, and a witness, if I do not mistake, swore point blank that Ben, desired to make an arrangement with him to go down to the rebel capital. What does the honorable member do but go to work and prove that the witness has been guilty (convicted I think,) of forgery, and that nobody has any business to believe him under oath. About the worst thing done by Wood was to circulate his treasonable speech, which he did North and South.'
lead_paragraph: -- A Washington correspondent of the Boston Traveller writes: "Ben. Wood will escape from the Judiciary Committee without serious damage. Ben, is a sharp fellow and has not been blundering. The attempt was made to prove that he had been trying to communicate with Richmond, and a witness, if I do not mistake, swore point blank that Ben, desired to make an arrangement with him to go down to the rebel capital. What does the honorable member do but go to work and prove that the witness has been guilty (convicted I think,) of forgery, and that nobody has any business to believe him under oath. About the worst thing done by Wood was to circulate his treasonable speech, which he did North and South.'

abstract: Response to call for troops in Eastern states
snippet: Response to call for troops in Eastern states
lead_paragraph: Col. FRANK E. HOWE, Military Agent of the State of Vermont, yesterday received a telegram from the Governor of Vermont, informing him that the Ninth Vermont Regiment, raised in pursuance of the new call by the Government, was about proceeding to the seat of war. This regiment is commanded by Col. GEORGE J. STONNARD, of St. Albans, and will arrive here to-morrow morning. Col. HOWE made immediate arrangements for their proper reception, and our citizens will see that this, the first regiment of the new levy to march through our City, will meet with a cordial greeting.

abstract: A THEFT OF $4OO WORTH OF DIAMOND RINGS.  Mr. JOHN GEORGE, of No.5 Carroll-place, Bleeckerstreet, appeared before Justice OSBORNS, yesterday, and made complaint against Sarah J. Adams, Ann Adams, Margaret Gleeson and John Scott, who are charged with purloining two diamond cluster rings, of the value of $400, from the wife of the complain, ant, on Sunday evening.
lead_paragraph: A THEFT OF $4OO WORTH OF DIAMOND RINGS. -- Mr. JOHN GEORGE, of No.5 Carroll-place, Bleeckerstreet, appeared before Justice OSBORNS, yesterday, and made complaint against Sarah J. Adams, Ann Adams, Margaret Gleeson and John Scott, who are charged with purloining two diamond cluster rings, of the value of $400, from the wife of the complain, ant, on Sunday evening. The facts of the case, as they transpired upon the investigation before the magistrate yesterday, may be briefly stated as follows: The complainant's wife, Mrs. GEORGE, was out walking with her son, a lad aged about seven years, when she encountered SARAH J. ADAMS, one of the prisoners, who importuned her to call at the house of her sister, in Marlon-street, and rest herself. While Mrs. G. was there, she was presented with a glass of wine, a portion of which she drank. Soon after she fell into a state of stupor, so profound that all the efforts of her little son to arouse her were unavailing. During the time she was in this condition the prisoner, SARAH J. ADAMS, took the two diamond cluster rings, above mentioned, from Mrs. GEORGE's fingers, placed them upon her own, and in a few minutes afterward, left the house with two or the other prisoners. The lad immediately followed, and, although he ran as fast as possible, he could not keep up with the parties, and for the time they escaped. Yesterday, however, all the persons thought to be implicated in the theft, were arrested by Officer FARLEY, of the Fourteenth Precinct, and committed for examination. The rings have not yet been recovered.

abstract: Immediately after the publication of Maj.-Gen. HALLECE's dispatch to the Secretary of War, attributing the victory at Pittsburgh Landing chiefly to the determined bravery and energy of Gen. SHERMAN, a movement was set on foot in this City by Wm. SCOTT, Esq., of No. 111 Wall-street, to collect funds for the presentation of a testimonial to the gallant soldier, in
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the publication of Maj.-Gen. HALLECE's dispatch to the Secretary of War, attributing the victory at Pittsburgh Landing chiefly to the determined bravery and energy of Gen. SHERMAN, a movement was set on foot in this City by Wm. SCOTT, Esq., of No. 111 Wall-street, to collect funds for the presentation of a testimonial to the gallant soldier, in token of the appreciation in which his gallant services were held by the citizens of the Metropolis. So general and earnest was the feeling of admiration for the conduct of Gen. SHERMAN during the trying days of Shiloh, that in a few hours after the effort to raise the money had been commenced, the entire sum was subscribed, and an order was given to Messrs. TIFFANY & Co. to prepare the sword which has just been completed, and of which the following is a brief description:

abstract: text of newly revised bill
snippet: text of newly revised bill
lead_paragraph: Lord BROUGHAM rose to call attention to the civil war now raging in America, in the horrors of which, according to information which he had received from persons who were most friendly to our kinsmen across the Atlantic, surpassed anything which had been made public. It appeared that not only were thousands of men embattled on either side, and displaying a courage and a conduct which were above all commendation, but the war had taken root in every rank of life, and all the evils of a civil contest were experienced in their greatest intensity. The inhabitants of the same village were banded against each other, and neighboring farmers and proprietors daily armed themselves and went forth, not to fight in their armies, but to carry on a sort of private warfare, and to gratify their feelings of animosity or revenge. In private families, where a difference of opinion as to the war prevailed, the most intense animosity existed, and was avowed almost without shame. He knew one instance of a respectable family in which the son said he hoped to hear of his father's death, because they had taken opposite sides. He threw out no imputation on the character of the American people. Proverbially, the corruption of the best was always worst, and a dispute among near relatives was always excessively bitter. But although the war might be explained, it could not be justified or even extenuated. It was clear that neither the Government of France nor that of England could interfere in the quarrel. [Hear, hear.] But at the same time every one was anxious that these horrors should cease, and those who most fervently cherished that desire were those who had always been most friendly to the Americans. For upward of sixty years he had been known as a warm advocate at all times of the American Government and the American people. Some might recollect that he was once called the partisan of JEFFERSON and the Attorney-General of MADISON. Others, too, who had uniformly taken the part of the Americans were now most cruelly shocked and disappointed by the present course of events. If the civil war continued they would be bound to admit that the worst stain on the American character was not domestic Slavery. The white men had suffered more in the war than ever did the negroes under the most cruel of their masters. The present strife was doing more mischief, creating more misery, and laying the foundation of more lasting animosity even than slavery. If the Americans would only listen to the voice of their true friends they would, if they regarded the continuance of their reputation in their country and of our affection toward them, see the absolute necessity of putting an end to this horrible war. He could not for his life believe that the good sense of those among the Americans who were better informed and capable of calm reflection, would not, sooner or later, be exerted to put a stop to this calamitous quarrel. [Hear, hear.]

lead_paragraph: We have no heart to make a mock of aught Lord BROUGHAM says on American affairs. HENRY BROUGHAM has earned the kindly good-will of Americans by too long a life of friendly service and appreciation for us to have anything else but patience with him, now that his natural strength fails him, and he is given to saying very foolish and feeble things about us. But it is a painful spectacle, nevertheless. The war in the United States has become his bete noir; with senile loquacity be speaks now about every day on the subject, in season and out of season, without any apparent practical object, and only to "have his say." Each time, too, he grows more foolish and more feeble; but perhaps he reached the climax of these qualities in his latest utterance in the House of Lords, on the 1st of July. "It appeared," he said, "that not only were thousands of men in the United States embattled on either side, and displaying a courage and a conduct which were above all commendation, but the war had taken root in every rank of life, and all the evils of a civil contest were being experienced in the greatest intensity. The inhabitants of the same village were banded against each other, and neighboring farmers and proprietors daily armed themselves and went forth, not to fight in their armies, but to carry on a sort of private warfare and to gratify their feelings of animosity or revenge!" Such, he says, is the information which he gets "from persons who are most friendly to our kinsmen across the Atlantic." The wild fiction is not worth a moment's notice, except as showing into what idiotic drivel a noble mind can sink in its dotage. The erst robust HARRY BROUGHAM, the champion of freedom and progress, is now little else than

abstract: The preparations for the meeting this afternoon have been pressed with so much zeal, that not only is there a certainty of a vast attendance of hearers, but of speakers, strong in number, character and eloquence, to animate and gratify the largest gathering.
lead_paragraph: The preparations for the meeting this afternoon have been pressed with so much zeal, that not only is there a certainty of a vast attendance of hearers, but of speakers, strong in number, character and eloquence, to animate and gratify the largest gathering. All classes, professions and ages will be present. It is expected the pupils of the public schools -- beneficent little heroes, whose alms have comforted thousands of suffering soldiers -- will march to the ground by thousands. The Fire Department and the resident military will be represented. What, with the general closing of the stores, and the ardent patriotic movement of the citizens, New-York will present to the country to-day the spectacle of a mighty population leaving all personal interests and considerations behind, and hastening to aid in the work of saving and restoring the Union.

abstract: under the new requisition, bound for the seat of war, will pass through this City to-morrow morning. The regiment is from the hills of Vermont -- the men such as those who passed through New-York. with green sprigs in their caps, a year ago. Since then those hardy fellows have smelt gunpowder and have tasted battle; and on every field have borne themselves with a heroism and a fortitude worthy of their glorious State. Their comrades now rush to the rescue; and with none the less alacrity because their aid is so greatly needed, and the work they have to achieve will call forth so much of their native spirit. Had the regiment arrived here but one day earlier, so as to be present at the great Union meeting, it would have given an impetus to volunteering, though it might have made New-York ashamed of herself. Where are our volunteers under the new call? Let there be at least one, if not ten, regiments in uniform by to-night to greet the Vermonters to-morrow morning.

abstract: A fete of proportions nearly equal to that at Jones' Wood, was held yesterday in Leveridge Park near Brooklyn, by the Washington Aid Society for the Sick, No. 1. A procession of societies started at 8 A.M. from OLTMANN's Hall, on the corner of Graham-avenue and McKibbin-street, and proceeded through many neighboring streets to the beautiful wood known by the name given above. The Venus Verein of the Sons of Herrmann; the Schuhmacher Verein; the Zoellner Maennerchor, of Williamsburgh, and the Harmonta Gesangverein, of East New-York, participated, and the day was spent in the most agreeable manner, with musical and other entertainments, yielding a handsome sum to the funds of the German Hospital. The Committee of Arrangements consisted of Messrs. G. Herrbruck, K. Ringsdorf, F. Tay, A. Weber, A. Wetterer, J. Johann, H. Claus, and H. Kuechler, Secretary.

abstract: Congress has taken a very important step in the passage of the Act of Confiscation. That it will promptly receive the President's approval, we cannot doubt.
lead_paragraph: Congress has taken a very important step in the passage of the Act of Confiscation. That it will promptly receive the President's approval, we cannot doubt. And we are equally confident that it will contribute very essentially, by its moral effect as well as its practical operation, to destroy rebellion in the Southern States.

abstract: Gen. GRANT has issued an order requiring the families of all persons connected with the Confederate army or Government to leave the city within five days, or take an oath that they have not, and will not furnish information to the enemy. This sweeping order is in consequence of constant communication between persons in the rebel army and friends here. This order causes considerable excitement.

abstract: -- Our correspondent at Port Royal sends us the official report of Gen. STEVENS, in regard to the disaster at Secessionville. From that document and the highly interesting memorandum which accompanies it, the reader will learn that Gen. STEVENS denies, emphatically, two points which have been urged in defence of Gen. BENHAM in ordering the attack. One was, that the Council of War held before the battle, was unanimously favorable to the project. This, Gen. STEVENS produces the vouchers of Gens. WILLIAMS and WRIGHT, strengthened by his own word, to refute. All three of the general officers with whom Gen. BENHAM advised, believed that, until the heavy batteries had made an impression upon the enemy's works, an attack would be suicidal, as it proved. The other point was, that Gen. STEVENS' neglect to make the assault at the time prearranged, rendered the attempt abortive. Gen STEVENS is very specific in disproving this assertion, giving the exact time of each of his movements, and showing them to have anticipated the periods predetermined by BENHAM.
lead_paragraph: -- Our correspondent at Port Royal sends us the official report of Gen. STEVENS, in regard to the disaster at Secessionville. From that document and the highly interesting memorandum which accompanies it, the reader will learn that Gen. STEVENS denies, emphatically, two points which have been urged in defence of Gen. BENHAM in ordering the attack. One was, that the Council of War held before the battle, was unanimously favorable to the project. This, Gen. STEVENS produces the vouchers of Gens. WILLIAMS and WRIGHT, strengthened by his own word, to refute. All three of the general officers with whom Gen. BENHAM advised, believed that, until the heavy batteries had made an impression upon the enemy's works, an attack would be suicidal, as it proved. The other point was, that Gen. STEVENS' neglect to make the assault at the time prearranged, rendered the attempt abortive. Gen STEVENS is very specific in disproving this assertion, giving the exact time of each of his movements, and showing them to have anticipated the periods predetermined by BENHAM.

abstract: -- It is a curious evidence of the recklessness with which public money is squandered at Washington, the report of the House Committee on the extension of the Treasury building. That an architectural horror was rising before the eyes of the nation would seem to be a sufficient invitation to protest and inquiry. Not, however, until Mr. WALL, the member for the Williamsburgh District, moved an investigation, was it found that the men who contrived and superintended the work were not architects, or engineers, or otherwise professionally prepared for their office; that parts were put together without any regard to permanency or security; and that what is likely to cost $5,000,000 might have been readily accomplished for $1,000,000. The probability now is, the whole mass of costly masonry will have to he removed and the Druidical task done afresh.
lead_paragraph: -- It is a curious evidence of the recklessness with which public money is squandered at Washington, the report of the House Committee on the extension of the Treasury building. lead_paragraph: WAR MEETING IN JERSEY CITY. -- A mass meeting of patriotic citizens has been called, to be held at the City Hall, Jersey City, on Wednesday evening, for the purpose of adopting such measures as will enable the city to response a new to the call of the Government. Several distinguished speakers have been engaged, and the interest taken by the citizens promises a large and enthusiastic gathering. The follow ing address has been issued to people by the Commitiee:

abstract: Nervous people will be good enough not to be unduly agitated by the story which comes to us, by way of Mobile and Richmond, to the effect that Gen. VAN DORN has succeeded in distinguishing himself by recapturing Baton Rouge, with fifteen hundred of our troops. For one thing, the General in question would be too anxious to wipe out the memory of the drubbing which he received at Pea Ridge, at the hands of Gen. CURTIS, to allow intelligence of such an important success to linger on its way to Richmond long enough to make it necessary for it to pass through New-Orleans. Then, too, our dates from New-Orleans direct are to July 4, when Gen. BUTLER had just returned from a trip to Baton Rouge to look after its defences, and to assure the citizens that he was determined to hold it at all hazards. VAN DORN's attack, if he made one, must have taken place the very day after Gen. BUTLER left the State Capital, and then there would hardly have been time for the story of its result to have reached New-Orleans, so as to be carried to Mobile by the flag of truce boat referred to. Once before, it will be remembered, this identical story came to us in this very same shape, and for a few days people were made uncomfortable by the reflection that fifteen hundred prisoners had been added to the rebel stock in trade. Before becoming unhappy over this last announcement, it will be well to await another arrival from New-Orleans direct.

Once before, it will be remembered, this identical story came to us in this very same shape, and for a few days people were made uncomfortable by the reflection that fifteen hundred prisoners had been added to the rebel stock in trade. Before becoming unhappy over this last announcement, it will be well to await another arrival from New-Orleans direct.

abstract: The country has approved, with unexampled unanimity, the proposition of President LINCOLN in regard to gradual emancipation in the slaveholding States.
lead_paragraph: The country has approved, with unexampled unanimity, the proposition of President LINCOLN in regard to gradual emancipation in the slaveholding States. The proposed cooperation of the National Government with the States removed all objections founded on the doctrine of State rights; while the offer of compensation to owners saved individual rights. The further proposition to colonize the liberated slaves, who might be desirous to found a nationalty of their own, meets the views of many statesmen, as well as the prejudices of the masses. Taken as the first step toward the removal of the gigantic evil of our political and social system, the President's policy is a master-stroke of wisdom, humanity and statesmanship.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the vote of thanks to Commodore FOOTE was passed. The bill for the admission of Western Virginia as a State was taken up, debated at considerable length, and passed. The bill as passed provides that all slaves born within the limits of the State after the 4th of July, 1863, shall be free. The House bill to prevent the fraudulent sale or use of postage stamps was passed. The bill requiring commanders of American vessels sailing from foreign ports to take the oath of allegiance was passed. A report of the Conference Committee on the bill for the better government of the navy was agreed to. The resolution relating to the law of prizes, providing that returns of money from the sale of prizes shall be paid into the Treasury within twenty days, was passed. The resolution for the expulsion of Senator SIMMONS was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with no recommendation. Mr. WILSON called up the bill amending the Militia Act of 1795, and offered a substitute for it, when the Senate took a recess until 7 o'clock.

abstract: The steam transport Haze, Capt. CLIFT, arrived yesterday morning from Harrison's Bar, the headquarters of Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, whence she sailed on Friday afternoon last. She arrived at Harrison's Bar on the 5th inst., and remained nearly a week. She took out a large cargo of war material, including ordnance and rifles, and sixty tons of fixed ammunition.

abstract: on meeting acting as stimulus for volunteers
snippet: on meeting acting as stimulus for volunteers
lead_paragraph: A practical result of the great Union meeting to-day would be that it should act as a direct and immediate stimulus to volunteering. When the patriotism and enthusiasm of the people are raised high by the display of the sacred emblem of our country, by the power of eloquence and music, and by the magnetism of numbers, then is the time that the feeling rises in the bosom of every generous and gallant man, that for such a country and cause, life itself, or a hundred lives, were all too poor a sacrifice. The Republic has not yet lost the power to attract the love of its sons; Freedom is still a word to conjure with, and an idea dear to every true American; the "Union" has lost none of its charms because of the assaults made upon it by rebels; and the waving of the Star-Splangled Banner still stirs the heart of youth and age -- of the stemer sex as of the fair. When these things are held up before the assembled multitude of citizens, and when it is seen that they are all menaced and endangered by the traitorous minions, of JEFF. DAVIS, then it is that tens of thousands will rush to arms for their defence.

abstract: The scarcity of silver continues unabated, and the talk of the City is still on change. One-half of the community spends its time in searching out, and hurling its anathemas against, the authors of the panic, and the other half in devising means for remedying the evil. From the former, the railroad companies and brokers get the largest share of the curses; and from the latter, the people at large get all manner of shinplasters and every variety of plausible substitute for silver. Postage stamps continue to be advocated by many, and in order to avoid the objections urged against them, the firm of LEEDS & FRANKLIN, No. 112 Broadway, have invented what they call mounted stamps, which they sell at 2 1/2 per cent. premium for sums less than $100, or 1 per cent. for sums of $1,000 and upward. These stamps are inserted in inclosed cards, with raised rims around the edge of each stamp, which effectually protects them from wear and tear, and make them very convenient to handle. If no better substitute can be had than postage stamps, this will prove a very useful contrivance. Many dealers have adopted the plan of discounting on the price of the goods purchased, the amount of the current premium, if paid [???] and charging the same premium when they are required to change a bill. This, certainty, is [???] all dealers to adopt the plan, purchasers would not suffer by the arrangement; but if a person is obliged to pay a premium for silver to a dealer in dry goods, and then has to pay the same out to the grocery man, who does not allow the premium, [???] evidently a loser by the operation. What the community want is some temporary substitute for change that will pass current everywhere, until the originators of this panic, and the speculators in silver, shall find their occupation gone, and then the article will quickly find its way back into circulation. The plan proposed in the TIMES a few days ago, of authorizing the City Chamberlain to issue checks, purchasable in current bills, and redeemable in the same, is the speediest and most effectual that has yet been suggested, but as the Common Council have not seen fit to take any action in the matter it only remains for some responsible Banking-house, in which the community has full credit, to adopt the suggestion, and do themselves credit, and benefit the public by carrying it out. The City of Newark has already adopted the plan, and relieved its citizens of the nuisance and burden of the change panic it has been urged that the City authorities have no legal right or authority to issue these checks, but neither has a dealer any right to issue shinplasters, yet hundreds of them have done it, and it is certainly better to have one substitute for silver that is current throughout the City, and sure to be redeemed, than to have a honored of limited currency, and many of them issued by irresponsible parties. Thompson's Bank Note Reporter, for this week, proposes that the railroads, ferry and other companies unite with the retailers and appoint a Committee to select a Trustee, who shall be empowered to issue 10, 25 and 50 cent change certificates, taking therefor United States 6 per cent. bonds, the certificates to be redeemable at par, whenever presented in sums of $5 or upwards. The fines imposed by law for carrying out this plan would amount to $3,000, which could be sued for by the District-Attorney, and collected for the benefit of the poor. The income from the stocks deposited, it is said, would cover the entire expenses, including the fines. Some plan should be adopted to remedy the evils from which the public are now suffering, and the speedier the better.

abstract: Mrs. President LINCOLN and her two sons, accompanied by Col. SWEENEY, Col. HOWE, Col. MURPHY  and several lady friends, made an excursion in the harbor yesterday (Monday), under the suspices of the Surveyor of the Port, Mr. ANDREWS. The revenue steamer Winants, having the party on board, left the barge office at 1 o'clock, and by invitation of Capt. PETRIE, of the steamer City of New-York, and JOHN G. DALE, agent of the New-York and Liverpool Steamship Company, paid a visit to that ship, where a lunch was provided in the best style by Capt. PETRIE. At the table the health of the President of the United States and the Queen were duly mentioned and drank with much good feeling. At the conclusion of the entertainment the party proceeded up the East River to visit the Great Eastern. On the arrival of that ship Capt. PATTON received Mrs. LINCOLN with customary honor, and conducted herself and friends through all the most interesting portions of the ship, the band playing "Hail Columbia," and other National airs. The party passed several hours on board, and, before leaving, were invited to a fine entertainment, provided impromptu. Great pains were taken by Capt. PATTON and his subordinate officers to make the visit agreeable. When the party left, and the revenue steamer got under way, the men on board the great ship assembled on the wheelhouses, and along the side of the ship, and cheered for the President of the United States, while the band played "Yankee Doodle." The guns of the Great Eastern also gave the customary salute.

abstract: The effort to establish a German Hospital in New-York has, for many months past, seriously engaged the attention of all that vast mass of our fellow citizens who claim their origin in Vaterland, and the most influential personages, male and female, of that estimable class of our population, have united heart and hand in the undertaking.
lead_paragraph: The effort to establish a German Hospital in New-York has, for many months past, seriously engaged the attention of all that vast mass of our fellow citizens who claim their origin in Vaterland, and the most influential personages, male and female, of that estimable class of our population, have united heart and hand in the undertaking. Committees and clubs have been formed in every ward to further the project, and a Central Committee of weight and respectability presides over the action of these subsidiary bodies. The grand Industrial Fair in behalf of the hospital will not take place till September, but in the meanwhile various preliminary festivals have been arranged. The first of these took place yesterday at Jones' Wood, and although in the earlier part of the day the attendance, owing to the intense heat and other causes, was not so large as had been anticipated, in the evening, after dusk, the concourse that took part in the festivities amply compensated for the apprehensions of the morning.
