abstract: The instances in which sacrifice and effort for the cause of the country during the time of its sharp trial have been made by those who, from their position and circumstances, might well have said that they could do nothing, are numberless; but among the most striking is that of CONRAD ROSE, a pupil in one of our public schools, who brought to one of the managers of the Women's Central Relief Association $51, which he himself had collected for the fund of the Sanitary Commission. The devotion of this little fellow to the cause of the Republic -- the merits of which, we are told, he seemed to understand pretty well -- and his patient persistence in his determination to do all that he could for it, are well worthy the imitation of people who are his seniors in years, and his superiors in advantages of all kinds. At the present moment his example appeals strongly to the ladies, young and old -- if ladies are ever old -- who are spending the Summer months in the seclusion and comparative quiet and idleness of the country and of watering-places. We have called three hundred thousand more of their brothers, husbands, sons, and lovers, into the field; they will be in the field for a year, and perhaps more. Now, will any woman who has a brother, a lover, a husband, or a son, or who thinks herself worth one, spend her time over embroidery and elegant nonsense, when she can just as well spend her time and stir her fingers in providing the stockings, the shirts, the sheets, and the bandages which the men who fight for the Republic are sure to need? We think not. We believe that all over the loyal States, by the sea-side, on the mountain, at watering-places, at the farm-houses, where the more fortunate of our fairer population are seeking health and relaxation, it will be pronounced bad ton to spend that time and exertion on elegant needlework which might be spent in aiding the Sanitary Commission in providing for the needs of sick and wounded soldiers.

abstract: -- We would suggest to those who will have control of the movement through the City of bodies of volunteers from the country, that a comparatively short march on City pavements may lame the feet of men accustomed to tread only the uncovered soil, more than many days walking on country roads. In this City, troops from the country districts are often, after leaving the boat-landing or railroad station, seen limping on the cobble-stones long before they are permitted to reach their quarters. Do not let those expected to-day, or those who will follow them, be paraded up and down for miles in a July sun. Is it necessary to beguile our consciousness of our country's danger, or to excite our own action by their example?

abstract: endeavored to exclude from the columns of the TIMES, so far as possible, attacks upon prominent officers of the army actively en  gaged in the service of the country, whatever provocation their apparent misconduct might offer for such strictures. Correspondents
lead_paragraph: -- We have endeavored to exclude from the columns of the TIMES, so far as possible, attacks upon prominent officers of the army actively en gaged in the service of the country, whatever provocation their apparent misconduct might offer for such strictures. Correspondents have, however, occasionally indulged in a latitude of comment upon individual officers which would have excluded their letters if it had attracted special notice at the time. Of this character were remarks made recently on the conduct of Gen. HEINTZELMAN and Capt. MOTT during the retreat of the Army of the Potomac to the James River, and especially a most wanton and unjust attack upon the loyalty and personal honor of Gen. MCDOWELL. The latter was written by an officer in MCDOWELL's Division, and, though a private letter, was published at the special request of parties who had a right to speak on the writer's behalf.

abstract: The great popular demonstration in this City, yesterday, was of a spirit and character sufficiently decided and enthusiastic. It, with
lead_paragraph: The great popular demonstration in this City, yesterday, was of a spirit and character sufficiently decided and enthusiastic. It, with the April demonstration of last year, forms the second of the two largest and most influential meetings ever held in New-York. It proclaimed, in unmistakeable language and in clear voice, the purpose of the people in regard to the war and in support of the Union and the Government. From every stand and by every speaker there was but one tone; and every man present seemed inspired by the spirit of the hour. It was that the war begun by traitors must be pushed on till treason is extirpated from the whole land; that the Union which, during the year has cost so much blood and treasure, must be battled for while any blood or treasure is left in the country; and that, to this end, the legitimate directors of the war must be upheld in every effort for its successful prosecution, and impelled onward by the people to greater efforts and the most decisive measures. Though during the year thousands of the bravest and best of the sons of New-York have given their lives for the sacred cause, there were yet thousands more ready to meet the ordeal of battle for its support; and though tens of thousands were now on the battle-field in Virginia, there would be no lack of men willing to follow them there or anywhere else. They were in favor of the strongest measures on the part of the Government; the most determined vigor on the part of commanders; the most unflinching prosecution of the war. The most energetic words were applauded with most vehemence; the most courageous expressions met with the warmest response in the people's hearts. There was no talk of discouragement, not the shadow of a thought of doubt of ultimate triumphant success. Recent disasters were acknowledged and felt to be but temporary and accidental; and the long roll of victories that glorify the year gave faith that the triumphs of our arms in the future would be none the less prouder and decisive.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Sons of Vermont held a meeting at the rooms of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association, in order to make arrangements for the proper reception of the Ninth Vermont Regiment, on its arriral in New-York this morning.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Sons of Vermont held a meeting at the rooms of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association, in order to make arrangements for the proper reception of the Ninth Vermont Regiment, on its arriral in New-York this morning. Mr. C.F. DEWEY was in the Chair. Col. FRANK E. HOWE stated that he had just received a telegram from Gov. HOLBROOK, saying that the regiment had left Brattleboro' that morning at 9 1/2 o'clock; and, that in thirty days the Tenth would be ready to follow, and in forty the Eleventh.

abstract: It was stated that the distribution of the aid fund of $500,000, lately appropriated by the Common Council for the benefit of the families of volunteers would be begun yesterday.
lead_paragraph: It was stated that the distribution of the aid fund of $500,000, lately appropriated by the Common Council for the benefit of the families of volunteers would be begun yesterday. Owing to this statement the various places designated by the Comptroller for the payment of moneys were crowded by the relatives of those brave men, belonging to this City, who are now away defending the integrity of the Union. They were disappointed, however, for the different Ward Committees, who have the matter in charge, were unable to complete their arrangements, having had to inquire into each applicant's particular case; only to aid those who are in actual need -- the fund being designed for charitable purposes alone. The weekly allowance is fixed at $1 50 for the head of a family, and fifty cents for each child, not exceeding three, under fourteen years of age, which will be paid in money once in two weeks. If the person who is receiving aid is of intemperate habits the Ward Committee can, if it be deemed advisable, pay the amount in groceries instead of money. By the 22d July the paymasters will be ready to distribute the fund, and will do so at the subjoined places, as follows:

abstract: The Officers and Medical Examiners at the mustering office in White-street, are now having a busy time of it. Recruits are coming in now much more rapidly than they have hitherto done since the last call of the President.
lead_paragraph: The Officers and Medical Examiners at the mustering office in White-street, are now having a busy time of it. Recruits are coming in now much more rapidly than they have hitherto done since the last call of the President. Dr. MOTT, the examining officer, states that the prospect of recruiting has not looked so bright for some time. On Monday an officer in one day raised thirty men, had them examined and mustered into the service of the United States. From the opening of the office till the close. Dr. MOTT and his assistants are kept busily employed testing the lungs and examining the limbs of [???]. At present, nearly two regiments a week are being mustered in, and judging from the manner enlistments have increased during the last few days, New-York will soon be raising three, if not four, regiments weekly.

abstract: stated by our reporter, yesterday, as to the rush of liquor-dealers to the Excise Commissioners for licenses on Monday, deserve more prominence than their place in an item gives them. If it be true that "full six hundred applicants came forward" on that day, and the liquor-dealers generally "are beginning to feel that it is the intention of the authorities to enforce the law to its full-extent," there are other and far more important consequences than the replenishment of our City Treasury. It is one of the most hopeful and significant indications of the triumph of law over chronic lawlessness. The combination of liquor-dealers to resist the Excise law has been an anomaly of selfishness and wrong. If it has been baffled at last, and its more honest members have determined by hundreds to cease their contest with the Police authorities -- few others have interfered with their craft -- good citizens may take courage and count no wise reform impossible. The Police will see to it, we trust, that the law-abiding dealers are protected from the competition of the unlicensed. No claim can be more just; and in securing this, the City may be freed from the nuisance of many thousand breeding-dens of vice and crime.

abstract: Yesterday the city was full of rumors of guerrilla raids. There is no doubt but the vile suggestion of marauding bands to rob, steal and murder has been put into practice.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the city was full of rumors of guerrilla raids. There is no doubt but the vile suggestion of marauding bands to rob, steal and murder has been put into practice. Night before last a skirmish took place at New-Hope, between a rebel force under the notorious JACK ALLEN, one of MORGAN's gang, and some Union troops. The rebels were beaten and pursued several miles. They had their revenge, however. They went to Lebanon, robbed the Commercial Bank and a private Bank, and burned the depot of the railroad, and, it is said, burned part of the town.

abstract: The Grainmen's Union Protective Society held another meeting at Tammany Hall, last evening, to decide upon the course to be pursued with reference of the elevators, and the opposition of the shovelers thereto.
lead_paragraph: The Grainmen's Union Protective Society held another meeting at Tammany Hall, last evening, to decide upon the course to be pursued with reference of the elevators, and the opposition of the shovelers thereto. Since their last meeting the stevedores have joined them in their opposition to the elevators, and they, as well as the measurers, who occupy a sort of middle ground, were invited to attend the meeting.

abstract: editorial on meeting
snippet: editorial on meeting
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ariel, which arrived at this port last night from Aspinwall, brought $441,179 in treasure, and later advices from the United States of Colombia and South America. Affairs were again in a troublous condition in Panama. A difficulty had occurred between the Governor and the representative of MOSQUERA, which had resulted in the flight of the former to Santiago, in the interior. It was feared that the State might, in consequence, be convulsed into civil war. It is understood that MOSQUERA returned to Bogota on the 6th of June, not deeming it necessary longer to keep in the field, where it was reported he had nineteen thousand men. The news from South America is unimportant. Business at all points was dull.

abstract: Editorial on advantages of 1-year enlistments for new volunteers rather than normal 3 years
snippet: Editorial on advantages of 1-year enlistments for new volunteers rather than normal 3 years
lead_paragraph: -- There is a growing sentiment in favor of one year enlistments for the volunteers newly called for. The good effects of the change from three years to one, are supposed to be these: first, recruiting will be much more speedy, and the new troops sooner ready for the field; and second, the burden will come more lightly on the people.

abstract: Gov. Morgan, Sec. Seward and Sen. Sumner send lrs. of regret on being unable to attend
snippet: Gov. Morgan, Sec. Seward and Sen. Sumner send lrs. of regret on being unable to attend
lead_paragraph: Clouds had long crept from all points of the compass over the sky -- spaces above Union-square -- like the stealthy, but gathering outlying squadrons of JACKSON in the Valley of the Shenandoah; but nearly two hours of patriotic joy had only halted the vapors as a screen from the fierce July sunshine. It was almost six o'clock, and music, artillery and shouting from 25,000 throats were swelling the popular paean to a pitch that influenced every mind with indescribable effect, when a sudden gust from the southward, sweeping dense columns of dust upon the Square like a charge of cavalry on an army in line, drew attention to the aspect of the weather.

abstract: We cannot too earnestly insist upon the entire concentration of the public thought and energies upon the great increase of the military arm of the Government. Let us, for the
lead_paragraph: We cannot too earnestly insist upon the entire concentration of the public thought and energies upon the great increase of the military arm of the Government. Let us, for the time being, close our ears to all clamors of alarm coming from new and unexpected quarters. We are told one day that there are guerrillas in Missouri. Very well, so there have been since the day the rebellion ripened into war. There are fewer there now than ever before, and sufficient Union soldiers to take care of them. We are told next, and freshly two days since, that JOHN MORGAN has reappeared in Kentucky with 1,200 men, and is spreading consternation in the peaceful districts of that State. What of it? HALLECK's army stretches from Cumberland Gap, by way of Nashville, Huntsville and Corinth, to Memphis, cutting off MORGAN from all hope of cooperation from any armed body of rebels. He can only plunder by night, and flee as any other robber may. But the Government has wisely established a military guard in Kentucky, under Gen. BOYLE, whose special mission it is to catch and hang brigands of the MORGAN type. We need not fear that Kentucky will be given over to the rebellion, when she is armed within and defended without, and has no more dangerous foe than MORGAN on her borders.

abstract: The new camp of instruction at Wissahickon, near Philadelphia, is rapidly assuming form and magnitude. The several companies of the Fifteenth Regular Infantry are being concentrated there.
lead_paragraph: The new camp of instruction at Wissahickon, near Philadelphia, is rapidly assuming form and magnitude. The several companies of the Fifteenth Regular Infantry are being concentrated there. OnMonday two companies from Newport, Mo., arrived, and went into their tents. Gen. HARVEY BROWNE, who was ordered from this neighborhood to the post of Chief Artillerist in the school, has not yet reported there. The preliminary exercises in small arms and artillery are going on every day.

abstract: of the most interesting facts in the recent letters of our correspondent from New-Orleans is that yellow fever has not made its appearance in the city, and that, notwith
lead_paragraph: -- One of the most interesting facts in the recent letters of our correspondent from New-Orleans is that yellow fever has not made its appearance in the city, and that, notwithstanding the contrary predictions and hopes of the rebels, physicians of experience are of opinion that there may probably be no epidemic this year. It will be remembered that the disease last Summer was very slight, and Gen. BUTLER's judicious sanitary precautions will, it is hoped, prevent any outbreak of the pestilence.

abstract: THE WAR MEETING IN JERSEY CITY. It has been decided to hold the mass meeting called for this evening in Jersey City at Van Vorst-square, instead of at the City Hall, as previously announced. The meeting will commence at 8 o'clock. Gen. HIRAM
lead_paragraph: THE WAR MEETING IN JERSEY CITY. -- It has been decided to hold the mass meeting called for this evening in Jersey City at Van Vorst-square, instead of at the City Hall, as previously announced. The meeting will commence at 8 o'clock. Gen. HIRAM WALLBRIDGE, Hon. FRED. T. FRELINGHUYSEN, RICHARD BUSTEED, Esq., BUTLER G. NOBLE, Esq., CHARLES H. WINFIELD, Esq., and ISAAC W. SCUDDER, Esq., are to be the speakers. From present indications, this meeting will be the largest ever held in Jersey City.

abstract: SCHOOL -- GRAND TIME FOR CHILDREN. -- Jones' Wood was, if the word can be allowed, crowded yesterday, the occasion being the annual pic-nic of the school attached to St. James' Church, in Roosevelt-street. The scholars and their friends were there by thousands, and to say that any one did not enjoy himself or herself, to their heart's content, would he a libel upon the gentlemen who had the matter in hand. The grounds were crowded with a happy and delighted throng, which could be numbered only by thousands. The platform erected for dancing was crowded, as a matter of course, and every one seemed bent on having the full of their money's worth. Everything was carried on in the precise order of the programme, and every party present, as well as every visitor, cannot but recognize with kind feeling the attentions of the Committee having the matter in charge. In addition to the school for whose benefit the pic-nic, was originated, the "'Long Shoremens' Benevolent Society," and the "Father Mathew Total Abstinence Society," were present in full force, and added greatly to the pleasure of the occasion, and it is a matter of regret that the want of space compels us to make such brief mention of so pleasant an occasion. It was one however of which the managers may well feel proud, and the probabilities are that the school will realize a very handsome sum by the felt.

abstract: A portion of the French residents of this City assembled at the Steuben House, on Monday evening, to celebrate the capture and destruction of the Bastille. Although the meeting was announced for 8 P.M., the proceedings did not commence until 9, when Mr. ROLLE was called to the Chair, and Mr. DEBUCHAY was chosen Secretary. Vehement radical speeches, in both the French and American sense, were made by Messrs. SUIRBAU, Dr. FEDER, MARTOLET, CATTANIO, and others, and the Emperor NAPOLEON and the Courier des Unis came in for some pregnant left-handed compliments, The long hall of the Steuben House was crowded with both sexes who vigorously applauded the hard hits of the speakers. There was, however, no decoration in the rooms, save the portrait of WASHINGTON, and about 11 P.M., with the chant of the Marseillaise, the meeting dissolved with cheers for the great memories of the 14th of July.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was passed providing that all the right and title of the United States in the Stevens' Battery be released and committed to the heirs of ROBERT L. STEVENS. A
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was passed providing that all the right and title of the United States in the Stevens' Battery be released and committed to the heirs of ROBERT L. STEVENS. A bill was introduced further amending the Articles of War so as to render it the duty of officers to furnish protection to slaves. The bill amending the Militia act of 1795 was considered, the question being on Mr. SHERMAN's amendment limiting emancipation to the slaves of rebels. This was adopted -- 18 to 17. A proposal to strike the words "mother, wife and children," from the emancipation clause, was rejected. A further amendment was proposed, that such mother, wife and children, shall not be freed unless they belong to rebels. This was debated at great length, but does not appear to have been adopted. The bill was finally passed -- 28 to 9. A resolution from the House, postponing the final adjournment until Thursday, in accordance with the desire of the President, was passed. The House bill, making provisions for pensions to masters, &c., on gunboats, was passed. The bill providing an additional tax of one cent per pound on sugar was passed. The bill making supplementary appropriations was reported with amendments, one of which provides $15,000 to purchase artificial limbs for wounded soldiers and seamen. The Senate then took a recess until evening.

abstract: At the great mass meeting held as unionsquare yesterday afternoon, it is estimated there were 30,000 people present. The five stands were
lead_paragraph: At the great mass meeting held as union-square yesterday afternoon, it is estimated there were 30,000 people present. The five stands were surrounded by a great and enthusiastic crowd, to whom speeches were made by Mayor OPDYKE, Gen. FREMONT, and other distinguished citizens. The meeting was a great and grand success -- such an one as this City has not seen before. Full details will be found in the columns of the TIMES this morning.

abstract: Supposed MURDER NEAR WEST HOBOKEN-- Coroner BOHNSTEDT, of Hoboken, commenced an inquest yesterday upon the body of MARTIN DEMAREST, a volunteer belonging to the Fifty-third New-York Regiment, encamped at Red House, Harlem, who
lead_paragraph: Supposed MURDER NEAR WEST HOBOKEN. -- Coroner BOHNSTEDT, of Hoboken, commenced an inquest yesterday upon the body of MARTIN DEMAREST, a volunteer belonging to the Fifty-third New-York Regiment, encamped at Red House, Harlem, who was found lying dead at Fox Hill, with a gunshot wound in his leg. From circumstances attending the case, it is supposed that DEMAREST was murdered and robbed. From the evidence adduced, it appeares that on Monday morning deceased called at the public house in the Elysian Fields and had some refreshments, and in paying for them, the bartender noticed that he had a considerable quantity of bills, mostly Treasury notes. From there he went out into the fields. Lieut. HINCKLEY, of the Fifty-third New-York Volunteers, testified that DEMAREST was at the camp at Red House on Monday morning, and as he was about going away, he remarked that he expected to receive $100 that day. PATRICK DONOVAN, of Hoboken, testified that on Monday evening about 8 o'clock, as he was going up to the toll-gate at West Hoboken, two women, who were a little way off, called out to him, saying that a soldier was shot. He paid no attention to this, supposing the women were "funning." They appeared to be talking to the man. The body was discovered on Tuesday morning. About fifty yards off, in different directions, were found a single-barreled pistol and a razor. The deceased appeared to have been dragged some distance. An empty leather purse and some business cards were all that was found. Dr. ELMER made an examination, and found that a ball had entered above and came out below the knee, severing a large artery and causing death. The inquest was adjourned until to-day.

abstract: --The President  dent has called for three hundred thousand additional soldiers. The country is responding promptly, enlistments are going rapidly forward, and the men will soon be in the field. Three hundred thousand guns will be immedi-...
lead_paragraph: -- The President has called for three hundred thousand additional soldiers. The country is responding promptly, enlistments are going rapidly forward, and the men will soon be in the field. Three hundred thousand guns will be immediately required to arm them. Is the Ordnance Department prepared to meet this demand? Is it prepared to place in the hands of each man either a Springfield or Enfield rifled musket, or some other safe and efficient arm? We all know that a sufficient number of the Springfield and Enfield guns cannot be had in time, as evidenced by the fact that a considerable part of the force now in the field is armed with smooth-bored guns. The Government can produce the Springfield rifle only at the rate of some 13,000 per month. Private contractors are not producing a thousand a month. We doubt, indeed, whether a thousand guns of the Springfield pattern have as yet been delivered from all the private manufactories of the country. Where then are our arms to come from? We should have less anxiety on this subject if onr Ordnance Department had heretofore shown efficiency in the discharge of its duties. Unforunately our Chief of Ordnance, we all know, is disposed to practice a cruel and expensive economy, and pursue a sort of hand-to-mouth policy, which, if it can furnish the supplies needed for to-day, allows to-morrow to take care of itself.

abstract: Editorial favors employing freed Negroes in military camps as McClellan is doing; editorial says emancipation would not deter intervention of Great Britain or France in Civil War
snippet: Editorial favors employing freed Negroes in military camps as McClellan is doing; editorial says emancipation would not deter intervention of Great Britain or France in Civil War
lead_paragraph: -- A letter from Gen. MCCLELLAN, the substance of which was given in the TIMES of yesterday, corrects another of the many misapprehensions which have taken possession of the public mind. He states that he has received all the negro slaves who have come to his camp for protection, and that he has employed them in digging trenches, attending to the sanitary condition of the camps, and other work of this kind. This we know to be perfectly true. But the number of such negroes who fall into our hands, and whose services thus become available, is much smaller than is generally supposed. There may be a thousand at Fortress Monroe, five or six hundred at Yorktown, and as many more in MCCLELLAN's army -- women and children included. These are not enough to relieve our troops to any very great extent, in building fortifications, digging trenches, &c. But what few are there are kept at work.

abstract: Editorial proposes putting new volunteers in experienced regiments rather than current practice of forming new regiments with inexperienced officers
snippet: Editorial proposes putting new volunteers in experienced regiments rather than current practice of forming new regiments with inexperienced officers
lead_paragraph: The process has already begun in the City and the State of forming new regiments. Captains, Majors and Colonels are appointed according as they bring in each the given number of men, or according to the favor of the military authorities. We have the old experience to go through with, of raw regiments and of inexperienced officers. The old lessons, which have cost us so much, of discipline and of organization and camp-police, arc all to be learned again. And this at an immense cost, both to the men themselves and to the country. Why should this be? Why should not the new volunteers be enlisted in old regiments? They must prefer it, if they reflect on the matter. A man's life and health are vastly safer, if he be in the hands of an experienced officer than of a raw one.

abstract: Patriotic responses from East and West being made to new call for troops
snippet: Patriotic responses from East and West being made to new call for troops
lead_paragraph: The Western part of New-York seems to be thoroughly aroused to the necessity of placing its quota of troops, under the new levy, in the field at once. In Buffalo, the Express of Monday states that the work of organizing the new regiment is progressing as rapidly as could be expected. The several Committees intrusted with the preliminary and incidental labors of the undertaking have been working for the past two or three days with the utmost energy, and have accomplished much. The District Committee, appointed by Gov. MORGAN, have designated Major CHAPIN, of the Forty-fourth Regiment, as commandant of the Buffalo Depot, to be Colonel of the regiment, when it shall be organized. Lieut. J.B. WEBER, also of the Forty-fourth, has been named as Adjutant, and Mr. JAMES ADAMS as Quartermaster. Steps have already been taken to secure from Albany the necessary equipments, and a camp is to be immediately organized at Fort Porter. Hon. ORLANDO ALLEN is taking a prominent part in organizing the regiment, having assumed the responsibility of raising a company. He has has 24 men already enrolled, and when the company is formed will use his influence to secure a capable Captain. Energetic exertions are making to secure subscriptions to defray the expenses attendant upon the organization of the regiment. Among other schemes a grand festival, at which the Hon. MILLARD FILLMORE will probably make an address, is talked of.

abstract: Every day brings something new on the Mexican question. The detailed reports of Gen. LORENCEA have been published, and they throw a flood of much needed light on the question. The serious nature of the defeat at Puebla, and the almost total want of sympathy for the French and for ALMONTE by the Mexicans, are the important features of this official
lead_paragraph: Every day brings something new on the Mexican question. The detailed reports of Gen. LORENCEA have been published, and they throw a flood of much needed light on the question. The serious nature of the defeat at Puebla, and the almost total want of sympathy for the French and for ALMONTE by the Mexicans, are the important features of this official news. The result of this news may be briefly stated as follows: An order to the French army to remain at its present encampment at Orizaba till Autumn; the dispatch of 2,000 men to Martinique, to remain there until Autumn within call of the commander at Orizaba, if by any bad fortune he should need them; and lastly, the sending out of 10,000 more troops in September, to join those already there, and with Gen. FOREY at their head to march on Mexico.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the raising of a volunteer force for the better defence of Kentucky was reported back from the Military Committee, and laid aside informally after some debate. The resolution from the House explanatory of the Confiscation act was called up by Mr. CLARK of New-Hampshire who offered
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the raising of a volunteer force for the better defence of Kentucky was reported back from the Military Committee, and laid aside informally after some debate. The resolution from the House explanatory of the Confiscation act was called up by Mr. CLARK of New-Hampshire who offered an amendment that no punishment under the bill shall work the forfeiture of real estate beyond the natural life of the person accused. This amendment, Mr. CLARK explained, was offered to meet one of the objections of the President to the bill. Several Senators objected to such a method of legislation, preferring rather to receive a veto message from the President, which should state his objections in full, and enable the Senate to meet them understandingly. The debate was continued at great length, and it was finally voted to make the amendment as well as another suggestion to meet the President's objections, rather than jeopardize the success of the bill. The bill for the discharge of the State prisoners was considered until the recess. During the proceedings, Senator CHANDLER, of Michigan, made a speech in review of the Conduct of the War, from the battle of Bull Run to the present time.

abstract: British steamer Ann captured at Mobile Bay trying to run blockade
snippet: British steamer Ann captured at Mobile Bay trying to run blockade
lead_paragraph: The prize steamship Ann, of London, cut out from under the guns of Fort Morgan, at the mouth of Mobile Bay, on June 20, arrived at this port yesterday. The Ann had run in during the night by the blockading fleet, as it was so dark that she could not be seen by our vessels. Lights had been kept burning on the fort all night, so that she had no trouble in finding the channel. The next morning she was discovered by the Susquehannah, within a half mile of the fort, unloading her cargo into a rebel steamer alongside. The Susquehannah, accompanied by the gunboat Kanawha, then got underweigh and steamed within gunshot and opened fire on the strange steamer. The fire was returned by the fort, and kept up for an hour on both sides. In the meantime the crew had deserted the strange steamer, as the shells from our vessels fell about her rather too thickly for safety. She was soon discovered to be adrift, and dropped down with the current about a mile, when the Kanawha was ordered to go in and bring her out, which she did in fine style, under a heavy fire from the fort. When the Ann was boarded by Acting Master PARTRIDGE from the Kanawha, she was found to be in a sinking condition, her injection pipe having been cut, and the kingston valve left open. The engine and fire-room were soon filled with water, but as she was built in 4 water-tight compartments and the communication between them had not been opened, only one compartment was filled. Through the persevering efforts of the officers of the Susquehanna and Kanawha, the leak was stopped and the water pumped out.
headline: {'main': 'AN IMPORTANT PRIZE.; Capture of the British Steamer Ann at the Mouth of Mobile Bay. She is Cut Out from Under the Guns of Fort Morgan.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'AN IMPORTANT PRIZE.; Capture of the British Steamer Ann at the Mouth of Mobile Bay. abstract: At an enthusiastic war meeting in Indianapolis, on Saturday evening, Gov. MORTON and Gen. E. DUMONT, made stirring addresses. Gov. MORTON urged
lead_paragraph: At an enthusiastic war meeting in Indianapolis, on Saturday evening, Gov. MORTON and Gen. E. DUMONT, made stirring addresses. Gov. MORTON urged the necessity of reinforcing MCCLELLAN, believing that when the rebel army before Richmond was destroyed and the rebel Capital taken, that the rebellion would receive its death-blow. He had faith that the people would come to the rescue and save the Government. He appealed to the men of wealth and to those whose business was prospering to reflect upon what would be their condition should the country be destroyed. He considered that their private as well as public interests demanded that they should give their services to the Government at any sacrifice.

abstract: It will be seen by our dispatches this morning, that Gov. MORGAN has decided, after due deliberation, not to call an extra session of the Legislature, but to take upon himself the responsibility of offering at once a State bounty of fifty dollars to each recruit under the new levy of
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our dispatches this morning, that Gov. MORGAN has decided, after due deliberation, not to call an extra session of the Legislature, but to take upon himself the responsibility of offering at once a State bounty of fifty dollars to each recruit under the new levy of Volunteers, and to provide a sum sufficient for that purpose, trusting to the next Legislature to legalize and indorse his action. This policy will save much time, and an expense of some eighty thousand dollars to the State.

lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Col. JAMES H. PERRY of the Forty-Eighth (Brooklyn) Regiment, reached this city on Monday last, from Port Royal, and have since that time, lain in state in the Governor's room. City Hall. Yesterday, the body was removed to the Fleet street Methodist-Episcopal Church. where a funeral sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. KENNADY, formerly of the Washington-street Church, but now of New-Haven, when the body was again removed to the City Hall. The military funeral will take place to-day, from the City Hall, at 3 o'clock P.M., and the body will be interred at Cypress Hills. abstract: INSTITUTE OF REWARD.--In the interest of a movement for meeting the educational necessities of patriot orphans, the Board of Trustees met at their rooms in the Bible House on Monday evening, Rev.
lead_paragraph: INSTITUTE OF REWARD. -- In the interest of a movement for meeting the educational necessities of patriot orphans, the Board of Trustees met at their rooms in the Bible House on Monday evening, Rev. S.D. DENISON in the chair. The several Committees were appointed as follows: Executive -- Rev. S.D. Denison, Charles C. Leigh, Esq., M.M. Vail, Edward Warren, Joseph W. Richards. Finance Committee as follows: Chas. Gould, Esq., Alexander Knox, Caleb T. Rowe, and the several Departmental Committees specified in the Constitution. The Board concluded by appointing DAVID P. HOLTON, M.D., to act as General Agent to collect information and to devise plans of operations whereby the Institute can best realize the objects contemplated in the appointment of the Departmental Committees. Valentine Mott, M.D., President; Arthur F. Wilmarth, Esq., Treasurer; Henry Thomas Hunter, Esq., Recording Secretary; David P. Holton, M.D., Corresponding Secretary.

abstract: The Committee of the Fourth Senatorial District have made their selection of Colonel and Lieutenant-Colonel for the regiment to be raised by them. Their choice has fallen upon Major PETER M. DERMOTT, for Colonel, and Capt. LEVI A. FULLER, for Lieutenant-Colonel. The latter gentleman was recommended by the Governor for the appointment. Major DERMOTT is a native of this State. He was in the Mexican war, and assisted very materially in the raising of the Excelsior Brigade, of one of the regiments of which he was Major. Capt. FULLER is attached to Col. PRATT's Regiment, but is now on furlough on account of sickness. The Committee is determined to have the regiment they are raising the first in the field.

DUNVAY, is an experienced officer, who has seen service with the gallant Irish Brigade of Gen. MEAGHER.

abstract: We give, in other columns of this issue, a brief view of the prospects of volunteering throughout the country. It will be seen that the people generally are now waking up to the necessities of the present situation. In this State, recruiting is beginning to show lively signs, though it is not yet as active as the necessities of the occa-...
lead_paragraph: We give, in other columns of this issue, a brief view of the prospects of volunteering throughout the country. It will be seen that the people generally are now waking up to the necessities of the present situation. In this State, recruiting is beginning to show lively signs, though it is not yet as active as the necessities of the occasion demand; and in this City we are still far behind. The great meeting of Tuesday has resulted in but a slim addition to the ranks; and there seem to be causes of dissatisfaction which, whatever they are, should be promptly removed. Nothing can be of such importance to the country at present as the rapid formation of our new army. The soldier is now the bulwark of our liberties; the hope of the Union; the safeguard against foreign interference; the power which must give to the country permanent peace. Whoever or whatever stands in the way of the army's growth and efficiency, is a public enemy and nuisance, and a coworker with or aid to the disunion traitors, and must be driven from or swept out of the path of its progress. The people, however, are assuredly arousing themselves, and when once the military spirit is fully called out, and the machinery of volunteering fairly adjusted and in motion, we shall see regiments formed and thrown forward to confront the enemy with a rapidity as great as the work was done last year.

abstract: One of the most amusing events in trotting annals, took place on Tuesday, on the above course. It was a match between Mr. ALLEN'S Gen. Butler-- which lately beat panie, to wagon, in 2 minutes 28 seconds--and Mr.DATER'S Rattlesnake, mile heats, in harness. The trot was announced to take place at
lead_paragraph: One of the most amusing events in trotting annals, took place on Tuesday, on the above course. It was a match between Mr. ALLEN's Gen. Butler -- which lately beat panie, to wagon, in 2 minutes 28 1/4 seconds -- and Mr. DATER's Rattlesnake, mile heats, in harness. The trot was announced to take place at 3 o'clock, but it was 4 before the horses came up for a start, when Rattlesnake had the inside place. DAN MACE, as on the previous trot, handled Butler, and D. PFIFFER steered Rattlesnake. From 4 to 5 1/2 o'clock, as petty a series of trotting finesse and maneuvering as it was ever our ill fortune to witness, took place on the part of the drivers. It was evident from fact, that PFIFFER would not let Rattlesnake go unless he had decided advantage at the start; and it was as evident MACE was not going to throw a chance away by giving any advantage to his antagonist; hence, one or the other would be reined in or broke up for period of an hour and a half, to the utter disgust of the majority of an unusual field of sporting men, and New-York City and County.

abstract: -- Next to him who does brave deeds in these days, is he who speaks stirring, truthful words to inspire those deeds. Such were spoken at the Suffolk County celebration of the Fourth, by Hon. DAVID R. FLOYD JOKES, whose oration we find reported in full in the Suffolk Democrat. Mr. JONES humorously declined to pursue the usual course adopted on such occasions, and "trace the history of our beloved country, from the landing of COLUMBUS to the present time." But he did show, in the course of a brief and intelligent historical analysis, how radically different is the rebellion of which JEFFERSON DAVIS is the head, and that which had GEORGE WASHINGTON for its leader. He showed that the party now fighting for popular rights and constitutional liberty, is that which is upholding the Government, and not that which is seeking to destroy it. He applied this lesson, too, in such a way as must have stimulated the patriotism of his hearers to yet greater sacrifices for their country, and yet greater devotion than they have yet exhibited. Among the most gratifying and promising signs of the times in the present crisis of the country, is the hearty, unquestioning support which the Government receives -- merely as the embodiment of the Republic -- from such Democrats as Hon. FLOYD JONES.
lead_paragraph: -- Next to him who does brave deeds in these days, is he who speaks stirring, truthful words to inspire those deeds. Such were spoken at the Suffolk County celebration of the Fourth, by Hon. DAVID R. FLOYD JOKES, whose oration we find reported in full in the Suffolk Democrat. Mr. JONES humorously declined to pursue the usual course adopted on such occasions, and "trace the history of our beloved country, from the landing of COLUMBUS to the present time." But he did show, in the course of a brief and intelligent historical analysis, how radically different is the rebellion of which JEFFERSON DAVIS is the head, and that which had GEORGE WASHINGTON for its leader. He showed that the party now fighting for popular rights and constitutional liberty, is that which is upholding the Government, and not that which is seeking to destroy it. He applied this lesson, too, in such a way as must have stimulated the patriotism of his hearers to yet greater sacrifices for their country, and yet greater devotion than they have yet exhibited. Among the most gratifying and promising signs of the times in the present crisis of the country, is the hearty, unquestioning support which the Government receives -- merely as the embodiment of the Republic -- from such Democrats as Hon. abstract: The new Tariff bill passed Congress last week, and having received the signature of the President is now a law. Its provisions have occasioned much uneasiness and disquietude to a large body of our merchants, whose interests are thereby affected. Since we last referred to the bill many important amendments to it have been made, by the House of Representatives, the Senate, and a Conference Committee of both bodies. We have not space to note the many alterations in the rates of duty, and can only briefly refer to the changes made in the general provisions of the bill. The bill as first reported to the House made it the duty of importers to withdraw from bonded warehouse all merchandise, paying the duties thereon, before the day on which the act should take effect. This was fixed at Aug. 1. The bill was so altered, however, as to require goods which were bonded previous to the time of the passage of the three months' warehouse law, to be withdrawn before the 1st of August, in order to escape the imposition of the new rates. Those which were deposited in store under the law referred to, are not necessarily to be withdrawn before the first of August, but may remain in store for the time for which they were originally bonded, without being subject to the additional duty. The time allowed for goods to remain in bond, under the new law, is one year, when they shall be withdrawn for consumption, and three years when they are to be exported.
lead_paragraph: The new Tariff bill passed Congress last week, and having received the signature of the President is now a law. Its provisions have occasioned much uneasiness and disquietude to a large body of our merchants, whose interests are thereby affected. We have not space to note the many alterations in the rates of duty, and can only briefly refer to the changes made in the general provisions of the bill. The bill as first reported to the House made it the duty of importers to withdraw from bonded warehouse all merchandise, paying the duties thereon, before the day on which the act should take effect. This was fixed at Aug. 1. The bill was so altered, however, as to require goods which were bonded previous to the time of the passage of the three months' warehouse law, to be withdrawn before the 1st of August, in order to escape the imposition of the new rates. Those which were deposited in store under the law referred to, are not necessarily to be withdrawn before the first of August, but may remain in store for the time for which they were originally bonded, without being subject to the additional duty. The time allowed for goods to remain in bond, under the new law, is one year, when they shall be withdrawn for consumption, and three years when they are to be exported.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Persia, we receive advices from Europe three days later than have been before published. The Liverpool Cotton Market was still much excited, and heavy purchases were being made by speculators at a further advance. In Breadstuffs the market was dull but steady. The Provision Market was inactive. The English Press was busy in
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Persia, we receive advices from Europe three days later than have been before published. The Liverpool Cotton Market was still much excited, and heavy purchases were being made by speculators at a further advance. In Breadstuffs the market was dull but steady. The Provision Market was inactive. The English Press was busy in the discussion of affairs in the United States, with the Fourth of July as a text. Contradictory reports were afloat as to the designs of the French Government in regard to Mexico. The Paris papers had been requested to be particularly reserved in treating of Mexican affairs. The accounts from the French manufacturing districts continue very unfavorable, and the Bank of France is asked to come forward and aid the manufacturers by discounting their paper.

Every town and village are vicing with each other to see which shall first place its quota in the field, and there is every prospect that Ma-sachusetts will be far ahead of her sister States in the promptness with which she will respond to the call. Enthusiastic meetings, which have had substantial results, have been held in all the principal towns.

abstract: The spirit which prevails in the Green Mountains is sufficiently indicated by the fact that the Ninth Regiment from Vermont passed through New-York yesterday, and is already close to the seat of war. abstract: Which has done so nobly heretofore, is girding up her loins for the work, although her fighting material has been somewhat depleted by placing in the field two regiments of three months' men. The City Council of Providence has just taken action which will tend to stimulate enlistments in that city. It has passed a bill appropriating one hundred dollars for each volunteer; twenty-five dollars to be paid upon taking the prescribed oath, after a surgical examination; fifteen dollars when the company to which he is assigned is mustered into the Federal service, and ten dollars per quarer thereafter until the whole sum is paid.

abstract: As an act of the purest justice we admit into another column some remarks of Gen. BENHAM in review of the report of Gen. STEVENS upon the James Island disaster. It will be seen that Gen. BENHAM not only shows that STEVENS, WRIGHT and WILLIAMS acquiesced in the project of attack, which had, in fact, been ordered by Gen. HUNTER, but that the failure was entirely due to the tardiness and neglect of orders of which Gen. STEVENS was guilty. The proofs of these points, as presented by Gen. BENHAM, would seem to be unanswerable. It is also asserted in Gen. BENHAM's note that had Gen. STEVENS led or even accompanied his troops, the assault might have been successful; whereas that commander was throughout the engagement nearly half a mile distant from the enemy's battery, concealed by a hedge. As the issue in this matter has now been distinctly made, we presume it will pass out of the newspapers. The controversy must, at all events, cease, so far as this journal is concerned.
lead_paragraph: As an act of the purest justice we admit into another column some remarks of Gen. BENHAM in review of the report of Gen. STEVENS upon the James Island disaster. abstract: The Green Mountain State is the first to send troops to the war under the new call of the President. The Ninth Regiment of Vermont arrived in this City yesterday morning, in route for the seat of war. After having been only ten days in camp, at Brattleboro'. It received marching orders, and the command to break camp was immediately given. Previous to
lead_paragraph: The Green Mountain State is the first to send troops to the war under the new call of the President. The Ninth Regiment of Vermont arrived in this City yesterday morning, in route for the seat of war. After having been only ten days in camp, at Brattleboro'. It received marching orders, and the command to break camp was immediately given. Previous to leaving, Gov. HOLBROOK presented the regiment with a handsome stand of colors. They left Brattleboro' at 9 1/2 o'clock on Tuesday morning for New-Haven, and left that city for New-York by the steamer Bay State.

abstract: Harlem River Bridge, being built in NYC, described
snippet: Harlem River Bridge, being built in NYC, described
lead_paragraph: The new bridge in process of construction over the Harlem river at the terminus of the Third avenue, is destined to be one of the first structures of the kind in this country, and is well worth a visit from such of our citizens as admire engineering skill, and take an interest in the improvements that are going on in their midst. The work on this bridge was commenced in October, 1860, under the direction of commissioners appointed by the Legislature, and consisting of the Mayor of New York, (who at that time was FERNANDO WOOD,) the Street Inspector, President of the Board of Supervisors, and the County Judge of Westchester county. For certain reasons not now necessary to mention, but which may be easily inferred from the above named head of the commission, the Legislature found it necessary, for the economical prosecution of the work, to appoint a new set of commissioners, and in the winter of '61 they selected WILLIAM MINOR, JOSEPH SOUTHWORTH and JAMES DAVIS, of New York, and Judge ROBINSON and ALSOP H. LOCKWOOD, of Westchester county. Since the new commissioners entered upon their duties, in April, 1861, the work has been prosecuted with vigor, and at an expense of forty per cent less, it is said, than under the previous management.

abstract: GOV. MORGAN has unintentionally ruined the present prospects of the Regular army. He has killed recruiting. Less than $50 no man will enlist.
lead_paragraph: GOV. MORGAN has unintentionally ruined the present prospects of the Regular army. He has killed recruiting. Less than $50 no man will enlist. Within the space of twenty-four hours the whole aspect of affairs has been changed among the regulars. Hundreds of men, even, whose terms of enlistment has expired in the latter, will take their big bounty and leave the old force for the new. There is another class of professional military adventurers who will not enlist now at any price. "By and bye drafting will be in full blast -- merchants, editors and lawyers will want substitutes. Talk of $50! why we will be, like gold, at 120 premium then." No doubt these cogitations keep volunteers as well as regulars from the field. Thus it may be imagined we have more veritable men in our very midst than would seem credible after an inspection of some unsuccess-rendezvous.

abstract: A very large meeting assembled in Columbus, O., on Tuesday evening. Hon. S. GALLOWAY moved the election of Gov. TOD as the Chairman of the meeting, which nomination was hailed with rousing cheers ...
lead_paragraph: A very large meeting assembled in Columbus, O., on Tuesday evening. Hon. S. GALLOWAY moved the election of Gov. TOD as the Chairman of the meeting, which nomination was hailed with rousing cheers Gov. TOD being escorted to the stand, addressed the assembled multitude in a most stirring speech. He pointed out the duty and interest of all parties in this contest. He pronounced the statement of VALLANDIGHAM as to the sufferings and neglect of the Union troops at Washington City as an utter falsehood -- Which was reported to by immense cheers. He announced to the people that the Executive rooms have been continually crowded by persons from all quarters of the State, who are entering upon the work of enlistment with the most encouraging success. He said that to-day Gov. DENNISON, in company with Mr. JEWETT, his (Toms) former competitor, would, upon his invitation, go through the State and see the people on this question; also, that he had invited Judge RANNEY to the same duty, and he doubted not but that he would receive a like response from him.

abstract: Capt. JOHN B. LEVERICH, formerly of the Ellsworth Zouaves, and well known amongst the politicians and firemen in this City, is recruiting a battalion, of which he is to be the Lieutenant-Colonel, with the intention of uniting with other companies of sufficient numerical strength to constitute a full regiment, which will be commanded by Col. LOESER, also of the Zouaves. Capt. LEVERICH did well with his former command, and we are not surprised to learn that his headquarters (Lafayette Hall,) attract a full share of recruits.

abstract: New-Hampshire's quota of some 4,000 men will probably be raised without drafting. The State offers $25 bounty, towns and cities will be called on to pay $35, which, with the United States advance of $38, and private subscriptions, will carry the bounty up as high as any other State. The Ninth Regiment has 600 or 700 men, and is fast progressing; the Tenth, of Irishmen, ought to be easily raised; and the Eleventh will be recruited in Belknap, Carroll and Strafford Counties.

abstract: The young gentlemen and ladies of the two departments of Grammer School No. 13, in the Seventeeth Ward, held their last reception for the season yesterday morning and afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The young gentlemen and ladies of the two departments of Grammer School No. 13, in the Seventeeth Ward, held their last reception for the season yesterday morning and afternoon. The school will be closed for the Summer vacation, and desirable improvements will make it more than ever attractive by the next term, which commences on the second Monday in September. The large hall of the Primary Department was well filled by 10 o'clock in the morning, and, in spite of the oppressive atmosphere, the large company enjoyed the well-chosen and varied entertainment afforded them by the pupils, who, in clear tones and with distinct emphasis, supported their share in elocution, dialogue, ringing &c. Mrs. HAGGERTY, the esteemed principal, was absent on account of illness, to the regret of all. The order maintained was excellent, and the two hundred and twenty-five children of the 'Gallery" presented an appearance most gratifying.

abstract: George W. Stevens vs. James Flynn. -- This was an action brought by the plaintiff to recover his fees as counsel for the defendant in 1859. The complaint alleges that the plaintiff was retained by the defendant in four cases in the Superior Court, and in one in the United States Circuit Court, and that in two of the cases, a verdict was rendered for Mr. Flynn. The claim was laid at $362, which includes $125 retaining fees, taxable costs and some disbursements.

The complaint alleges that the plaintiff was retained by the defendant in four cases in the Superior Court, and in one in the United States Circuit Court, and that in two of the cases, a verdict was rendered for Mr. Flynn. The claim was laid at $362, which includes $125 retaining fees, taxable costs and some disbursements.

abstract: Our much-abused National Congress, which the Herald and WENDELL PHILLIPS have been calling on some CROMWELL to step in and put an end to, as the great Puritan put an end to ...
lead_paragraph: Our much-abused National Congress, which the Herald and WENDELL PHILLIPS have been calling on some CROMWELL to step in and put an end to, as the great Puritan put an end to the "Rump Parliament," yesterday peaceably dissolved of its own accord. The Secessionist and Abolitionist shriekers for a new CROMWELL, in fact, forget that there is no sort of analogy between the two cases. Congress with us has its Constitutional beginning, and its legitimate ending; but it was precisely because the "Long Parliament" had no limits that CROMWELL could brook its everlasting sitting no longer. It had lasted for thirteen years, and had declared itself perpetual, when the iconoclast, after much wrestling with the Lord, stepped in and indignantly drove, the babblers from their stools. It would doubtless be too much to expect of those who have been shouting for a second CROMWELL to know what the first actually did, and why.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate activities in Southwest
snippet: Editorial on Confederate activities in Southwest
lead_paragraph: The sudden forays by bodies of rebel marauders in Tennessee, Kentucky and Missouri, -- their capture of Murfreesboro and menace of Nashville -- their ravages in Kentucky and advance toward the capital of that State, and toward the Ohio River -- their reappearance in Northern Missouri, and their operations on the very border of Iowa -- their demonstrations in the vicinity of Corinth and along our entire line in North Alabama -- the bold front they assume in Northern Arkansas and along the Mississippi River -- indicate that the embers of rebellion in the Southwest are still hot and smouldering. They prove that the rebels have taken new heart from their so-called successes on the Peninsula, and that they yet look forward to a reconquest of the Southwestern States; or rather, perhaps, they may indicate that, though Kentucky, Tennessee and Missouri are inevitably lost to the Confederacy, the expelled rebels are determined to carry into them fire and sword, destruction, confusion, rapine and bloodshed; and thus, if they cannot rule, they will at least do their best to ruin. We are inclined to think that the latter purpose is the real one intended, and that these irruptions are but the first attempt at that guerrilla system in the Southwest which the rebels have threatened when other means of success failed. The rebel force in Kentucky which has been operating on the railroad lines, and up as high as Harrodsburgh, if not by this time to Frankfort, is reported to consist of but two mounted squads of about a thousand men each; the cavalry force which captured Murfreesboro, and to which a regiment of our troops is stated to have so discreditably surrendered, is reported as between three and four thousand strong; and in other places generally the rebel bodies have appeared in small cavalry troops. Of course such demonstrations can mean nothing but rapine. If this rebel troop should take Frankfort they could not possibly hold it a week; and if such an impossible event should occur as the fall of Nashville before the Texan savages, they could not hold it for a longer time than was necessary to plunder it, and perhaps to hang the Unionists and slaughter those who have taken the oath of allegiance. But the damage they may do to the States in which they operate, and to the Union cause in those States, is incalculable.

abstract: A meeting of citizens of the Twenty-first Ward was held last evening at No. 435 Fourth-avenue, for the purpose of aiding the cause of recruiting in that Ward, and throughout the Senatorial District in which the ward is situated. Alderman FROMENT occupied the Chair, and JOHN H. WHITE was chosen Secretary. After a full discussion of the proposedplans of procedure, it was decided to appoint a Committee of five to report upon the subject. Messrs. John H. White, Daniel W. Clarke, Wm. P. Esterbrook, John Stephenson and Theodore Froment were appointed for that purpose. The Secretary was authorized to give due notice of the next meeting, whereupon an adjournment was had to next Monday evening, at 8 o'clock.

abstract: GOV. MOR  GAN has acted with wisdom in taking upon himself the responsibility of offering, on behalf of the State of New-York, the liberal bounty of fifty dollars to each private soldier ...
lead_paragraph: -- GOV. MORGAN has acted with wisdom in taking upon himself the responsibility of offering, on behalf of the State of New-York, the liberal bounty of fifty dollars to each private soldier who shall volunteer in the military service of the United States -- to be given in addition to the bounty now offered by the General Government. The Government's bounty is one hundred dollars -- twenty-five of which is paid when the regiment is mustered in, -- making, in all, the handsome sum of seventy-five dollars cash in hand to each volunteer. Many cities and towns also, in different parts of the State, offer bounties in addition to these, from their own exchequer; and it is strongly urged upon our civic authorities by public meetings which have been held in different Wards of the City, that they also offer a special Municipal bounty to men volunteering from this City. Gov. MORGAN says that, "individual and organized effort are in no degree to be intermitted in consequence of this offer. On the contrary, it is hoped and expected that both will be stimulated thereby."

abstract: Turning over  Plutarch's Lives the other day, we came upon the narrative of the battle of Cannae. What PLUTARCH there says of the "magnanimity and temper of the Romans, when the ...
lead_paragraph: Turning over Plutarch's Lives the other day, we came upon the narrative of the battle of Cannae. What PLUTARCH there says of the "magnanimity and temper of the Romans, when the Consul VARRO returned after his defeat, much humbled and very melancholy, as one who had occasioned the greatest calamity and disgrace to the Republic," how the whole Senate and people went to welcome him at the gates, and, when silence was commanded, the magistrates and principal Senators commended him for not giving up the circumstances of the State as desperate after so great a misfortune," has occurred to us repeatedly within the last few days. We have not, indeed, suffered such a defeat by the rashness of our commander, nor are we Romans, but there may be something in their behavior wherein we, enlightened Americans as we are proud of being, may learn a lesson from those ancient heathen. There are, indeed, some few fearful souls among us who speak of the movement of the army to the James River as if it were a disaster quite equal to that of Cannae. We suggest to them that if it were so, they should, as did the Romans of old, at least commend our General for not having given up the circumstances of the Republic as desperate.

abstract: Congress adjourned sine die yesterday at 2 o'clock P.M., the hour previously fixed upon by resolution. Some important legislation marked the closing hours of the session. In the Senate, Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, from the Committee on...
lead_paragraph: Congress adjourned sine die yesterday at 2 o'clock P.M., the hour previously fixed upon by resolution. Some important legislation marked the closing hours of the session. In the Senate, Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, entered his protest against the use made of certain testimony taken before it, by Senator CHANDLER. The bill to establish a Bureau of Migration was reported from Committee on Foreign Affairs, and will probably be acted upon by the next Congress. The House bill to defray the expenses incurred in raising volunteers in Delaware was passed. The bill making postage and other United States stamps currency was passed. The bill also prohibits the issue of notes of less than one dollar. At 2 o'clock a Committee notified the President that the Senate was ready to adjourn, and the President having no further communication to make, it did adjourn, after passing a vote of thanks to Hon. SOLOMON FOOTE, President pro tem.

abstract: A brief, neat, compre  hensive bill to furnish relief from our currency difficulties passed both Houses of Congress yesterday afternoon, received the signature of the President, and is now a law.
lead_paragraph: -A brief, neat, comprehensive bill to furnish relief from our currency difficulties passed both Houses of Congress yesterday afternoon, received the signature of the President, and is now a law. It provides that from the first of next month, all postage and other United States stamps shall be received for dues of less than five dollars, as a legal tender in ordinary business transactions, and may be obtained in exchange for United States notes. The second section prohibits the issue of shinplasters or currency of less than one dollar by any private corporation or bank; and the third and last section provides penalties for the violation of the second section of the act. This law will effect two good purposes. It will relieve the public of the nuisance of a scarcity of specie change, which has wellnigh become intolerable; and it will be the means of furnishing a loan, of no trifling sum, to the Government. Of the thousand-and-one modes proposed for relieving the small-change scarcity, this is the simplest, justest, most universally applicable and most satisfactory. We stated, the other day, as the main objection to the use of our present style of postage stamps as a general currency, that they stuck to the fingers and the portemonnaie, and quickly got torn, dirty, wasted and uncurrent. But the style of stamps to be issued for currency purposes, under the new law, will obviate these objections, as they will be printed on stout, thick paper, and will have no gum on their backs.

abstract: Recruiting in this City is still actively improving; for the past week every day has shown an in  crease of enlistments over the preceding one. The examining officers at the mustering office in Whitestreet, state that yesterday was one of the busiest days they have had.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting in this City is still actively improving; for the past week every day has shown an increase of enlistments over the preceding one. The examining officers at the mustering office in Whitestreet, state that yesterday was one of the busiest days they have had. From shortly after 8 o'clock A.M., when the office was opened, till past 5 P.M., when it was closed, a steady stream of recruits kept pouring in to be examined. Most of the men that have lately enlisted seem to be a steady, respectable class of people, who are determined that the integrity of the Union must and shall be maintained.

abstract: The Committee appointed at a meeting of influential citizens of the Fifteenth Ward, (included in the Sixth Senatorial District,) held at Clinton Hall on Tuesday evening, for the purpose of taking meas- ...
lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed at a meeting of influential citizens of the Fifteenth Ward, (included in the Sixth Senatorial District,) held at Clinton Hall on Tuesday evening, for the purpose of taking measures to aid enlistments, met yesterday, in the Comittee Room of the Board of Councilmen. Capt. CHAS. H. MARSHALL was Chairman, and P. O'SHEA, Secretary. The following are the names of those gentlemen who were present: Charles H. Marshall, A.T. Stewart, Wm. Allen Butler, R.W. Townsend, Councilman Lent, Maltby G. Lane, Seabury Brewster, and P. O'Shea. The object of the meeting was to decide whether the increased bounty to be offered to recruits be raised by private subscription or by the Common Council.

abstract: On Sunday morning, Capt. CONNELLY, of the  Police, received information that a German living in Canal-street, named ANTOINE SCHAFFER, had been boasting of having had revenge on the New-Jersey Railroad Company, for not allowing him to pass over the ferry free, by throwing a train off the track.
lead_paragraph: -- On Sunday morning, Capt. CONNELLY, of the Police, received information that a German living in Canal-street, named ANTOINE SCHAFFER, had been boasting of having had revenge on the New-Jersey Railroad Company, for not allowing him to pass over the ferry free, by throwing a train off the track. Accordingly, in the afternoon he was arrested by Chief WAMBOLD and Capt. CONNELLY, and placed in close confinement. The circumstances of the case are as follows: On Thursday SCHAFFER went to New-York to look for work, and on his return, toward evening, endeavored to pass the ferry-master without paying. He was stopped, and after some words, threw down two cents, and ran through. Not having enough money to ride out in the cars, he walked, and on the way, stopped at one of the houses used by signal men, to get a light for his cigar. Finding the man asleep, he stole a flag used for signaling trains to run slow, and put it in his pocket.

lead_paragraph: The enthusiasm in Massachusetts continues unabated, and there is hardly a town which has not offered generous bounties to volunteers. Northampton, for instance, gives $70; Hadley, $100; Amherst, $125; Hatfield, $100; Goshen, $100; Worthington, $100; and, with characteristic liberality, Mr. WILLISTON, of East Hampton, has pledged to give as large an amount as the town raises.

abstract: A POLICEMAN COMMITTED TO THE TOMES.  JOHN S. TAYLOR, a Policeman of the Fifth Precinct, yesterday arrested a woman and conveyed her before Justice CONNOLLY, upon the charge of gross intoxication.
lead_paragraph: A POLICEMAN COMMITTED TO THE TOMES. -- JOHN S. TAYLOR, a Policeman of the Fifth Precinct, yesterday arrested a woman and conveyed her before Justice CONNOLLY, upon the charge of gross intoxication. During the investigation of the charge before the Magistrate, some things transpired which induced the Policeman to believe that he was not being fairly treated by the Court, and he therefore said in substance: "I am not treated right; I have no justice done to me; I am not treated like other officers; rum is at the top and bottom of it." The Justice thereupon reprimanded the Officer, and stated to him that in order to maintain the dignity of the Court, and to protect it from insult, he must commit him to the Tombs for five days, and sentence him to pay a fine of $5 for a contempt of Court, Mr. TAYLOR was accordingly committed to prison.

abstract: Driggs vs. Williams The suit in this case grew out of partnership relations that existed between the parties prior to the month of June, 1842. A bill had been filed in Chancery, and judgement was entered on the 8th day of June, 1842.
lead_paragraph: Driggs vs. Williams. -- The suit in this case grew out of partnership relations that existed between the parties prior to the month of June, 1842. A bill had been filed in Chancery, and judgement was entered on the 8th day of June, 1842. The matter rested here until the 6th day of June, 1862, when an order of arrest was obtained. The defendant was not found until the 8th day of June last. The counsel for the defence now moved to vacate and set aside an order in proceedings supplementary to execution, insisting that the Statute of Limitations applied to the case, and that the presumption of law was, that the judgment had been paid, and, moreover, that the equitable powers even of a court of law would favor such a view. The counsel for the plaintiff maintained that the twenty years had not expired till the close of the 8th day of June, and that the true interpretation of the language of the Statute was in his favor.
headline: {'main': 'Judgment The Statute of Limitations.; SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS. Before Justice Clerke.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Judgment The Statute of Limitations.; SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS. Before Justice Clerke.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On receipt of the intelligence of MORGAN'S movements, great excitement was created in Louisville. Mr. W.H. REASER was among the speakers at a meeting held to devise defensive measures.
lead_paragraph: On receipt of the intelligence of MORGAN's movements, great excitement was created in Louisville. Mr. W.H. REASER was among the speakers at a meeting held to devise defensive measures. He said the City of Louisville can take care of herself, but the sympathizers with secession, the mischief-makers who rejoice in rebel successes and grow frantic with joy over Union reverses, will have to leave here, or behave themselves very quietly. We are getting tired of allowing them to go free on bond for good behavior, and then to insult us by their sympathy with the country's vilest enemies. Our country is a great, merciful and magnanimous country -- it can well afford to be so -- but, in trying times like these, magnanimity may cease to be a virtue if exercised on behalf of those who would rejoice to see an enemy in our streets, robbing our banks, firing our houses, and devastating our hearthstones. There is no use of multiplying words or holding parley with treason; the people will have the fullest guarantees that Secessionists shall not remain among us. Louisville wants none but loyal people in her midst when treason braves the field. We cannot consent to shake hands with traitors, and the security of our hearthstones is more sacred to us than is the blood of every Secessionist in Kentucky. He wished to use no harsh language or to advise any harsh measures, but there is an evil existing which demands an immediate remedy, and whatever is demanded as that remedy must be administered, let the blow fall where it may.

abstract: -Mr. DIVEN, Member of Congress from this State, who is engaged in raising volunteers among his constituents, has written a brief letter to a gentleman engaged in the same work, in which he remarks: "Don't say that we must resort to drafting. We have not the time to draft." There is no doubt of the truth of this remark. If men will volunteer with any sort of promptitude, the new muster can be raised much quicker in that way than by drafting. There would be many delays in the latter mode which do not appertain to volunteering. And as volunteering is the speediest mode of raising troops, it is consequently the best. The Secretary of State, in a note urging an officer to aid Mr. DIVEN, says: "All is well if we instantly show our strength." This is the voice that comes from every quarter in which the circumstances of the case are known, and it is a voice which the country must heed.

abstract: DR. REA VS. THE KINGS COUNTY MEDICAL SOCIETY. This Society, as we have before recorded, was thrown into a spasm a few weeks ago at the narrow ...
lead_paragraph: DR. REA VS. THE KINGS COUNTY MEDICAL SOCIETY. -- This Society, as we have before recorded, was thrown into a spasm a few weeks ago at the narrow escape they had from admitting as a member a gentleman whose complexion is of the contraband standard -- one-fourth black. His application was referred to the censors, and they reported him duly qualified, and the Society was about to vote to admit him, when a gentleman having no respect for the nerves of those present and with scalpel in hand, laid bare the shade of the candidate's skin. The balloting was at once suspended and the "subject" laid upon the table as one of a too intricate nature to be manipulated upon without consultation and deliberation. At the next regular meeting, the case of Dr. REA was again called up and discussed, with closed doors, in all its various bearings, scientific and artistic, and was again referred to a Committee -- this time of three -- one of whom had favored the motion to admit the candidate, one who was equally opposed under all circumstances, and one who was upon the fence -- open to conviction. The Committee, on Thursday evening last, reported unanimously in favor of admitting the applicant to all the honors of the Society. Upon investigation they not only found that he was a skillful physician with a large practice, but that he was also a scientific man, and would be a great acquisition to the Society. But the Society "did'nt see it," and rejected Dr. REA -- only three members voting for his admission. The King's County Medical Society has relapsed into its wonted quiet, and it is to be hoped the members' nerves may not be disturbed again, or until Dr. REA makes a legal demand to be admitted into their Society.
