abstract: editorial on Pope's advance
snippet: editorial on Pope's advance
lead_paragraph: POPE is determined to justify the terms of the high-sounding address to his army, which he issued the other day. It is announced this morning that the advance of his command has entered the town of Gordonsville, at the junction of the Orange and Alexandria with the Virginia Central Railroad, seventy-six miles from Richmond, and one of the most important points in Eastern Virginia. Over the latter road, as the telegraph tells us, the Richmond rebels obtain three-fourths of their supplies; but not only this, it is also the great route which Stonewall JACKSON and other marauding rebels take in their incursions into the Shenandoah Valley, and in their rush back to the rebel capital again. The holding of Gordonsville also secures Washington from the dangers which perpetually beset that unhappy town. If again it be true that JACKSON is now on the North side of the Blue Ridge, he will find it hard work to get back to Richmond, even should our troops do no more than they have already done in destroying the railroad. Gordonsville is a point the importance of which has long been seen by every one; and if POPE did not contemn and laugh at bases of operations, it would be a real nice base from which to operate upon Richmond. This renewal of active operations against the rebels will greatly cheer and gratify the public; and we hope that the new General-in-Chief of the army will not find it necessary to put a stop to it, for the public are greatly in need of cheer at present.

abstract: Coggswell vs. Kline. -- This was a habeas corpus for the discharge of the defendant, who is a soldier. It was urged that there was no valid reason for his arrest and imprisonment. The following are the facts in the case, as appeared from the papers and argument. The defendant was arrested in June, 1861, on an allegation of fraud. He then gave bail, to which exceptions were taken, but the bail did not justify. A judgment was subsequently obtained for $221 01 against the defendant, and execution was issued against his property, and returned nulla bona. Afterwards, execution was issued against his person, and returned "not found." But having been in this City some six weeks ago, he was arrested and thrown into prison. It was held that where the execution against the person was returned "not found," and no action had been commenced against the Sheriff for neglect to rearrest the party, there could be no doubt as to the right of the prisoner to be discharged. The District Attorney contended that such was not the case; and that the party in interest, (Coggswell, who lives in Connecticut,) or his attorney, ought to have the usual time, eight days' notice, and that he, as counsel for Sheriff, could not safely enter into the merits of the case without the usual notice to the other side, or a waiver of notice by them.
lead_paragraph: Coggswell vs. Kline. -- This was a habeas corpus for the discharge of the defendant, who is a soldier. It was urged that there was no valid reason for his arrest and imprisonment. The following are the facts in the case, as appeared from the papers and argument. The defendant was arrested in June, 1861, on an allegation of fraud. He then gave bail, to which exceptions were taken, but the bail did not justify. A judgment was subsequently obtained for $221 01 against the defendant, and execution was issued against his property, and returned nulla bona. Afterwards, execution was issued against his person, and returned "not found." But having been in this City some six weeks ago, he was arrested and thrown into prison. It was held that where the execution against the person was returned "not found," and no action had been commenced against the Sheriff for neglect to rearrest the party, there could be no doubt as to the right of the prisoner to be discharged. The District Attorney contended that such was not the case; and that the party in interest, (Coggswell, who lives in Connecticut,) or his attorney, ought to have the usual time, eight days' notice, and that he, as counsel for Sheriff, could not safely enter into the merits of the case without the usual notice to the other side, or a waiver of notice by them.

abstract: Union mass meeting held, Jersey City, NJ; progress of military recruiting elsewhere noted
snippet: Union mass meeting held, Jersey City, NJ; progress of military recruiting elsewhere noted
lead_paragraph: One of the largest and most enthusiastic mass meetings ever held in Jersey City, assembled last evening in Van Vorst-square. The Mayor of the city, JOHN B. ROMER, Esq., presided, and upon the platform were the members of the Common Council of Jersey City, Judge GRIFFITH, Judge MARSH, and other prominent citizens. A fine band of music was in attendance, and the large Square was illuminated by bonfires, while over the heads of the immense concourse of people, bursting skyrockets shed innumerable stars of variegated hue.

abstract: Editorial on rumored appointment as General-in-Chief of Army; Editorial on rumored appointment of Halleck as Gen-in-Chief of Army
snippet: Editorial on rumored appointment as General-in-Chief of Army; Editorial on rumored appointment of Halleck as Gen-in-Chief of Army
lead_paragraph: A very current rumor, to the effect that Gen. HALLECK had been appointed to the chief command of the army, takes shape and consistency in dispatches received yesterday afternoon. It is known that Gen. HALLECK has laid down the subordinate function of Commander in the Department of the Mississippi. The order communicating the fact to his troops was issued on Wednesday last, the probable date of his departure for Washington, where his arrival cannot be expected for a day or two. If we may trust the statements now received, the successful Western Commander will assume, as soon as he reaches the Capital, the position so long filled by Gen. SCOTT, and which has been vacant since Gen. MCCLELLAN led the army of the Potomac to the field, namely, that of General-in-Chief.

abstract: disgraceful has been exposed during this war than the open and shameless venality of Sen  ator SIMMONS. He acknowledged that he sold ...
lead_paragraph: disgraceful has been exposed during this war than the open and shameless venality of Senator SIMMONS. He acknowledged that he sold his official influence to procure a gun contract from the War Department, for the sum of $50,000, -- that part of it had been paid, while he expected payment of the residue, and that he was not aware that there was anything wrong in the transaction! This is worthy of a New-York Alderman in the worst days of our Common Council. Nothing worse was ever charged against the members of that body, whose very name was at one time a synonym for official corruption and venality, than this.

abstract: Reports on war in Kentucky and Tennessee
snippet: Reports on war in Kentucky and Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The city has been full of rumors in regard to the engagement which took place at Murfreesboro, Sunday, between the Federal troops stationed there and a brigade of Confederate cavalry. The Federal troops at Murfreesboro consisted of the Third Minnesota and Ninth Michigan, infantry, HEWITT's Artillery, of six pieces, and four companies of the Seventh Pennsylvania Cavalry, most of the latter being out on a scout, at the time the Confederates made the attack. From the most reliable information we can get, it appears there were three regiments of Texas Rangers and two regiments of Georgia Cavalry, under the command of Gen. FORREST, and that they made the attack about 4 o'clock Sunday morning, first upon the camp of the Pennsylvania Cavalry, and then upon the camp of the Ninth Michigan.

lead_paragraph: A large, highly respectable, and extremely patriotic assemblage of the citizens of Newark, N.J., was held in the Park of that city last evening for the purpose of strengthening the hands of the Government in the existing crisis. The occasion seemed to be made quite a holiday; the National flag greeted the eye in every quarter, while the determined resolution to do all that men and money can do to put down the unholy rebellion, was made most apparent. At about 5 o'clock P.M., the meeting organized by the selection of the following officers:

abstract: District Attorney E.D. Smith moved on the case of Ferdinand Demarchi, indicted for the murder of Frank Vincent, on board the ship Blondel, on the 7th of July, 1861. At the time of the alleged murder, ...
lead_paragraph: District Attorney E.D. Smith moved on the case of Ferdinand Demarchi, indicted for the murder of Frank Vincent, on board the ship Blondel, on the 7th of July, 1861. At the time of the alleged murder, the vessel was bound from Sunderland, England, to Singapore, East Indies. The prisoner is a native of Trieste, and is 24 years of age. The deceased was a Frenchman. He had an altercation with the prisoner which resulted in a fight, and the latter stabbed him with a knife. He threw up his arms, exclaiming, "I am killed," and died shortly afterward. The deed was committed while the vessel was in the Mediterranean Sea. The quarrel originally arose as to the relative merits of the prisoner, and deceased as singers, and deceased struck the first blow.

abstract: ators grow rich upon public calamity, and high officials make money out of the country's ruin, it is pleasant to have our faith in human nature and in the Republic fortified by such acts as that of Mr. ASPINWALL, of this City.
lead_paragraph: ators grow rich upon public calamity, and high officials make money out of the country's ruin, it is pleasant to have our faith in human nature and in the Republic fortified by such acts as that of Mr. ASPINWALL, of this City. Having transacted some business inguns for the Government, out of which a profit of over twenty-five thousand dollars accrued to him, he returns the money to the Government "in accordance with a determination not to receive any pecuniary benefit for services rendered." This noble, munificent and patriotic action has called out an order from the War Department, in which Mr. ASPINWALL is warmly thanked; and Secretary STANTON finds also in the deed, "assurance that a Government supported by citizens who thus prefer the public welfare to their private gain must overcome its enemies." The public will unite with Secretary STANTON in his praises of the patriotic spirit which induced this action, and the name of the distinguished merchant will stand in illustrious contrast with those of the cormorants who smell so foully in the nostrils of the nation. It would be well if this noble act might shame into repentance some of these men; and if in this hour, when the nation is pouring out its life blood for their benefit, they should be induced, at least, not to plunder the pockets of the people. The merchants of New-York in general have acted with splendid patriotism and self-denial during the war; but of them all there is none worthier of the country's applause than Wm. H. ASPINWALL.

abstract: The hours from 10 in the morning till 1 P.M., were cheated of their weariness, yesterday, by the instructive as well as amusing attractions presented for ...
lead_paragraph: The hours from 10 in the morning till 1 P.M., were cheated of their weariness, yesterday, by the instructive as well as amusing attractions presented for the patrons of School No. 11, under the direction of Mr. ALONZO HOPPER. After the opening ceremonies, as reading of Scripture and singing of a hymn, declamations in prose occupied the attention of auditors, and absorbed the energies of four young gents, who, each in his turn, put forth efforts which are "beyond criticism." Then came declamation in verse, by three others, who vied with their predecessors. A cherished part of the school exercises now claimed the attention and admiration of all; it was the exhibition drill of Company D, McClellan Grays, conducted entirely, and with the most admirable tact, by one of the schoolboys, in elegant, full-dress uniform, Lieut. J. HOWARD GRAY. The evolutions were performed as might be expected of a company of hale, hearty boys who drill daily in the open air. The uniform was a full suit of gray, with black band and white gloves.

abstract: The death of this gallant and lamented young officer, briefly announced a few days since, claims a more extended obituary. He died at the Brevoort House, in this City, on Sunday last, at the age of 28 years, of a wound received at the battle of June 30, near Richmond.
lead_paragraph: The death of this gallant and lamented young officer, briefly announced a few days since, claims a more extended obituary. He died at the Brevoort House, in this City, on Sunday last, at the age of 28 years, of a wound received at the battle of June 30, near Richmond. His remains were removed for interment to Albany, where his obsequies were attended on Wednesday by the military of that city, and a large concourse of citizens, among whom he had grown to manhood, and whose universal regard he had won by the exhibition of every manly and estimable quality. The solemnities were fitly accompanied by the usual military honors.

abstract: In the Matter of Jesse Allen. -- This was another habeas corpus to discharge Allen from the State Prison, where, it was alleged, he had spent the term of his imprisonment. It appeared from the record that the prisoner was convicted of grand larceny while an inmate of the Penitentiary, and sentenced to four years and eight months in State Prison after the expiration of his term in the Penitentiary. The counsel for the prisoner argued that in consequence of the indefiniteness of the period of confinement in the Penitentiary, (there being no record to show its duration,) and in consequence of four years and eight months having elapsed since the passing of the sentence, the prisoner was entitled to his discharge. The District Attorney argued that the statute was explicit on that point, and that in like cases the one term of confinement always commenced on the expiration of the other; and, that as the prisoner's four years and eight months would not expire till next September, he was not entitled to his discharge. He cited the case of The People ex rel. Madame Restell vs, The Sheriff, where Madam Restell, having been liberated from State Prison on a writ of error, and having been in the custody of the Sheriff for nearly a year, and having been again remanded to prison, was compelled to serve the full term of her imprisonment.

abstract: graph referring to a City cotemporary as "a semi-secession paper, which is principally notorious for having one of its proprietors concerned in swindling the Government," was ...
lead_paragraph: -- Through inadvertence a paragraph referring to a City cotemporary as "a semi-secession paper, which is principally notorious for having one of its proprietors concerned in swindling the Government," was permitted to appear in the TIMES of yesterday. It is needless to say neither of the imputations contained in these phrases applies to the World newspaper. While erratic and possibly disserviceable to the cause of the Union in its peculiar editorial policy, there can be no doubt of the sterling and devoted patriotism of the journal; and while Mr. ALEXANDER CUMMINGS, formerly connected with it, was certainly shown to have exhibited less than his ordinary shrewdness in conducting a portion of the public business placed in his hands, there has been no testimony adduced to raise against him a presumption of dishonesty or "swindling." We make this correction frankly and cheerfully, simply as a tribute to journalistic fairness.

abstract: A BROKER ROBBED OF $1,600 IN WALL-STREET.  Mr. CHARLES H. MEIGS, of the firm of MEIGS  Co., Brokers and Bankers, at No. 50 Exchange-place, was ...
lead_paragraph: A BROKER ROBBED OF $1,600 IN WALL-STREET. -- Mr. CHARLES H. MEIGS, of the firm of MEIGS & CO., Brokers and Bankers, at No. 50 Exchange-place, was robbed yesterday afternoon, in Wall-street, of the sum of $1,600 in United States Treasury Notes. From the evidence given by Mr. MEIGS, before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, we learn that he was passing along Wall-street, carrying two bags of gold, one upon each shoulder, $5,000 in each bag. The $1,600 in Treasury Notes were thrust into a side pocket of his coat. He had not proceeded far on Wall-street, before his attention was directed to three men, who seemed to be watching him very attentively, and following him closely. He immediately suspected their motive, and although both his hands were occupied in holding the bags upon his shoulders, he traveled on as rapidly as possible toward his destination, keeping a watchful eye upon the funds in his pocket. Very soon his three followers all brushed and jostled him as they passed, two upon one side and one on the other, and one of them very skillfully thrust his hand into MEIGS' pocket and took the $1,600 therefrom. They then all started to run away, but Mr. MEIGS, who had constantly kept his eye upon his money, saw which one of the three abstracted it from his pocket, and he thereupon pursued the guilty party as fast as his golden burden would permit. He traced him to a saloon just out of Wall-street, where the thief was arrested by Officer THOMPSON, of the First Precinct, and immediately searched, but no money was found him upon. Justice CONNOLLY committed him for examination. He gave his name as WM. CURTIS, but the Police say this is not his true name. The other parties, it is believed, have escaped with the stolen money.

lead_paragraph: STATES. -- The appeal of the President to the members of Congress from the Border Slave States, on the subject of the gradual abolishment of Slavery in these States, made at the meeting of those members called by the President on last Saturday, together with the response of the members, will be found in this morning's issue. Mr. LINCOLN's remarks, like everything that emanates from him, are clear, direct and earnest. He urges the adoption of his line of policy with great cogency, shows its benefits to the Border States, its necessity to the nation, its bearings upon the rebel States, and the effect it would have in bringing the war to a termination. In these characteristic and eloquent words he closes:

abstract: Some seven miles from Newport on a pretty point where the cool sea breezes bring health again to the exhausted frame, have our authorities placed a ...
lead_paragraph: Some seven miles from Newport on a pretty point where the cool sea breezes bring health again to the exhausted frame, have our authorities placed a new hospital for sick and wounded soldiers -- the Portsmouth Grove Hospital, as it is called. It gives one a most vivid picture of one side of the war. You see there, as in so many other hospitals, what it is that has checked us at Richmond and may yet be our defeat. There they lie in the hospital tents, the most vigorous and the noblest young men of the country, from the slopes of the Alleghanies, from the forests of Maine, from the villages of Michigan, the mountains of New-Hampshire, from New-Jersey and New-York, and Massachusetts and Rhode Island, gathered up by chance from all regiments or fragments of regiments -- some eighteen hundred or two thousand of them. You enter an airy hospital tent; a young man, robust and ruddy, moves his body with an expression of pain, on his board-bed. He has "the rheumatics," he says, in answer to your inquiry -- caught it in night work in the trenches at Yorktown; used to have to work with the pick or spade all night, often up to his knees in water, then get a bit of breakfast and a little sleep and go to other duty, and then again to spading at night. He cannot walk, because he is so lame, and yet he is not nineteen. He belonged to the -- New-Hampshire; they marched through New-York, he said, 1,000 strong, splendid fellows, and now you could almost number them on your fingers. "Fever -- was it?" said I. "Yes;" he replied, "those trenches and that cursed Peninsula!" Next to him lay a man with pale, peaked features, and that peculiar expression of listlessness and hopelessness which indicates the presence of the demon of the camps -- the Typhoid.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship City of Washington we receive advices from Europe four days later than by the Persia. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market for two days amounted to 27,000 bales, the market closing arm at an advance of 1/4d. Breadstuffs were quiet, at a slight decline, and Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 92 1/8@92 1/4. The political news by this arrival is comparatively unimportant. Earl RUSSELL had announced in the British House of Lords that France had declined to enter into a treaty regarding the Slave-trade, similar to the one recently negotiated with the United States. He expressed the belief, however, that she would offer no objection to the exercise of its provisions. Rumors were still current that France would retrace her steps in Mexico. The Paris Constitutionnel says that proceedings against her will terminate only when the glory of the French arms is vindicated and money matters settled. Deputations of cotton manufacturers from Rouen and Lille had visited the Emperor to represent their difficulties. Rumors of French intervention in American affairs are again rife. Russian papers are said to assert that France has invited Russia to join her in an offer of mediation. The London papers continue their daily diatribes on affairs on this side of the Atlantic, but any offer of mediation is discountenanced.

abstract: SOLDIERS. -- It has been suggested by a few persons whose judgment is not as good as their intentions, that our wounded soldiers should receive the appointments under the internal Tax bill. If this plan were not obviously inadmissible from its costliness, and from the laborious and exhausting nature of duties to which it would be cruel to appoint invalids, and useless to promote any but men of great energy, special aptitude and active habits, there would be still the objection that by this means a very few men would be temporarily provided for at great expense, while the majority would be passed by, though equal to the rest in merit, in bravery and in rightful claim to consideration.

abstract: The Board of Commissioners of Health met at the Mayor's office, yesterday afternoon. After the transaction of other business, the Health Officer called ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Commissioners of Health met at the Mayor's office, yesterday afternoon. After the transaction of other business, the Health Officer called the attention of the Board to the report in yesterday's Herald of the proceedings of the Commissioners of Emigration, on Wednesday last, in which it is stated that the letter of His Honor the Mayor, in the TIMES of last Monday, as to the Floating Hospital, was inaccurate, both in regard to the fact of the Commissioners having other hospitals than those on Ward's Island, and as to the causes which operated upon that Board to induce it to supply the necessary funds to support the Floating Hospital. In reference to this, the Health Officer stated as follows:

abstract: The Vosburgh Chasseurs, Eagle Brigade, Fifty-third Regiment New York Volunteers, had a large and fashionable concourse in attendance at dress parade on Wednesday afternoon last, at Camp Scroggs, Red House Grounds, Harlem. The regiment went through the various battalion movements with a high degree of proficiency. The occasion was made still more gratifying by the presentation to Dr. ALEX. B. MOTT U.S.A., Examining Surgeon at this station, of a massive silver ice bowl, as a memento of the regiment's high appreciation and regard for him as a citizen, a soldier, and a faithful public officer. Colonel BUCKINGHAM, commanding this fine regiment, made the presentation in an appropriate and feeling manner, and was neatly and cordially responded to by Dr. MOTT. The testimonial bore the following inscription: "Presented to Dr. ALEX. B. MOTT, Surgeon, U.S.A., by the officers of the 'Vosburgh Chasseurs,' Fifty-third Regiment, N.Y.V., July 16, 1862." After which, the regiment and its guests (including many ladies) sat down to a sumptuous dinner. The President of the United States, Gen. MCCLELLAN, Dr. MOTT, Col. BUCKINGHAM, Lieut.-Col. DENIKE, the staff and line officers, the "Vosburgh Chasseurs" the ladies, &c., were toasted. In the evening, the Glee Club -- Company K -- (German,) serenaded the officers, and the assemblage broke up at a late hour. The testimonial (the workmanship of Messrs. TIFFANY & Co.) will be on exhibition in their window during the next week.

abstract: The crisis of the war and our national existence is upon us. The time has come for the adoption of more decisive measures.
lead_paragraph: The crisis of the war and our national existence is upon us. The time has come for the adoption of more decisive measures. Greater animus and earnestness must be infused into our military movements. Blows must be struck at the vital parts of the rebellion. The Government should employ every available means compatible with the rules of warfare to subject the traitors. Summon to the standard of the Republic all men willing to fight for the Union. Let loyalty, and that alone, be the dividing line between the nation and its foes. Generals should not be permitted to fritter away the sinews of our brave men in guarding the property of traitors, and in driving back into their hands loyal blacks who offer us their labor and seek shelter beneath the Federal flag.

abstract: There is a great deal said all over the country about the somewhat vague publication of charges made against Gen. MITCHEL, and there is a general demand for specifications.
lead_paragraph: There is a great deal said all over the country about the somewhat vague publication of charges made against Gen. MITCHEL, and there is a general demand for specifications. As we happen to be pretty well informed about those points, we presume it is our duty to make known definitely what the charges against Gen. MITCHEL are. He is accused of speculations in cotton. It is alleged that he granted special facilities to a certain cotton buyer, in the way of guards and Government wagons, and that this individual was detected in passing counterfeit and bogus money upon the people, and, being arrested for if, was summarily discharged by order of the General. We have seen in the hands of Col. NORTON, of the Twenty-first Ohio, documents on this point, which, if genuine, and he assured us they were, would be exceedingly difficult to explain. It is not charged that Gen. MITCHEL had anything to do in the way of showing bogus money upon the people,, but many of his officers do believe that he was interested in the cotton business, and used his official position for speculative purposes. While we desire distinctly to disclaim any personal knowledge or responsibility as to the justice of these charges, we feel bound to state that we know more than one prominent officer who has served under Gen. MITCHEL who is firmly persuaded of their truth.

abstract: "If there be one man in New-Orleans who, more than all other men, deserves well of his country, that man is Mr. JOHN McGINNIS, Editor and proprietor of of the True Delta.
lead_paragraph: "If there be one man in New-Orleans who, more than all other men, deserves well of his country, that man is Mr. JOHN MCGINNIS, Editor and proprietor of of the True Delta. He has been faithful among the faithless, and was bold and manly in a time of danger. We commend him to the President of the United States, to Secretary SEWARD, and to Maj.-Gen. BUTLER. He has done more for the cause of freedom and American nationality than all the other newspaper Editors in the State of Louisiana. We trust that President LINCOLN will, in some signal way, evince his appreciation of the pluck of this brave Editor, Long may the True Delta live."

abstract: We receive from Washington a semi-official intimation of the meaning of the recent important occurrences which have come to the knowledge of the public through indirect channels. A dispatch from Washington states:
lead_paragraph: We receive from Washington a semi-official intimation of the meaning of the recent important occurrences which have come to the knowledge of the public through indirect channels. A dispatch from Washington states: "It is known that the President has recently visited Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT, and subsequently Gen. MCCLELLAN and the Army of the Potomac, and now he has the benefit of their experience, as well as that of Gen. POPE, Gen. MITCHEL, and other distinguished military officers. The expected presence in Washington of Major-General HALLECK becomes important in this connection. The current belief is that he will not take the field, but be intrusted with important duties in Washington." The arrangements now known to be consummated, and in course of consummation, are expected to secure everywhere unity of action, or a specific plan of operations against the enemy, the better to insure success, and to prevent all conflict of jurisdiction.

abstract: The Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council, (both branches,) met yesterday, and a report indorsing the action of Governor MORGAN in offering a bounty of $50 on behalf of the State to every volunteer, was unanimously adopted. The faith of the City was pledged to meet its share of the tax which this bounty would impose, and the payment of funds to the volunteers was assured to be continued until the end of the war.

abstract: Editorial on censorship of foreign press
snippet: Editorial on censorship of foreign press
lead_paragraph: "How did you overcome his arguments?" asked a philosopher of a young theologian who had engaged a powerful antagonist. "Arguments!" replied the other, "I said nothing about his arguments. I told him first that he was Judas Iscariot, and next that he was Anti-Christ." There could scarcely be a better illustration than this of the treatment of loyal America at the hands of her European censors. We are barbarians, cut-throats, madmen, idiots, steeped to the lips in hallucination and folly. We are attempting what is impossible, and what, if it were possible, would be extremely undesirable. Our patriotism is a sham, our love of freedom a delusion. Our finances are rotten, our army and navy are mere bloated symbols of incapacity. Epithets are exhausted in the bombardment of vituperation, so that absolutely new adjectives are invented to describe American unworthiness. The persistent repetition of untruth is said to persuade even the relator of his own veracity; and every one knows that if only plenty of mud is thrown, some of it is certain to stick. It would seriously appear that the foreign Press has been solely actuated by a determination to realize the force of these two apothegms. Our arguments arc rebutted by the simple logic of abuse, and, instead of being held up for the world's praise as patriots battling for their country's salvation, we are pilloried for its scorn as the types of everything which is mean and execrable.

abstract: The annual Exhibition of St. Joseph's Academy, Flushing, L.I., took place on the 16th inst., before a large and highly respectable audience, composed of a great many clergymen from Brooklyn and New-York, as well as the parents, friends and patrons of the Institution.
lead_paragraph: The annual Exhibition of St. Joseph's Academy, Flushing, L.I., took place on the 16th inst., before a large and highly respectable audience, composed of a great many clergymen from Brooklyn and New-York, as well as the parents, friends and patrons of the Institution. Among the clergymen present, we noticed Rev. Messrs. McGorrick, Williamsburgh; Campbell, do.; O'Bierne, Flushing; Cassidy, O'Neill, Fagan, Turner, McEnroe, Keegan, McKenna, Brooklyn; and Phelan, Astoria. Before saying anything about the Exhibition, perhaps it would not be out of place to give a short history of St. Joseph's Academy. The institution is under the charge of the sisters of St. Joseph, who have also an academy in Williamsburgh. They purchased the present location in Flushing somewhat about a year ago. The place was formerly occupied as a College by the Episcopalians under the guidance of Dr. HAWKS, of this City. The grounds are very pleasantly situated near the Railroad depot, and everything connected with the institution is kept in that neat and cleanly manner which is so thoroughly carried out by the good sisters of St. Joseph. A better place for an academy for young ladies it would be difficult to find; and we have no doubt that before many years this will become one of the most flourishing Catholic institutions in this country.

lead_paragraph: The Picayune says that WM. WILSON, better known as Red BILL -- the genuine original Red BILL -- has been made a prisoner. The honor of his capture belongs to Lieut. DUANE, of the Fourth District Po lice. BILL had gone into retirement on the banks of Lake Salvador, a small sheet of inland water which lies on the opposite side of the river, about twelve miles distant from Carrollton. It is said that BILL had a female companion, but she was absent when the force under Lieut. DUANE surrounded his camp and demanded the surrender of its solitary occupant. But we anticipate.

abstract: -- A fire occurred in the rear of No. 133 Eldridge-street at 6 o'clock last evening, on the premises occupied in the basement by FRANK HAGERMAN, as a vinegar factory. Damage to stock and building $1,200; insured. Mr. WOOD, manufacturer of seamen's chests, occupied the second and third floors of the building. Loss not known. The tenement house No. 150 Forsyth-street, owned by HENRY MAY, was damaged about $100. A number of tenants in the buildings lost in the aggregate about $400 worth of furniture, not insured. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: A few evenings ago we met with Mr. MORTON MORRIS, a gentleman who recently ran the Southern blockade to avoid the conscription act.
lead_paragraph: A few evenings ago we met with Mr. MORTON MORRIS, a gentleman who recently ran the Southern blockade to avoid the conscription act. He is the son of PASCHALL MORRIS, of Philadelphia, and for a number of years kept an agricultural warehouse at Galveston, Texas. His account is most entertaining, and the difficulties and dangers to which he was subjected, and which he so daringly and ingeniously overcame, speak well for his loyalty to the old flag. It was the second time he attempted to escape. When he returned after the first trial he found they had advertised him, but his return gave them confidence and in a measure paved the way for his final attempt. He left Galveston on the 11th of May, on the 15th the conscription act went in operation. When he arrived at New-Iberia, Louisiana, an order was telegraphed from Opelousas, the present rebel capital of Louisiana, not to permit any person to pass the lines. The route taken by him was opened since the blockade from Galveston to Houston, thence due east across Louisiana to New-Orleans by railroad, stage and boat. Innumerable inquiries were met with the reply that he was en route for the rebel army, and many most affecting messages were confided to him for sons and brothers serving in the secesh ranks. Arriving at Algiers, he was taken to Col. MCFILLAN, of the Federal army, who, after listening to his story, complimented him. He also received like praise from Gen. BUTLER, in New-Orleans. After spending three weeks there, he started for Boston, and from thence returned home. Mr. MORRIS states that ANDREW J. HAMILTON, of Austin, who, at the commencement of the secession movement, battled strongly for Union in Congress, is still a staunch and brave Unionist. With a small number of compatriots he for a long time defied secession in his own home at Austin, but becoming overpowered, he retreated to his ranche in the northwest part of the State, to which place his friends followed and clustered about him. SAM HOUSTON is living yet, a strong Union man at heart, but seems to have been broken down physically and in spirit by reason of our National trouble. In a Galveston company connected with the Lone Star Regiment, nine-tenths are Northern men; they were compelled to fight or starve. Two or three schooners run the blockade during a week, the Government vessels being to unwieldy that they can clear it easily. Their military bands consist of a drummer and fifer, both colored, and their National airs are "Dixie" and "Donny Blue Flag." Had Mr. MORRIS remained in secessia twelve hours longer he would have been drafted.

abstract: According to the accounts issued by the Board of Trade in London for the month of May, the number of vessels entered at British ports, under the flag of the United States, during the five months last past, was 477, against 780 in the corresponding period of last year, and 558 in that of 1860, the aggregate tonnage falling, at the same time, from 552,501 tons and 703,195 tons, to 407,267 tons.
lead_paragraph: According to the accounts issued by the Board of Trade in London for the month of May, the number of vessels entered at British ports, under the flag of the United States, during the five months last past, was 477, against 780 in the corresponding period of last year, and 558 in that of 1860, the aggregate tonnage falling, at the same time, from 552,501 tons and 703,195 tons, to 407,267 tons. There cleared from the British ports 433 American vessels, of 371,812 tons, against 653 and 593,213 tons in the corresponding period of last year, and 573 and 551,524 tons in that of 1860. But the number of vessels which arrived at British ports, from ports in the United States, irrespective of nationality, was 770, of 612,066 tons, against 1,344 ships and 1,080,552 tons in the corresponding five months of 1861, and 864 ships and 813,501 tons in those of 1860; and the number which cleared from British for American ports was 444, of 452,585 tons, against 709 and 635,741 tons in the first five months of last year, and 654 and 611,439 tons in the corresponding period of 1860. The total value of the British manufactures and produce exported to the United States was 4,615,442, being about one-eighth of the total exports from Great Britain to all parts of the world, and considerably more than was exported to any other country, or to any British possession, not excluding even India. This total was made up chiefly of the following articles, the exports of which to this side are shown also for the corresponding periods of 1860 and 1861, for the sake of the comparison:

abstract: MORTALITY There were 152 deaths in this city during the week ending yesterday, from the following causes: Menstrual suppression, casualty, inflammation of the brain, congestion of the lungs, ...
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- There were 152 deaths in this city during the week ending yesterday, from the following causes: Menstrual suppression, casualty, inflammation of the brain, congestion of the lungs, whooping-cough, epilepsy, cancer, erysipelas, inflammation of the stomach, disease of the heart, croup, delirium tremens, malignant pustule, hemorrhage from the car, and diarrhoea, 1 each; suffocation, inflammation of the lungs, bronchitis, inflammation of the bowels, and puerperal fever, 2 each; apoplexy, old age, dysentery, premature birth, teething, measles, and debility, 3 each; diphtheria, 4; typhoid fever, 5; scarlet fever, 6; hydrocephalus, 7; congestion of the brain, 9; marasmus, 10; consumption, 11; cholera infantum, 23; convulsions, 26; still born, 6. Males, 74; females, 78. One hundred and six of those who died were five years of age and under.

abstract: Commanders of a corps d'armee, or of a division of this command, may grant passes for the day to officers and men of their commands which must be signed by one or two staff officers who must be designated for the purpose, and whose signatures are to be ...
lead_paragraph: Commanders of a corps d'armee, or of a division of this command, may grant passes for the day to officers and men of their commands which must be signed by one or two staff officers who must be designated for the purpose, and whose signatures are to be immediately reported to the Provost Marshal of the corps d'armee. These passes will not be construed to permit their bearers to leave the vicinity of their respective stations, or to visit the City of Washington, except as above specified. No officer or soldier of this army will be permitted to leave his command on any pretence whatever, without special authority from these headquarters. All officers found absent from their commands five days after the date of this order will be arrested and tried for disobedience of orders. All soldiers absent after that time will be confined and returned under guard to their regiments for trial by Court-martial. By command of.

abstract: editorial on dangers in using such currency; editorial on dangers in using such currency
snippet: editorial on dangers in using such currency; editorial on dangers in using such currency
lead_paragraph: -- Two evils have been pointed out as likely to attend the use of Postage Stamps as a legal tender in business transactions. One is their tendency to inflate the currency. This objection, however, is futile, and the danger from this source quite imaginary. For the Postage Stamp money cannot, from the restrictions placed upon it, be issued to a larger amount than will supply the place of the silver and other coin which speculation and a rising specie market have withdrawn from circulation. In proportion as silver coin disappears postage stamps will fill up the vacuum in the currency, and the aggregate of this new species of small change will adjust itself, and contract or expand its volume in proportion as silver coin is more or less scarce. All apprehensions of any excessive issues of this small currency may, then, be dismissed, while its numerous advantages are confessed by all.

abstract: The large area of territory won by the arms of the Nation, requiring numerous garrisons to hold the military positions thereof, the casualties incident to war, together with the threatened interference of two of the great Powers of Europe to destroy our greatness and diminish our power, have caused the President of the United States to call for 300,000 men, to secure the Nation's integrity, and if needs be to punish properly the impertinent intermeddling with our internal affairs. Of this number, the State of Virginia has been called upon to furnish 2,080 men, as her proportion, for the term of three years, or during the war.

abstract: The meeting at the Cooper Institute, on the 1st inst., was called just at the right time, in our opinion, though we think perhaps some of its managers may wish that it had been delayed a little. When it was called, the fall of Richmond, as they thought, and as we all thought, was near at hand. The rebellion was about to be overthrown at once, and then was the time to prepare the way for political action which should enable them to play the old game over again, -- to lay the foundations of a party among us which should, by the aid of the States which have been deep in the rebellion, seize the reins of power, the places of trust and patronage for the same hungry gang who occupied them, with the aid of the South, before the rebellion. And if our army had entered Richmond, we fear it would have proved the signal for divisions among us, for the uprising of an organized opposition to the Administration, which would have insisted upon throwing away all good fruits of the rebellion and leaving only the evil, under the false plea of restoring the Union as it was.

lead_paragraph: There is not a little discussion among liquor-dealers and their legal advisers as to the operation of the internal tax law, and its relation to the Excise law of the State. The question is a natural one. Will the $20 license required by section 64 of "retail dealers in liquors, including distilled spirits, fermented liquors, and wines of all kinds," authorize the prosecution of business, without compliance with the State laws? This question is met by section 67, to the effect "that no license shall be construed to authorize the commencement or continuation of any trade, business, etc., within any State or territory in which it is or shall be specially prohibited by the laws thereof, or in violation of the laws of any State or territory, and nothing in this act shall be held or construed so as to prevent the several States from placing a duty, tax or license for State purposes, or any business on which a duty, tax or license is required to be paid by this act." That is sufficiently explicit, it would seem, to settle the mooted point.

abstract: The advertised trotting match for a purse and stake, which was to have taken place on Friday, on the above course, did not come off; but as quite a number of sporting men and patrons of the turf were present, a new match was made, for entrance money and gate money, between some horses from the sale stables in Twenty-fourth-street, near Third-avenue, which, from the number and closeness of the heats and the even quality of the horses, besides the numerous pools sold, (which amounted to nearly $1,200), was one of the most interesting events of the trotting season. The match was made between the owner of a fine black gelding (whose owner withdrew him previous to the start), Mr. JOHNSON's gray mare Kate. Mr. WHITSON's sorrel gelding Gen. Halleck, and Mr. JACK's bay gelding Shark. The latter has been some weeks in charge of DAM MACE, who drove him, while Mr. JOHNSON drove Kate, Mr. WHITSON driving Gen. Halleck. Mr. JOHNSON weighs 190 lbs., the other drivers being light weights.

abstract: The two great mass meetings held in Unionsquare of April, 1861, and July, 1862, are commonly cited as having been similar in object, numbers and enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: The two great mass meetings held in Union-square of April, 1861, and July, 1862, are commonly cited as having been similar in object, numbers and enthusiasm. It is customary to consider the late demonstration as a sort of copy or reindorsement of the first. Such, indeed, it may have appeared to unreflecting eyes, and also to eyes which, more reflecting, wished to see no change. Unquestionably there were many points of similarity. There were banners and cannon, music and shouting, masses of people and high enthusiasm, each and all in abundance at both meetings. Yet there existed between the two a radical difference. It was evident that popular opinion had undergone serious changes, and had made vast strides toward comprehending in their fullest sense the mighty issues depending on the present war. The meeting of last year expressed general indignation at the outrage put upon our flag at Fort Sumter, and a patriotic resolution to see that outrage expiated. It indicated surprise and sorrow at the misconduct of our Southern brethren, and breathed a hope that they would yet see the error of their ways. It avowed a determination to suppress the insurrection and enforce the laws, by the gathering of large forces and abundant means, to be employed in an extremely delicate, considerate and constitutional way. The Herald had only just made its ridiculous sommersault, and FERNANDO WOOD had barely got through insulting the President of the United States on his passage through our City to the capital. The adherents of these two respectable authorities had scarcely got over the bewilderment which the rapid changes going on around them had created. The mass meeting then meant a vigorous support of the Government in the prosecution of the war, within carefully-guarded limits and with a respectful deference for the "peculiar institution;" the mass meeting now means something quite different.

abstract: The Knoxville Register learns from a refugee, who left Huntsville on the 28th of May, that "[???] went from Huntsville across the Tennessee River at Whitesburgh, on a mission to JOHN BELL, who was sojourning at Blount Springs, Ala., to induce him to return to Nashville; that it was said in Huntsville that Mrs. BELL had written to Gen. MITCHEL, requesting him to give her husband a safe passport; that MITCHEL consented to do so, and NICH. DAVIS was the bearer of a message to JOHN BELL from MITCHEL, communicating the wishes of Mrs. BELL, and promising Mr. BELL protection. DAVIS returned, but Mr. BELL did not accompany him. As Mr. BELL's return has never been announced, the inference is [???]  that he refused to accept the invitation to return [???] his home under Federal protection, and that he patriotically awaits a safe conduct under Confederate suspices. As a recent date he was still at Blount [???]."

DURANT, a prominent lawyer and citizen, and Capt. HAGGERTY, of the Division Staff, as Recorder, was ordered by Gen. BUTLER to examine into the matter of his seizure of $50,000 in specie, and other property, at SAMUEL SMITH & Co.'s, at the same time of the seizure at the Consulate of the Netherlands, and to decide whether there was sufficient evidence of SMITH & Co. having aided and comforted the enemy to continue to hold the money and other property for adjudication by the Department at Washington. abstract: Editorial on Congressmen who grant unnecessary furloughs and discharges to servicemen
snippet: Editorial on Congressmen who grant unnecessary furloughs and discharges to servicemen
lead_paragraph: Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, made a telling point in his speech in the Senate, a few days ago, on the apparent waste of human life in the army of the Potomac, since the commencement of the advance upon Richmond. The sum of the matter was this: That what forces Gen. MCCLELLAN took with him when he started to the Peninsula, and what were subsequently sent to him, amounted to 150,000 men; whereas, since the battles before Richmond, and the encamping of the army on James River, only 80,000 of the great army could be found. The inference was that, except the few thousands killed and disabled in battle, all the rest of that noble and patriotic host, who had gone forth to defend their Government, had perished ignobly, from exposure in swamps and in digging ditches! If this was not the import of Senator CHANDLER's speech, then he has a very sorry faculty of making himself understood.

abstract: The city has finally determined to issue shinplasters -- they will be ready in about fifteen days -- they will be printed on bank-note paper, two plates being used. To prevent their being photographed, they will be printed in two colors, black and red, and it is intended that they shall make a creditable appearance. There seems to be a desire on the part of the public that the city should at once issue these notes, while at the same time there is a disposition to discourage the issue of shinplasters by individuals, and the only plan to check such issue is for the city to take the matter in hand, and issue their notes. We understand that the City of Philadelphia has issued shinplasters, notwithstanding there is a law against it, and the effect there has been to afford immediate relief. The Mayor of Philadelphia has made application to our authorities, desiring them to take a quantity to use in this city. It is not probable the necessity which seems to call for this issue will exist for more than two or three weeks, as coin will very rapidly emerge from its lurking-places when the hope of gain which prompted its concealment shall disappear. The notes are being printed by the Union Bank Note Company of this city. -- Newark Mercury, July 15.

abstract: The United States steam transport Star of the South, Capt. WOODHULL, arrived at this port last evening. She sailed from Pensacola July 11, and Key West 14th.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Star of the South, Capt. WOODHULL, arrived at this port last evening. She sailed from Pensacola July 11, and Key West 14th. Left at Pensacola United States sloop-of-war Vincennes and schooner Maria Wood; also ship Young Eagle, bark Evelyn and brig C.F. O'Brien, the latter to sail on the 12th inst. for New-York. She also left at Key West the United States steamer San Jacinto, flag ship; United States steamer Santiago de Cuba, United States steamer Quaker City, United States steamer Pomona, United States steam frigate St. Lawrence, United States bark Pursuit. Also prize steamer Adela, captured by the Quaker City, and prize schooner loaded with cotton, taken by the steamer Pomona.

abstract: -- An association has been formed at Newark, which undertakes to collect gratuitously the back pay and bounty due to the widows and representatives of deceased soldiers. The claimant has only to sign the necessary papers before the County Clerk of Essex to have the whole business transferred from his shoulders to those of the beneficent gentlemen who have so thoughtfully given their charity this direction. Mr. MARCUS L. WARD, whose exertions in creating the State Hospital for sick and wounded soldiers, have been referred to in our columns, is Chairman of the Association. Cannot a similar organization be instituted in New-York?

abstract: -- The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals should take the "anaconda" under its protection, for never was beast so unmercifully belabored as that harmless mythological creation. It is the old story of the fetish-worshiper drubbing his god, for not doing what he never should have expected it to do. The popular degradation of the anaconda is just as senseless as was his former deification. What though some of his joints have been loosened, and he himself parted in twain, his remaining segments are vital still. Will the abusers of the anaconda consider that it is his fiery folds that hold the whole rebel coast in their tight, terrible grip -- from the Chesapeake to the Rio Grande? Here, at least, he is doing the work of a genuine anaconda, and he should get due credit for it, instead of the vials of vituperation that are now poured on his head. It is like human nature to undervalue present benefactors. But let us suppose our coast to be not thus begirt, and we may form some idea of the immense silent service rendered by the anaconda. Imagine that, instead of holding the long stretch of seaboard by our vessels and our troops, it were possessed by the rebels -- the seaports free for them to receive supplies of all kinds from abroad? And what complexion would intervention take if, instead of holding the seaports of the South in the most perfect blockade ever established, and having our corps of ten or a dozen regiments dotted here and there all along the coast, the rebels could salute and solicit Europe from the Atlantic shore? It is the great marine anaconda that, more than anything else, keeps the hands of Europe off. We hope, therefore, that this part of the anaconda will not be weakened. It is true that, by removing the expeditionary armies that occupy various points along the coast, it would be possible to employ them in work more active, but not, in the long run, more useful and effective. So along our long Southwestern inland line and on the Mississippi River the anaconda still well performs his part. Let us give the anaconda his due.
lead_paragraph: -- The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals should take the "anaconda" under its protection, for never was beast so unmercifully belabored as that harmless mythological creation. It is the old story of the fetish-worshiper drubbing his god, for not doing what he never should have expected it to do. The popular degradation of the anaconda is just as senseless as was his former deification. What though some of his joints have been loosened, and he himself parted in twain, his remaining segments are vital still. Will the abusers of the anaconda consider that it is his fiery folds that hold the whole rebel coast in their tight, terrible grip -- from the Chesapeake to the Rio Grande? Here, at least, he is doing the work of a genuine anaconda, and he should get due credit for it, instead of the vials of vituperation that are now poured on his head. It is like human nature to undervalue present benefactors. But let us suppose our coast to be not thus begirt, and we may form some idea of the immense silent service rendered by the anaconda. Imagine that, instead of holding the long stretch of seaboard by our vessels and our troops, it were possessed by the rebels -- the seaports free for them to receive supplies of all kinds from abroad? And what complexion would intervention take if, instead of holding the seaports of the South in the most perfect blockade ever established, and having our corps of ten or a dozen regiments dotted here and there all along the coast, the rebels could salute and solicit Europe from the Atlantic shore? It is the great marine anaconda that, more than anything else, keeps the hands of Europe off. We hope, therefore, that this part of the anaconda will not be weakened. It is true that, by removing the expeditionary armies that occupy various points along the coast, it would be possible to employ them in work more active, but not, in the long run, more useful and effective. So along our long Southwestern inland line and on the Mississippi River the anaconda still well performs his part. Let us give the anaconda his due.

abstract: The People ex rel. Frederica W. Neidlinger vs. Ann Lohman, alias Restell. This was an application for an attachment against the person of Mme. Restell, the famous female physician. In August, 1855, the relator, who was enciente at the time, came to live with the respondent as a domestic servant, and continued to live with her for eleven months.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Frederica W. Neidlinger vs. Ann Lohman, alias Restell. -- This was an application for an attachment against the person of Mme. Restell, the famous female physician. In August, 1855, the relator, who was enciente at the time, came to live with the respondent as a domestic servant, and continued to live with her for eleven months. Soon after her arrival a male child was born to the relator, and immediately on its birth it was intrusted to a Mrs. Wright for a few days, but was afterward given by respondent for adoption to an unknown lady who lived in the country. On the 14th of November, 1856, a habeas corpus was issued by Judge Roosevelt requiring the respondent to show cause why the child should not be given up. The case was immediately referred for examination into the facts, but after the filing of the referee's report, as there appeared no satisfactory result, an order of court was granted in April, 1858, to the effect that an attachment should issue, unless the respondent should set forth, in an amended return, to whom and by what authority she parted with the child. It was alleged for the defence that the child was given away by the free will and at the request of the relator. The matter rested here until September, 1861, when another order was issued, to show further cause why an attachment should not issue against the respondent. Testimony was again taken, but nothing further was elicited about the person to whom the child had been given, or as to the child's whereabouts at the time. The relator was determined not to let the matter rest here, and accordingly, on Friday last, applied for an attachment against the defendant, who, it was alleged, was an abortionist by profession. Proof to that effect was offered by the counsel for relator, in one of the respondent's own advertisements in the Sunday Times of July 13, but the Court refused to admit the evidence. Decision reserved.

abstract: "Gen. HALLECK has ordered Memphis to be fortified, and the work has begun. This will enable us to garrison the place with a small force, and will give to the Union people a sense of security against attack from those flying bands who are traversing the country.
lead_paragraph: "Gen. HALLECK has ordered Memphis to be fortified, and the work has begun. This will enable us to garrison the place with a small force, and will give to the Union people a sense of security against attack from those flying bands who are traversing the country. Contrabands owned by Secesh are to be used in the work. Seventeen hundred of them have already commenced cutting a canal around back of Vicksburgh, which will carry the bed of the river ten or fifteen miles east of that sweet little village, thus rendering it an inland town, and destroying its importance forever. It is a pity that some such poetic justice could not be dealt out to Charleston. Gen. GRANT says he is not going to make his soldiers work this hot weather, when the country is swarming with able and willing hands, who can bear the heat so much better.

abstract: Business has been checked during the past week by the reluctance of holders to sell, unless at materially advanced prices.
lead_paragraph: Business has been checked during the past week by the reluctance of holders to sell, unless at materially advanced prices. Some importers have withdrawn their supplies of foreign altogether, until the exchange market shall have become more settled. Domestic is coming in to market rather more freely, and finds ready and eager buyers. The week's sales include 100,000 lbs. Domestic fleece, at 48c.@55c.; 40 bales Lamb's Pulled, at 50c.; 50 bales California, at 23c.@35c.; 59 bales Rio Grande, at 25c. for washed and 16c. for unwashed; 240 bales Spanish and 200 bales Mestiza on terms not disclosed. abstract: Recruiting for the United States Navy has begun on an entire new basis. Henceforward the rule for enlisting men for three years exclusively will be abolished, and seamen can ship for any term not less than a year, which they may choose. Already the recruiting officer of the receiving ship Alleghany, at Baltimore, the North Carolina, at this port, and the Ohio, at Boston, have put the new law in force, and are enlisting men under it. Naval recruiting has recently been brightening up. Over 110 men were enlisted in this City last week, being a clear increase of 40. There are now over 300 effective sailors on board the receiving ship Ohio, at Boston, and more than 500 in the North Carolina, and nearly as many in Baltimore and Portland, Maine. Seven hundred have been enlisted at Portsmouth, N.H., a large number at New-Bedford, at Chicago, St. Louis and Cairo, so that, for a short time, at least, we shall hear no more of the scarcity of crews for our men-of-war.

abstract: A WASHINGTON BANKER ROBBED BY HIS SERVANT ARREST OF THE GUILTY PARTY IN THIS CITY.  Mr. W.W. CORCORAN, the celebrated Washington banker, appeared before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of entering a complaint of theft against a former servant of his, named DANIEL WINSLOW.
lead_paragraph: A WASHINGTON BANKER ROBBED BY HIS SERVANT -- ARREST OF THE GUILTY PARTY IN THIS CITY. -- Mr. W.W. CORCORAN, the celebrated Washington banker, appeared before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of entering a complaint of theft against a former servant of his, named DANIEL WINSLOW. Mr.CORCORAN was accompanied to the Police Court by Ex-Mayor BERRET, of Washington, and Mr. HIRAM CRANSTON, the proprietor of the New-York Hotel. The complainant made an affidavit to the effect that on or about the 30th day of June last, WINSLOW, who was then a servant in his employ, in the City of Washington, feloniously stole and carried away from his house in the last-named city, the following articles, viz.: one silver-cased sword, of the value of $100; one linen shirt, $17; three napkins, 50 cents; one large table cloth, $20; one musical box, $17; one silver sugar tongs, $3; one silver slide, $1 -- Total, $1.8 50. Upon this affidavit, a warrant was immediately issued and placed in the hands of Officer POOLE, of the Fifteenth Precinct, who proceeded to the residence the accused, No. 195 Sixth-avenue, where he arrested WINSLOW, and after considerable search the officer succeeded in recovering all of the stolen property. The prisoner was then conveyed before Justice KELLY, and asked what he had to say to the change preferred against him. He replied that he was guilty, and said that he would live and be raised back in Washington for trial. The Justice in answer to this request, stated that he would see that the requisite papers were immediately made out, so that he might be sent on to the Capital for trial without delay; in the meantime he must be committed to the Jefferson Market Prison.

abstract: The mustering office in White-street was kept all day yesterday in an extraordinary state of bustle and excitement, by the recruiting offices throughout the City hurrying up with their squads of newly enlisted volunteers.
lead_paragraph: The mustering office in White-street was kept all day yesterday in an extraordinary state of bustle and excitement, by the recruiting offices throughout the City hurrying up with their squads of newly enlisted volunteers. The ninety dollars bounty and advance pay, now guaranteed to every one who spontaneously responds to the call for fresh troops, is having the effect of bringing men along faster than was expected -- first-class men, most of them are, too, equal in all respects to those who composed some of the first and best regiments that New-York sent to the war. Besides the large number enrolled at the White-street office, several of the commanders of regiments under way here have sent a great many recruits up to the various encampments to be mustered in. This has been a considerable relief to the United States officers at the former place, and adds to the total of enlistments a good deal more extensively than the official figures would seem to show. In every way the prospects of soon raising the Empire State's quota of the additional army of three hundred thousand are brighter than ever.

abstract: The Beekman Hill Methodist Church has just completed its new Sabbath School Hall, the finest in the City, which was duly dedicated, yesterday, with appropriate services.
lead_paragraph: The Beekman Hill Methodist Church has just completed its new Sabbath School Hall, the finest in the City, which was duly dedicated, yesterday, with appropriate services. The building is situated on Fiftieth-street, between First and Second avenues, on the rear of four lots, measuring 105 by 130 feet. It measures 40 feet by 108, and is two stories high. The lower floor is set apart for infant class-rooms, Bible class-rooms, Minister's study, a kitchen and tea-room, to be used on festival occasions, Secretary's and Librarian's rooms, and a fine Young Men's reading-room. The main Sunday School Hall on the second floor is 76 by 38 feet in size, with 25 feet ceiling. The plastering, cornicing, coping and general finish of the interior are in the utmost good taste. Including the organ-loft, there are seats for about 1,200. The light at night proceeds from two circular clusters near the ceiling, with about forty jets each, fitted beneath concave reflectors. This not only sheds a brilliant light throughout the room, but is less trying to the eyes than side-lights or chandeliers, and affords an efficient aid to ventilation by a current which is caused to rush past the burners through an aperture in the roof. The building cost 12,000 exclusive of the ground. It is in contemplation to erect in the course of about two years, a fine church edifice on the front of the lots. The society has been formed eighteen months. Rev. JOHN S. MITCHELL, D.D., is the present pastor. The services yesterday morning were conducted by the pastor, assisted by Rev. Mr. PALMER, who made the prayer, and Bishop JANES, who preached the sermon from Matt. v.,13: "Ye are the salt of the earth, &c." The choir led by Dr. MITCHELL, jr., is excellent, and has the assistance of a fine organ. Rev. J.P. NEWMAN was called to preach the afternoon sermon, and Dr. STEVENS in the evening. The attendance was large, and the contributions in aid of the church liberal.

abstract: We are glad to see that the Navy Department is vigorously pushing forward the building of our new iron-clads. It is announced to-day that in three months ten of them are to be completed. It would be improper to reveal the secrets of the workshops and navy-yards, but we can say that such strides in advance have been made in iron naval construction that our next gunboats will be a new article altogether. That great geometer in iron, ERICSSON, has been diligently at work, and has already effected improvements that render the Monitor all but obsolete. England, France and Spain have each official agents in this country, picking up what hints they can as to our new iron navy. It would be well not to let them know too much.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the Navy Department is vigorously pushing forward the building of our new iron-clads. It is announced to-day that in three months ten of them are to be completed. It would be improper to reveal the secrets of the workshops and navy-yards, but we can say that such strides in advance have been made in iron naval construction that our next gunboats will be a new article altogether. That great geometer in iron, ERICSSON, has been diligently at work, and has already effected improvements that render the Monitor all but obsolete. England, France and Spain have each official agents in this country, picking up what hints they can as to our new iron navy. It would be well not to let them know too much.

abstract: ITEMS. -- It requires the constant attendance of a Police force at the Brooklyn City Hospital, to prevent outsiders from supplying the sick soldiers with cheap whisky and gin....The grocery of JOHN MYERS, corner of Flushing-avenue and Spencer-street, was robbed on Saturday night of $14 in silver and a revolver valued at $10....A lot of silverware, marked "H.C. BEEBE." was found buried in a vacant lot on Elliott-place, on Saturday, by some workmen who were excavating, supposed to have been the proceeds of a robbery. The articles can be seen at the office of the Deputy Inspector of Police, basement of the City Hall....Sergeants CROFT and CURRAN, of the Forty-second Precinct, at an early hour yesterday morning, made a descent upon a disorderly house kept by FRANCIS MURPHY, at No. 10 Franklin-place, and arrested three of the inmates named PERCY MOTT, CAROLINE VELSOR and MARIA WILSON. They were committed as vagrants, having no "visible" means of support....A little girl, three years old, named TERESA HOWARD, at about 7 1/2 o'clock Saturday evening, fell from a window in the third story of a house on Twenty-first-street, between Third and Fourth avenues, but without receiving serious injury. ....The bulk of the hay and harvest crops of Long Island has been secured. The farmers say that there is an average crop....THOMAS JOHNSON, son of ALEXANDER JOHNSON, of Douglas Farm, Flushing, of the the firm of WIRT & JOHNSON, publishers, Richmond, is in prison at the latter place, on suspicion of being disloyal to the rebel Government.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon, between 8 and 9 o'clock, the steam propeller Blanche Page, Capt. WILLIAM ELLSWORTH, having in tow the barge Cremorne, on board of which was a large number of excursionists, started down the Bay for the Fishing Banks. Most of the party belonged in Brooklyn and Jersey City. On leaving the dock about fifty of them went on board of the towboat, but tills being against the rules they were required to go on board of the barge, which they did, with considerable reluctance. This was but just accomplished, as they were passing Red Hook Point, when a terrible explosion took place on the propeller, and in an instant the air was filled with flying fragments of timber, other materials, and an immense volume of steam from the boiler. When this had cleared away it was found that a piece of the boiler, about 3 1/2 feet in length and 2 in width, directly in front of the steam-pipe and smoke-stack, had blown out with such force as to carry away the roof extending from the rear of the smoke-stack to the front of the pilot-house, a distance of about 18 feet, and also shattering the sides of the house.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic meeting was held on Saturday evening by the citizens of the Sixteenth Ward, in the Eighth District Court-room, corner of Seventh-avenue and Twenty-second-street, with a view to the raising of a regiment of Volunteers in that District, under the recent requisition made by the President. Mr. W.J. HASKETT presided. Mr. D.R. JAQUES then spoke, stating the object of the meeting, and, in conclusion, offered a number of resolutions, to the effect that the residents of the Sixteenth Ward pledge their earnest efforts to the raising of men and means for the prosecution of the war. Also, that a Committee of five citizens of that Ward be appointed to act with the Military Committee of the Sixth Senatorial District, in promoting enlistments and otherwise aiding in the organization of regiments in the District. Also, that a Finance Committee be appointed and authorized to collect funds in the Ward, to defray the expenses of Committees and for the support of the families of such as enlist.

abstract: An important step toward perfecting the piano-forte has lately been made by Mr. HORATIO WORCESTER, of this City. By a very simple process this experienced manufacturer has contrived to obtain the whole vibration of which the sounding board is capable, and in so doing has fairly doubled the quantity and musical quality of the tone throughout the entire scale. The instruments which we have examined containing the improvement are 7 1/4 octaves, squares, wooden and iron frames. The cast-iron plate is in these divided into two nearly equal portions -- one of which is affixed to the case in the common way, while the second is coupled with it at the base end, and held in position by the string tension exerted in an opposite direction. The modification is termed "Hinging the slate." The improvement is so marked and substantial that it needs not the many indorsements received at the hands of Messrs. GOTTSCHALK, MASON, FRADEL, BERGE, MUZIO, THEO. THOMAS and other esteemed artistes, to satisfy even incipient amateurs of its value. How to free the piano from the deleterious effect of the iron used to strengthen certain portions has long been a question with the best makers of the day, and Mr. WORCESTER's ready solution of the difficulty meets with great favor from all interested in the advance of musical science.

abstract: Whenever we hear a general outery from the enemies of our Government at home or abroad, denouncing the conduct of its officers or agents, it is pretty conclusive evidence ...
lead_paragraph: Whenever we hear a general outery from the enemies of our Government at home or abroad, denouncing the conduct of its officers or agents, it is pretty conclusive evidence that the latter have been doing something well calculated to serve the country, and to aid substantially in the work of restoring and preserving the Union. Maj.-Gen. BUTLER, for example, has lately been so savagely abused, that even in the absence of any other testimony to his merits, we should be convinced that the administration of his Department has been such as to command the gratitude of all loyal men. It has certainly not been his ambition to be cursed with the praise of traitors, or of those who sympathize with treason. He went to Louisiana to reestablish the authority and repossess the property of the United States, and the censures of his assailants were sure to wax virulent in proportion to his success in the fulfillment of his mission.

abstract: No European echoes of American affairs that for a long time have come to us from across the Atlantic have possessed half the interest that attaches to their views of the late series of great battles in front of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: No European echoes of American affairs that for a long time have come to us from across the Atlantic have possessed half the interest that attaches to their views of the late series of great battles in front of Richmond. It was generally felt at the time of their occurrence that their effect in Europe could not fail to be very marked; and those timid souls who have for months been preaching up the imminence of intervention, were sure that England and France would interpret those fights as the ordeal of the war, and promptly step in and recognize the Southern Confederacy.

abstract: Will it surprise the public to know that books are yet written and printed? Will any one raise an eyebrow on being told that paper that might be turned so excellent account in the composition of cartridges is made into folio and duodecimo volumes that metal that might be moulded into bullets is run into type? Surprising as the fact indicated may seem, it is a fact nevertheless.
lead_paragraph: Will it surprise the public to know that books are yet written and printed? Will any one raise an eyebrow on being told that paper that might be turned so excellent account in the composition of cartridges is made into folio and duodecimo volumes -- that metal that might be moulded into bullets is run into type? Surprising as the fact indicated may seem, it is a fact nevertheless. Books are yet written and printed -- whether they are read or not is another matter, and wholly concerns the publishers. From this singular activity of presses and pens, we infer that the time has not yet arrived when every one neither too old nor too young to read -- including the unfortunate minority that don't know how to -- shall have gone to the war, though we fancy that that time rapidly approaches. It certainly requires, considerable stoicism to sit down to a tale of imaginary woes and sorrows while one great wall in going up from the sick and wounded in the swamps and trenches before Richmond; an incredible amount of apathy to sit leisurely down to a book under the shade of a green tree while the nation is sending out a great heart-cry for reinforcements to her shattered legions. It is more than probable that those who busy themselves with lesser literature will lose occasional chapters in the glorious history we are new writing in letters of fire on pages that can never fade nor perish. And we must confess that we turn from the long, long list of killed, wounded and missing, in the morning paper, to contemplate the bread and buttery desperation of some mythical man or hypothetical woman, who suffered from dyspepsia and called it love, or talked an incalculable amount of nonsense and called it passion, with a feeling quite as nearly approaching disgust as impatience. But there are duties in life that ever obtrude themselves, often at inauspicious and [???] moments, and even the all-occupying war forms no adequate excuse for neglecting them. To lighten our labors as much as possible, in some instances the publishers have sent us neat and appreciative notices of their books, ready written -- ave, and printed -- to hand. For the most part they are ingenious hole puffs, technical in form and expression, yet graceful as muslin sleeves in their entirety. The only possible objection to using them is found in the positive psychological tact that we all like to have an opinion of our own, formed in ulter ignorance and with total disregard of and for what others may have said or thought on the same subject, and spoken in our words. For this reason we offer a few notices of new books, -- not to influence the popular judgment, but simply as an expression of individual opinion.
