abstract: LOST, STRAYED OR STOLEN. A PACK OF CONFEDERATE COMMODORES. -- Wonder what has become of those jolly old dogs the rebel Commodores, who used to figure around so amusingly with their "little Confederate mosquito fleets?" There were HOLLINS and TATNALL and PEGRAM and SEMMES, and BUCHANAN and the rest. Now that all their little Pickaninnies of a navy have been captured or sunk by Uncle Sam's gunboats, and even their great panjandrum the Merrimac has been blown skyward to atoms in a fit of desperation, these old boys find their occupation gone. Have they retired to private life, to be laid up safely in lavender; have they suffered a sea-change, and made themselves into land-rats in place of water-rats; have they fled to Mexico, or have they committed suicide? we should like to have a sign of life from them, for they were very amusing in their day, and BARNUM would give a big price for a real live one.
lead_paragraph: LOST, STRAYED OR STOLEN. A PACK OF CONFEDERATE COMMODORES. -- Wonder what has become of those jolly old dogs the rebel Commodores, who used to figure around so amusingly with their "little Confederate mosquito fleets?" There were HOLLINS and TATNALL and PEGRAM and SEMMES, and BUCHANAN and the rest. Now that all their little Pickaninnies of a navy have been captured or sunk by Uncle Sam's gunboats, and even their great panjandrum the Merrimac has been blown skyward to atoms in a fit of desperation, these old boys find their occupation gone. Have they retired to private life, to be laid up safely in lavender; have they suffered a sea-change, and made themselves into land-rats in place of water-rats; have they fled to Mexico, or have they committed suicide? we should like to have a sign of life from them, for they were very amusing in their day, and BARNUM would give a big price for a real live one.

abstract: editorial on tax collection procedures
snippet: editorial on tax collection procedures
lead_paragraph: If, as M. DE TRACY assures us, any system of taxation is more likely to stimulate production by its gentle pressure, and promote the material interests of the industrial classes of any country in proportion as the taxes it imposes are moderate and various, our internal tax bill has an obvious claim to precedence. For the duties it imposes are very small, and in few cases exceed three per cent., while the number of articles reached by the tax is larger than has ever been embraced by any of the fiscal laws of European countries.

abstract: What with the war, the weather and the want of anything startling enough to make a sensation, no one of the theatres has been, of late, besieged by anxious crowds.
lead_paragraph: What with the war, the weather and the want of anything startling enough to make a sensation, no one of the theatres has been, of late, besieged by anxious crowds. Not to put too fine a point upon it the demand for dramatic entertainments is small, with a downward tendency, whilst the supply is, for the time of year, unusually extensive. But histrionic stars of the more prosperous class, seem to have laid it down as a general principle, that a nominal New-York summer season indorsement, even though it cost them a trifle out of pocket, is the best thing with which to go to the country, (where they make their fortunes) in the Fall and Winter.

abstract: One of the American characteristics which most surprises the good-natured Mr. TROLLOPE in his recent journey through this country, is the imperturbable good humor and hopefulness of people.
lead_paragraph: One of the American characteristics which most surprises the good-natured Mr. TROLLOPE in his recent journey through this country, is the imperturbable good humor and hopefulness of people. He meets frequently persons who are ruined by the calamities of the war. They never weep, or wring their hands, or tear their hair. One man, from whom the Secessionists of Missouri had taken cattle and crops and all the fruit of the labor of years, merely remarked in a quiet way, while he picked his teeth with a bowie-knife, "Yes, they have been kinder rough with me!" That was all -- he had nothing else to say. Mr. Trollope thinks a genuine American never complains and never despairs. Whatever happen, in the external world, says Mr. T., "the man is always there." In these qualities of hopefulness and independent manhood of our people lies the great confidence which we all possess of the speedy recovery of the country from the calamities of this civil war. Political economists have frequently presented it, as one of the proofs that the wealth of a people is in labor, more than in accumulated goods -- the remarkable recovery of countries which had been desolated by war. But with us there are various extrinsic circumstances which will aid this happy result, and produce, we believe, a career of prosperity after this contest such as the country has never seen.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship North American off Cape Race, we receive advises from Europe one day later to the 11th inst.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship North American off Cape Race, we receive advises from Europe one day later -- to the 11th inst. The news of the series of battles fought before Richmond had been received, and excited the greatest attention. The London Daily News regards the result of the fighting as a serious reverse to the National cause. The Times regards the strategical movements of Gen. MCCLELLAN as purely unintelligible, and thinks that recent events must infuse new energy into the Confederate arms. A large open-air meeting had been held at Stockport which had adopted a petition to Parliament praying the Government to take into serious consideration the propriety of mediation in American affairs, with a view to obtaining an immediate supply of cotton. From France we learn that Admiral DE LA GRAVIERE had left Paris for Cherbourg, to embark for Mexico, and it was asserted that Gen. FOREY was also to embark for Mexico on the 20th inst. The news from the other Continental States is unimportant. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market for the week added up 67,000 bales. Surats had declined 3/4d. and American descriptions 1/4d. The market closed flat. Breadstuffs had an upward tendency. Provisions were dull. Consols, 92 1/4@92 5/8 for money. American Stocks quiet.

abstract: Editorial on 1st anniversary of battle of Bull Run; editorial on collection procedures; Editorial speculates on outlook for Union after war
snippet: Editorial on 1st anniversary of battle of Bull Run; editorial on collection procedures; Editorial speculates on outlook for Union after war
lead_paragraph: It is not to add a shadow to the present hour of National gloom that we recall the fact that this day, the 21st of July, is the Anniversary of the Battle of Bull Run, or, more properly speaking, of Manassas. That affair, in fact, has now become a matter of history upon which we speculate without a feeling of passion, or a thought of National discredit. We can clearly trace the causes of our disaster; and we can see how, as things went, it was unavoidable. The courage of our army, as a whole, on that occasion, is unimpeached; and we have, in our National calendar, no finer heroes than many of the officers and soldiers who fought and fell on that day. The consequences of our defeat on that field, too, we now clearly see. It has been the means of prolonging the war until now. It gave the South time, which to it was all-important. It gave it nearly a whole year in which to consolidate its power unmolested; to fix and settle its so-called Government; to raise an army five or ten times as great as it then had; to unite, by necessity or force, the public sentiment of the entire South, and to crush out every vestige of Unionism; to raise provisions for the support of its army; to obtain warlike supplies from abroad, or from its own soil and manufactories; and, in short, to present such a defiant front as it yet shows to the Nation. Had our arms achieved victory on that day, and had our army marched onward to Richmond, and scattered the rebel host, we believe that it would virtually have ended the war, and that the nation, after a brief struggle, would now have been enjoying peace. Prolonged resistance in the Far South at that season, and under such circumstances, would have been out of the question; and the masses of the Southern people would have regarded secession as an abortion, and would have returned to the Union after administering justice to the false prophets who had betrayed them.
headline: {'main': 'Necessity of a Short War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Necessity of a Short War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The traitor TWIGGS, whose death is announced, was born in Georgia, in 1790, entered the army as a Captain in the Eighth Infantry in 1812, and served through the war of that day. In the Mexican war he held the rank of Colonel of the Second Dragoons, but acted as Brigadier, commanding the right wing in the battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma, and in the same month was created Brigadier-General, and shortly afterward Major-General by brevet, for his conduct at Monterey; and through the campaign of Gen. SCOTT in Mexico he was in command of a division. In 1847 Congress presented him with a sword, for his storming of Monterey. This sword has recently been taken possession of by Gen. BUTLER at TWIGG's house in New-Orleans. At the time of the breaking out of this present war, he was in command of the Union troops in Texas; and, through complicity with the secession leaders, he managed to render the whole National force there ineffective to operate against the rebels, and surrendered great quantities of military stores and materiel into the rebel hands. His conduct on this occasion was treasonable and treacherous in the extreme, and secured for him the scorn and hatred of his country. He was in command of the rebels at New-Orleans for some time, but was suspended, and retired first to a residence on the coast of Mississippi, from which he was frightened by our fleet, and subsequently to New-Orleans, from which he fled when it was threatened by Gen BUTLER. He finally retired for safety to Augusta, Ga., where he has died.

abstract: The rebels have just sent us one canard to the effect that Baton Rouge had been captured by them, when it was not. To-day they give us what is doubtless another, to the effect that they have captured all Gen. CURTIS' force, which is no doubt a bird of very large feather; and still another, as to the doings of their rams near Vicksburgh -- all of which we will believe when Gen. CURTIS and Com. FARRAGUT certify to their truth.

abstract: President LINCOLN is again about to suffer from an invasion that will throw his experience at the time of the raid of the office-seekers completely into the shade. Legions of would-be tax-gatherers are rushing to Washington, eager for appointments. Every train to the Capital is literally loaded with those who wish to do the State some service in the excise line. The poor President -- it is well his shoulders are broad and his back strong, for be has a load to carry under which Hercules might stagger!

lead_paragraph: Photography came to us smilingly and trippingly, fragrant with meadows and beautiful with landscapes, seemingly the handmaid of Peace. She had a bucolic air. Vague rumor, it is true, stated that she was not quite the pastoral maid that the popular imagination painted her; that she used gun-cotton liberally in the making of her toilette, and indulged in vitreous acids and sulphuric mixtures with unbecoming freedom. But all such rumors floated unheeded by, or were but noticed to be stamped as slanders. Consequently, one may be pardoned for starting with surprise when she suddenly flashes from the clouds, helmeted, plumed, and be-belted, at once the Minerva and the Clio of the war.

abstract: TWO MEN KILLED, AND ONE FATALLY INJURED. BY THE FALL OF A SCAFFOLD. About 10 o'clock yesterday A.M., an accident occurred at the northwest corner of Avenue B and Third-street, whereby two men lost their lives, and a third was so much injured that his life is considered hopeless.
lead_paragraph: TWO MEN KILLED, AND ONE FATALLY INJURED. BY THE FALL OF A SCAFFOLD. -- About 10 o'clock yesterday A.M., an accident occurred at the northwest corner of Avenue B and Third-street, whereby two men lost their lives, and a third was so much injured that his life is considered hopeless. The men were painters, engaged in painting a four-story house on the corner above mentioned, and for the purpose of enabling them to paint the upper part of the building, they had erected a scaffold even with the third story. The fastenings, owing to some defect, suddenly gave way, and precipitated them all to the pavement. The names of the persons killed by the fall are CYRUS BEAK and JOHN SHIELDS. JAMES BEAK was so seriously injured that his physicians said it was impossible for him to live beyond to-day. In addition to the injuries received by the fall upon the pavement from the third story, it appears that a number of spars and planks fell upon the unfortunate victims, and that they were thus bruised and mangled in a horrible manner. Officer MCCOLLOUGH, of the Seventeenth Precinct, was promptly on hand, and by his orders the timbers were speedily removed from the bodies of the men, and the attempt was made, under the directions of the officer, to convey them to the Hospital. They first attempted to remove Mr. CYRUS BEAK, but they had proceeded only a short distance before it became evident to all that he was breathing his last. Officer MCCOLLOUGH then directed the men who acted as bearers to take the injured man to a neighboring drug-store, but he expired just as they were about entering the latter place with him. Just before he died he exclaimed to Officer MCCOLLOUGH several times, "Oh my wife -- oh my family." The deceased has left a wife and two or three children, who reside at No. 298 Second-street, where the inquest was held. The verdict of the jury was that deceased came to his death from accidental causes. An inquest was also held upon JOHN SHIELDS, who died soon after the accident. A large number of witnesses testified that the catastrophe might have been prevented if proper care had been exercised in the erection of the scaffold.

lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK, it is stated in our dispatches, is expected in Washington to-day. The order of the President assigning the General to his new position will be issued immediately after his arrival. It is intimated that further important changes, regarding the conduct of the war, are to be made soon. An extraordinary meeting of the Cabinetwas held yesterday, at which several Generals were present, and at which military affairs and military changes were discussed.

abstract: Business at the mustering office in White-street wears a more cheering aspect than ever. The place is open for the reception and examination of recruits from 8 in the morning until 51/2 P.M.; and, during the while of that time, the work of swearing in goes bravely on. abstract: Editorial on increased profits from manufacturing and how profits aid war effort
snippet: Editorial on increased profits from manufacturing and how profits aid war effort
lead_paragraph: "Individuals grow rich," it has been said, "by the acquisition of wealth previously existing, nations by the creation of wealth that did not before exist." With certain limitations, this is undoubtedly true. For everycountry will obviously develop its resources and power in proportion as its citizens are quick to find new sources of material wealth find laborious in availing themselves of such as are old. Hence, as the inventive powers and enterprising genius of any people lead them to work to better purpose, so in proportion as they possess these high qualities, is their growth in opulence and prosperity.

abstract: column we reproduce from "BANCROFT's Handbook Almanac for 1862" -- a highly useful publication, issued at San Francisco last December -- a brief but highly instructive essay on the art of war, from the pen of Gen. HALLECK. This paper has many claims to attention. The author has practiced for some months past under the eye of the nation the art here taught, showing that he is no mere theorist upon the subject, but knows well how to make his knowledge into facts. And then it is he who is to direct hereafter the military measures of the Government. A glimpse at the principles on which the future General-in-Chief rests his method of campaigning is not, therefore, without its significance; and when, in addition, he ventures brief criticisms on the conduct of the war during last year, we may console ourselves that a repetition of such disasters as at Great Bethel, Bull Run and Ball's Bluff is not likely to disfigure the new military administration. The essay deserves careful perusal.

abstract: To-morrow, 18th instant, says the Richmond Dispatch, of July 18, is the first anniversary of the battle of Bull Run, in which the First Regiment, from this city, gained its first laurels. The Yankees, it will be remembered, attacked the Confederates,and after several hours' fighting, were driven back to Centreville, with heavy loss. Monday next, 21st, is the anniversary of the battle of Manassas.

abstract: KNOXVILLE, July 15. -- On the 9th inst., at Thompkinsville, Monroe County, Ky., Col. MORGAN's cavalry surprised and routed the Seventh Pennsylvania regiment, capturing 30. Among the prisoners is Maj. THOMAS JORDAN, who was brought here last night. Our loss is two slightly wounded. The whole camp of the enemy and all the stores fell into the hands of MORGAN, including one hundred head of horses and mules, a hundred rifles and a large quantity of ammunition and clothing. It was not Capt. LEWELLYN, Col. MORGAN's Quartermaster, who was killed, as reported, but Capt. O'BRIEN, of the Texas Rangers.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, July 15. -- On the 9th inst., at Thompkinsville, Monroe County, Ky., Col. MORGAN's cavalry surprised and routed the Seventh Pennsylvania regiment, capturing 30. abstract: The Savannah Republican says: "We saw a private letter yesterday, which states that the planters of Florida are contracting to deliver corn, of the growing crop, on the Florida Railroad, at 35 cents per bushel. The crop is immense, and far enough advanced to be considered safe. Our letters from all parts of Georgia and Alabama, indeed, nom the entire Confederacy, represent the crop as in a most flourishing condition, with the promise of an immense yield."

abstract: The London Herald treats the affair before Richmond as a decisive defeat of Gen. McCLELLAN, and says that the Confederate capital is safe.
lead_paragraph: The London Herald treats the affair before Richmond as a decisive defeat of Gen. MCCLELLAN, and says that the Confederate capital is safe. It does not believe, however, that the campaign in Virginia is ended, but supposes that it will go on until Europe stays the uplifted swords, and in the name of humanity enforces peace.

abstract: It will be remembered that when this road was seized and interrupted by the Confederates in June, 1861, they destroyed nearly twenty bridges in all, between Harper's Ferry and Piedmont.
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that when this road was seized and interrupted by the Confederates in June, 1861, they destroyed nearly twenty bridges in all, between Harper's Ferry and Piedmont. Since that period the railroad company has been actively engaged in preparing new iron bridges, of a permanent and beautiful character, with which replace the temporary but substantial timber structures that are now being used in that portion of the road. One of these bridges, at a point where the double track is in use over the Cherry Run, twelve miles west of Martinsburgh, has just been put in position. This will be at once followed by several others of the smaller bridges. The extensive bridge over the Potomac River at Harper's Ferry, about 1,000 feel long, will soon be put in its place. The masons have been at work for several weeks past in raising and renewing portions of the piers and abutments, in order to receive this superior viaduct. A number of workmen are still engaged at the Mount Clare shops, Baltimore, in the extensive iron work belonging to this and the other bridges.

abstract: Editorial on state of Union and gloomy attitude of public
snippet: Editorial on state of Union and gloomy attitude of public
lead_paragraph: In spite of all well-meant endeavors to conceal the fact, a profound gloom has settled upon the public mind in regard to the conduct and prospects of the pending war. The great mass of the people are discouraged and disheartened. And the reason of it is that they have lost faith in everybody and everything except their own exhaustless resources and their own indomitable purpose to crush the rebellion and preserve the life and unity of the nation. They have poured out their treasures and their blood like water; and they do not see the fruits they were promised for such sacrifices. They have given their confidence without stint to the men who wielded the weapons they had placed in their hands, -- and they do not find that confidence justified by success. They have waited patiently week after week, month after month, through the slow revolving seasons of a whole year, for victories, brilliant and decisive, promised them from day to day; and though every home mourns its dead, and every heart grieves for friends who will return no more forever, the victories are yet delayed and seem indeed further off than when the war began.
headline: {'main': 'The State of the Nation The Government and the People Future of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The State of the Nation The Government and the People Future of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

MORGAN, speaking for the State authorities, has granted. Resolutions, referring to this ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held a special meeting yesterday, the purpose being to act in concert with the Board of Aldermen in the proposed allowance of $25 to each enlisted recruit, in addition to the $50 which Gov. MORGAN, speaking for the State authorities, has granted. Resolutions, referring to this subject-for which vide the official report-were referred the Committee on National Affairs, which is virtual death to the project.

abstract: The steamship Asia, which passed Cape Race yesterday evening, brings advices from Europe to the 13th inst., two days later. The news is in some respects important. The result of the fighting before Richmond is treated as a severe National reverse by the entire English Press, and as insuring the safety of the rebel capital.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Asia, which passed Cape Race yesterday evening, brings advices from Europe to the 13th inst., two days later. The news is in some respects important. The result of the fighting before Richmond is treated as a severe National reverse by the entire English Press, and as insuring the safety of the rebel capital. The Times is of the opinion that the rebel army is strong enough to hold its position in Virginia for a time which may be indefinitely prolonged. The new American Tariff excited much attention and much hostility. The Liverpool Post thinks it will be looked upon as a measure tantamount almost to a declaration of war. Lord PALMERSTON had declared, during some remarks in the House of Commons, that there was no intention of withdrawing the British troops from Canada. It is now understood that France intends to prosecute the war against Mexico with the requisite vigor to insure success. The Paris Patrie asserts that she will never treat with JUAREZ, but that when the French army has entered the City of Mexico the Mexicans will be consulted, and their wishes scrupulously respected. The date of Gen. FOREY's departure for Mexico is doubtful, but there appears to be no doubt that the army which he is to command will comprise several divisions of infantry, and a proportionate number of batteries. The awards of prizes in the Great Exhibition have been made before a crowd of some 100,000 persons. Notwithstanding the paucity of her display America figures quite conspicuously among the prizes. The Liverpool cotton market had suffered a slight depression, but had recovered again. Breadstuffs were firm but quiet, and Provisions were flat. Consols were quoted at 92 1/4@ 92 3/8 for money.

abstract: Editorial urges change in present method of offering bounties to induce military volunteers
snippet: Editorial urges change in present method of offering bounties to induce military volunteers
lead_paragraph: The roundabout method adopted by the Government in making the new call for three hundred thousand volunteers, does not appear to work happily. It is now evident that it would have been much better had the required levy been made in precisely the same manner as the previous ones, namely by Proclamation from the President direct, instead of coming circuitously as a proposition from the Governors of the several States. It would have secured the needed unity of action; while, at the same time, by appealing directly to the people, it would have shown a juster appreciation of and fuller confidence in the spirit that animates them.

abstract: While New-York has been multiplying hospitals for her sick and wounded volunteers, our neighbors of New-Jersey have not been behind in this work of patriotic benevolence.
lead_paragraph: While New-York has been multiplying hospitals for her sick and wounded volunteers, our neighbors of New-Jersey have not been behind in this work of patriotic benevolence. Beside the State Hospital at Newark, they have now at Jersey City a hospital established by private enterprise, inferior to none in the substantial necessities of comfort and attention provided for the disabled soldiers of New-Jersey, to whom its doors are at all times freely opened. Four hundred and eighty-six have thus far experienced its attentions since its establishment on the 23d of last April, and the fact that of this number but four have died, best tells the story of the care the patients receive. Everything that thoughtful kindness can provide is at their disposal, and those loving attentions, such as no money can purchase, are freely tendered by the warm-hearted ladies of Jersey City, who have taken this institution under their especial charge, through the Ladies' Relief Association, two members of which attend at the hospital each day to lend their aid in caring for its inmates.
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; How New-Jersey Provides for Her Sick Soldiers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; How New-Jersey Provides for Her Sick Soldiers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: 83rd anniversary of Battle of Minisink marked, Goshen, NY
snippet: 83rd anniversary of Battle of Minisink marked, Goshen, NY
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a memorable day at Gosben, Orange County, N.Y. It was the anniversary of the battle of Minisink, and likewise the occasion of the dedication of a new monument which has just been completed In honor of the heroes who fell in that [???] engagement. The citizens of Orange, Sullivan, Ulster and Rockland Counties, as well as the Sane of Orange and Sullivan from all parts of the State, attended in large numbers. Special trains on the Erie Railroad brought in each full delegations -- the fairer sex by no means in the minority. New-York City was represented in the Orator of the Day, JOHN C. DIMMICK, Esq., Councilmen LENT, FRANK HORTON, and others of equal, note. There were four fire companies from Middletown, four from Port Jervis, four from Walden, and one from Montgomery. One of the features of the day was the presence of a bevy of young girls, representing the States of the Union, with two or three extra ones in anticipation of any addition of States that may be made. Each carried a badge with the inscription --

abstract: The 300-pounder Armstrong gun, which, since its proof with 90 lbs. of powder, has been in a dangerous state, was yesterday again used at Shoeburyness, against iron plates, at a range of two hundred yards. The target represented a portion of the side of the new class of steam-frigates to which the Minotaur belongs. In these frigates the armor is 5 1/2 inches thick, instead of 4 1/2 inches, as in the Warrior, but the thickness of the teak backing is reduced from 18 inches to 9 inches. The inner skin and iron framing are the same as in the Warrior. For the first three trials the shot was of cast iron, and the charge was 50 lbs., as usual. No. 1 struck and pierced the centre plate, damaging but not passing through the inner skin and framing. No. 2 struck the upper plate, and went completely through armor, timber, and skin. No. 3 was directed against the lower plate, and, like No. 2, passed quite through the target. The fourth shot was of wrought iron, and the charge was 50 pounds, as before. At this round, however, the gun gave way, the breech being blown backwards to a distance of 30 or 40 yards. The gun did not break into fragments, and no one was hurt. The experience gained by these extreme tests will doubtless be made available in the construction of the new gun of this description now nearly ready for service.

abstract: The President, through the Secretary of War, has just issued a very important order, which will settle, for the remainder of ...
lead_paragraph: The President, through the Secretary of War, has just issued a very important order, which will settle, for the remainder of this war, two points of military policy, regarding which there has been wide discussion, and for lack of which there has been much embittered feeling. The first provision of the order is, in brief, that military commanders within the rebel States shall seize any property which may be needed for supplies or other military purposes; and the second provision is that commanders shall employ as laborers so many slaves as are needed for military or naval purposes. Both of these measures are strictly within the established rules provided for an army when operating in an enemy's country.
headline: {'main': 'Two Important Points of Military Policy Settled.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Two Important Points of Military Policy Settled.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on large concentration of Union troops at Cumberland Gap, east Tennessee
snippet: Editorial on large concentration of Union troops at Cumberland Gap, east Tennessee
lead_paragraph: When, in the early part of this year, the rebels evacuated Bowling Green, and the various divisions of our troops in Kentucky followed them southward, this column was left in Southeastern Kentucky, for the purpose of capturing the rebel stronghold at Cumberland Gap - which had been regarded as probably the most formidable and valuable strategic position in the South - and afterward penetrating into East Tennessee. The column remained, doing various work and with varied fortune, in the hilly and desolate regions in Eastern Kentucky during the whole of the Spring, and till well on in the present Summer. At the beginning of last month it was still on the Northern side of the Cumberland Mountains. At length, on the 18th of June, Gen. MORGAN, its commander, and a very able and gallant officer, obtained possession of the long-coveted Cumberland Gap, by one of the most difficult and scientific operations of the war, but which, on account of the more immediately important news we were at that time receiving from Virginia, was almost entirely overlooked by the Press. He, for a time, so manoeuvered his troops, that the enemy at the Gap could get no clue whatever to his purposes; and when, finally, having made a terrible march of a hundred miles, over mountains heretofore considered impassable, he fell upon their rear, they fled in confusion, and the Southern Thermopylae, which a thousand men might have successfully defended, fell into his hands. It was universally supposed by those who had followed up Gen. MORGAN's movements, and understood the military and political situation in that section of country, that he would at once push on to Knoxville, the capture of which would have been equivalent to the possession of nearly the whole of East Tennessee. The retention of the Gap was of vast importance to the rebels, as the means of keeping us out of East Tennessee; but the position once in our hands, it was of value only as the gateway to further conquests. Gen. MORGAN, however, with his whole force, still remains at Cumberland Gap -a force which, though the rebels overestimate it when they state it to be 20,000 strong, is yet of very considerable numbers, and is amply able, with a little of the assistance near at hand, to take military possession of all of East Tennessee. He remains there in obedience to orders.

abstract: The Morgan raid in Kentucky has not been a success. Much was undoubtedly hoped for by the rebels.
lead_paragraph: The Morgan raid in Kentucky has not been a success. Much was undoubtedly hoped for by the rebels. Their infatuation in regard to Kentucky, Missouri and Maryland has been marvelous. They have claimed those States all the time as their own, and kept up a pretence of Government for two of them, of the most absurd and ridiculous character. The rebel Governor and Lieutenant-Governor of Missouri have been for nearly twelve months wandering homeless, expelled from their State by the citizens whose confidence they had betrayed. In Kentucky a provisional rebel State Government was set up, on the Southern boundary line, that never exercised sway over a half dozen counties of the State, and that fiction of a Government is now lost. Yet, by virtue of such vagabond and paltry organizations, both Kentucky and Missouri were nominally united to the rebel Confederacy, and representatives were admitted from those States to the Richmond Congress.
headline: {'main': "Morgan's Raid into Kentucky.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Morgan's Raid into Kentucky.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON and RICHARD COBDEN have fallen out. In the House of Commons, on the 7th inst., during a debate on the Fortification bill, ...
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON and RICHARD COBDEN have fallen out. In the House of Commons, on the 7th inst., during a debate on the Fortification bill, Mr. COBDEN observed that the facts proved that the former statements as to the French navy had been incorrect, and he asked whether there was any man accustomed to public affairs who had not been led by Lord PALMERSTON to believe that the French had unduly altered the proportion which their navy bore to ours in former times? And that was the reason why the House had been called upon to vote enormous estimates for the navy. He had had as good an opportunity as Lord PALMERSTON himself for knowing the state of both navies, and he undertook to say, in opposition to his assertion, that, for the last twelve or fourteen years, the French navy had borne a far less proportion to that of England than in the time of LOUIS PHILIPPE, He read statements of the expenditure In the French and English dock-yards, and of the number of seamen in the two navies, and asked, if these statements could not be gainsaid, what foundation was there for these gigantic fortifications? He maintained that the exaggerated accounts of the increase of the French navy were wholly delusive, and he cited various statements made by Lord PALMERSTON of the forces of France, naval and military, the correctness of which; he challenged.

abstract: The bestowal of relief to the families of volunteers, out of the appropriation made by the Common Council for that purpose, was resumed yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The bestowal of relief to the families of volunteers, out of the appropriation made by the Common Council for that purpose, was resumed yesterday. This source of bounty is known as "The Family Aid Fund, No. 3;" two previous appropriations for the same purpose having been already expended. The Legislature have not given their sanction to the raising and distribution of this third appropriation; but there is little doubt that, when it again meets, the action of the Common Council in the matter will be sustained.

abstract: The large number of troops required to garrison and hold the great extent of territory which has been wrested from the possession of the rebels by the many and distinguished victories that have attended the Union arms, enables the rebels greatly to ...
lead_paragraph: The large number of troops required to garrison and hold the great extent of territory which has been wrested from the possession of the rebels by the many and distinguished victories that have attended the Union arms, enables the rebels greatly to outnumber our forces now in the vicinity of Richmond. The greater part of the rebel army has been concentrated at Richmond, their last stronghold, for a final and desperate struggle, and the army of the Union, while fighting with a gallantry hardly equaled and never surpassed in the annalas of warfare, has, by overwhelming numbers, been compelled to a short and temporary retreat.

abstract: The Annual Distribution of Premiums at the Christian Brothers' Academy, Jay-street, Brooklyn, took place on Monday, 21st inst., in presence of a large ...
lead_paragraph: The Annual Distribution of Premiums at the Christian Brothers' Academy, Jay-street, Brooklyn, took place on Monday, 21st inst., in presence of a large and highly appreciative auditory, composed of clergymen, parents, friends and patrons of the Academy. The large school-room was crowded to excess, and the audience appeared not only to take a deep interest in the proceedings, but by their loud and prolonged approbation at the delivery of patriotic speeches, evinced their true sentiments on the question of the Union. Among the numerous clergymen present we noticed the Rev. Messrs. TURNER, V.G., FARRELL, KEEGAN, and MAGUIRE. The "Green immortal" banner of old Ireland waved in unison with the glorious Stars and stripes. A band composed of twenty-five of the students, dressed in a neat and becoming uniform discoursed sweet music during the evening, consisting of National and Irish airs.

abstract: A greater number of recruits were examined and mustered into the service of the United States at  the mustering office, yesterday, than at any time since the issuing of the President's last call.
lead_paragraph: A greater number of recruits were examined and mustered into the service of the United States at the mustering office, yesterday, than at any time since the issuing of the President's last call. Daily thenumber is increasing; the examining officers, who are never absent from their posts throughout the day, are kept constantly engaged. Dr. MOTT states that appearances are most encouraging. The Empire State will soon have her quota of troops in the field.

abstract: At Goshen, Orange County, in this State, yesterday, the eighty-third anniversary of the battle of Minnisink was celebrated with peculiarly appropriate ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: At Goshen, Orange County, in this State, yesterday, the eighty-third anniversary of the battle of Minnisink was celebrated with peculiarly appropriate ceremonies. The occasion was signalized by the dedication of a new monument, just erected in honor of the deceased, through the munificence of the late Dr. MERRITT H. CASH, of Orange County, who bequeathed in charge of the County the sum of $4,000 for that purpose. Citizens flocked to witness the ceremonies from all the adjoining counties. There was a grand procession, reception speeches and an oration by JOHN C. DIMMOCK, of New-York. The citizens of Goshen did their best to accommodate the visitors, and the entire affair was unmarred by any untoward occurrence.

abstract: There has just been a species of mutiny on Governor's Island. The majority of the paroled soldiers, or "Texans," as they are commonly called, ...
lead_paragraph: There has just been a species of mutiny on Governor's Island. The majority of the paroled soldiers, or "Texans," as they are commonly called, formerly belonging to the First, Third and Eighth Regiments, (Regulars,) but now attached to the general service at Fort Columbus, have laid down their arms and refuse to do any duty except that usually performed by the ordinary camp or garrison police. The cause of this refusal is a conviction among the men that they have been violating their parole by doing guard duty at a post where Southern prisoners were confined. It is not known what will be done with those men who have laid down their arms. They are still at large, and will probably be allowed to remain so until they are exchanged or discharged.

abstract: Editorial says military power of Confederacy is exhausted while Union still has plenty of reserves
snippet: Editorial says military power of Confederacy is exhausted while Union still has plenty of reserves
lead_paragraph: It is a most singular fact that the varying fortunes of the war should be attended by such depressions of popular feeling and such agitations of the financial world as we witness. Not one man in ten thousand of all our people doubts the power of the loyal States and their unyielding purpose to suppress the rebellion, though the effort should cost their entire available wealth, and demand the service in the field of every citizen who is capable of bearing arms. We know that if the whole power of the Republic is put forth the rebellion must be overwhelmed.

abstract: The work to which all our present recruiting efforts should tend is the filling up of regiments already existing, but which have been reduced in numbers by battle and disease. If these skeleton organizations could be filled the army would be reinforced, and that, too, in a way which would be more effective than the addition of double the number of men organized into new regiments. We are glad to notice in this connection that the State authorities have decided to advance the fifty dollars bounty only to such as enlist to join regiments already in the field; those who enlist in new regiments will not receive the bounty till after leaving the State. This is a move in the right direction.

abstract: Capt. LARNED and Dr. MOTT, with their assistants, had their hands full, as usual, yesterday. From quite early in the morning until near 5 o'clock P.M., men continued to be brought in from the numerous ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. LARNED and Dr. MOTT, with their assistants, had their hands full, as usual, yesterday. From quite early in the morning until near 5 o'clock P.M., men continued to be brought in from the numerous recruiting offices with which the City is studded. More than an average number were enrolled; though many, who would otherwise have been brought to the United States mustering office, have, under special instructions, been taken direct to the regimental encampments and mustered in by the Adjutants there. It is evident that, as the liberal provisions of the Governor's proclamation become known, a greater willingness is being manifested to enter the army. This is particularly the case with men who have wives and families to provide for. As they begin to understand that they will not have to leave those dependent on them without resources, they will come forward with increased readiness, and soon fill up the ranks of the 300,000 which the country calls for and must have.

abstract: We give place in  another column to the opinion of the Supreme Court in regard to the celebrated "gridiron" grants. It will be seen that a majority of the judges concur in regarding the grants as valid, overruling all the legal and ...
lead_paragraph: We give place in another column to the opinion of the Supreme Court in regard to the celebrated "gridiron" grants. It will be seen that a majority of the judges concur in regarding the grants as valid, overruling all the legal and technical points raised by the opponents of the roads. Of these the principal appears to be the right set up by property owners on the several routes, to compensation for the right of property they possess in the soil of the several streets. The Court decides that no such right exists either in the adjoining property owners or in the corporation; but that the streets belong to the people of the State, who may grant the use without question, or restraining injunction. The injnction against the construction of the roads is therefore dissolved, and the companies may begin the work to-morrow if they please.

abstract: Senator WILSON has very properly nailed to the counter a falsehood which first issued from that mint of mendacity, the New-York ...
lead_paragraph: -- Senator WILSON has very properly nailed to the counter a falsehood which first issued from that mint of mendacity, the New-York Herald, and which has since had considerable of that currency which such bogus coinages sometimes obtain. That sheet has repeatedly charged Mr. WILSON, Chairman of the Senate Military Committee, with having risen in his seat and stated that the Government had 150,000 more troops than were wanted. To this false statement the Senator has lately taken occasion, in the course of a speech made at Newton, Mass., to give emphatic denial. "There is," said he, "not only no truth in it, but there is not a shadow of truth on which to lay the foundation of the assertion." Senator WILSON then went on to define his position in the Senate on the question, as follows:

abstract: In view of the dangerous clouds of treason which now most alarmingly threaten the very existence of our hitherto united and prosperous country, it behooves every man among us who loves our (Government and its institutions, to leave the avocations.
lead_paragraph: In view of the dangerous clouds of treason which now most alarmingly threaten the very existence of our hitherto united and prosperous country, it behooves every man among us who loves our (Government and its institutions, to leave the avocations of ordinary business, or the endearing ties of home and engage hand to hand and shoulder to shoulder in most efficient, fearless warfare, to put down and forever crush out this disunion rebellion in our Southern States. I feel, most seriously impressed with a sense of my duty in this case, and the necessity of my earnest working in support of this war.

abstract: Gen. HAL  LECK'S new position and duties are at length authentically and officially defined. He is to take "command of the whole [of the] land forces of the United States, as General-inChief," with his headquarters at Washington.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK's new position and duties are at length authentically and officially defined. He is to take "command of the whole [of the] land forces of the United States, as General-inChief," with his headquarters at Washington. This is the third or perhaps the fourth, functionary of that grade which we have had since the opening of the war -- SCOTT, MCCLELLAN, and STANTON, or rather the President, having preceded HALLECK. It is just a year ago that Gen. MCCLELLAN was assigned to the position; and he performed its arduous duties for about nine months. The events that have taken place over the country since he entered upon active field work, show the imperative necessity for some strong, clear-headed military man to guide the movements of all our armies.

lead_paragraph: A rather exciting and interesting sporting affair took place yesterday on the above course, which brought together quite a gathering of prominent members of an up-town church, who were desirous of adding their pious mite to a fund for liquidating a demand which hung over their consecrated house of prayer. The medium for this desirable object was furnished by three religious, moral, philanthropic and enthusiastic Irish gentlemen -- members of the church -- well-known to the community; who furnished their pet road horses for a grand contest on the Fashion Pleasure-ground Association's Course.

lead_paragraph: The United States District Attorney, E. Delafield Smith, moved on for trial the case of the Stephen Hart and cargo. Messis, Benedict, Donohue and Kursheedt moved off the case. The Court intimated its readiness to proceed with the trial. But in view of the facts submitted by counsel, and also in view of the unremitting labors of the Judge and officers of the Court and counsel, for upward of a year, the District Attorney, stated that he would move no further prize cases [???] the September term, except that during the present week all cases will be disposed of in which both until parties shall be ready.

abstract: The United States transport steamer Fulton, Capt. WOTTON, arrived at this port, last night, from New-Orleans, consigned to Quartermaster TOMPKINS. She left New-Orleans on the 16th inst., at 5 o'clock P.M., and the Southwest Pass on the 17th, at 7 o'clock A.M.
lead_paragraph: The United States transport steamer Fulton, Capt. WOTTON, arrived at this port, last night, from New-Orleans, consigned to Quartermaster TOMPKINS. She left New-Orleans on the 16th inst., at 5 o'clock P.M., and the Southwest Pass on the 17th, at 7 o'clock A.M. The Fulton brings on freight 151 hogsheads New-Orleans sugar. She also has on board the remains of Lieut. DE KAY, killed at Grand Gulf, and 469 sick and discharged soldiers from Gen. BUTLER's Division. Private H.L. MILLER, Company 1, Eighth New-Hampshire, died July 16; private DAVID SAWYER, Company K, Fourteenth Maine, died July 18; drummer EDWIN KILGORE, died July 23, all buried at sea.

abstract: Delavan vs. Lakey. This was an action to re cover the value of an iron Mateawan planer which the defendant sold, last May, on commission, for the plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: Delavan vs. Lakey. -- This was an action to re cover the value of an iron Mateawan planer which the defendant sold, last May, on commission, for the plaintiff. The proceeds of this sale, together withhis commission, the defendant, as alleged, appropriated to himself. The grounds of defence were that the planer came wrongfully into the possession of the plaintiff, through George D. Baldwin, and that the proceeds really belonged to Benjamin Lord, who notified the defendant not to pay the money to the plaintiff.

abstract: A very exciting trotting-match took place on Tuesday on the above course, between the gray mare Lady Suffolk, to 85 pounds wagon, and the bay gelding Rattlesnake, to 170 pounds wagon, mile heats, best ...
lead_paragraph: A very exciting trotting-match took place on Tuesday on the above course, between the gray mare Lady Suffolk, to 85 pounds wagon, and the bay gelding Rattlesnake, to 170 pounds wagon, mile heats, best three in five, for $2,000. Lady Suffolk was driven by HIRAM WOODRUFF, and Rattlesnake by D. PFIFER, the latter being the favorite at 100 to 60, previous to the day of the race, notwithstanding the difference in weight; but after the horses had been driven over the track two or three times, the quick and lively action of Lady Suffolk caused the betting to turn so much in her favor as to be nearly even before starting, it being influenced to some extent by her owner offering to back her at 400 to 500.

abstract: POPE's bull of yesterday, providing, among other things, that all male persons within his department, who do not choose to swear allegiance, shall be escorted beyond the lines of the army and into the regions of rebeldom, will, we hope, operate conveniently and usefully. Nearly all the young men in Eastern Virginia have joined the rebel army - leaving behind them just enough hardened old cases to act as spies upon our movements, and keep the enemy thoroughly posted. These men, too, are generally malignant and annoying; and though they do not enter the rebel ranks, are not backward in taking a shot at any stray parties of our troops, or assassinating them whenever it is convenient. It is better to crowd this whole class down South at once - so that as our armies advance they may not leave an enemy in the rear. By putting them all there, we can finally deal with the rebellion in a small space and as a whole, without distraction. If this policy had been adopted in the Valley, it would have cost us much less trouble. Those who will not support the Government cannot demand its protection. All that these or any other rebels are required to do, is to take the oath of allegiance.
lead_paragraph: POPE's bull of yesterday, providing, among other things, that all male persons within his department, who do not choose to swear allegiance, shall be escorted beyond the lines of the army and into the regions of rebeldom, will, we hope, operate conveniently and usefully. abstract: editorial urges more and faster recruiting; Report on progress of military recruiting
snippet: editorial urges more and faster recruiting; Report on progress of military recruiting
lead_paragraph: We cannot urge too strongly on our Governor and the military authorities, the importance of haste in recruiting. One man now on the James River is worth what fifty will be next Autumn. The army must be strengthened, so that it may be able to press the enemy's line continually and keep him occupied before Richmond, otherwise the raid of POPE to Charlottsville, may turn out only a misfortune, and his advance columns be crushed by an overwhelming force from the rebel army near Richmond. Time is everything to us. Our army burns to atone for its apparent retreat; the Southern raw levies are being drilled every day, their army is badly cut up and is probably at its weakest now; intervention looms up in the distance, and every possible motive presses us to the most energetic measures.
headline: {'main': 'More Activity in Recruiting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'More Activity in Recruiting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We trust there is no mistake as to the truth of the Washington telegram of this morning, which announces that Gen. Dix has made an arrangement with the rebels for an immediate and general exchange of prisoners.
lead_paragraph: -- We trust there is no mistake as to the truth of the Washington telegram of this morning, which announces that Gen. DIX has made an arrangement with the rebels for an immediate and general exchange of prisoners. A similar announcement has been made several times before; but there have been delays, postponements, difficulties and obstructions of various kinds in carrying it out, and in the mean time the Union prisoners have lingered month after month in the dungeons of rebellion, while hundreds of them have died of neglect and harsh treatment. The principle of exchange has now been accepted by our Government, and there is no reason, if the rebels are willing, as they seem to be, that there should be any delay in carrying it out. The large numbers of our sick and wounded, in particular, who were captured by the rebels on the Peninsula during the late battles, should be attended to immediately. Some of our self-sacrificing Surgeons stayed behind with them to wait upon them, as far as possible; but we have learned that there is still a great deficiency of proper medical and surgical attendance. If all of those who can be removed without danger were brought within our lines at once, enough of the surgeons would doubtless remain to take care of the poor fellows who may be too far gone or in too much suffering to endure removal. We have about twenty thousand rebel prisoners now in our hands, mostly in the Northwest, where they have been well taken care of during the hot Summer months; while of our men the rebels cannot have altogether more than half of that number. We believe, however, that the return of these eight or ten thousand men would be the means of inducing twice or thrice that number to join the ranks of the army at once. If the telegraph be correct in saying that an arrangement has been made for an immediate exchange, we hope that the arrangement will be immediately carried out.

abstract: The request on the body of DAVID M. DEMAREST, a volunteer who was murdered on the 14th inst., at Fox Hill, West Hoboken, was concluded yesterday (Wednesday) for noon. There was no further evidence to offer.
lead_paragraph: The request on the body of DAVID M. DEMAREST, a volunteer who was murdered on the 14th inst., at Fox Hill, West Hoboken, was concluded yesterday (Wednesday) for noon. There was no further evidence to offer. Coroner [???] stated that the [???] had found a lawyer who had a power of attorney to collect back pay and bounty money belonging to deceased, and amounting to about $[???], but that he had not drawn any of it. Mr. DEMAREST, uncle of deceased was of opinion that he had obtained money from his brother, but he has been, missing since the day previous to the murder.

abstract: Between the upper and nether mill-stones of State and National excise laws, there seems to be some prospect of grinding the lawlessness out of the liquor dealers. Now that the Police and Excise Commissioners are acting in concert, and the Police Justices show some determination to discharge their duty, the question of further contumacy will rest with the Grand Jurors and the District Attorney. We have yet to learn that there has ever been a session of the Grand Inquest when any reluctance was shown to indict offenders of this class; so that the whole responsibility wiil be concentrated on the prosecuting officer. The shuttlecock among City officials will rest at last in a definite place, and the public will understand that a continuance of unlawful rum-selling can only be possible with the tacit consent, or by the positive neglect of a single officer of law.

abstract: The rumor has been industriously circulated that this regiment, which has won so much honor is the field, and has never failed, when under fire, to vindicate its claim to the proud title of Gardes Lafayette, has suffered so severely by the hard service it has seen that no more than fifty effective men survive.
lead_paragraph: The rumor has been industriously circulated that this regiment, which has won so much honor is the field, and has never failed, when under fire, to vindicate its claim to the proud title of Gardes Lafayette, has suffered so severely by the hard service it has seen that no more than fifty effective men survive. We are glad to be able to give the fullest contradiction to these reports. M. DE TROBRIAND, the Colonel-Commandant of the regiment, in a letter to the Courrier des Etats Unis, states that his musterroll for the 18th July shows that the regiment "numbers 500 effective men, at the least."

abstract: The closing reception of Primary School No. 37 in the Third Ward, took place yesterday, and was largely attended by the parents of the children, and other citizens who take an interest in the school. Commissioner EDWARD B. HEATH presided at the exercises, and his colleague, Commissioner R.S. GOULD ...
lead_paragraph: The closing reception of Primary School No. 37 in the Third Ward, took place yesterday, and was largely attended by the parents of the children, and other citizens who take an interest in the school. Commissioner EDWARD B. HEATH presided at the exercises, and his colleague, Commissioner R.S. GOULD, Superintendent RANDALL and the members of the local Board, Messrs. JOHN COSTAR, PATRICK KERRIN, GEORGE F. DEWLAND, and H. J. WELBROOK, also occupied seats upon the stand. The exercises were of the usual character, and consisted of readings, declamations, songs, dialogues, &c., in which Masters Eugene Diemer, Abraham Hardy, William Noe, Edward Beardsley, Charles Denehay, Daniel Mahoney, Ferdinand Altman, Benjamin Baker, and Misses Ellie Rice, Mary Finn, Julia Kennell, Annie Cropsey, and Mary Murphy took part. This school has only been established two years, previous to which time there had never been a public school in the Third Ward. The prosperity of the school has far exceeded the anticipations of those who were instrumental in its establishment, and has falsified the predictions of those members of the Board of Education who argued against its necessity on account of the sparseness of the population of the Ward.

abstract: The appointment of Gen. HALLECK to be Commander-in-Chief of the army will be regarded with high satisfaction by the country. It will do all that any single Administrative act can do, to revive public confidence in the conduct of military affairs. It will not stimulate popular enthusiasm like a brilliant victory, but it will fortify the country against ...
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Gen. HALLECK to be Commander-in-Chief of the army will be regarded with high satisfaction by the country. It will do all that any single Administrative act can do, to revive public confidence in the conduct of military affairs. It will not stimulate popular enthusiasm like a brilliant victory, but it will fortify the country against fears of fresh disasters growing out of incapable councils, or the vascillating policy of unprofessional commanders.

abstract: Editorial on modern iron-making providing new elements in warfare
snippet: Editorial on modern iron-making providing new elements in warfare
lead_paragraph: The present results of unproved iron-making, with reference to what ought to be the principal business of this people until the rebellion is crushed out, are of the highest importance. The great want is stronger material for armor-plates, artillery and heavy ordnance, and cheaper war materiel in general -- the chief cost being in iron and steel -so that more of it can be afforded. There is in the Exhibition at London a cast-steel locomotive-tire, which, unlike the thirty or forty thousand locomotive-tires running in America, was never a pig of cast-iron, nor a puddle-ball, nor an ingot of wrought-iron, nor a bar. In a quarter of an hour from the time it had trickled from the iron ore, it was a cast steel hoop without a weld, and only needed rolling in a tire-mill to be ready to run. A large number of tires, made by this Bessemer process, are running in Europe. The ordinary tire requires from five to eight heats, and sets of manipulations. This required two; which explains the wonderful cheapness of the process. An unforged ingot of this steel, 14 inches in diameter, is broken, to show as perfect a fracture and as perfect solidity as ordinary hammered steel, and several 24-pounder guns, and a 50-horse crank shaft cast from it, and the 6,410th "direct steel " ingot, (18 inches square,) made by BESSEMER, are exhibited; which shows the scale upon which it has been worked. Its quality is illustrated by a variety of specimens, for instance, a railway rail, 40 feet long, is twisted cold into a spiral, and a bar five inches square is folded together like a pocket-rule, all without fracture. This metal is not only shown, but has been used for several years in the form of saws, chisels boiler-plate, cannon, shafting, &c.; and its success is complete. It is made in England, Sweden and Germany, and is about to be made even in India. But there was never a pound of it made in America, or used by our Departments, or contemplated in the immense Government iron-works lately discussed by Congress, as far as we are aware.

lead_paragraph: By the telegram from Albany, published above, it will be seen that arrangements have been made for the immediate payment of the State bounty offered by the Governor in his late proclamation. For some time to come his attention will most probably be almost monopolized by this branch of his duties.

abstract: One remarkable peculiarity was noticed by all in the grand Union-square meeting, and is an evidence, no doubt, of general popular feeling, and that was, that all demands for the most unsparing punishment of the rebels, and for the most vigorous measures ...
lead_paragraph: One remarkable peculiarity was noticed by all in the grand Union-square meeting, and is an evidence, no doubt, of general popular feeling, and that was, that all demands for the most unsparing punishment of the rebels, and for the most vigorous measures toward them, were met with the greatest applause. From every quarter we receive, ourselves, communications urging the most extreme penalties of the law on the treasonable States and communities. A universal confiscation of real estate, so that loyal settlers may occupy the deserted properties, the wasting of rebel fields and harvest, the armed occupation of their houses, and the appropriation of all property, are some of the mildest of the penal remedies recommended. In the meeting before referred to, one of our most benevolent and excellent citizens, calmly advised sending all the rebel inhabitants further South, and occupying their houses with our soldiers. All these strongly expressed feelings are good signs in one respect -- they show that the people demand vigorous action, and will sustain the Government in it. They prove that the popular instinct feels what has been thus far our mistake -- the not striking at our enemy's weakest point. Still, the time has come when sound statesmanship and practical Christianity should indicate some distinctions and limitations in this cry for punishments and revenge. It might as well be understood now as hereafter, that there are some things which the American people can do, and some which it cannot. Whatever be our wrongs received from the South -- and their number is infinite -- we cannot exterminate or make houseless and landless the whole five or six million whites implicated in this rebellion. The thing is simply impossible. If we begin an indiscriminate, universal policy of destroying rebel property, confiscating it, and "sending women and children South," and the like, we merely excite every man, woman and child to a pitch of fury which would lead them to take to the mountains and swamps rather than submit, and which would call out a storm of wrath to which the rage of Europe, under NAPOLEON's exactions, was feeble. We must remember, ourselves, how many years it needed before the ashes over our burnt homesteads, in the War of 1812, cooled again. Not all the British victories or insults ever sowed such dragon-teeth of hatred as did their destruction of the public buildings of Washington and other towns. To let an army plunder buildings, or even occupy them -- to permit every soldier to grasp and gel as he likes -- is simply to demoralize our army, and enrage the enemy past any possibility of submission.

abstract: Last evening Gen. MEAGHER and Staff visited Wallack's Theatre. The house was crowded. When the General entered the people rose en masse and cheered, ladies waved their pocket handkerchiefs, end the greatest enthusiasm was manifested. At the end of the first piece, "The Irish Lion," calls were made for the General, who came forward and bowed to the audience from a private box. "Speech,' "speech," was cried from all parts of the house. On which the General, on behalf of the Irish Brigade, thanked them for the [???] given him, and for such a reception, [???] he was indebted to the bravery of the officers and men of his brigade. He did not intend to make a speech, as he was going to [???] all about the Irish Brigade at the Seventh Regiment Armory this evening. On speaking of Gen, MCCLELLAN, he was interrupted by loud and prolonged cheering, and when mentioning the gallantry of the Excelsior Brigade, DURYEE's Zouaves, the Thirty-seventh, (Irish,) and the Second New-York Milltia, the house fairly reng with applause. In conclusion, the General appointed all the ladies present recruiting officers in the Irish brigade.

abstract: FOUND DROWNED.--The body of JOHN STEFFEN, a German, 59 years of age, was found floating in the water at the foot of Corlears-street, yesterday, and was taken out by Officer NELSON, of the Thirteeoth Precinct. Deceased had been in the employ of the NewYork Steam Sugar Refining Company, and had been ...
lead_paragraph: FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of JOHN STEFFEN, a German, 59 years of age, was found floating in the water at the foot of Corlears-street, yesterday, and was taken out by Officer NELSON, of the Thirteeoth Precinct. Deceased had been in the employ of the NewYork Steam Sugar Refining Company, and had been missing since Sunday evening. A verdict of accidental drowning was rendered at an inquest held by Coroner COLLIN. The same Coroner held an inquest yesterday at the house of CHARLES WARREN, NO. 547 First-avenue, upon the body of WM. H. WARREN, who was drowned on the day previous in the dock foot of Thirty-third-street. He was only 7 years of age, and had been out of the house but 15 minutes when intelligence of his death was brought to his mother. Verdict, accidental drowning.

abstract: Upon the reception of the telegraphic dispatch yesterday afternoon announcing the death of ExPresident VAN BUREN, GILBERT DEAN, Esq., moved an adjournment of the Supreme Court in respect of his memory. In moving the adjournment, Judge DEAN ...
lead_paragraph: Upon the reception of the telegraphic dispatch yesterday afternoon announcing the death of ExPresident VAN BUREN, GILBERT DEAN, Esq., moved an adjournment of the Supreme Court in respect of his memory. In moving the adjournment, Judge DEAN remarked that during his term in Congress, the deceased was one of his constituents, and that his personal and official relations with Mr. VAN BUREN had always been such that there was a peculiar fitness in his calling the attention of the Court to his death. Mr. DEAN then passed a high eulogium upon the character of the deceased, and referred to his confidential relations with Gen. JACKSON. He was the peer of CLAY, WEBSTER, CALHOUN, BENTON, and others of America's greatest statesmen, and his dignity of character had made him always a marked man in the councils of the nation.

abstract: -- SEIZURE OF COIN, TOOLS AND MATERIALS. -Yesterday Sheriff FRANCIS, of Hudson County, Constables MCDONOUGH, of Hoboken, and MOONEY, of Bull's Ferry, made a descent upon a house in Guttenberg, on the Dallytown Road, and arrested a German named GUSTAFF BERLIN, together with a boy, on a charge of being engaged in the manufacture of bogus coin which has been very extensively circulated of late. After considerable search, they succeeded in finding a quantity of crucibles, several molds, a portion of a press, a lot of tools, and other implements and materials used in the manufacture of coin. A further search brought to light a quantity of bogus ten-cent pieces secreted in a match-safe, and another lot hid away in a closet; also, a small lot on BERLIN's person. The accused was taken before Justice POPE, of Hoboken, and committed to the County Jail to await trial. The articles used in manufacturing the coin were also seized. BERLIN's house is in the centre of about two acres of ground, which he cultivates in raising vegetables in daytime, and manufactured the coin at night. The accused denied the charge, but his conversation not only strengthened the charge, but implicated others. Sheriff FRANCIS has been several days in working up this case, which at first gave little hope of success, but has also gained important information regarding parties in New-York and elsewhere, which will probably lead to the arrest of a number of persons engaged in this business. The coin was a very good imitation of the genuine, and in these times would pass very readily.

abstract: A tremendous gathering of Irishmen and sons of Irishmen was held at the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening to welcome Gen. MEAGHER on behalf of the Irish Brigade, and to aid the cause of recruiting for that noble corps.
lead_paragraph: A tremendous gathering of Irishmen and sons of Irishmen was held at the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening to welcome Gen. MEAGHER on behalf of the Irish Brigade, and to aid the cause of recruiting for that noble corps. Gen. MEAGHER received a most flattering greeting, and, in a speech replete with lofty patriotism and fervid eloquence, urged the replenishment of the thinned ranks that still guard the three green flags. He announced that a recruiting office for the brigade will be open at the old stand, No. 596 Broadway.

abstract: We publish elsewhere a full re  port of the prizes and medals awarded to the American exhibitors in the Great World's Fair in London.
lead_paragraph: We publish elsewhere a full report of the prizes and medals awarded to the American exhibitors in the Great World's Fair in London. The most entire impartiality has evidently presided over the action of the jurors, and their decisions, we have every reason to believe, are thoroughly satisfactory to all concerned. It is, indeed, extremely gratifying to find that, although in the present state of our National affairs, Congress did not think it wise to make the proposed grant for the exhibition of American industrial products, private enterprise has done so much in vindication of American prestige, and, even under such signal difficulties, has carried off a fair proportion of the honors given to successful competitors. In the department of the Mechanic Arts, as might have been anticipated, the inventive genius of our citizens has been specially distinguished.

abstract: On Saturday last, in the  Court of Quarter Sessions, a man named HENRY SCHMIDT was convicted of robbing the United States Mint.
lead_paragraph: -On Saturday last, in the Court of Quarter Sessions, a man named HENRY SCHMIDT was convicted of robbing the United States Mint. The offence was committed in the year 1857. The case was delayed until Saturday, in consequence of a question being raised as to whether the accused should be tried in the United States or State Courts. It was finally decided that the United States Court had no jurisdiction in the matter. The circumstances of the case were these:

abstract: E.N. Bond vs. John Dempsey, impleaded,   This was a motion made by the plaintiff, to set off a  judgment recovered in a former action against the  defendants, against a judgment for costs in this action, about to be entered for the defendant Dempsey.
lead_paragraph: E.N. Bond vs. John Dempsey, impleaded, &c. -- This was a motion made by the plaintiff, to set off a judgment recovered in a former action against the defendants, against a judgment for costs in this action, about to be entered for the defendant Dempsey. The action is one of a number of[???] which have been [???] in this Court between the same parties during the past year. In one of the actions a [???] for $2,500 was recovered against two of the [???], (copartners), as makers of several promissory notes, and against the defendant [???], as indorser. Before judgment was rendered, a sale of their copartnership property, amounting to the alleged value of $75,000, was made by the makers of these notes to a third party, subsequently to the recovery of the judgment. The [???] this action, thereupon, to set aside the sale, on the ground that it was a frandulent one, and praying that a receiver be appointed to take charge of the property assigned, &c. In this action, the defendant Dempsey, indorser of the notes, and as [???] judgment debtor, was made a party defendant; be demanded to the complaint, on the ground that no cause of action appeared against him, and on a hearing before [???] J., judgment with costs was rendered for Dempsey.

abstract: On Tuesday evening last there was a fight at Middleton, on the Valley turnpike, about eight miles from Winchester, between our cavalry scouts and the pickets of the enemy, in which they sustained a loss of eight killed and wounded. The only loss suffered on our side was the wounding of a horse.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening last there was a fight at Middleton, on the Valley turnpike, about eight miles from Winchester, between our cavalry scouts and the pickets of the enemy, in which they sustained a loss of eight killed and wounded. The only loss suffered on our side was the wounding of a horse. This little skirmish bad greatly excited the fears of the whole Federal camp, and they had withdrawn their pickets from that road entirely. The gentleman from whom we obtain our information says that he came through from Winchester to Staunton in a buggy without the slightest interruption the entire route.

abstract: Editorial on inequities in new enlistment procedure; urges Federal Government, rather than states, set standard
snippet: Editorial on inequities in new enlistment procedure; urges Federal Government, rather than states, set standard
lead_paragraph: -- We can hardly credit the statement that comes to us through a Washington telegram, that the Government has determined to accept the Pennsylvania volunteers for nine or twelve months. And yet we can scarcely conceive that Gov. CURTIN, who, previous to his proclamation, had been to the Capital, and had an interview with the Washington authorities, could have issued his call for nine or twelve months' men without any warrant whatever. The experience in Pennsylvania, in fact, is a striking illustration of the ill effects of the system adopted by the Government in making the new levy through State instead of National organization. In consequence of Gov. CURTIN's proclamation for recruits on the short term, a large number had enlisted, when a few days ago the announcement came from Washington that there was neither law nor regulation that could allow the Government to receive volunteers on any other term of service than for three years or the war. However annoying this might be to the Pennsylvania recruits, it is undoubtedly the law of the case; and hence, as we said at the beginning, we can scarcely credit the report that the Government has resolved to permit these nine and twelve months enlistments to go on. There is no reason why any discrimination should be made in the case of Pennsylvania; and we are not prepared to think that the patriotism of that State, already so nobly proved, has declined to such an ebb as to ask for any such discrimination. The bounties and pensions provided by the Government are for those enlisting for three years or the war. They could not justly claim the same rewards who but offer their services for one year. Besides, there is no certainty that the lapse of nine or twelve months will see the rebellion wholly crushed; it is safe, at least, to assume that it will not. In that event, therefore, we should have all the trouble and risk of disbanding regiments and enrolling new ones, perhaps at a critical moment. Moreover, it is the purpose that the new enlistments shall be used mainly in filling up regiments now existing, but depleted by battle or disease. It is easy, then, to foresee the endless confusion and demoralization that must arise from this diversity in the terms of enlistment.

abstract: The crops in Frederick, Clarke and Jefferson, were unusually good, but owing to the scarcity of labor, only a portion of the wheat harvest would be gathered. Many of the farmers were saving what they could, but others were permitting the wheat to stand in the field, without the entrance of a scythe. The Yankee commandant had issued a circular to the farmers to induce them to gather their grain, assuring them the Government would purchase it at a price hereafter to be fixed.
