abstract: Detailed report and statistics on strength and equipment of US Navy
snippet: Detailed report and statistics on strength and equipment of US Navy
lead_paragraph: The rebellion has enabled us to show the Powers of the world that our naval resources have been almost as erroneously estimated abroad as our military power. Twelve months ago we had 88 vessels of war, of all kinds, about 30 of which were steamers. We have now 290 vessels, all of which are propelled by steam, except a few sailing corvettes and frigates which can at any time be cut down, converted into iron plated rams or sloops-of-war, and propelled by steam. We had 8,000 sailors and marines a year ago There are now over 23,000 seamen in the United States naval service; the marine corps has been doubled, and, besides, a proportionate increase of officers on the regular staff, Commanders, Lieutenants and minor officers, have been easily obtained for nearly 200 vessels, purchased or chartertered for war purposes. These are facts which should make European Nations hesitate before they still further tax our resources.

lead_paragraph: A NOVEL RIFLE-BATTERY. -- A very novel and apparently formidable instrument of war was exhibited and tested yesterday at McGiehan's Basin, Jersey City, under the supervision of Messrs. SMITH & BRADLEY, of No. 36 Liberty-street, New-York, in the presence of Col. DELAFIELD and others. The inventors are Messrs. REQUA & BILLINGHURST, practical gunsmiths, of New-York. abstract: Gen. T F Meagher holds rally, NY 7th Regiment Armorny, to recruit Irish Brigade; response to new call for troops throughout Eastern States noted
snippet: Gen. T F Meagher holds rally, NY 7th Regiment Armorny, to recruit Irish Brigade; response to new call for troops throughout Eastern States noted
lead_paragraph: Young and old Ireland congregated en masse at the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening, to welcome Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, on behalf of the Irish Brigade. The room was by far too small to accommodate even half of the ten thousand who rushed to demonstrate by their presence their sympathy with the cause as well as with the noble sons of Erin who have so fearlessly thrown their lives into the breach to defend the land of the free from its traitorous assailants. The Armory was ablaze with light, and brilliant with the flags of Ireland and America tastefully disposed. Long before the hour for opening the meeting, the room was densely packed with a sweltering, but none the less enthusiastic, audience. The appearance of the band was the signal for a good-natured outburst of calls for Hibernian music of all kinds, and hearty applause greeted the musicians as they complied, and gave "The Exile of Erin," "St. Patrick's Day,' "Garryowen," &c. The boys were in an excellent humor, and cheered the policeman who ordered the windows opened, the thirty gentlemen who helped themselves to water from the speaker's pitcher, and the reckless individual who threw up camp stools toward the platform, landing them on the heads of unfortunate bystanders. There were calls and hisses for "GREELEY." With the punctuality of a soldier, Gen. MEAGHER struggled toward the platform at precisely 8 o'clock, accompanied by DANIEL DEVLIN, SAMUEL SLOAN, RICHARD LALOR, JOHN SAVAGE and other gentlemen of note. The welcome of Gen. MEAGHER was uproarously cordial, and the utmost enthusiasm was manifested as he took his seat beneath the huge banner:

abstract: The Memphis Bulletin of July 19, reports a meeting which was held in that city on the preceding evening to secure recruits for a National regiment. Col. NABERS, an old resident of Memphis, spoke. He referred to the fact that Gov. JOHNSON, soon after his coercion speech in the Senate, had been hung and burnt in effigy in front of the Adams-street engine-house by the secession mob, which then ruled the city, and expressed the hope that that great man would be here soon, and that all Union-loving men might be permitted to hear his voice raised again for "the Union, the Constitution and enforcement of the laws," and from the very stand where the great indignity had been offered him. Col. NABERS said that the Government of the United States would protect the persons and property of loyal citizens, and that no other had any claim to protection, since no one had a right to claim the protection of a Government which he wished to destroy. He knew not bow it was with others, but as for himself, he was glad to say, that since the arrival of the Federal army, he had been as amply protected in his property and his rights under the Constitution as he could have desired, and presumed the same could be affirmed of all other loyal citizens.

abstract: The Yankees have retreated into Culpepper. They are estimated to number between 30,000 and 40,000, and are mainly stationed in Culpepper and Madison. The report of the taking of Madison Court-house by the enemy is confirmed. After the skirmish on Friday morning at Orange Court-house, our cavalry retired toward Gordon ville, and the enemy mustering courage, advanced as far as Madison, on Run Station, four miles from Gordon ville, where they captured two of the section-masters on the railroad. About the time of their arrival there, our troops having been reinforced, made their appearance, and a grand stampede commenced among the enemy. Our men pursued them some two miles, and captured some seventy of them, who were sent to Richmond on Saturday. There need be no fears of the enemy in that quarter.

lead_paragraph: The Navy Department will, until the 30th day of July, receive propositions from ship builders actually engaged in the construction of vessels, for the construction of the hull of a double-bowed side-wheel gunboat, with rudder at each end, protected by the stems; the masts, rigging, sails for fore-and-aft schooner rig, and awnings; four boats, with all their fittings and equipments complete; tanks for 2,000 gallons of water, with the necessary casks, breakers, buckets, &c. The vessel completed in every respect with all the fittings for sea service, except ordnance, anchors and cables, furniture, cooking utensils, instruments and stores, which will be furnished by the Government.

abstract: AN EXCITING CHASE FOR A PICKPOCKET. Mr. JOHN TAGGARD, of No. 69 Market-street, had his pocket picked yesterday of the sum of $46, while standing in front of a newspaper store in the Bowery, reading a news bulletin.
lead_paragraph: AN EXCITING CHASE FOR A PICKPOCKET. -- Mr. JOHN TAGGARD, of No. 69 Market-street, had his pocket picked yesterday of the sum of $46, while standing in front of a newspaper store in the Bowery, reading a news bulletin. He feit a strong pull at hispantaloons pocket, and upon looking suddenly around he saw a man, who afterward gave his name as WILLIAM JONES, in the act of drawing forth the pocketbook which contained the money in question. The thief at once ran off at full speed, followed by Mr. TAGGARD, who cried, at the top of his voice, "Stop thief! stop thief!" This cry, and the feeling produced upon the passers-by, who saw the whole affair, had the effect to start quite a large crowd in pursuit of the man with the stolen money. For a few minutes the interest and excitement of the race was equal to anything which was ever experienced on the Fashion Course. The chase was soon terminated, however, by Officer WOOD, of the Tenth Precinct, who sprang upon his victim so suddenly, that the most of the crowd had no opportunity to see how skillfully the man was caught. A search for the money was immediately instituted, and the greater portion of it was recovered. The offender was taken before Justice STEERS, and committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Affairs in the neighborhood of Gordonsville, remain comparatively quiet, and at the date of our latest advices the enemy had made no demonstration in force on this side of the Rapidan.
lead_paragraph: Affairs in the neighborhood of Gordonsville, remain comparatively quiet, and at the date of our latest advices the enemy had made no demonstration in force on this side of the Rapidan. On Friday morning last an an attack was made by the Yankee cavalry upon a small body of the Sixth Virginia Cavalry, hear Orange Court House, which was gallantly resisted by our troops, who drove the enemy back, killing and wounding several, and taking forty-four prisoners.

abstract: We give this morning the first authentic exhibit that has been made in the Press of the present strength of the American navy the classification of the vessels, and the number in each class, together with facts in regard to their size, build, armament, the number of men engaged on them, and so forth.
lead_paragraph: We give this morning the first authentic exhibit that has been made in the Press of the present strength of the American navy -- the classification of the vessels, and the number in each class, together with facts in regard to their size, build, armament, the number of men engaged on them, and so forth. We do not think it can be called either boasting or pretension to say that the facts there set forth are astonishing. We do not see that it can be construed into assumption, if we say that a knowledge of these facts will give the nation a feeling of security from aggression, and a firm and intelligent consciousness of power. We do not believe it can be taken for bravado or insult by any foreign Governments if we say that it would be well for them to study and ponder upon these facts before they may finally resolve to interfere in our affairs, or meddle with matters which are none of their business. It is a force intended simply for defence against internal and external foes; and in this work we believe it is capable of doing some successful service against the latter when called upon, as it has already been uniformly and triumphantly successful against the former whenever it has had an opportunity to operate.

abstract: Editorial says British press widens breach between Britons and Americans; Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Editorial says British press widens breach between Britons and Americans; Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: The secession Press of England is sparing no pains to make the alienation between the English and American people as wide as possible. To the ill auguries of our success in the beginning of the rebellion, and hypocritical homilies on what was our duty to the seceding States upon our own admitted principles of republicanism, there is now added a torrent of abuse more coarse and insulting than was ever before indulged in by a high-bred, first-class people against a country of equal respectability and rank. The late foreign mails bring us the London Times of July 9, from which we take the following sample of opinions now freely uttered of us in England:

lead_paragraph: The utmost quiet continues on the lines in the vicinity of Richmond, and there is no probability that this first anniversary of the battle of Manassas will be celebrated by another attempt of the Grand Army to capture the "Rebel Capital." The exchangeof prisoners is progressing as rapidly as circumstances will allow -- large number of the Yankee sick and wounded having been sent to City Point on Saturday, and others will be sent off by different routes.

abstract: There are to be built immediately four new iron clad vessels, to be constructed, in addition to the ten Ericsson gunboats, the Ironsides, Roanoke, and the vessels, the laying of whose keel blocks we notified on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: There are to be built immediately four new iron clad vessels, to be constructed, in addition to the ten Ericsson gunboats, the Ironsides, Roanoke, and the vessels, the laying of whose keel blocks we notified on Wednesday. As far as we can learn, they are to be constructed as follows: One at Jersey City, one at Greenpoint, one at Boston, and one at New-York. A leading iron-founder of this City, who is now in Washington, has telegraphed to his associates in town to employ all the available mechanics they can procure, to build four sets of boilers for new craft. It is said that there are even more than the number given to be commenced, but owing to a decided disinclination on the part of Secretary WELLES and the constructors, to have the fact? or dimensions published, we are compelled to omit them. The one to be built at Boston will be 240 feet long, 53 feet beam, and 1,300 tons. The upper deck will be flush, like that of the Monitor, neither bulwark or rail rising above it. The deck will consist of six-inch oak plank, with one and a half inches of iron plating outside of that. The iron mail on the outside of the hull will be five inches thick. Workmen are setting the blocks for this formidable craft, which will be built at once in the upper ship-house.

abstract: In pursuance of the sixth section of the Act of Congress entitled "An Act to suppress insurrection, to punish treason and rebellion, to seize and confiscate the properly of rebels, and for other purposes," approved July 17, 1862, and which Act, and the joint resolution explanatory thereof, are herewith published, I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, do hereby proclaim to and warn all persons within the contemplation of said sixth section to cease participating in, aiding, countenancing, or abetting the existing rebellion, or any rebellion, against the Government of the United States and to return to their proper allegiance to the United States, on pain of the forfeitures and seizures as within and by said sixth section provided.

abstract: Editorial derides British criticisms; Editorial notes how political sentiments on slavery have fluctuated throughout world
snippet: Editorial derides British criticisms; Editorial notes how political sentiments on slavery have fluctuated throughout world
lead_paragraph: The time has passed in which the violent abuse by the Tory Press of England, of all things American, can produce much sensation here. The sting in the popular feeling in regard to England, was the disappointment of a noble but very youthful sentiment toward her. We had somehow very simply come to believe the talk of her orators about "common blood, common liberties, common literature," and all that, and we had equally accepted, in penitent submission, as sincere, her severe rebukes of our great national sin. Foolish as it now seems, there had sprung up in our masses a certain "sentiment" toward Great Britain, and it probably did not enter the thought of one person in a hundred thousand, when the Rebellion for Slavery broke out, but that the whole moral weight of England would at once be thrown in our scale, and we should have the hearty sympathy of our kindred people. The revulsion, when the facts came out, may have caused here some undue expression of bitterness -- an excitement, however, honorable to the simplicity of our own feelings and to our former ideal of England. All that of course has passed now. We see as clearly as the most English of English journalists, the folly of our sentiments. We behold -- and will not again forget -- that nations have no sympathies; that in the great family of peoples, whether of "common blood" or most diverse blood, as in the great family of nature, the success in the "struggle for life" is only to the strong, and that power and success are alone considered in the relations of Governments. These have now become axioms here, as they must long ago have become in England. Therefore it is that the bitterest insult by English journals falls light as a feather, and the senile sniveling of BROUGHAM, or the mean contempt of RUSSELL, are now passed as the idle wind; and the only thing that concerns us, is that they should go no further. Deeds are the only things now from Great Britain that can cause us anxiety. Still, in the private relations with Englishmen, one is interested continually in the mental phenomenon of a national selfishness, become so ingrained as to be unconscious. These men tell us with the most naive candor that a disintegration of large communities into many small, is the latest politico-economic axiom, and that two or three or four separate republics on the American continent are necessary for a proper "competition" of nations. They coolly exhort us to follow the purest political philosophy, to give up all hopes of greatness, and to permit whatever separation each of our communities would prefer. "So they would act toward Canada." They are "impartial observers," and their advice should be received with some respect. These are the honest views of private Englishmen, and they never for a moment think how they would act if the question of secession were brought to their doors, nor do they remember their own most vigorous and consistent public policy. It does not seem to be before their minds that England has stopped at nothing in the past -- has sacrificed millions of treasure and priceless blood -- has held all Europe at bay -- has gripped the most distant peoples by the throat, and plundered the weak rich, and bullied the strong -- merely and solely that she might retain her Imperial power and position among nations; and all this, and much more, she would do and bear again for the same object. Should India rebel, should Wales secede, or Lancashire revolt, she would pour out her stored wealth like water -- her green fields would be drenched in blood, her cities burnt, before one of these events would be allowed to be consummated in peace. And yet scarce any Englishman ever thinks of the analogy, when American secession is before his mind. To his secret instinct, the whole war here is simply "a brawl" between "vulgar foreigners:" a riotous fight of low Democrats for power, on one side, and "niggers" on the other; and the world (that is, British manufactures) would be much better off if both were well beaten and exhausted, and certainly forever separated. This is literally and truly, we believe, the sentiment of four-fifths of the middle and upper classes of Englishmen toward America. Of course, there is no sympathy in it, but there is also none of the usual effort for even an apparently generous and intelligent understanding of a terrible foreign difficulty; no putting themselves historically or politically in our places, to get at our stand-point.

abstract: We are living in times when the flow of events is daily calling on us to remark that this old adage, however trite, is fortified in its accuracy by practical experience.
lead_paragraph: We are living in times when the flow of events is daily calling on us to remark that this old adage, however trite, is fortified in its accuracy by practical experience. In politics as well as in physical science, we are constantly reminded of the wisdom of being prepared for the refutal of preconceived notions, and to acknowledge as truth what yesterday was pronounced an impracticable paradox. When our fathers were informed that there were lands where the cherry-stone grew outside of the fruit, they treated the statement as we would now treat a revival of the story of the Anthropophagi. When further advised that, in the same countries, the barometer sometimes rose at the approach of foul weather and sank at that of fair, their philosophical incredulity was equal to that with which we now regard the existence of the philosopher's stone; -- yet experience has verified in Australia each of these seeming ab surdities.

abstract: Father O'HAGAN, of the Excelsior (Sickles) Brigade, who was taken prisoner by the rebels on the 30th of June, at Fair Oaks, has been unconditionally released, and joined his regiment in good health at this place, on Sunday morning last.

abstract: We are indebted to Dr. CUYLER, Medical Director at Fortress Monroe, and his efficient Secretary, Mr. VALENTINE SILVA, for the following full and authentic quarterly list of all the deaths that have occurred at the Fortress Monroe and adjoining Hospitals during the months of April, May and June. This list embraces the deaths at the Hygeia, Mill Creek and Chesapeake Hospitals, also the one at Newport's News. Many of these names have been published before, but never in so complete and authentic a form:

abstract: Matter of George Bogue. -- The petitioner alleged that he had been enlisted to go off to the wars when under age, and his affidavit showed him to be only seventeen years old. His infancy was considered established, and he was discharged, greatly to his delight.

abstract: Our community will be it only pained to learn that, yesterday afternoon, during the progress of some experiments in artillery practice at Fort Moultrie, a $2-pounder, which has been rifled and "banded," and with which the troops were firing at an non-plate target, burst, with terrible results to the officers and soldiers standing near the piece.

abstract: Under this caption the Richmond Dispatch says: "A wealthy gentleman, residing in [???], left a valuable portion of his estate, consisting chiefly of negroes, to be appropriated to the Free-school fund of that county. Upon the arrival of the Yankee army at Suffolk, its miserable [???] immediately commenced to [???] the slaves of the sorrounding country from their hitherto happy and contented condition. Among them were the negroes given to this fund, and each and everyone of them was run off, and they are now reaping the reward of their misplaced confidence in the camps and intreachments of their 'delivereis.'"

abstract: Wallace vs. Hollister. -- This was an action to recover the balance of a year's rent for premises let by the plaintiff to the defendant, at $650 per annum. Of the $659 the defendant paid $368 50, but refused to pay the balance, on the allegation that there was an express stipulation between him and the plaintiff that the roof should be made perfectly tight and rainproof, and that the defendant had suffered losses in his segar stock, in consequence of the leaky condition of the roof. It was submitted to the jury, who returned a verdict for the defendant.
lead_paragraph: Wallace vs. Hollister. -- This was an action to recover the balance of a year's rent for premises let by the plaintiff to the defendant, at $650 per annum. abstract: THE TRANSFIGURATION SCHOOL. -- The sixth annual examination of, and distribution of premiums to, the pupils of the school attached to the Church of the Transfiguration, Mott-street, took place on the evenings of the 24th and 25th inst., in the large hall of the La Salle Institute, Second-street. The school is under the charge of the Christian Brothers, and is one of the must successful of the Catholic schools of this City. The programme was extensive, and between the examinations of the various branches of education, was interspersed with speeches, dialogues, recitations, & c. The excellent band of the La Salle Institute, composed of twenty-five pieces, was in attendance, and enlivened the exercises at intervals. The pupils underwent a most thorough examination in the different branches of education -- history, grammar, geography, mathematics, algebra, mensuration, book-keeping, astronomy and the globas, mechanical powers, & c., in all of which they showed remarkable proficiency. The declamatory part of the entertainment was especially attractive, and well performed. The stage was beautifully decorated with American flags, and National airs were frequently payed by the band. On the whole, the examination and exhibition were a decided success, and the aptness shown by the pupils reflects much credit on the diligence of the Christian Brothers and the fostering care of Father TRAINOR, in whose parish the school is situated. At the conclusion of the exercises the premiums were distributed to the different classes, by Rev. Father TRAINOR.

abstract: From our files of Southern papers we make additional entertaining extracts. The reading columns of these journals speak for themselves; the advertising columns show that deserters still leave the rebel ranks in droves; that hundreds are dying from disease as well as from wounds received in battles that substitutes to perform military service are in brisker demand than ever; that the conscript law is sweeping every man able to bear arms into the Confederate ancy; and that thieves are doing brisk work in the larger towns and cities. It is also a fact worth noticing that the Richmond papers publish full reports of the speech recently delivered in Congress by Senator CHANDLER, and make all they can of the revelations therein placed at their disposal.

abstract: Journal of the Health of Louis XIV, by his physicians Drs. Vallot, L'Aguin and Fagon, reviewed; Journal of Health of Louis XIV, by his physicians Drs. Vallot, L'Aguin and Fagon, reviewed
snippet: Journal of the Health of Louis XIV, by his physicians Drs. Vallot, L'Aguin and Fagon, reviewed; Journal of Health of Louis XIV, by his physicians Drs. Vallot, L'Aguin and Fagon, reviewed
lead_paragraph: The above is the title of a most curious and interesting book, just published by M. LE ROI, the Librarian of Versailles. We have here, from authentic sources, a daily record ot the health of the Grand Monarque from his earliest infancy to the year 1711, that is to say, till within four years of his death. All his diseases, ailments, indigestions, vapors and disordered fancies are here chronicled in most minute detail, together with a full description of the purges, emetics, tonics, ointments, plasters, lavements and surgical operations which were from time to time administered, used, employed, performed and resorted to, for the purpose of keeping alive, solacing, comforting, cherishing and beautifying the proudest sovereign of his own or almost any other age. If "no man," as the proverb says, "is a hero to his valet de chambre," who shall be a hero to his physician? Fortunate is it for the memories of many heroes of antiquity, that their physicians have transmitted to posterity no such diary as that which now paints with photographical accuracy, to gratify the curiosity of the profane vulgar, the bodily infirmities of Louis XIV. Fancy the physician of ALEXANDER, who saved his life when he imprudently took a cold bath in the Cydnus, publishing a prognosis and diagnosis about his godlike master at every stage of his fabulous march through Asia. Fancy ANTONIUS MUSA, who received the honor of a statue, for curing AUGUSTUS of a dangerous illness, having left a note-book describing, day by day, the miseries of the sick chamber of the great valetudinarian Emperor. We know, in a general way, that JULIUS CESAR had the "falling sickness," and SHAKESPEARE imagines him calling out like a sick girl, "Give me some drink, Titinius;" but there is no medical record of what he said and did when he was seized with giddiness, what piece of furniture he caught hold of to steady himself with; how often the fits recurred, how long they lasted, and what treatment was used to relieve him. All this and much more is imperturbably told by M. LE ROI about LOUIS XIV., who played with vertigo all his life. The publication of this book is in itself a sign of the times and a mark of progress. But a few years ago such disclosures would have been thought politically dangerous, as tending to diminish the respect of the vulgar for that "divinity which doth hedge a king." Only so recently as 1846 LOUIS PHILIPPE's Minister, M. DE SALVANDY, positively prohibited the Duke DE LA ROCHEFOUCAULD LIANCOURT from publishing "an account of the last illness of LOUIS XV.," and, at the last moment, the review which had the paper in type, was obliged to substitute something else for it.
headline: {'main': "NEW PUBLICATIONS.; JOURNAL OF THE HEALTH OF LOUIS XIV. Written by Drs. VALLOT, L'AQUIN and FAGON, all three, successively, his First Physicians.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "NEW PUBLICATIONS.; JOURNAL OF THE HEALTH OF LOUIS XIV. abstract: The Chicago Tribune, for a wonder, applauds the calling of Gen. Halleck to Washington, and for these reasons: "He will be under the influence of the President who, by this time, must be thoroughly tired of nigger-catching and ditch-digging. He will be obedient to the laws which may force him to act sometimes against his will.
lead_paragraph: -- The Chicago Tribune, for a wonder, applauds the calling of Gen. Halleck to Washington, and for these reasons: "He will be under the influence of the President who, by this time, must be thoroughly tired of nigger-catching and ditch-digging. He will be obedient to the laws which may force him to act sometimes against his will. And he will be within the reach of that now exasperated public opinion which demands that a more vigorous and effective policy than that displayed in the Peninsula, or that which suffered Beauregard to escape from Corinth, shall be adopted. And last of all, we know that in this matter the President has not acted without full and unreserved consultation with his friends, most of whom entertain what man characterize as extreme views as to the way in which the war should be carried on. With his and their decision we are for the present content; and until we see new Orders No. 3 cropping out, and new intrenchments beginning to rise, we shall permit no slight thing to wring from us a complaint."

abstract: Peter Morris vs. T.J. Walsh et al. This action was brought to cancel a contract for the building of 24 houses in that part of Forty-second-street known as Morris-place.
lead_paragraph: Peter Morris vs. T.J. Walsh et al. -- This action was brought to cancel a contract for the building of 24 houses in that part of Forty-second-street known as Morris-place. The plaintiff obtained judgment against the [???] by default, and application wassubsequently made to open the default, which was granted conditionally. By the judgment the contract was adjudge cancelled, and the defendant was required to execute a release and conveyance of the premises, and about to deliver up the possession and the keys of the houses. A copy of the judgment was served upon the defendant on June 11, and on the 1st instant an order to show cause was granted why an attachment should not issue against Walsh for Contempt. The attachment was granted, and on the return day defendant's counsel moved to set it aside upon several grounds -- among others that a [???] copy of the judgment should have been served with the order to show cause, and that no demand had been made by the [???], who was appointed. abstract: The various churches were, on yesterday, largely attended by soldiers from quarters in and near the city, and their respective congregations being present also, in numbers more full than usual, were in some instances subjected to a considerable pressure. It is surprising to see so many from our army eager to visit the churches, and whether the impulse is occasioned by piety or a longing for relief from monotony, it is good evidence that the life of the soldier is not, as many of the over-pious believe, a school for vice and abandoned habits. Those who resort to the churches even to pass away time, manifest a taste in the character of their pleasure which cannot justly be deemed immoral.

abstract: The steamer Wilson, from Vicksburgh, arrived last night. When in Princeton Bend, 80 miles above Vicksburgh, she was fired into from the Mississippi side by several 6-pounders and a score or two of muskets, and was hit about sixty times, mostly by musket balls. One shell burst directly under the boiler. No one was hurt.

abstract: There are certain Presses and people among us that are never weary of pouring forth the vials of their wrath on the heads of the unlucky Abolitionists.
lead_paragraph: There are certain Presses and people among us that are never weary of pouring forth the vials of their wrath on the heads of the unlucky Abolitionists. There is no limit totheir invective, no measure for their scorn. They deprecate unceasingly the agitation of the "everlasting nigger" in diatribes which overrun their columns and engross their conversation. They insist that Abolition shall be "squelched" and put out of the way forever, and devote their entire time and attention to publishing its doctrines and advertising its progress. They are continually conjuring up the spirit they profess they wish to exercise, and indulge in endless discussions on a subject about which they declare there can be no rational argument. Where these people have one word of reprobation for the traitors in arms against their country, they have twenty for the class whose inexpiable crime consists in differing from themselves in opinion.

abstract: The announcement from Washington, made yesterday morning, to tho effect that the War Department (in compliance wah the suggestion of the New-York Common Council) had determined to pay twenty-five dollars of the United States bounty immediately on tho recruit being sworn in, had a marked effect on the business of enlistment.
lead_paragraph: The announcement from Washington, made yesterday morning, to tho effect that the War Department (in compliance wah the suggestion of the New-York Common Council) had determined to pay twenty-five dollars of the United States bounty immediately on tho recruit being sworn in, had a marked effect on the business of enlistment. Added to theState bounty of twenty-five dollars, and the premium of two dollars, heretofore accorded, this will make a total of fifty-two dollars for each volunteer to receive before leaving home to go into camp.

abstract: There are one or two points in the order issued by President LINCOLN appointing HALLECK General-in-Chief of the land forces of the United States, to which the attention of the quidnuncs is directed. First, it is dated at the Executive Mansion, and not at the War Department, and it bears the simple signature of "ABRAHAM LINCOLN," without the indorsement of Mr. STANTON, as Secretary of War. Then, although it bears date July 11, -- the morning after the President returned from his trip to James River, by the way, -- several days before the adjournment of Congress, the appointment was not sent in to that body for confirmation. What have the quidnuncs to say of these little informalities?

abstract: KNOXVILLE, July 17. -- A dispatch from Col. FORREST, giving an account of the engagement at Murfeesboro, says that the dash was capture on the town Saturday morning. Our success was complete. Col. FORREST states that he captured 1,200 prisoners, including two Brigadier-Generals, four pieces of cannon, and destroyed half a million of army stores. The Confederate loss was sixteen killed and thirty wounded; the enemy's loss between two and three hundred. After the capture of the town and securing the prisoners, Col. FORREST fell back to McMinnville, for fear of a surprise from greate forces.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, July 17. -- A dispatch from Col. FORREST, giving an account of the engagement at Murfeesboro, says that the dash was capture on the town Saturday morning. abstract: There are abundant signs of cheer in looking over the broad extent of the military field at present. In the first place, there is cheer in the fact that we have now a Soldier at the head of our armies.
lead_paragraph: There are abundant signs of cheer in looking over the broad extent of the military field at present. In the first place, there is cheer in the fact that we have now a Soldier at the head of our armies. We may now expectunity and directness of purpose, harmony of action, and a proper seizure and use of all the means and agencies of war. We may expect -- and it is to be hoped we will not expect in vain -- that there will be promptitude, speed, and decision in movement; that not a day will be lost, nor an opportunity missed. There is cheer in the fact that this commander has such an army, or armies, already formed and equipped to his hands. We have praised this army much and often during the past year, and we have not a jot to abate from any of our words now. It is still a superb -- an unequaled army. There have, undoubtedly, been popular exaggerations as to its numbers -- based, however, in the first instance, on official misapprehensions which were given to the public. It has been decimated, too, by battle, by disease and by work in the trenches. But, apart from exaggeration, and making all allowance for losses of every kind, we have still between three and four hundred thousand men in the field -- armed with the best weapons and supported by rifled cannon. There have been disappointments, it is true, that this great military force has not before now completely trampled down the rebellion, captured Richmond, and carried our flag from the Potomac to the Rio Grande. But the popular expectations were based on misapprehension as to the actual and possible power of the rebels, and a want of knowledge as to what the phrase "crushing out the rebellion" really meant. There is, however, as we remarked on a previous day, a positive gain, if not cheer to us in the fact that we now know this. We have seen, measured and wrestled with the foe in his full strength and ferocity; and though we did not completely overcome him in the grand encounter, we rose from the work with a consciousness that it was within our power. There is cheer in the fact that this power, which lies with the people, has now been called out to a greater degree than ever. We know that if Gen. MCCLELLAN had had fifty thousand more soldiers last month, the rebel host would assuredly have been overcome, Richmond would have fallen, and DAVIS and the remnants of his army and Government would probably, by this time, have been as far South as South Carolina. Had he that number of additional troops to-day, he would bring the campaign in Virginia to a speedy and triumphant end. All over the land the men are enlisting now to fill up the ranks; and the three hundred thousand volunteers called for, when once under arms, will give us the additional strength which the late battles and movements show that we need for our work. In the fact that the North has plenty of men able to take the field, there is an assurance of triumph; and in the fact that they are forthcoming there is a sign of cheer.

abstract: We have advices from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to Saturday. A flag of truco boat, conveying Col. WRIGHT and Lieut.-Col. SWEITZER, on Friday proceeded to a point twentyone miles above City Point, to meet ROBERT OULD, formerly District-Attorney in Washington, now...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to Saturday. A flag of truco boat, conveying Col. WRIGHT and Lieut.-Col. SWEITZER, on Friday proceeded to a point twentyone miles above City Point, to meet ROBERT OULD, formerly District-Attorney in Washington, now Commissioner of the rebel government to carry out the new arrangement for the exchange of prisoners. Gens. HALLECK, DIX, MEIGS and BURNSIDE, after an interview with Gen. MCCLELLAN, had gone down the river. A schooner loaded with condemned corn had been burned by the rebels in the James River, and her captain carried off prisoner.

abstract: The first of a home-and-home match between these clubs took place on Saturday, on the fine ground of the St. George's Club, Elysian Fields, Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: The first of a home-and-home match between these clubs took place on Saturday, on the fine ground of the St. George's Club, Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The Willow's were beaten in two matches last year by St. George, but having engaged the services of Mr. HAMMOND, the former professional of the German-town Club, of Philadelphia, they have been in such active practice, that they found themselves competent to play ten of their club -- with their professional -- against the St. George's Club's first eleven. The St. George's Club having accepted a challenge on these terms magnanimously made up an eleven without their professionals, and perhaps underrating the strength of the Willow's -- judging by last year's experience -- they substituted some of their second eleven, for first eleven men, and the result was an overwhelming defeat of the Dragon slayers.

abstract: A PROBABLE HOMICIDE IN ESSEX-STREET.  About 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, a serious stabbing affray occurred in Essex-street, between Broome and Delancey, during which a German baker of the Tenth Ward, named ADAM CHRISTMAN, was cut in the neck and shoulder so severely that no hopes are entertained of his recovery.
lead_paragraph: A PROBABLE HOMICIDE IN ESSEX-STREET. -- About 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, a serious stabbing affray occurred in Essex-street, between Broome and Delancey, during which a German baker of the Tenth Ward, named ADAM CHRISTMAN, was cut in the neck and shoulder so severely that no hopes are entertained of his recovery. Officer ACKERMAN, of the Tenth Precinct, arrested three men, named AUGUST KNOOP, FREDERICK SEICKEL and ADAM BURGER, who are supposed to be implicated in the affair. The account of the affray, as given by Officer ACKERMAN, who was in the immediate vicinity, is, that CHRISTMAN and a friend of his were passing along Essex-street, and when about opposite the brewery of Mr. KUNTZ he saw CHRISTMAN and his friend in an encounter with the three men who were arrested. During the melee CHRISTMAN threw a lager-bier glass at one of the men. which struck him upon the head, and inflicted a serious wound. The officer then Interfered and took CHRISTMAN into custody. While he was in the act of making the arrest, a knife in the hands of one of the parties was thrust forcibly toward him, but fortunately it struck his club, and he was thus saved from being wounded. On the way to the station-house, CHRISTMAN seemed weak and faint, but it was not until they arrived at the latter place that the prisoner fed senseless through loss of blood. It was then discovered that the man had been dangerously [???], and for a time it was believed that he was dying. Medical aid was soon [???], and shortly afterward he was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he now lies in a critical condition. Coroner NAUMANN visited him yesterday, at the re-quest of Justice STEERS, for the purpose of taking his deposition, but after consultation with his physicians, who say that his life depends upon his being kept quiet, it was deemed best to postpone the investigation. Officer ACKERMAN, while searching in the neighborhood of the place of the affray, found a dirk-knife, which is no doubt the instrument with which the offence was committed. The [???] arrested were yesterday taken before Justice STEERS, at the Essex Market Police Court, and after a preliminary examination, they were committed to await the result of the injuries.

abstract: It is a month since President LINCOLN issued his proclamation calling for a fresh muster of three hundred thousand men.
lead_paragraph: It is a month since President LINCOLN issued his proclamation calling for a fresh muster of three hundred thousand men. What proportion of that force is now under arms? Is there a half of it? Is there a single hundred thousand? Is there fifty thousand the whole country over? What proportion of it has been sent forward to reinforce the army of Gen. MCCLELLAN? Has there been twenty-five thousand men? Has there been ten thousand? We do not doubt, that since the battles of last month, Gen. MCCLELLAN has been strengthened by more than ten thousand new soldiers; for a great part of our forces in both the Carolinas, under Gens. BURNSIDE and HUNTER, has left those States and come forward to reinforce him; and detachments have also been sent him from other columns of our army. But of the new levy of volunteers, we fear that he has not yet seen, nor is likely for some time to see, the faces of half a dozen regiments.

abstract: We have received advice, that owing to the dryness of the weather, a very large quantity of the best quality of white and red pine, will not reach Quebec this season. Fifty to sixty thousand pieces are estimated to remain above Ottawa, as also 100,000 saw logs. The water is unprecedentedly low, and a good deal of timber, not included in the above, it is generally believed, will not come over the Calumet and Mountain Slides, and, indeed, the river will be pretty well covered with sticks of timber stuck in different places. Below Ottawa, on the Nation and other tributaries, at least 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 feet will remain, besides saw logs. On the St. Lawrence a very considerable quantity will remain behind at Peterboro', Lindsay and other lumbering districts. In short, the Spring's work has been much retarded, and the cost of lumber much enhanced by the extraordinary dryness of the season. Parties who have been so fortunate as to get their timber to market, ought to reap a rich advantage, as, no doubt, timber of a superior quality and average will be in much request this fall. -- Montreal Gazette, July 25.

abstract: It may be laid down as a general proposition that when a dramatist evinces any special anxiety  concerning the copyright of a production to which he puts his name, and aggressively threatens the world with pains and penalties for infringement of his valuable title it may, we say, be laid down as a...
lead_paragraph: It may be laid down as a general proposition that when a dramatist evinces any special anxiety concerning the copyright of a production to which he puts his name, and aggressively threatens the world with pains and penalties for infringement of his valuable title -- it may, we say, be laid down as a general rule that that dramatic has been either making a wholesale appropriation from the French, or pilfering in a smaller way from some piece of English origin. Advertised warnings not to play a piece, under terror of the law, are made much in the same spirit as a recommendation to a mob not to put the victim they may have in their clutches under a hydrant. In both cases it is inwardly hoped the very thing will be done which the apparent desire is to avert. Sometimes the trick, transparent as it is, is successful; oftener It is seen through, and fails, as it deserves to do. It was a trick that Mr. BOURCICAULT worked adroitly on several occasions; but Mr. BOURCICAULT has tact and genius, which the other dramatist of the day have not, though they probably think they have, and vaingloriously wonder how it is that a discriminating public differs from them in opinion.

lead_paragraph: -- ovation" is not the correct word, but it must do in default of a better -- on the occasion of their complimentary testimonial at Wallack's last Monday. The house was not only crowded, but a great many people had to go away and use their tickets the following evening. Those who did this enjoyed as great a treat in seeing the burlesque on "Fra Diavolo" as ever they could have done by sitting through a long programme of unadulterated Irish Boy and Yankee Gal. This barlesque is the quaintest, funniest thing of its kind that was ever written, it is played almost to perfection, and ought to run and bring in to the FLORENCES as much money as "Lalla Rookh" did, when it was done by them at WALLACK's old theatre.

abstract: The first installment of the State bounty money will be paid to-day. Preliminary matters have been arranged, and recruits will have a positive proof of the earnestness of Gov. MORGAN's proclamation awarding $50 to each one. The men belonging to the "Metropolitan Guard," Col. CHARLES S. TURNBULL, are to be the recipients, checks having been received from Paymaster-Gen. GEORGE BLISS on Saturday evening. To-day, at 12 o'clock noon, the soldiers will, after having indorsed the checks, be placed in possession of the money. This promptness in paying the bounty money is most praiseworthy, and must certainly have a most beneficial effect on enlistments. Men, when they Know that their wives and families are kept from immediate want by the payment of this money, will come forward more readily -- so readily, indeed, that New-York win, in a very short time, have her quota of men in the field. Other organizations besides the "Metropolitan Guard" will also, shortly, have checks for the payment of the bounty given them; the good work has begun, and a recruit can be in possession of the first installment of his bounty money within 48 hours after enlistment. At present, the regiment is encamped on Riker's Island, the name given to the encampment is "Camp Bowne," after Police Commissioner BOWNE. The majority of the officers attached to Col. TURNBULL's regiment are gentlemen of experience, having been connected with the Seventh an Seventy-first Regiments. H.M. RAYMOUR has been appointed Quartermaster, and GEO. H. WHEATON Adjutant.

abstract: Advices from Europe one day later to the evening of the 17th are received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Edinburgh. The news, however, is of little importance.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe one day later -- to the evening of the 17th -- are received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Edinburgh. The news, however, is of little importance. It is reported by private telegram from India, that 115,000 bales of cotton were shipped from Bombay in one week, following the news of the first rise in the Liverpool market. It was considered probable that this amount would be vastly increased when the news of the further rise reached India. A desperate conflict is reported to have taken place between the Turks and the Montenegrins, in which the former were victorious. The Commercial advices by the Edinburgh are no later than those by the Etna.

abstract: August
snippet: August
lead_paragraph: Harper's for August comes to us, as usual, in advance of the month, fair and smiling as a guest who is well assured of a welcome. The newspaper thatbrought intelligence of a great victory for the National arms could not make its appearance at loyal breakfast tables with a more confident air, and yet its cream-colored cover has not caught the faintest blush of crimson from the fields where the thousand battle-fires burn; in its pages we vainly look for even the dimmest reflection of the prevailing sentiment of the multitude. The chubby cherub, and the fat and fudgy little seraphim on the cover are disporting themselves precisely as they did in the days of peace, the one blowing soap-bubbles, the others recklessly raining roses, and other vegetables from inexhaustible baskets. But very many of the public are also occupied with somewhat similar saponaceous and floral amusements, and the cherubim, seraphim, or any other phim, resident in Franklin-square or elsewhere, have a right to mimic them.

abstract: We  presented a few days ago a protest against the impolicy and injustice of the short term of enlistment authorized by the Governor of Pennsylvania for the volunteers from that State.
lead_paragraph: -- We presented a few days ago a protest against the impolicy and injustice of the short term of enlistment authorized by the Governor of Pennsylvania for the volunteers from that State. A dispatch from Adjutant-General THOMAS clears up the complication so far as the bounty money is concerned, by the statement that no bounty will be allowed the nine months' men except the twenty-five dollars paid at the time of being mustered into service; the remaining seventy-five dollars is payable to those only who enlist for three years or the war.

abstract: Gen. BEAUREGARD is continually having a violent struggle with "the Eternal Veracities," from which both combatants emerge a good deal the worse for wear.
lead_paragraph: Gen. BEAUREGARD is continually having a violent struggle with "the Eternal Veracities," from which both combatants emerge a good deal the worse for wear. The last, as wellas one of the most notable demonstrations of this nature, had its origin in the rebel retreat from Corinth, the necessity for which appears to have irritated BEAUREGARD to a high pitch of mendacity. Not satisfied with the publicity of his "general orders" -- the usual vehicle for exhibiting his inventive genius -- the Creole officer fired off a big gun in the Mobile News, denying the statements of Gens. HALLECK and POPE in particular, and of almost everybody else in general. These refutals were of a sweeping and comprehensive character, but also included some circumstantial details. Now, most people, whether friends or foes, have got to know Gen. BEAUREGARD so thoroughly that it excited no great surprise when quite a number of authorities, rebel prisoners, as well as our own officers, united in a chorus of testimony to the incorrectness of his allegations; but the evidence of Gen. GRANGER, who led the advance of the Union pursuit, is of so minute and unmistakable a description, that -- backed as it is by irrefrigable corroboration -- we are forced to the conviction that BEAUREGARD has really outdone himself, and told a more monstrous series of lies than ever before. Gen. GRANGER says:

abstract: As our readers will testify, we have hammered away at different times on sanitary improvements in the army, till the patience of the public must be nearly exhausted.
lead_paragraph: As our readers will testify, we have hammered away at different times on sanitary improvements in the army, till the patience of the public must be nearly exhausted. A year ago, we did our best to impress upon the Quartermaster-General or the Surgeon-General, the indispensable necessity of a train of mule ambulances to our army. We urged them on the ground of humanity and of economy. At the very time one of the articles was in press on this subject, the wounded were left on the field of Mill Spring, many of them to die, because ambulances could not possibly reach the place, so bad were the roads. With the mule ambulances, one man and two mules can get off four wounded men. In every battle on the Peninsula, there have not been half ambulances enough, and usually two horses and two men have been needed to carry away two wounded. How many of our brave fellows would have been saved to the country in the late week of battles, had the army possessed this train of mules. The camp police, too, has beer, a subject on which much has been written in our columns. We have called attention to simple practical means for preserving the health of an army -- the enforced cleanliness of the men, the strict covering of refuse and garbage and filth with fresh dirt, the airing and drying of tent-floors, the drainage and best exposure for camps, and other like matters. We have argued strongly against the received army rations as being adapted to our former condition, when troops were scattered over such vast territory and were composed of trained soldiers; we showed that even with them, scurvy was fearfully prevalent, and that for our volunteers less fat and more acids were needed -- smaller rations of pork and more of vegetables or other luxuries. We pressed the claims of tea as an army ration, equally necessary with coffee, and perhaps more useful in the Northern climate -- the latter producing too much laxity of system.
headline: {'main': 'Health Matters in the Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Health Matters in the Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Had THEODORE WINTHROP lived the probabilities are he would have written a book that would have lived. The few works he has left behind him are as brilliant as rainbows, and as full of promise, but they are only rainbows after all. No one of them forms the perfect arch of an enduring monument.
lead_paragraph: -- Had THEODORE WINTHROP lived the probabilities are he would have written a book that would have lived. The few works he has left behind him are as brilliant as rainbows, and as full of promise, but they are only rainbows after all. No one of them forms the perfect arch of an enduring monument. Our children and our children's children will honor his name for what he did and not for what he wrote.

abstract: Editorial laments meager results of new military recruiting in last month; Editorial sees need to improve medical activities of Army; Editorial cites Beauregard tendency to tell falsehoods
snippet: Editorial laments meager results of new military recruiting in last month; Editorial sees need to improve medical activities of Army; Editorial cites Beauregard tendency to tell falsehoods
lead_paragraph: The President has just issued a Proclamation which forms another step in the grand proces against the giant crime of Rebellion. By this Proclamation, made in pursuance of the sixth section of the act of Congress, entitled "An Act to suppress insurrection, to punish treason and rebellion, to seize and confiscate the property of rebels, and for other purposes," approved July 17, 1862, he warns "all persons within the contemplation of said sixth section, to cease participating in, aiding, countenancing or abetting the existing rebellion, or any rebellion against the Government of the United States, and to return to their proper allegiance to the United States, on pain of the forfeitures and seizures as within and by said sixth section provided."

abstract: The people Liverpool, yesterday morning, were put in a state of enviable delight by the telegram from Londonderry. It told of Confederate successes at Richmond; and the Confederates are, throughout England, and especially on the Mersey, decidedly favorites. The advocates of the South looked cheerful, joyous and happy. Everything they had anticipated, more than they had hoped for, had come to pass. The Yankees were whipped; MCCLELLAN had to retreat; the Secessionists pursued him, and he had to burn large portions of his materials and supplies. People of Federal proclivities had, as it were, to hide their diminished heads. They looked grave, they were disappointed, and they were greatly afraid that what their opponents exulted at was true. To use the mildest language, Gen. MCCLELLAN had had to retreat; to use the strongest language, he had to fly. It could not be disguised that he was beaten. He had advanced, and was driven back; he was feeling his way, and he found the ground untenable under him. All that could be said in his favor was that he conducted his retreat very skillfully and with great success.

abstract: Since the failure of ZARAGOZA in his attempt to capture the French troops, he has made no fresh essay, and the Reactionists loudly boast that his army is ...
lead_paragraph: Since the failure of ZARAGOZA in his attempt to capture the French troops, he has made no fresh essay, and the Reactionists loudly boast that his army is completely demoralized, and that even the guerrillas have dispersed, leaving the communication between Vera Cruz and Orizaba completely free, so that the French troops are well supplied with everything; indeed, they are much better off than the people of Vera Cruz, where provisions are both scarce and dear, A great many vessels had arrived from France with stores -- so many that the wharfage and storage room were not sufficient. From Martinique there had arrived over a thousand French soldiers. But the yellow fever continued its ravage. The quarrel between ZARAGOZA and [???] continued, while GONZALEZ ORTEGA, suffering from his wound, was on bad terms with both. With regard to the position of ZARAGOZA, he was encamped at a distance of twenty-five leagues from Orizaba. The existence of such a small force as the French in the midst of a hostile country, is an enigma that, as the Prensa observes, only those who know the state of exhaustion to which that country has arrived, can comprehend.

abstract: British press observations
snippet: British press observations
lead_paragraph: Before we venture to presage the conduct and demeanor of the Americans in this new trial of their faith in their destiny and in themselves, let us think for a moment what would be our own feelings under similar circumstances. We need not try the question by any hypothetical test. Like every great community formed in the course of time by the confluence of races and the conjunction of kingdoms and provinces once separate from one another, our own unity as a nation has been more than once threatened, and more than once has the heroic instinct of greatness raised us above the time-serving folly of tampering with or tolerating a political schism. We need not even appeal to the history of other times for an illustration. In our own day the inhabitant of one-third of the United Kingdom, provoked by the neglect of their just local grievances, threatened political secession. Legislative independence was openly avowed as the object of millions of men, and in the united Parliament itself the purpose was avowed and maintained. The seceding portion of the empire was declared to be politically overborne by the remainder, and its social condition was said to be peculiar and distinct, not understood by the rest, and requiring separate laws. The terms of the Union were declared to have been violated, and the spirit of the compact to have been broken. Geographically, the line of separation between the two islands was deeply and indelibly marked; and the lapse of time -- not half as long as that which has sanctioned the American Confederation -- was not sufficient to obliterate from the minds of those who would have rescinded the Union with Ireland the vivid recollection of the state of things that existed previous to that act. Theoretically it was argued by the Irish Secessionists that if free to marry, they had a right to divorce on grounds of neglect and cruelty. The injustice and the neglect were admitted unreservedly by the best and wisest of our own statesmen. But while they pleaded for redress they told the Repealers of Ireland that the Union they were resolved to maintain at any hazard. Among the liberal statesmen of Great Britain there was on this point an unanimity as entire, a determination as unwavering, as among the most conservative of their rivals. On every other question of modern politics, domestic, colonial, foreign, municipal, imperial, financial, they differed again and again; but on this one great, vital, and essential question, they never differed. WELLINGTON and GREY, PEEL and RUSSELL, LYNDHURST and BROUGHAM, GRAHAM and PALMERSTON, all agreed that, come what might, the Union must be maintained, the integrity of the realm must be preserved. In one of the most brilliant and effective speeches ever delivered by MACAULAY, after reminding the Irish on how many questions the Liberal party had fought with them side by side, as they were ready to do again, he thus warned them of the infatuation of seeking to dissolve the Union: "The Repeal of the Union we regard as fatal to the Empire, and we never will consent to it; never -- though the country should be surrounded by dangers as great as those which threatened her when her American colonies, and France, and Spain, and Holland, were leagued against her, and when the armed neutrality of the Baltic disputed her maritime rights; never -- though another BONAPARTE should pitch his camp in sight of Dover Castle; never -- till the four quarters of the world have been convulsed by the last struggle of the great English people for their place among the nations."

abstract: When the train from the West, on the Central Railroad, reached Frederick's Hall, a station 50 miles from this city, it was met by a rumor that the Yankee cavalry had made another raid from Fredericksburgh, and had possession of the track at Anderson turn-out, 10 miles below Beaver Dam, and 30 miles from Richmond. The telegraph wire not being in working order, there was no means of ascertaining the truth of this report. Under the circumstances the conductor, not choosing to risk the passengers and train, took an extra locomotive and ran down to Andersons on a reconnoissance. When he reached this place he found the report of the Yankees at that point correct, but they had left several hours previous to his arrival. He learned the following particulars:

abstract: Editorial doubts intervention by France and Great Britain; says it would be to their disadvantage
snippet: Editorial doubts intervention by France and Great Britain; says it would be to their disadvantage
lead_paragraph: Our European letters this morning are big with portents of intervention. Our correspondent at Paris, always well poised and well informed, is satisfied that the vast naval and military preparations of France, ostensibly directed against Mexico, are ultimately aimed at the United States. It is with a view to apossible contest with the latter, growing out of the Mexican botchwork, if not out of some direct act of friendship and support offered to the South, that the Emperor is about to crowd his cuirassed steamers and ships-of-the-line into our harbors, and thus be prepared for all eventualities. England, servile to the Imperial policy, is obliged to make a similar disposition of its squadrons, in readiness to back NAPOLEON in any quarrel he may provoke. Our London correspondent, constitutionally less cautious, is still more positive that all England is rapidly hastening to the conclusion that the war can only be terminated by forcible intervention. The aristocratic party, touched with the sufferings of the masses, clamors for an enforced peace. It only remains for the suffering masses to be tricked into a concordant clamor, for the cry to become too unanimous to be resistible, and accordingly the entire energies of the London Times, Post and Herald are concentrated upon an effort to satisfy the starving workmen that their calamities are not only due to Northern pugnacity, but that the North, so far from exhibiting any symptoms of remorse, actually glories in the agonies of Lancashire and Lanark. These labors, it is assumed by our correspondent, must presently be successful in arraying the whole British people in favor of the South and intervention.

abstract: The effect on the Yankee soldiers of Gen. POPE's recent orders to the "army of the Rappahannock," is already being felt by the citizens of Culpepper. The party who burnt the bridge over the Rapidan on the 13th, took breakfast that morning at the house of ALEXANDER G. TALIAFERRO, Colonel of the Twenty-first Virginia Regiment. On their approach the Colonel was at home, and was very near being captured, but, by good management, contrived to escape. After they had breakfasted, the Yankee ruffians searched the house, took possession of the family silver, broke up the table ware and knives and forks, &c., and actually wrenched from Mrs. TALIAFERRO's finger a splendid diamond ring of great value.
lead_paragraph: The effect on the Yankee soldiers of Gen. POPE's recent orders to the "army of the Rappahannock," is already being felt by the citizens of Culpepper. abstract: Since the agreement of the Commissioners upon the exchange of prisoners, nearly twelve hundred wounded Federal prisoners taken in the late battles, have been sent to the Federal transports in James River. During this charitable, and, in all respects, honorable movement on the part of the Confederate Commissioners, we learn that the Federal army on the James made an advance up the river of about two miles. This intelligence reaching headquarters has caused a cessation of movements in regard to the exchange, and appropriate arrangements must be made before they are proceeded with. -- Daily Enquirer, July 24.
lead_paragraph: Since the agreement of the Commissioners upon the exchange of prisoners, nearly twelve hundred wounded Federal prisoners taken in the late battles, have been sent to the Federal transports in James River. abstract: Ward vs. Ruckman et al. -- This was a motion to open a default taken against the defendants in this action, upon the affidavit of counsel that a material first ground was good if it had taken at the trial, due diligence having been shown on the part of defendants. If it was not taken then, however, it was a neglect that could not be excused, for it would be trifling with the Court to permit a case to go to trial when a good reason exists for postponement, which is concealed for the purpose of such a motion. But it was shown in opposition to the motion, that this objection was taken at the time and the Judge at the Circuit passed upon it, refusing to allow the case to go off for the term. The Court was of opinion that even had the fact been shown that the Referee had been moved, and refused to allow an adjournment to enable counsel to attend this trial, still the costly machinery of the Circuit could not be expected to stand still to suit the convenience of a Referee.

abstract: The funeral of Ex-President MARTIN VAN BURKN took place at Kinderhook yesterday, and was attended by a large concourse of people from the vicinity, and many from abroad. Among the strangers present was Gov. MORGAN, Bishop POTTER, of Pennsylvania, and a Committee of Twelve from the Tammany Society of this City. The eulogy was pronounced by Rev. Mr. BERRY, Pastor of the Dutch Reformed Church in Kinderhook. The remains were buried in the public cemetery, near the village of Kinderhook.

abstract: A Minister of NAPOLEON III., appealed to by two friends, one in favor of the Federalists and the other of the Confederates, is said to have replied "I am for cotton."
lead_paragraph: A Minister of NAPOLEON III., appealed to by two friends, one in favor of the Federalists and the other of the Confederates, is said to have replied "I am for cotton." Imperialism may have ideas but it cannot seriously affect to have strong political sentiments. Political sentiments are the germ of political passions and political parties, and hese things are incompatible with the rule of Bonapartism. A Bourbon Prince professing to honor the representative system may consistently take a side in the controversy which rends the American Commonwealth, and draw a volunteer sword in its behalf. But there would be something palpably absurd in the present occupant of the throne of France, or his partisans, affecting sympathy with Republicanism in danger on the western side of the Atlantic. Material interests, not political rights, are the ends of the Second Empire. Unionism and Secession are all one to it, indifferent and equal in its eyes. Whichever is more likely by its triumph to subserve the immediate profit and gain of France is therefore entitled to its good wishes. "We are for cotton."

abstract: It is clear that we shall never again hear of a Confederate victory in America. Since Bull Run there never has been a Confederate victory, and that was only admitted to be a Federal defeat, because it ...
lead_paragraph: It is clear that we shall never again hear of a Confederate victory in America. Since Bull Run there never has been a Confederate victory, and that was only admitted to be a Federal defeat, because it was supposed to be rather creditable on account of its very decisive and exceptional character. Why should there ever be a Federal defeat? If the competitors at Wimbledon could only put off their English prejudices in favor of fair play and truth, and if they could only select their own markers at the targets, why should there be any doubt about results? If, under these circumstances, Mr. Smith had the nomination of the markers, and Mr. Jones had to shoot against him, it is plain that Mr. Smith would make all the bull's-eyes, and Mr. Jones would make all the misses. This is the case across the broad Western waters. Mr. LINCOLN has all the markers in his own hand. Gen. JACKSON makes a bull's-eye, and up goes the signal which telegraphs to all Europe a shameful miss. Gen. FREMONT makes a solemn shot, which never rings against the target, and from the other end of the range the flag of success waves triumphantly. There were a hundred targets at Wimbledon, and there are almost as many in these closely United States of America; but Mr. LINCOLN and his subordinates hold the markers at their mercy, and the reports of the scores have no relation to the facts of the shooting. We have henceforward just the same trust in the veracity of Gen. POPE as Prince Hal had in that of Sir John Falstaff.

abstract: With the exception of the Times all our contemporaries published the same telegraphic summary of the news brought by the China. The Times has a correspondent at Cork whose duty it appears to be to put a strong Confederate coloring on the news received at Queenstown. Accordingly, the great misleading journal yesterday came out with the great sensation announcement -- "The armies of Gen. MCCLELLAN and of the Confederates under Gen. LEE have come into collision before Richmond." Unobservant persons did not look at the dates, and did not suspect that this portentous intelligence was simply a repetition of what had been known for three or four days. Our evening cotemporaries, falling into the snare, proclaimed another "Federal defeat," and Confederate sympathisers in the city, and the clubs were chuckling over the ignominious and irretrievable disasters which had proved the mean Yankees utterly unable to stand against the chivalry of the South.

abstract: It is believed in Eastern North Carolina that an insurrection has taken place among the several thousand runaway negroes on Roanoke Island. It is said that becoming enraged with the harsh usage experienced at the hands of their new masters, they took advantage of an opportunity presented while the Yankees were at dinner, and seizing the stacked ed arms, fired into them and killed several. The Yankees recovering from the panic into which they were first thrown, retook their guns and slaughtered almost every negro on the Island.

abstract: We have received a full and correct account ofthe raid made by the Harris Cavalry, of New-York, upon the depot at Beaver Dam, Hanover County, on Sunday morning last. From the best information it appears that they left Fredericksburgh on Saturday evening about 4 o'clock, and came some fourteen miles of the way that night. Early on Sunday morning they name on to Beaver Dam, where they arrived about 8 o'clock. Here they found nothing to oppose them, and they at once set to work to destroy, by burning the depot office, water tank, and cord wood. In the depot there were about one hundred and seventy barrels of flour belonging to the army, a few bushels of oats, a case of shoes, a small lot of ammunition and a few arms, some tents, and perhaps a few other things of little value, nearly all of which were consumed.

abstract: The Herald very truly remarks that "the President, the Cabinet and the army appear to be working more cordially together now than at any previous time since the outbreak of the rebellion." We have never given full credence to the rumors of dissension and discord among the several departments of the Government, ...
lead_paragraph: The Herald very truly remarks that "the President, the Cabinet and the army appear to be working more cordially together now than at any previous time since the outbreak of the rebellion." We have never given full credence to the rumors of dissension and discord among the several departments of the Government, which have from time to time been sent out to vex the public ear. But we seem now to be in a fair way of reaching, what certainly we have not hitherto always enjoyed, unity of action and of councils in each branch of the public service. The appointment of Gen. HALLECK to be Commander-in-Chief of our armies, is accepted by the country as a pledge of this unity in the military department, where it is indispensable to success. What his plans for future action are it would of course be idle to speculate. But he is a Soldier, -- thoroughly conversant with the military art, and thoroughly competent to meet the present exigency in military affairs, the enemy will not find it easy to deceive him as to his real intentions, by ostentatious demonstrations intended only to mislead: nor will he be likely to abandon a plan of operations, deliberately adopted, for any light or insufficient cause.

abstract: In reply to our strictures upon the action of the Health Commissioners permitting yellow fever patients to be sent to Ward's Island Hospital, Mayor ...
lead_paragraph: In reply to our strictures upon the action of the Health Commissioners permitting yellow fever patients to be sent to Ward's Island Hospital, Mayor OPDYKE denies that the Board intended to send yellow fever patients to Ward's Island. Of the intentions of that anomalous body we know nothing, but that their resolution, carried out, would have sent yellow fever patients to Ward's Island, is now too apparent for even a Health Commissioner to fail to see. The Health Officer was directed to send cases of yellow fever to such of the hospitals under the charge of the Commissioners of Emigration as he deemed appropriate; but this Commission have but one hospital to which they are allowed to send patients, and that is [???] Island. Necessarily, this action of the Health [???] would consign yellow fewer to that [???] but the Mayor declares this [???] and asserts that the [???] Island are [???] Commissioners of [???]. Now, the [???] in [???].

abstract: THE MALARIA NEAR UNION-SQUARE. We gave place on Saturday to a communication complaining of the impure condition of the atmosphere noticeable ...
lead_paragraph: THE MALARIA NEAR UNION-SQUARE. -- We gave place on Saturday to a communication complaining of the impure condition of the atmosphere noticeable in that district of the City situated to the eastward of Union-square. Two or three other correspondents write on the same subject. One traces the nasty phenomenon to the "great purifying house of the Manhattan Gas Works, wherein the gas is passed through lime, etc.," and asserts that the whole vicinity is constantly poisoned by the fumes. Another says the stench proceeds from the sewers which empty into the East River in the vicinity of Sixth and Eighth streets. These sewers have become filled with mud and other material, until the water flows into the streets through the sewer openings, filling the gutters with a black and filthy liquid, which lies in the hot sun until it evaporates, poisoning the atmosphere and scattering the seeds of disease and death broadcast over the City. There is evidently a combination of causes in the production of the offensive result. Will not the Sanitary Police give the inquiry their instant attention?

abstract: We learn that owing to the interruption of receipts caused by Gov. MOORE's proclamation, sugars have materially advanced. Yesterday 140 hhds. fair sold at 6 1/8c., 200, also fair, at 6 1/4c., and 80 prime at 6 1/2c. There were some transactions at lower prices, but they were for poorer qualities. Two small schooners and two luggers, employed in bringing sugar to the city, were burnt by the Confederate guerrillas in St. James, which deters such craft from continuingthe trade.

abstract: For some time past a great deal has been said and written, both North and South, about the reinforcements that have been, or are about to be, received by MCCLELLAN. But from a source entitled to our confidence, but which we do not feel at liberty to mention, we learn that, up to Friday night, the 18th inst., MCCLELLAN's Army, now at Westover and Berkeley, had, since the battles, received not one man by way of reinforcement. BURNSIDE, with his army, was at that date at Newport's News, evidently awaiting the development of our plans, holding himself in position to reinforce either POPE or MCCLELLAN, as our movement's should render expedient. Had our army pressed MCCLELLAN after the battle of Malvorn Hill. BURNSIDE would have hastened to his relief. On the other hand, should POPE be menaced by a superior force, the BURNSIDE fleet will sail up the Rappahannock or Potomac.
