abstract: The most intense commotion has been excited in the local naval circles by the threatened suppression of the grog ration. It is feared that recruiting will suffer seriously from its stoppage. There is a strong impression that the $1,50 to be given for commutation will be withdrawn after a while. If the 30,000 (or thereabouts) persons who are eligible to draw their grog-ration, were to do so every day, 359 gallons of strong whisky would be used every month, or 4,308 in the year. This would be worth, according to the navy commutation, $448,000. About half the force in the service drink their grog, but the other half receive their commutation $1 60 per month per man. They will still receive $1 50, or 10 cents less. The ration consisted of about two wine glasses full of pure spirits in the day, one at 8 A.M. the other at noon. On special occasions "the main brace" would be "spliced," which means that another wine glass full would be given. In England 80,000 sailors and marines get two glasses of whisky in the day, which is worth, on shore in Great Britain, $13,333, or $4,800,000 in a year. In France 40,000 sailors get wine three times a day, and in the Spainish, Portuguese, Russin, Prussian and Danish navies a pretty strong spirit is served out.

abstract: Application of Emma Baker. - This was a Rabeas corpus for the recovery of Mrs. Baker's child, alleged to be in the possession of one John Y. Baker, her divorced husband. It appearing that the petitioner had been employed as a waiter-girl in a saloon on Broadway; that she had been out with gentlemen under suspicious circumstances, and was, by her own admissions, rather indiscreet, the Court decided she was not a proper party to have the custody of the child, and dismissed the writ. The child in question is only about four years of age.

abstract: "Hotter than ever!" has been the daily cry during the entire week just closed. For the last few days the sun has had his own unclouded way, without any impertinent interference of refreshing showers to moderate the intensity of his reign, it has been as much as mortals could do to sit still and endure. Active occupation has been a penance, evaded and avoided as much as possible, and by every one who was able. Motion has been a burden, and excitement a positive punishment.

abstract: A great Union mass meeting is in progress tonight, in Monument-square. Gov. BRADFORD is Chairman, and Gen. WOOL and Staff are on the stand, which is beautifully illuminated, and bears the inscription, "Our country -- our fathers formed it -- we'll sustain it." The square is densely packed, and the Union Leagues are marching, with innumerable flags and transparencies, while bonfires and fireworks are lighting up the square. Gov. BRADFORD's speech was enthusiastically received. His allusion to the course of President LINCOLN, and commendation of his patriotism, were loudly cheered.

abstract: When Gen. POPE advertises his absentees it would probably suggest a nicer compliance with the graces of life, if he omit the offer of five cents reward for their recapture. Capt. HARRISON, who has been pursued with this particular courtesy, writes a card to disclaim his title to it. He is no runaway -- not he. He is simply an officer who deposited his resignation in improper hands, and without waiting to know of its acceptance, took an informal, or possibly French leave, of his command. But the simple fact of such irregularity is hardly a fair occasion for establishing a hue and cry after the fugitive, and still less of offering so paltry a compensation as a half-dime for his return. The service of the country will be promoted if all officers who are worth to their country no more than that inconspicuous sum, are permitted to go home in peace and quietness.

abstract: To GEN. KING: General I have the honor to report that in obedience to your orders, I left Fredericksburgh at 4 o'cock P.M., the 22d inst, with .....
lead_paragraph: To GEN. KING: General -- I have the honor to report that in obedience to your orders, I left Fredericksburgh at 4 o'cock P.M., the 22d inst, with detachmentsof the Harris Light Cavalry (160), Third Indiana Cavalry (130) and Fourteenth Brooklyn, N.Y.S.M. (100), in all 390 men -- crossed the Massaponix River at 8 P.M., and bivouacked four miles the other side, leaving the Brooklyn Fourteenth to guard the ford and roads leading from Bowling Green and New-Market. At 2 o'clock, A.M., of the 23d, I commenced a rapid march for the rebel camp, supposed to be at Carmel Church. At daybreak I saw the church but no camp, the rebels having crossed the North Anna River a few days before. A woman having informed me that a scouting party came along at 7 A.M. daily to the church, I pieced in ambush Capt. ALLAN M. SEYMOUR with his company. He had just placed his men in position, when his alluring [???] was suddenly attacked by nine or ten men, supported by some filty others. Capt. SEYMOUR immediately charged, forcing the advance back upon their supports. I went to his assistance with a small force, leaving Major CHAPMAN and DAVIES to guard the cross roads at the church. The enemy was whipped and driven into the river. Lieut. KIMBALL crossed and soon returned, reporting that the camp was in sight and the enemy in column of platoons in the road, with skirmishers covering several hundred yards in front.

abstract: Editorial sees signs of activity with Army of Virginia since Pope took over
snippet: Editorial sees signs of activity with Army of Virginia since Pope took over
lead_paragraph: -- Signs of activity are making themselves manifest in that sluggish region formerly known as The Department of the Rappahannock, which lead us to hope much for the future. Since entering on his new command, Gen. POPE hasscarcely had time to make any decisive demonstration in that quarter, but he has been by no means idle. A state of thing entirely different from that which existed under the old dynasty has been inaugurated. The prominent rebel sympathizers, in the vicinity of Fredericksburgh, have been seized and placed beyond the power of doing further mischief. The cavalry has been released from its former service of simply guarding the rebel property of the neighborhood, and applied to the use for which cavalry is intended. Two detachments have already penetrated far down into the turbulent heart of disloyal Virginia, spying out the land, and awakening the enemy to the fact that they have an agile foe to contend with, and cannot occupy themselves wholly with offensive operations.

abstract: Editorial on dangers of military use of telegraph in Civil War; Editorial on dangers of military use of telegraph
snippet: Editorial on dangers of military use of telegraph in Civil War; Editorial on dangers of military use of telegraph
lead_paragraph: OF CAUTION. -- The telegraph is of infinite service in transmitting military orders, but it is subject to some most serious disadvantages. One is, that it offers no means of verifying on the instant the genuineness of its message. If a rebel agent, for example, could get control of an office between Washington and MCCLELLAN's headquarters, he could send any order he might choose in the name of the President to Gen. McCLELLAN, and the latter could not detect the imposition until, perhaps, it might be too late. Even if he were to telegraph for further information to Washington, the rebel agent, being on the watch, could intercept the message and answer it.

abstract: The pleasant little village of Kinderhook, on the far up Hudson, long since made famous as the birthplace and residence of MARTIN VAN BUREN, the ...
lead_paragraph: The pleasant little village of Kinderhook, on the far up Hudson, long since made famous as the birthplace and residence of MARTIN VAN BUREN, the boon-companion, friend, counselor and successor in office of ANDREW JACKSON, yesterday paid her last earthly honors to her favorite son. While in other portions of the country the thousands of flags, waving at half-mast, bespoke the sorrow of the nation at the loss of an Ex-President, in the village of Kinderhook the emblems of mourning were of a more heartfelt character, and betokened a deeper sorrow at the loss of an old neighbor, a kind friend, and an esteemed citizen. Business was entirely suspended in the village, the stores were all closed, and many of them, as well as the principal hotel of the place, were draped in mourning. The people of the surrounding country appeared to have turned out en masse to the funeral, and the number of old men to be seen among them was truly a marvel. It would hardly seem that the Ex-President, octogenarian though he was, outlived a majority of the friends of his boyhood.

abstract: The arrival at this port of the United States iron-clad gunboat Naugatuck was briefly announced in the ship-news columns a few days since, and escaped general notice.
lead_paragraph: The arrival at this port of the United States iron-clad gunboat Naugatuck was briefly announced in the ship-news columns a few days since, and escaped general notice. As she did not go to the Navy-yard rumors about her loss were very rife over there, and came near getting into print. Meantime she was quietly anchored near the Hoboken shore, waiting orders to "dock," which were received on Sunday.

abstract: -- The latest advices indicatethe shipment of large quantities of Cotton from India for the English market. If the English Cotton interest is once satisfied, as they must begin to be by this time, that the war in America will not end until the rebellion is crushed, they will turn their attention with earnestness to procuring Cotton from elsewhere. And if they succeed in doing this, the principal motive for intervention will disappear. If the late intelligence from India prove to be true, it will have, therefore, an important influence on the relations of England to this country, and on the fortunes of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: -- The latest advices indicatethe shipment of large quantities of Cotton from India for the English market. If the English Cotton interest is once satisfied, as they must begin to be by this time, that the war in America will not end until the rebellion is crushed, they will turn their attention with earnestness to procuring Cotton from elsewhere. And if they succeed in doing this, the principal motive for intervention will disappear. If the late intelligence from India prove to be true, it will have, therefore, an important influence on the relations of England to this country, and on the fortunes of the rebellion.

abstract: There was published in the TIMES, a few days ago, a call for some charitable organization to supply soldiers losing limbs in battle, with artificial substitutes. Charity in periods like these is obliged to be versatile. There is no end to demands for help in building up new armies, and in taking care of the damaged and ruined fragments of old ones; but it strikes us forcibly that this specialty of supplying the maimed volunteer with the means of locomotion and labor is one which has permanent claims upon the attention of the beneficent. To resupply these helpless men with the implements for helping themselves is almost to share the prerogatives of the Creator. We trust steps will be taken at once to give this movement energy and consistency.

abstract: It is reported from Fortress Monroe that a large rebel force is being concentrated on the line of the James River, above the junction of the Appomattox and the James, sent from Richmond by way of Petersburgh.
lead_paragraph: It is reported from Fortress Monroe that a large rebel force is being concentrated on the line of the James River, above the junction of the Appomattox and the James, sent from Richmond by way of Petersburgh. This force, it is believed, already numbers from fifty to seventy thousand men, and it is asserted that Stonewall JACKSON is in command, notwithstanding the stories of his threatening Gen. POPE's advance at Gordonsville. It is also surmised that an attack will soon be made on Suffolk by the rebels.

abstract: The following facts, derived from unquestionable authority, may serve to illustrate the danger incurred by Federal officers who seek to entice or corrupt the slaves of our people. One of our citizens having missed a valuable slave woman, made inquiry for her, and ascertained that she was in the service of an officer of one of the Federal regiments. He proceeded to the boarding-house of the officer, and there finding the woman, asked if she was not ready to go home. The woman replied that she was, but that the Federal officer, in whose service she was, would not permit her. The citizen then saw the officer, and received from him assurance that the woman would be sent to him. This promise was not kept, and our citizen being disgusted with the double-dealing and bad faith of the officer, laid his complaint before Lieut. WEITZEL, who manifested great indignation against the officer, and requested the citizen to see Gen. BUTLER. The wife of our citizen undertook the mission to Gen. BUTLER, and after some difficulty, succeeded in obtaining an interview with him. Gen. BUTLER immediately took the matter in hand, and sent a guard to the boarding-house where the slave was harbored, had the officer who so harbored her arrested and sent to jail, and on the interference of a Chaplain of one of the Federal regiments against the arrest of the woman, had his Reverendship also arrested and placed in confinement. The girl was sent home to her master, with the request that she should not be cruelly punished. This course on the part of the General commanding is calculated to put a stop to an abuse which must produce quite as much trouble to the Federal authorities as to our own citizens. We trust it will be followed up in all similar cases of intermeddling with our slaves.

abstract: At the evening sitting of the House of Commons, on the 15th inst., Mr. W.E. FORSTER gave notice of his intention to move an amendment on Mr. LINDSAY's forthcoming resolution in favor of the recognition of the Confederate States. Mr. LINDSAY will move, on Friday: "That, in the opinion of this House, the States which have seceded from the Union of the Republic of the United States have so long maintained themselves under a separate and established Government, and have given such proof of their ability to support their independence, that the propriety of recognizing these States as an independent nation is worthy of the serious and immediate attention of Her Majesty's Government, and that this House will cordially support Her Majesty in endeavoring, in concert with foreign Powers, by mediation or otherwise, to bring to a termination the existing contest in America." On the other hand, the member for Bradford will ask the House to pledge itself to support the Government in their present policy of non-intervention.
lead_paragraph: At the evening sitting of the House of Commons, on the 15th inst., Mr. W.E. On the other hand, the member for Bradford will ask the House to pledge itself to support the Government in their present policy of non-intervention.

lead_paragraph: The pleasant little village of Kinderhook, on the far up Hudson, long since made famous as the birthplace and residence of MARTIN VAN BUREN, the boon-companion, friend, counselor and successor in office of ANDREW JACKSON, yesterday paid her last earthly honors to her favorite son. While in other portions of the country the thousands of flags, waving at half-mast, bespoke the sorrow of the nation at the loss of an Ex-President, in the village of Kinderhook the emblems of mourning were of a more heartfelt character, and betokened a deeper sorrow at the loss of an old neighbor, a kind friend, and an esteemed citizen. Business was entirely suspended in the village, the stores were all closed, and many of them, as well as the principal hotel of the place, were draped in mourning. The people of the surrounding country appeared to have turned out en masse to the funeral, and the number of old men to be seen among them was truly a marvel. It would hardly seem that the Ex-President, octogenarian though he was, outlived a majority of the friends of his boyhood.

abstract: A correspondent asks an explanation of the statement made by Dr. GUNN before the Commissioners of Health at their last meeting, and reported in the NEW-YORK TIMES of Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent asks an explanation of the statement made by Dr. GUNN before the Commissioners of Health at their last meeting, and reported in the NEW-YORK TIMES of Saturday. We frankly confessthat we do not understand it. We hope the Health Officer has been incorrectly reported. We are utterly unable to reconcile the statement purporting to have been made by him, with frequent personal assurances of his understanding of the law of 1859, by which our people have been persuaded the Health Officer would be guided, should the emergency ever arise requiring his action. If our correspondent has read the Gazette leader of last Wednesday, he will see by the statement of Dr. GUNN that we were correct in our surmises of the intent and meaning of the resolution of the Commissioners of Health, which has excited so much severe animadversion in New-York -- by which, we said truly, that the public and the Emigration Board had been misted. We have correctly exposed the strategy of Mayor OPDYKE. He never intended that yellow-fever patients should be sent to Ward's Island; but having conferred with Dr. GUNN, and having agreed with him in regard to the concealed interpretation of the resolution, that resolution was made public, and everybody supposed, as did the Commissioners of Emigration, that nothing short of a transfer of the Quarantine to Ward's Island was intended; whereas it was the reopening of the "Quarantine Hospital and five others on Staten Island," for yellow fever patients, that was to be the consequence of the resolution, in case the desired effect was not produced upon the Commissioners of Emigration. While we cannot concur with Dr. GUNN in the line of argument he has seen fit to adopt, we congratulate him that the action of the Commissioners of Emigration, in providing the floating hospital, has relieved him from the necessity of a practical application of it. Our people have, for three year past, flattered themselves that these hospitals were forever closed against [???] diseases. Let us endeavor to comprehend the argument which the Health Officer offers for the restoration of their old uses and abuses.

abstract: Editorial on civil engineers contributions to war effort; urges Government make more use of their talents; Editorial on current scene and outlook; Editorial on civil engineers contributions to war effort; urges Government make more use of their talents
snippet: Editorial on civil engineers contributions to war effort; urges Government make more use of their talents; Editorial on current scene and outlook; Editorial on civil engineers contributions to war effort; urges Government make more use of their ta...
lead_paragraph: Without discussing the profound question of a cotemporary -- is the practice of civil engineering compatible with military genius? -- we would call public attention to the immense service rendered by civilians, in inventing and improving the material of war; a kind of aid which would vastly increase if it was more widely understood and encouraged, and if there could be more harmony between the civil and Governmental branches of the profession. A glance at the leading war facts and names, here and in England, will show the importance of affording greater facilities for experiment, research and fair trial to civil engineers, rather than to confine these vital means of improvement to bureaus and departments.

abstract: MOORE, one of our youngest and most promising artists, has on exhibition at SNEDICOR'S Gallery' near Ninth-street and Broadway, a large landscape recently completed, representing a phase of Catskil scenery not often attempted.
lead_paragraph: MOORE, one of our youngest and most promising artists, has on exhibition at SNEDICOR's Gallery' near Ninth-street and Broadway, a large landscape recently completed, representing a phase of Catskil scenery not often attempted. It is a bold and strikingpicture, the details being wrought out with rare patience and fidelity. The sky is especially good. Such faithful study as this picture exhibits must insure rapid progress and ultimate success.

abstract: POLICY. -- As completing the documentary history of the President's patriotic negotiations with the representatives of the Border States, we give in another column a letter of Hon. J.C. HENDERSON, United States Senator from Missouri. It is evident that Mr. HENDERSON accepts Mr. LINCOLN's programme in its entirety, so far as personal convictions go, but is indisposed to think the people of Missouri quite prepared to go as far and as promptly as himself. He is satisfied, however, that a just appreciation of the selfishness which has actuated the Confederate States in their relations with the Border States, begins to have currency in Missouri, and will tend to give a new and salutary direction to public opinion. A result of this eye-opening will be a willingness to entertain the Presidential policy. Mr. HENDERSON's letter is an able paper, and will be read with interest.
lead_paragraph: POLICY. -- As completing the documentary history of the President's patriotic negotiations with the representatives of the Border States, we give in another column a letter of Hon. J.C. HENDERSON, United States Senator from Missouri. It is evident that Mr. HENDERSON accepts Mr. LINCOLN's programme in its entirety, so far as personal convictions go, but is indisposed to think the people of Missouri quite prepared to go as far and as promptly as himself. He is satisfied, however, that a just appreciation of the selfishness which has actuated the Confederate States in their relations with the Border States, begins to have currency in Missouri, and will tend to give a new and salutary direction to public opinion. A result of this eye-opening will be a willingness to entertain the Presidential policy. Mr. HENDERSON's letter is an able paper, and will be read with interest.

abstract: Lieut. ROBERTSON, of the Fourteenth Maine Regiment, was dishonorably discharged from service by Maj.-Gen. BUTLER, and sent before Judge BELL, on a charge of having swindled a number of soldiers who had been discharged on account of disability and sickness. It appeals that the Ex-Lieutenant had received certain sums of money from said soldiers, on the promise that he would procure them speedy passages by sea to their homes, and that he gobbled up the money, but did not perform his part of the contract. E.A. ALLEN, one of the witnesses in the case, was only a day or two ago sent to the Parish Prison two months, for the same offence, and it was through his "peaching" that the rascality of ROBERTSON leaked out. The Judge sent the Ex-Lieutenant to the Parish Prison for two months.

abstract: It is believed in Eastern North Carolina that an insurrection has taken place among the several thousand runaway negroes on Roanoke Island. It is said that becoming enraged with the harsh usage experienced at the hands of their new masters, they took advantage of an opportunity presented while the Yankees were at dinner, and seizing the stacked ed arms, fired into them and killed several. The Yankees recovering from the panic into which they were first thrown, retook their guns and slaughtered almost every negro on the Island.

abstract: The County Commissioners of Lehigh have appropriated $10,000 and Northampton $30,000, for the volunteer bounty. The Norristown citizens subscribed $30,000 as a loan to the county, if legalized by the State Legislature, otherwise to be considered as a gift for giving bounty to volunteers. The County Commisioners are all Democrats, and refused to receive the money or offer any bounty.

abstract: As many idle stories have been going the round of the papers relative to Gen. BEAUREGARD's where about, and the cause of his absence from the army, we think it well to state that he is at present with his family at Bladon Springs, South Alabama. It will be recollected that Gen. BEAUREGARD look the field in the Southwest when our fortunes in that quarter were at their darkest period. In the active campaign which ensued, and in the perrect organization of the immense army at Corinth, he performed labors which seriously affected his health, and rendered a period of rest and recuperation absolutely necessary. That he might enjoy the muca needed rest, he procured a relief from his command for a few months.

abstract: We are happy to know that the opposition displayed by our wealthy citizens toward the restoration of the flag is gradually subsiding, and that individual examples are displaying themselves of genuine patriotism among a class not heretofore distinguished for zeal in the Union cause. We are led to make these remarks in announcing the fact, that ALFRED PENN, President of the Union Bank, has taken the oath of allegiance, and has ranged himself beside the loyal citizens of New-Orleans. We have no doubt his patriotic example will soon be followed by all the capitalists and moneyed men of New-Orleans.

abstract: SOMETHING FOR THOSE WHO LINGER AT HOME.  A very spirited letter from one of the Children's Aid Society boys, gives an idea of what our brave men have to contend with in an unequal contest with disunion.
lead_paragraph: SOMETHING FOR THOSE WHO LINGER AT HOME. -- A very spirited letter from one of the Children's Aid Society boys, gives an idea of what our brave men have to contend with in an unequal contest with disunion. He says the news that drafting is likely to stir up the slumbering patriotism of the home [???] is highly welcomed in the camps -- for those already there are groaning beneath the existing necessity for inaction while awaiting reinforcements. He say fifty thousand good, determined men, with a heart in them such as the early volunteers brought to the conflict, would make short work of the heart of rebellion. "'Tis useless," he write "to contend that southerners won't fight, for they will; and in our last hotly contested battle before Richmond, they marched up in solid columns to within six fee of the cannon's mouth, all the while that grapeshot and canister were mowing them down by companies. Their force was so overwhelming that in spite of this they kept an unbroken front, one company always ready to take another's place, [???] our infantry, with one of their enthusiastic Union [???], broke their files by a charge of the bayonet thus finishing the contest. The Southerners [???] themselves more like fiends than human beings whether whisky was the cause or not. It is, however, a noticeable fact that their canteens were [???] fired with gunpowder whisky. To this they resort for courage and strength to whip the -- Yankees. A poisoned cause, truly."

abstract: The crumbs of news received yesterday from Mexico contain matter of dubious import. The French, it seems, are left to recruit and strengthen themselves at leisure in Orizaba.
lead_paragraph: The crumbs of news received yesterday from Mexico contain matter of dubious import. The French, it seems, are left to recruit and strengthen themselves at leisure in Orizaba. The Mexican Generals, as was to be expected, celebrated their recent victory by a battle royal among themselves; and, in attending to this little bit of private, business, have had no time to spend upon the invaders and enemies of the country. Even the guerrillas, who have hitherto rendered intercourse between Vera Cruz and the French encampments extremely difficult, have deserted the routes, leaving free passage for the transportation trains and reinforcements, so that all the advantages of the recent success at Puebla have been wasted.
headline: {'main': 'The Situation in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Situation in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The return match between the first eleven of the New-York Club and sixteen Americans from various Cricket and Base Ball Clubs, took place yesterday on the New-York Club ground, Hoboken. The NewYork Eleven had strengthened themselves by the addition of SADLER and HAMMOND, in addition to CROSSLEY, their ground keeper thus bringing three professional cricketers against the Americans, in addition ...
lead_paragraph: The return match between the first eleven of the New-York Club and sixteen Americans from various Cricket and Base Ball Clubs, took place yesterday on the New-York Club ground, Hoboken. The New-York Eleven had strengthened themselves by the addition of SADLER and HAMMOND, in addition to CROSSLEY, their ground keeper -- thus bringing three professional cricketers against the Americans, in addition to the well-known first-rate cricketers of so many years standing -- such as Hudson, Higham, Wilby, Marsh, Sharp and Balliere, and Steward, the new "Point," and Scudder. The Americans had insisted that HARRY WRIGHT, of the St. George's Club, (who has been an American since he was twelve month's old,) should be allowed them, and expected that Dr. ANDREWS, and Messrs. CREIGHTON and BRAINARD would be on hand, all of whom are fine bowlers; but the latter three gentlemen were not on hand, and the game was played by only thirteen Americans at the bat, and substitutes in the field. It is not, therefore, very surprising that the English came off the victors.

abstract: The prize steamer Tubal Cain, of Nassau, Acting-Master Joasson, commanding, arrived yesterday morning, in eight days from Nassau, N.P. She was boarded on the 24th inst., in lat. 32 , lon. 78  14', by the United States gunboat Octorara.
lead_paragraph: The prize steamer Tubal Cain, of Nassau, Acting-Master JOHNSON, commanding, arrived yesterday morning, in eight days from Nassau, N.P. She was boarded on the 24th inst., in lat. 32, lon. 78 14, by the United States gunboat Octorara. Upon examining her papers she was seized as a prize, as they established the fact that she was one of the numerous steamers at Nassau, loaded with arms and ammunition, which have been endeavoring to run the blockade. She is 194 tons, iron built, 50-horse power; was built at Paisley, and is nine years old. Vessel and cargo are valued at $250,000. Her cargo consists of small arms, saltpetre, salt, soldiers' buttons, shells, and various other goods suitable for the Southern market.

abstract: Editorial on Negro "contrabands" that have congregated in Washington, DC
snippet: Editorial on Negro "contrabands" that have congregated in Washington, DC
lead_paragraph: The world has the right to expect that a great nation shall show itself generous to misfortune. In the tremendous rebellion which has arisen between two sections of our country, the rights of an unfortunate class of persons have been especially at issue. These people -- loyal, of course, in their feelings, and inclined to aid our cause, as well as eager for liberty -- have everywhere entered our lines and intrusted themselves to the honor of the Government. Some have labored in the camps; some have been servants of officers; others have merely wailed until occupation could be assigned them, or they have tilled the ground under the protection of our armies. No complaint has yet been made either of their industry or their faithfulness to the National cause. It would be a shame beyond any on the catalogue of national basenesses if any of these poor creatures, through our reverses, should be abandoned to their ancient masters. It would be a living death to them. Torture and floggings and punishment, and possibly execution under horrible agonies, would be their fate. They are the nation's freedmen -- intrusted to the nation's honor. We trust if any of the islands on the South Carolina coast are obliged to be abandoned by our forces that the negroes will all be removed from the reach of their cruel owners. We are sure that the humanity of Gen. SAXTON or Gen. HUNTER will lead them without fail to provide for this.

abstract: It must be confessed that, as far as my observations go, since day before yesterday, the military public of this vicinity shows remarkable indifference upon the subject of the departure of the Commander-in-Chief for other spheres of activity.
lead_paragraph: It must be confessed that, as far as my observations go, since day before yesterday, the military public of this vicinity shows remarkable indifference upon the subject of the departure of the Commander-in-Chief for other spheres of activity. You will hear very frequently such questions as "Where is he going?" "What in the deuce does it mean?" referring to the suddenness of his going, and similar expressions of sheer curiosity; but symptoms of any real regret are entirely wanting, except in the immediate surroundings of Gen. HALLECK.

abstract: Editorial on anti-Union demonstrations in England; Editorial on condition of Confederate Navy; Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Editorial on anti-Union demonstrations in England; Editorial on condition of Confederate Navy; Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: Two events have occurred recently in England, which are significant of the state of public feeling toward America. On the annual Commemoration Day of the Founders of Oxford, the students are in the habit, before the usual address is delivered, of cheering and hissing the different names of popular or odious public men as they are proposed. The name of GARIBALDI had been cheered, and that of NAPOLEON both cheered and hissed, when some one shouted out the name of "JEFFERSON DAVIS;" it was received with tumultuous and unanimous applause. "President LINCOLN" was proposed, and it was greeted with hisses and groans.

abstract: Article on increased counterfeiting of paper currency
snippet: Article on increased counterfeiting of paper currency
lead_paragraph: There are very few persons, if any, in the United States, who can truthfully declare their ability to detect at a glance any fraudulent paper money. So numerous are our Banks, and so varied the tricks of the counterfeiter, that even professional detectors of bad bills, brokers, bank tellers and others in the constant habit of handling large sums of money, are frequently imposed upon. Our "Counterfeit Detectors" have, within the last few years, increased in size, until their proportions rival our Family Bibles, and generally compel much more studious perusal. If a man offers a bill in payment for anything, it is a signal for the production of the inevitable volume. The merchant wades through the long list of "altered," "counterfeit," "spurious," "old plate," "broken bank," and a hundred other frauds, and if he fails to find a description of the proffered bill, concludes that it is good. Then if change is given, the purchaser must borrow the book and go through the same tedious process, in his turn to prevent being imposed upon. So rapidly are these frauds in paper money produced, that in all our large cities the aid of the police and the telegraph is called into requisition to protect the merchant. Even the types and the printing-press, the police and the telegraph, are frequently too late for the shrewd counterfeiter, and in defiance of them all, the City is often flooded with a worthless issue before citizens can be put upon their guard. In spite of all precautions, every merchant has his pile of counterfeit money, and his hourly [???] of having it increased. Our wives and daughters accept a bank-note from a stranger with fear and trembling, and the memories of our servants are taxed to recollect who gave them that last "bad bill." The poorer people are, the less likely are they to be able to avoid taking counterfeit money [???] while the poorest apple-woman is as good a judge, as the best, of all the coins; it is only a privileged class who can rely to any extent upon their judgment of the genuineness of our paper currency.

abstract: It is not to destroy anybody's faith in the current paper money -- now that paper is the only currency which we have -- that we publish an article on counterfeiting this morning. We give it so as to furnish information to the public, and put them, as well as the police, on their guard, and also to furnish some hints to banking institutions, bank-note engravers, and the authorities. The practice of counterfeiting has grown enormously within the last few years; and now that the use of bills of all denominations, from one cent to one thousand dollars, has become universal in business, it is likely to increase still faster. The field is great, and the temptations enormous.

abstract: Major-Gen. BURNSIDE being in New-York on a temporary visit in the interests of the Government was identified by several persons as he drove up to the Post-office yesterday about 1 o'clock, and imme- ...
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. BURNSIDE being in New-York on a temporary visit in the interests of the Government was identified by several persons as he drove up to the Post-office yesterday about 1 o'clock, and immediately a large crowd gathered to see the hero of Roanoke and Newbern. By the time he had pro cured his letters and had entered his carriage to drive away, Nassau-street was so blocked up by the people that his driver found it impossible to move. Hoping to evade the people, he entered the marble building opposite; but the crowd only increased in density as the magic word "BURNSIDE" passed up and down the street. The new porch of the Post-office, fronting Nassau-street was covered with the clerks, who emerged by the windows of that establishment, and whose novel position gazing into the windows of the building opposite only tended to excite public curiosity, and to increase the throng in the street. Finding there was no escape, the brave General did what he never did before -- capitulated, and made his appearance on the porch over the main entrance in company with two or three citizens. His appearance was the signal for a shout of welcome which rang through the crowded street. Removing his hat, and with his face lighted up by that hopeful smile so characteristic of the General, he said:

abstract: We have been visited by a recently paroled Union prisoner, (Mr. CHAS, B. DENNY, Hospital Steward, Second Fire Zouaves, SICKLES' Brigade,) who has given us a statement of his experience while in the hands of the rebels.
lead_paragraph: We have been visited by a recently paroled Union prisoner, (Mr. CHAS. B. DENNY, Hospital Steward, Second Fire Zouaves, SICKLES' Brigade,) who has given us a statement of his experience while in the hands of the rebels. He was detailed by Dr. SIN, Medical Director of HOOKE's Division, to remain in the rear of our retreating army and assist Dr. JOHN J. MCGOWAN, Surgeon of the Second Regiment Excelsior Brigade, in ministering to the wants of our brave soldiers who were unable to march, owing to various diseases contracted in the swamps before Richmond.

abstract: -Among the excerptsfrom the Richmond Press which we gave yesterday, was a paragraph to the effect that "twenty-two pieces of artillery, part of the eighty pieces taken by the English from the Russians at the battle of Inkerman, and presented to the Confederacy by British merchants, brought over in the Nashville, had just arrived at Macon;" and that "thirty-eight pieces more were expected at the same place." This is the first mention we have seen of this liberal donation of our Britishcousins to the rebels of the South. It is certainly a remarkable evidence of practical sympathy that the national trophies of England should be disposed of in this way. We suppose, however, they must have been sold by the British Government for old iron, and bought up dirt cheap by these British merchants. But that, though a matter of some importance to the merchants, is of no moment to us, and of still less to the rebels. The eighty pieces will do service in slaughtering our citizens, in destroying our Union and our liberties, and in strengthening the Confederacy whose cornerstone is Slavery. And if these things are effected, the British merchants will be amply rewarded for their donation. If the malign spirit of John Bull could only be crammed into one of them, and blown to -- where he blew the unfortunate Sepoys to, they would serve a better end then any they are likely to be used for.

abstract: The rebel  navy, which a month ago seemed to be clean snuffed out, is again giving signs of life. The vessels are few in number, but quite formidable.
lead_paragraph: navy, which a month ago seemed to be clean snuffed out, is again giving signs of life. The vessels are few in number, but quite formidable. The iron-clad Arkansas, after its recent exploit near Vicksburgh, is, it is said, again ready to take the field, or at least the river. We have neither ship nor ram in the Mississippi that can cope with it. It is feared by some that, after doing further damage to our fleet at Vicksburgh, it may pass down to New-Orleans, and destroy the few wooden ships we have in front of that city, while the rebels in the city will assail the half-dozenregiments under General BUTLER; and thus New-Orleans will again fall into rebel hands. PORTER's mortar-fleet has now left the river; and our effective naval force upon it is small. But still, if the rebels attempt any such thing as this, they will probably find difficulties upon which they have not counted. We should feel greater security, however, for New-Orleans, if we had one or two of our iron-clad gunboats in front of the city, ready to engage the Arkansas if she make any such audacious stroke. Could not the Navy Department send just one as soon as possible?

abstract: A WARNING TO RAILROAD CONDUCTORS. EDWARD LYNCH, a Conductor in the employ of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, was convicted before Justice PERRY yesterday of committing an assault and battery upon RICHARD HARGET, a colored man, and fined $10, or in lieu thereof, to be imprisoned in the County Jail ten days.
lead_paragraph: A WARNING TO RAILROAD CONDUCTORS. -- EDWARD LYNCH, a Conductor in the employ of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, was convicted before Justice PERRY yesterday of committing an assault and battery upon RICHARD HARGET, a colored man, and fined $10, or in lieu thereof, to be imprisoned in the County Jail ten days. The circumstances of the case are as follows: Complainant entered a Court-st. car to ride to the ferry, and having no change tendered the defendant a $1 bill from which to take his fare. The Conductor refused to change the bill, and ordered defendant to leave the car. Not moving quickly enough to suit the conductor, that official facilitated the egress of defendant by a shove, a blow and a kick, landing him in the street while the car was in motion. The Justice, in passing sentence, took the opportunity to say that he had himself observed a great deal of brutality on the part of conductors towards passengers, and intimated that while justified in removing a passenger for nonpayment of fare, no unnecessary violence should be used. In this case, he said, the complainant had been pushed to the street while the car was in motion, and if no blow had been struck, the forcing of a man from a car while in motion was of itself an assault and battery.

abstract: -- To-morrow is the day fixed for the new tariff to come into operation. In the Tax bill, as it passed through Congress, the 1st of August was also named as the day for that measure to take effect; but subsequently a joint resolution authorizing Secretary CHASE to postpone the time was passed; and of this authority the Secretary availed himself by appointing Sept. 1 as the era of the new taxation. The interval will be crowded with the business of selecting the subordinate officers, preparing books, blanks, and stamps, and the thousand and one preliminaries to a methodical opening of business.

abstract: -- The President yesterday gave practical effect to the recent act of Congress to establish and equalize the grade of line officers of the navy, by commissioning a number of naval captains to be Rear-Admirals on the Retired and Active lists. The nine placed on the Retired list are sailors, all of whom have for fifty years or more illustrated the glory of the Stars and Stripes on sea; while the four Rear-Admirals named on the Active list --FOOTS, DUPONT, FARRAGUT and GOLDSBOROUGH -- are those who have during the present war done most signal service in that arm of the National defence, which is acknowledged to have won three-fourths of all our victories.
lead_paragraph: -- The President yesterday gave practical effect to the recent act of Congress to establish and equalize the grade of line officers of the navy, by commissioning a number of naval captains to be Rear-Admirals on the Retired and Active lists. abstract: The officers detailed for recruiting at the United States Mustering Office, in White-street, are having a busy time of it. Yesterday, squads of volunteers were rushed upon them with a rapidity that put their powers of inspection and enrollment to a pretty severe test. From all the places around town, where enterprising Captains and Lieutenants hang out their banners to attract the attention of those disposed to volunteer, a steady stream of men came in from early in the morning until quite late in the afternoon. There has not been anything like so much activity and enthusiasm displayed, nor so much determination to at once supply the President's requisition, for which New-York is responsible, since the commencement of this second uprising of the North.

abstract: -- The Vicksburgh correspondent of the St. Louis Republican writes: "I mentioned a few days ago that it was rumored that BRECKENRIDGE was trying to get to Europe vid Mexico. The rumor originated in Vicksburgh, was brought over by a deserter, and was not altogether without foundation. It seems that this follower of BURR, his "illustrious predecessor," went to visit his friend, the princely KEEN RICHARDS, near Milliken's Bend, at whose house he was taken unwell. His friends in Vicksburgh, not knowing where he was, but thinking he would be sharp enough to "draw out" at the right moment, began to mistrust that he had left them for safer climes. But not so. While he was yet unwell, NIM's Massachusetts Battery made an excursion up the river as far as Milliken's Bend, and as they stopped near RICHARDS', the Ex-Vice-President got alarmed, and departed for other quarters in a family carnage, with the curtains down. As he was riding along, several of the artillerymen unwittingly passed the carriage on the road. I would like to know how many pulsations a minute the heart of the gallant General made during that [???] meeting."
lead_paragraph: -- The Vicksburgh correspondent of the St. Louis Republican writes: "I mentioned a few days ago that it was rumored that BRECKENRIDGE was trying to get to Europe vid Mexico. His friends in Vicksburgh, not knowing where he was, but thinking he would be sharp enough to "draw out" at the right moment, began to mistrust that he had left them for safer climes. But not so. While he was yet unwell, NIM's Massachusetts Battery made an excursion up the river as far as Milliken's Bend, and as they stopped near RICHARDS', the Ex-Vice-President got alarmed, and departed for other quarters in a family carnage, with the curtains down. As he was riding along, several of the artillerymen unwittingly passed the carriage on the road. I would like to know how many pulsations a minute the heart of the gallant General made during that [???] meeting."

abstract: Editorial on report of scurvy in Army of Potomac and on measures being taken to send it fresh vegetables and dried fruit
snippet: Editorial on report of scurvy in Army of Potomac and on measures being taken to send it fresh vegetables and dried fruit
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac begins to suffer somewhat from scurvy. This is mainly due to the sameness of its food, not to any defect in its quality or quantity. It is a recognized fact that uniformity of diet kept up for a sufficient period, (especially if coupled with overwork, or anything that reduces the vital powers,) tends to produce this insidious and destructive disease. It is feared that a considerable portion of the army may already be more or less tainted with it, and that many who are now only a little ailing and still fit for duty will soon be on the sick list, unless steps be promptly taken for their relief.

abstract: The country receives with intense satisfaction the assurances that reach it from every quarter, that the war is at last to be prosecuted with vigor and determination.
lead_paragraph: The country receives with intense satisfaction the assurances that reach it from every quarter, that the war is at last to be prosecuted with vigor and determination. Possibly these declarations command somewhat less of confidence than similar assurances did some months ago, for they have been made to do duty too often within the last year to be quite as good as new. The people cannot forget that every new General has advertised the world that, with his accession to office, the era of imbecility had passed away: nor is it surprising that the notice should command somewhat less of confidence with every fresh instance of its repetition. Still, the country is steadily, though slowly, bringing itself up to the task of confiding in the purpose of the Government to prosecute the war to a speedy and successful end. The appointment of a skillful and experienced Soldier to command the army, has done more than any other circumstance to lift the cloud of gloom that was rapidly settling down upon the public mind; for it gives us reason to hope that the Government sees at last the weak point in its contest with the rebellion, and that it has the courageous self-distrust to apply the remedy. It is from no lack of money or men; it is not from lack of courage or of good conduct in the field; it is from no failure on the part of the people, that our past misfortunes have arisen. We have placed power enough in the hands of the Government to have crushed the rebellion long ago. But that power has not been wielded with the skill, the vigor, the concentrated and determined energy which the task required. The fault has been with the Government and not with the people, and it is, therefore, for the Government to apply the remedy.

abstract: Parliament debates war situation
snippet: Parliament debates war situation
lead_paragraph: Mr. CLAY rose, and said he wished to make an appeal to the honorable member for Sunderland not to bring forward his motion on this subject. [Hear, hear.] It was true that a discussion such as the honorable member wished to provoke might at the right time be productive of very great good; but unless the time were admirably chosen -- and it did not appear that the present was the proper moment -- it would be productive of very considerable mischief. abstract: In the present state of the atmosphere there are few among us who are prepared to refuse the consideration of ice, be it presented in sherry cobbler, cream, or its grand first principle, water or recondensed in newspaper form to be taken with the morning coffee. "A big thing on ice" is not promised, but ...
lead_paragraph: In the present state of the atmosphere there are few among us who are prepared to refuse the consideration of ice, be it presented in sherry cobbler, cream, or its grand first principle, water -- or recondensed in newspaper form to be taken with the morning coffee. "A big thing on ice" is not promised, but merely a few fact, traceable to the same source whence emanates the lumbering but ever welcome concern that pauses before our kitchen entrances early these sultry mornings, and forth from which bounces the hale, rosy "ice man," who, plunging for an instant half out of sight into the stern quarters of his vehicle, produces a tremendous pair of pincers with a huge pendant all bristling with spears of rainbow tint, and showering its cool bends over Biddy's apron, as he slings it into the pan she presents for its reception. Should flirtations ever occur (and it is believed by passers by that they sometimes do) during these refrigerating interviews, it must be because it is so early in the morning when all the family are asleep and some bright Yankee girl takes the part of Biddy -- for it is a fact that one of the largest companies in town employ, to a man, none but thoroughbred Yankees, and it is well known how natural a tendency those cute persons possess for the interesting and attractive, incident to their various professions.

abstract: A regular meeting of this Board was held yesterday afternoon, nearly all the members being present. A few bills were referred to the Auditing Committee, after which Commissioner PURDY gave notice that at the next meeting of the Board he would call up the report of the Castle Garden Committee relative to retrenchments. Commissioner CARRIGAN moved to take action on the report at the present meeting, but in view of the absence of Commissioner LOWE, who had taken a prominent part in the matter, it was finally postponed, and the Board adjourned to Aug. 13.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the Cunard steamship Australasian, we receive advices from Europe three days later to the 20th inst.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the Cunard steamship Australasian, we receive advices from Europe three days later -- to the 20th inst. The most important feature of the news is the debate in the British House of Commons on the 18th, on the question of mediation in America. Mr. LINDSAY made the motion for mediation, but after a very full discussion, withdrew it at the request of the Government. The Paris Moniteur had published a meagre and rather gloomy dispatch from Gen. LORENCEZ, as to his position in Mexico down to the 11th June. The General claims that his communication with Vera Cruz had been reestablished, but he had received warning that he was to be attacked on the following day by Gen. ZARAGOSA, at the head of 10,000 men. The dispatch is said to have added to the apprehension felt at Paris. On the Bourse the Funds fell 1/4 per cent. from no other apparent cause. Cotton in the Liverpool market, in consequence of a canard, purporting to have come by the Glasgow, announcing the utter defeat of Gen. MCCLELLAN, and the probable capitulation of his army, had taken a considerable [???], but it had recovered when the truth became known. Breadstuffs were steady. Consuls were quoted at 92 [???] @ 92 7/8. American Stocks were dull.

abstract: The western portion of the State gives glowing and encouraging accounts of the spirit and enthusiasm manifested there for the vigorous prosecution of the war, and the necessity of sending on reinforcements at once. At Buffalo the whole of Friday was devoted to a "war festival," got up by the most prominent ladies of the city. Stores were generally closed, newspapers did not come out on Saturday, and the whole city took part in the fete. During the day a beautiful grove, about three miles from the city, was opened to visitors, where, in addition to dancing and refreshments, they were treated to addresses from leading orators. In the evening a concert was given, which drew many more hundreds than could find admission, the day's work realizing a very handsome addition to the bounty fund.

abstract: A temporary light will be exhibited from the old tower at Cape Hatteras on the night of the 15th inst., and on every night thereafter until an apparatus of the first order is available for that light-station of which due notice will be given. The illuminating apparatus is a second order Fresnel lens. showing a fixed light varied by flashes. A bright flash of one minute duration will be seen once every three minutes followed and preceded by a bright fixed light of two minutes duration. The tower is 140 feet high painted white from the base to the height of 70 feet, and the remainder painted red. This light should be seen in clear weather from the deck of a vessel [???] feet above water, 20 nautical miles.

abstract: Whatever progress the Anti-American feeling may have made among the British people, it certainly gathers no headway in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Whatever progress the Anti-American feeling may have made among the British people, it certainly gathers no headway in Parliament. Once more the indefatigable LINDSAY has thrust his protean resolution before the House of Commons; this time advocating mediation with alternative recognition of the South. And the House has debated the resolution with far more than customary energy, and to the discussion have been brought the entire resources of the men who have been distinguished as the leaders on the two sides. Mr. LINDSAY, nothing if not at once statistical and egotistical, not only laid before the Commons a succinct, and we are sorry to say, grossly partial history of the immediate occasion of the rebellion, but repeating the thrice exploded folly that the whole trouble arises out of tariffs, proceeds to give a history of the revenue policy of the Government, in which we are told that South Carolina began to complain of the Northern tariff as far back as 1833, and was only pacified by the promise of early Free-Trade; and the North broke faith by passing the greatly augmented tariff of 1846. Mr. LINDSAY did not stay long enough, perhaps, in America, to learn that in 1833 all the tariff troubles of South Carolina were ended; and that the tariff of 1846 was made a law by the votes of South Carolina and the other Southern States.

abstract: An accident occurred on board the steamer Thomas P. Way, while on her trip from Coney Island to Newark, yesterday afternoon, by which a lad, 12 years of age, named JOHN HENRY BESHER, living corner of Nassau and Bridge streets, Brooklyn, was drowned.
lead_paragraph: An accident occurred on board the steamer Thomas P. Way, while on her trip from Coney Island to Newark, yesterday afternoon, by which a lad, 12 years of age, named JOHN HENRY BESHER, living corner of Nassau and Bridge streets, Brooklyn, was drowned. He was sitting on a small boat, which was turned bottom upward, on the upper deck, and the boat tipping forward, the boy fell overboard and was drowned. A boat was launched, but at the first pull the oar-locks broke, rendering it useless. The father of the lad is book-keeper for T.C. MOORE, No. 108 Beekman-street.

abstract: Gov. MAGOFFIN, of Kentucky, has called an extraordinary session of the Legislature of that State, to meet two weeks from to-day.
lead_paragraph: Gov. MAGOFFIN, of Kentucky, has called an extraordinary session of the Legislature of that State, to meet two weeks from to-day. As set forth in that part of his proclamation which has been telegraphed to us, the object of the session is to consider two things: First -- The military situation in Kentucky, seeing that a civil conflict is impending over the State, and the Governor is "without a soldier or a dollar" to protect the people; and, Second, "to look to" "the late action of Congress touching Slavery, and provide for the safety of our institutions."

abstract: Our Louisville, Ky., correspondent, states that a new religious weekly newspaper is about to be started in that city, and that Dr. R.J. BRECKINRIDGE will be one of its leading contributors.
lead_paragraph: -- Our Louisville, Ky., correspondent, states that a new religious weekly newspaper is about to be started in that city, and that Dr. R.J. BRECKINRIDGE will be one of its leading contributors. The special occasion for starting it is the disloyalty of the present organ of the Presbyterian denomination in that State. We may rely upon it that Dr. BRECKINRIDGE will have a leading part in any movement for maintaining the Union in Kentucky. He has been from the beginning one of the staunchest, ablest and most effective supporters of the Union in that State; and the position which she has held, and the services she has rendered to the Government are due in very large degree to his zealous and indefatigable labors. He is a writer of great argumentative as well rhetorical ability and has long ranked as confessedly one of the foremost orators in the whole country. While he has always distrusted the wisdom of the political action of the Republicans and other opponents of Slavery in the North, he has never aided or countenanced in any way the Pro-Slavery projects which have culminated in the rebellion. And no man anywhere has denounced more unsparingly than he, or shown up more clearly and strikingly the enormous moral guilt, as well as political wickedness, of those who are now engaged in attempting to destroy the Union. Whatever newspaper in Kentucky may have the aid on his pen, will deserve the attention and confidence of loyal men everywhere.

abstract: -- We copied a few days since an extract from a speech made by Senator WILSON, recently, in Massachusetts, in which hecomplained of injustice done him by the Herald, in saying that he had insisted that the Government should stop recruiting, as we already had more men than could be used to advantage. Mr. WILSON denied that he had ever urged any such action, and said he had "always maintained that the Government wanted more men."
lead_paragraph: -- We copied a few days since an extract from a speech made by Senator WILSON, recently, in Massachusetts, in which hecomplained of injustice done him by the Herald, in saying that he had insisted that the Government should stop recruiting, as we already had more men than could be used to advantage. abstract: The negro story telegraphed from Washington, to the effect that the rebels are evacuating Richmond, is a very good one, but somewhat doubtful.
lead_paragraph: -- The negro story telegraphed from Washington, to the effect that the rebels are evacuating Richmond, is a very good one, but somewhat doubtful. In the first place, the great bulk of the rebel army is not in the city of Richmond, but somewhat nearer our own lines, and on both sides of the James River -- as we very well know. And next, [???] the regiments in and about Richmond are really leaving it, the object probably is to move to some point where they are needed -to move north to Gordonsville or south to Suffolk, or up to Fredericksburgh, or down to the Appomattox, or to a point below and in front of our position on the James -- or in some other direction which Gen. HALLECK, and not we, should know. The rebels will not be likely to evacuate Richmond as long as it is possible for them to hold it; and it does not yet appear to them that it is impossible -- though we hope it soon will appear.
